HEADLINE: The 1992 Campaign: Media;
TV Viewers Get to See the Candidates, and See the Candidates

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 15

 BODY:
For anyone who still wants to get to know the Presidential candidates, these are happy days to be a television viewer. The candidates are showing their inner selves. They are looking haggard on the news. They are turning mean in their advertising. They are personally pre-empting entire programs.
At 9 o'clock Friday evening, for instance, viewers expecting the situation comedy "Baby Talk" were instead offered Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and a toll-free number for asking him questions. Not being seasoned political journalists, most viewers did not realize that the only important question this election is Mr. Clinton's 1969 draft deferment, so they got sidetracked on other issues, but there were valuable lessons nonetheless. 
 "I'm very interested in trains," one potential voter said. "I'd like to be able to take a train from Portsmouth to Boston. You know, I'd like to commute. Are you going to do anything about trains?"
"I am," Mr. Clinton replied, but before he spelled out his high-speed-rail program he made a confession. "I can't promise you a route from Portsmouth to Boston because I don't know enough about the economics of that." He smiled sheepishly and shrugged. "Perhaps I should, but I don't."
 
Candidate With a Plan
 Yes, he was apologizing for not knowing offhand the projected ridership of the Portsmouth-Boston rail corridor, and that says quite a lot about who Mr. Clinton is: the candidate with an earnest smile, a statistic and a plan for just about every other question facing himself or America.
When he is in good television form, it is tempting to disregard all the political obituaries for him in the national press, and the last couple of days he has had his moments again: hugging a weeping woman on the evening news, sincerely talking to the camera on his commercials, intelligently handling question after question on his 30-minute live commercials.
But then there have been the awkward moments when he is seen facing reporters determined to know why he did not fight in Vietnam. It is difficult to say who comes off worse: the righteous reporters, most of whom do not look like veterans of the Tet offensive, or Mr. Clinton, whose poised answers start to look suspiciously pat.
"He seems like a Barbie doll to me," one caller complained on Boston's WRKO radio, and on late-night television they keep saying much worse things. On Friday, as Los Angeles braced for more flooding rains, Johnny Carson told his audience, "We need another storm like Bill Clinton needs another revelation." He expressed doubts that Mr. Clinton's unraveling campaign could be saved by the new slogan, "Clinton: He never robbed a liquor store."
 
Going for the Media Gusto
 The other candidates are not quite this mean to Mr. Clinton, although Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa has come close. Lately he has done some advertising to soften his image, like a half-hour commercial Friday that pre-empted "Entertainment Tonight" and featured him chatting with a woman who asked questions like, "I'd like to know a little more about Tom Harkin the man." But he is still the candidate most willing to go for media gusto.
He looked most at home in front of a foreclosed home -- a favorite photo scene for everyone this campaign -- as he shook his fist and proclaimed, "I just want to grab Bush and shake him, you know, grab him and shake him a couple of times, and see if I get some sense into that skull of his."
Mr. Harkin appeared this week on the news in front of a nuclear power plant as he lambasted former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts for supporting nuclear power. He was quick to speak out about Mr. Clinton's character problems. And he lumped both men with Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska in a commercial that began the negative advertisement war on television this week. It showed their photos as the announcer intoned, "These three Democrats are all saying the same thing: more tax cuts for the rich and big business."
 
Projecting Nicer Image
 Mr. Kerrey retaliated on Friday with an advertisement denying that he supports tax breaks for the rich. Mr. Kerrey's advertisement said he supports tax cuts for the middle class, which are opposed by Mr. Harkin, and the announcer sums up Mr. Harkin this way, "Old style Democrat, old-style negative campaign."
Mr. Kerrey's other negative advertisements have been a little more subtle, criticizing his rivals without naming them. One advertisement stresses the importance of choosing someone capable of beating President Bush and points out certain qualities of Mr. Kerrey's, like his military record: "No one can question his patriotism."
In other ways, though, Mr. Kerrey has recently been projecting a nicer image. On the news he has refrained from commenting about Mr. Clinton's Vietnam problem. A new advertisement shows him sitting in a living room, smiling slightly and speaking in much gentler tones than in the previous commercials that stressed his toughness.
Mr. Tsongas' commercials still show him doing everything but talking; that is left to an announcer with good diction. And he still spends a lot of television time in the pool, both in his commercials and on the evening news. Last week dozens of reporters were on hand for his daily swim, which has become his visual answer to questions about his recovery from cancer.
The face of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has become familiar in New Hampshire, thanks partly to the news coverage of his speech at Harvard University on Wednesday, but mainly to the television commercials urging voters to write in his name. One half of the screen shows Mr. Cuomo speaking -- "We are going absolutely down the wrong road" -- while the other half shows his name being written.
 
Bush, Flag and War
 President Bush's advertisements are broadcast constantly, but for some reason they seem the easiest to ignore. Perhaps this is because they look like so many other images of Mr. Bush over the last four years, or because the strategy behind the commercials seems so blatantly manipulative: combine Mr. Bush, the flag, stirring music, the Oval Office and fighter planes from the Persian Gulf war.
Or perhaps it is because of the commercials of Patrick J. Buchanan, who may have pioneered a new form of negative campaigning: consciousness alteration through saturation advertising.
Mr. Buchanan has some advertisements showing himself speaking somberly to the camera about America's future, but his most memorable commercials continue to be ones featuring Mr. Bush's 1988 pledge: "Read my lips. No new taxes." The advertisements have been on so often for so long that a curious effect has occurred. The advertisement at first seems hard-hitting, then tiresome, then reason to lunge for the mute button.
But then at some point, maybe around the 50th showing, for some viewers the sound bite begins to acquire a surreal fascination, as if it is disclosing something deep inside Mr. Bush. As he jabs his finger into the air and screeches the words again and again, with each commercial he begins to seem more and more desperate, more and more absurd. For these dedicated television viewers, it has been difficult to take the President seriously ever since.

HEADLINE: Not a Grandma Moses Picture: Poker in the Woods

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEDYARD, Conn., Feb. 15

 BODY:
The Connecticut countryside was covered with frost today when the first early bird appeared at the doors of the Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino at 6 A.M. for the state's first day of legal casino gambling.
By the time a loud cheer went up four hours later, as the gaming floor finally opened and thousands of people swarmed toward the blackjack, roulette, craps and poker tables, more than the frost had disappeared from the landscape. 
 Here in a casino built by an Indian tribe, the Mashantucket Pequots, a casino in the woods with the soft ambiance of an expensive suburban mall, a world away from the hard glitz of Atlantic City, the crowds coming in to look and to play could imagine only one future: more casinos, everywhere.
"How can the state go on and not make money on these things?" said Roger Henry of Hampton, Conn., referring to the singular fact that Connecticut, hard-pressed financially, will not receive a dollar from all the chips bet here, because Foxwoods is on a federally recognized Indian reservation.
"They're going to get their foot in somewhere," Mr. Henry predicted. "When you look at the fiscal state of this state, how bad shape they're in, they're going to grab every buck they can."
 
A Different Tone
 Today Foxwoods opened as the first legal casino on the East Coast outside Atlantic City, and the circumstances of its birth could hardly be more different from the spirit of almost puritanical distrust that set Atlantic City apart when New Jersey legalized casinos for it, and it alone, in 1976
Atlantic City is where Guy A. Potolicchio, a police officer from Stamford, Conn., has gone every few months to gamble. This morning he came to Foxwoods, and just after noon was knocking off for the day, having built a $200 stake into $1,200 at blackjack.
A Connecticut native, he never imagined his home state would have a casino, he said, but now he expects more casinos and probably slot machines. "It's a new source of revenue," he said.
Compared to Atlantic City, Mr. Potolicchio said, Foxwoods "is a shorter drive and a more pleasant drive. But when you win, any drive is pleasant."
Where Atlantic City's gambling industry was born of a state referendum, justified in public policy terms by the need to revive the city and raise new revenue for the state, Foxwoods is a vision of a small but sovereign Indian tribe, authorized by Federal law to offer any kind of gambling that Con necticut already allows.
The irony is not lost on members of the clergy, mental health professionals and others concerned about the human costs of organized gambling: Connecticut has a casino now not because it wanted one, but because gambling was already pervasive, legalized in lotteries, betting on horse racing and dog racing, jai alai, and church bingo and Las Vegas nights.
What Connecticut, and so Foxwoods, do not have, is slot machines, but that too may change as the state seeks not only new sources of revenue but also some way to blunt the Pequots' drain on the state's gambling dollars.
In this grim budget season, legislators in Hartford are talking about licensing more casinos, selling $10 lottery tickets and putting slot machines in off-track betting parlors. As a last resort, one legislator has proposed putting a $5 toll on the section of Route 2 that leads into the Pequot reservation here.
"They're going to take away from the horse racing, the dog racing, the jai alai," Vincent Finelli, of North Smithfield, R.I., said of the Pequots, predicting that states will have to join them and other New England tribes like Rhode Island's Naragansetts in opening casinos. "Gambling is here to stay, and there's nothing you can do about it."
Proponents of gambling in Connecticut cite other states that have approved casinos: South Dakota, Colorado and Iowa have all allowed it in limited ways.
Set in a corner of Ledyard, miles from the town's two-stop-light center, Foxwoods at first sight appears to be a new shopping center, with grading equipment still parked on the edges of its freshly paved parking lots.
Inside, the atmosphere is soft and understated, accented with Indian patterns and designs that lead the eye to the casino's most unusual feature, windows that open upon the wooded hills of southeastern Connecticut. In this casino, at the Pequots' insistence, the players will know night from day.
Despite the tribe's efforts to maintain harmony between their land and their business, Foxwoods is still a casino. Cash machines near the entrance stand next to a display of Indian pottery. At 9 A.M. the bar behind the waterfall that dominates the center atrium was crowded with people drinking beer, waiting for the 10 A.M. opening. The fringed tunics worn by cocktail waitresses are slashed to the hip.
When security men in green blazers stepped aside and let players onto the floor, craps and roulette tables were ringed immediately, and lines formed at the video slot machines along one wall which neither take money nor pay money while they await the state's blessing.
By 10:15, 13 tables were playing poker, a game that Atlantic City does not have. By 10:30 the bar and a buffet restaurant, crowded at 10, were empty. All over the casino the crowd noise was punctuated by the clicking of the chips, like crickets on a summer's day.
By 12:15 the 1,730-space parking lot was full, and by 3 P.M. the police were towing cars parked along the two-lane country road leading to the casino.
 
The Money Is Real
 Many of the casinos' 2,300 employees worked almost through the night Friday to prepare for the opening, as play money used for three nights of practice play -- two of them dedicated as charity benefits -- was exchanged for real money, and tables were stocked with chips.
The casino's president, Alfred J. Luciani, a non-Pequot with experience in Atlantic City and Las Vegas, estimated that 2,500 people had come in the first hour and that 15,000 would pass through by the end of the day.
"Today is not a day for serious gamblers," Mr. Luciani said of the opening crowd. "A lot of people are here just for entertainment -- which we want them here for."
The casino, if it chooses, can operate 24 hours a day, though Connecticut liquor laws do not allow it to serve alcohol between 1 and 9 A.M. during the week and 2 and 9 A.M. Saturdays and Sundays.
"Once this apparation is out of the way," Mr. Luciani said of the opening, "we'll see what the public wants and adjust our hours accordingly."
Foxwoods has the freedom to adjust hours and quickly to make other business decisions like opening or closing gaming tables because its business activities are regulated not by the state but by the Mashantucket Pequot Gaming Commission, which has its offices right here.
That freedom, Mr. Luciani said, sets the Pequots' casino apart from those of Atlantic City. But it is also symbolic to some people of how freely gambling has grown.
This week members of the clergy from southeastern Connecticut warned that there would be human casualties from the casino, because of compulsive gambling and the illegal activities that gambling centers can attract, and called on Foxwoods to contribute to the cost of helping those.
But their warning was carefully measured, in part because church bingo nights opened the door for Foxwoods.
"The clergy are in no way critical of the Mashantucket Pequots for the establishment of the casino," the Rev. Christopher J. Emerson of the Mystic Congregational Church said Friday. "The tribal council has simply taken fair advantage of the gaming environment in the state of Connecticut and has chosen to play the game as it's laid.
"We're concerned about the growing dependence of the state on gambling revenues," he continued, "but we are hardly critical of the Pequots for wanting a piece of the action."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Puts Off Medicaid Cut After Pleas From Pharmacists

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Pharmacists across New York State envisoned economic disaster for their businesses, and Medicaid patients expressed deep misgivings for their health yesterday, as the state went to the brink of a long-planned cut in Medicaid payments for prescription drugs -- then postponed action for a few days.
Under intense pressure from pharmacy trade groups as a midnight deadline approached, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo late Friday night put off a 10 percent cut in the state's $550 million program of reimbursing pharmacies for the prescription drugs they dispense to 2.5 million poor people covered by Medicaid. 
 "The change will be implemented -- it's just a question of when," Terry Lynam, a spokesman for the Governor, said. He said the Governor had acted to allow more time for talks between the state and representatives of 3,700 pharmacies, which filled 25 million prescriptions under Medicaid last year.
Jerome Sager, general counsel and executive director of the Empire State Pharmaceutical Society, representing 1,000 stores, said pharmacists wanted the cut limited to 5 percent, and other concessions, including a rise in dispensing fees for each prescription to $4.05 from $2.60 and the use of monthly rather than semiannual wholesale price surveys to set reimbursement rates.
 
Excessive Profits Suspected
 State officials say they must make the cuts under Federal regulations aimed at controlling soaring medical costs, and because $1.1 billion must be trimmed from Medicaid in this year's state budget. Federal and state surveys have suggested that some pharmacies, by buying drugs at discounts from wholesale prices, made excessive profits on Medicaid.
But trade groups representing the pharmacies vehemently deny this. Noting that pharmacies have had no increase in Medicaid drug-reimbursements for 14 years, despite soaring drug costs, they contend that the cuts would be devastating, especially to small independent stores.
Moreover, if the cuts are imposed, some pharmacies say they might stop serving Medicaid patients or handling the most expensive prescriptions, many of them used to fight cancer or the virus that causes AIDS, and they have suggested that one of the first things to be canceled would be free deliveries to homebound elderly patients.
While the postponement was expected to last only a few days, it drew some expressions of relief. "Thank God they stopped this thing," Jerry Ginsberg, a pharmacist and part-owner of C. O. Bigelow Chemists in Greenwich Village, said. "We were planning to give customers a last refill, but we weren't going to fill any new prescriptions."
 
'People Will Be Devastated'
 An elderly woman named Margaret, who wanted a Medicaid prescription filled, was taken aback by the possibility that C. O. Bigelow might not be able to serve her in the future. "It's ghastly," she said. "People will be devastated. Heart medication, hypertension drugs -- all these medications are essential."
The State Department of Social Services, which administers the reimbursement program, contends that the cuts will not seriously harm most pharmacies, and it has set up a phone line -- (800) 541-2831 -- to tell Medicaid patients where to find the nearest pharmacy that will fill their prescriptions.
In Rochester, Robert G. Single, the owner of Culver Pharmacy, said that if the cuts take effect, it will be hard to stay in business, let alone offer free delivery. At the Saratoga Pharmacy across town, Charles Robertson noted that 80 percent of his business was filling Medicaid prescriptions.
"This is going to have a big impact on the little guy, the independent," Mr. Robertson said. "It is very hard to compete with the chains. We can't buy in bulk quantities. We are one store." And, referring to the state, he said: "They are trying to use us to decrease their budget."
 
Posing Moral Quandary
 In Harlem, Victor LaPerla, co-owner of Better Buy Pharmacy, said his store would refuse to fill more than half its Medicaid prescriptions if the cuts were imposed, but he noted that refusing service to a customer who had been coming in for years would pose a moral quandry.
"It's not illegal to refuse the prescription," he said. "If you're not making a profit, you don't have to sell. Legally, you're covered. Morally? It's your conscience. I don't want to see anybody drop dead. A lot of our customers are very, very concerned, especially the elderly."
A customer at the Harlem store, Capus Teague, a 57-year-old retired printer who depends on Medicaid for drugs and treatment for his emphysema and diabetes, said he was angry about the possible cuts. "It's all messed up, the whole system from the Government down through the drug stores," he said. "And we're the ones who have to suffer."
Under the Medicaid program of assistance for poor people, the state has paid pharmacies since 1978 for the prescriptions they dispense under a complex formula based on the average wholesale price of each drug, plus $2.60 as a dispensing fee for each prescription.
 
U.S. Ordered Cut in 1987
 In 1987, the Federal Government wrote new rules to control health costs, and directed states to cut 10 percent from their reimbursement rates if they wanted to continue receiving Federal aid for Medicaid, which provides 50 percent of the program's money. Lawsuits by pharmacies and their trade groups kept New York State from imposing the cuts immediately.
The state offered to settle by increasing the dispensing fees to $3.90 a prescription, but the pharmacies refused. Rulings in Federal Court in Manhattan in December and January finally resolved the suits, largely in the state's favor, and cleared the way for the state to impose the 10 percent cuts at 12:01 A.M. yesterday.
As the deadline approached, pharmacy trade groups warned in advertisements and fliers about a looming crisis, lobbied in Albany and urged Governor Cuomo to postpone action pending further talks. The Governor agreed after legislative leaders also asked for a delay to discuss the prescription-drug issue as part of larger budget talks aimed at cutting Medicaid by $1.1 billion.

HEADLINE: Woman Uses Wealth to Ease Maine's Bank Woes

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 15

 BODY:
After two banks in this state closed last year, a 61-year-old woman who has adopted Maine as her home decided to do something to help reverse that trend. She opened a bank: the Maine Bank & Trust Company.
With a fortune estimated at $100 million, most of it invested in a computer company, Elizabeth B. Noyce can afford to furnish the capital for a bank. She invested almost $7 million to start Maine Bank & Trust, which opened here on Nov. 20. 
 On the first day, customers seeking to open accounts steadily filed into the bank, a 10-story marble building near the cobblestone streets of the Old Port district.
The president, Wayne C. McGarvey, said the bank had done well in its first three months. "In six weeks," he said, "we more than doubled our assets to $14 million." Since then, he added, the bank's assets have continued to grow rapidly.
 
Glimmer of Sunshine
 Donald Groves, deputy superintendent of the Maine Bureau of Banking, described the bank as "one of the few glimmers of sunshine in an otherwise gloomy economy."
In an interview, Mrs. Noyce, who holds 90 percent of the stock in the bank, said she was not concerned about making a profit. Nor did she want to be involved in the bank's daily operations, she said.
"The fact is I have disposable income," she said. "I want the bank to be successful. But the truth is I don't have to worry about decent returns on my investment."
Her lawyer, however, said Mrs. Noyce is worried about Maine's economy. "Given the terrible economic situation in Maine, Betty was looking for an investment that would demonstrate confidence in the future of Maine," said the lawyer, Owen Wells.
Mrs. Noyce received half of her husband's fortune when they were divorced in 1974. Her husband, Robert N. Noyce, who died a year ago, founded Intel Corporation and was the co-inventor of the integrated circuit chip, the basis for the modern computer.
Mrs. Noyce had spent summers in Maine, and after the divorce she moved to Bremen, a fishing village of 675 people on Muscongus Bay, about 65 miles northeast of Portland.
In the last decade Mrs. Noyce has given a total of $25 million, most of it in Intel stocks, to Maine hospitals, museums and dozens of other nonprofit organizations. She has given away more money than any other benefactor in the state's history, Mr. Wells said.
"I've always believed you do good by doing well," Mrs. Noyce said. "In the past, most of my charitable gifts were to institutions that benefited myself, my quality of life. But I've become more altruistic with age."
Mrs. Noyce, the youngest of four children, said she learned the value of sharing as a child growing up during the Depression in Auburn, Mass., a small town in the south-central part of the state, just south of Worcester.
 
'Modest Needs'
 While she now enjoys the freedom of having money to give away, Mrs. Noyce said, she also has "modest needs."
"I don't like a lot of frills," she said. "I don't like to travel. I'd much rather be home, raking the leaves and sawing off extra branches from spruce trees."
The opening of Maine Bank & Trust Company came after two major banks in the state closed. The first was the Portland-based Maine Savings Bank, which failed last February because of bad real estate loans. A few months later, Maine National Bank closed after its parent company, Boston's Bank of New England, also collapsed because of bad loans. Both were acquired by the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., a Rhode Island-based company. More than 1,000 jobs in Maine were eliminated as a result of the closures.
Mrs. Noyce said she was upset to see the banks close. "I knew the people who ran Maine National, so I knew it was a well-run bank," she said. "It was disconcerting to me to see it close. I believe that Maine residents deserve to have a Maine bank."
That feeling is reflected in the bank's motto: "A Maine Bank for Maine People."

HEADLINE: Catholic Schools in Danger of Closing

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
For days now, forlorn principals of Roman Catholic schools, accompanied by equally concerned pastors, parents and often the school accountant, have marched into the offices of John Cardinal O'Connor to argue for keeping their schools open.
Worried about rising deficits and low enrollments, the Cardinal has already decided to close one of the 304 schools in the Archdiocese of New York. In the next few days, his office is expected to announce the shuttering of others. 
 The Cardinal's office will not specify how many schools besides the one closed, St. Joseph's in Yonkers, are in jeopardy. One early rumor had it that 41 closings were under consideration. A later report said that no more than 15 would close. And no one is discounting the possibility of a last-minute rescue maneuver by the Cardinal.
But his actions have sent chills coursing through the schools of the archdiocese and focused new attention on their tenuous place in the city's educational network.
 
Too Many Deficits
 Part of the problem the parochial schools face results from a lack of the traditional middle-class support. Over the last generation many of the schools have moved from educating middle-class and working-class Irish and Italian Catholics to educating poor Hispanic Catholics and blacks, many of whom are Protestants.
With 110,000 students, the schools of the archdiocese are second in size in New York City to the public school system, with about 980,000 students. But the Catholic schools receive almost no government subsidies and rely on tuition and support from the local parish church.
All of the schools at risk of closing are in poor neighborhoods.
For several years, the deficits of dozens of such schools were covered by the archdiocese. But the archdiocese has said it can no longer carry the load.
"People are nervous because nobody knows what is going on," said Brian Coyle, the principal of St. Joseph's School on Bathgate Avenue in the Bronx.
 
'New York Has Held Out'
 A year ago, the Cardinal began an effort to raise $100 million over three years for the schools but he has fallen far short of his first-year goal.
In a recent column in Catholic New York, the weekly newspaper of the archdiocese, Cardinal O'Connor said he was focusing on 41 inner-city schools that "my close consultants tell me are 'at risk'. " Most have raised tuition as high as they can, he wrote, yet they face a deficit of over $4.5 million. "Where do I come up with money like that?" he asked.
Cardinal O'Connor's problems are not singular.
According to Sister Catherine T. McNamee, president of the National Catholic Educational Association in Washington, other major Catholic centers, such as Chicago and Boston, closed dozens of schools in the 1980's. "New York has held out longer," Sister McNamee said. "It has a major commitment to keeping the inner-city schools open.
While the commitment has been there, she said, the realities of tough economic times and the migration of Catholics away from the inner cities have caught up with the archdiocese.
 
Opportunities for Poor Children
 The Archdiocese of New York covers 1.8 million Catholics in Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island, Westchester and six other counties north of New York City. Brooklyn and Queens make up a separate diocese, the Diocese of Brooklyn, which has its own Catholic school system with 183 schools and 75,000 children.
The last large-scale closing of schools in Brooklyn was in 1973, when the diocese shut 10 schools. Since then, schools in the diocese have closed at the rate of one or two a year.
According to the National Catholic Educational Association, the New York Archdiocese closed 19 of its 331 schools between 1985 and 1990. During the same period, the Chicago Archdiocese closed 39 of its 416 schools and the Boston Archdiocese closed 33 of its 215 schools.
The Cardinal's fund-raising campaign began in January 1991, when he formed an interfaith committee headed by Frederic V. Salerno, president and chief operating officer of New York Telephone. The committee includes Alan C. Greenberg, chairman and chief executive officer of Bear Stearns Companies; K. Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News America Publishers Inc., and Thomas S. Murphy, chairman of Capital Cities/ABC Inc.
The campaign was aimed at raising money from the business and financial communities. Committee members argued that the Catholic schools were an important factor in the region's economy, offering opportunities for children in poor neighborhoods. The schools claim a 1 percent drop-out rate and say that 90 percent of graduates go on to college.
 
Pledges and Cash Low
 In the first year, however, the fund-raising effort, known as Partnership for Quality Education, raised only $23 million in pledges and received less than half that amount in cash. "Everybody I go to tells me, 'You've got this job in the worst possible time,' " said Bishop Patrick V. Ahern, the archdiocese's vicar for development. "The economy is not on our side."
At the same time, the need has grown. Eleven years ago the archdiocese had 79 schools classified as poor inner city schools; now there are 140.
Several of the schools summoned to the headquarters of the archdiocese -- including Mr. Coyle's St. Joseph's School in the Bronx -- were told a few days later that they could keep their doors open but had to face a future of reduced subsidies from the archdiocese.
At the school that is being closed, St. Joseph's in Yonkers, Nancy Langehennig, the principal, has been trying to reassure children and their parents that a place would be found in nearby Catholic schools for every one of the 127 youngsters now enrolled. She said she was satisfied that the archdiocese did all that it could to keep the school open.
"The decision was based on low enrollment and our inability to keep ourselves going financially," she said.
A school that had a near brush with closing was St. Jerome's at Alexander Avenue and 138th Street in the Bronx. After a meeting earlier this month with the Cardinal, the pastor, the Rev. John O. Grange, led his committee in an impromptu prayer. "St. Jerome pray for us," he said, "and pray for Cardinal O'Connor."
The level of anxiety was high the next day at the school, which is in a run-down but clean and cheery 120-year-old building in the South Bronx. "My little one cried all night," said a secretary who has two children in the school. " My children have never been to public school. They're scared of what goes on there."
The next day, the Cardinal's office told the school that it would be given another chance to get its financial house in order. Among other fund-raising efforts, Father Grange hopes to start Friday fasts, in which both parents and children would give up a favorite treat or luxury and donate the money to the school. The school's population is one with few luxuries, but the pastor is convinced that the sacrifices can make a difference.
"It's like a new life," Father Grange said of the reprieve. "Everybody is happy. We've got a lot of work to do but we think we can make it."

HEADLINE: We Need a Real National Rebuilding Program;
Consumer Confidence

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In testimony before the Senate Budget Committee on Feb. 4, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, expressed dismay that American consumers have not shown the confidence they showed in past recessions. Until consumer confidence is restored, the economy will continue to wallow in recession. 
 In 1983-85, private citizen Alan Greenspan continually expressed a fear that consumers were too exuberant. He noted that prosperity was being largely financed by consumer loans collateralized by the growing equity that American households had in their homes. Citizen Greenspan argued for an end to spending financed by growing home equities.
Consumer confidence, however, is closely related to the net worth of consumers. For 40 years, from 1946 to 1986, household net worth rose at an average 8 percent annual rate. Brashly confident American consumers continually spent us out of the mild recessions of earlier post World War II days as soon as the Federal Reserve eased monetary policy.
But in 1990, for the first time in two generations, the collapse of real estate values caused a decline in the net worth of American households. Land values ($3.7 trillion) and residential structures ($4.6 trillion) together account for more than half the country's net worth. A family home is the largest investment for most consumers. No wonder consumer confidence stays depressed -- even after 14 Federal Reserve interest rate cuts.
Aggravating the depressed market for houses is the desire of the Resolution Trust Corporation to avoid increasing President Bush's deficit while disposing of failed savings and loan institutions. Instead of holding vacant housing foreclosed by the failed savings and loans, the Resolution Trust continues to dump properties on a depressed real estate market, causing those Americans who still own their homes to worry about the equity that remains.
Today, central banker Greenspan is surprised that he cannot stimulate the American consumer to borrow and spend us out of recession despite interest rate reductions. Moreover, without strong and growing demand in the consumer goods market, investment in entrepreneurial capital is unlikely to be profitable, no matter how low interest rates are driven.
It is unfortunate that we leave economic policy decisions to economists such as Dr. Greenspan, who are renowned experts on economic number crunching, but who apparently are completely uneducated in human economic behavior.
 
PAUL DAVIDSON
Knoxville, Tenn., Feb. 5, 1992
 
The writer, who teaches political economy at the University of Tennessee, is editor of the Journal of Post-Keynesian Economics.

HEADLINE: Campaign Trail Leads To New York for Cash

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
In the last desperate days before the New Hampshire primary, as each candidate spins wildly from one quaint village to the next, often it is cocktails in Manhattan that is really on their minds.
"It's cash," said Stanley Greenberg, a poll taker for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who traveled with the candidate to a New York fund-raiser on Monday. "Everyone needs a lot of it, and a lot of it is here. After New Hampshire, the campaign goes on. But if you can't buy a plane ticket it's hard to get your message out." 
 So even in the busiest week of the campaign year so far, when every New Hampshire minute counts for every candidate, Governor Clinton and his wife found time to spend an evening in New York. So did Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who showed up on Tuesday at the Regency Hotel, also with hat in hand. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa was here the week before. And the new leader in the polls, Paul Tsongas, found time to attend six events in New York over the last two weeks. Hoping for a shower of celebrity if he wins in New Hampshire, Mr. Tsongas will return to the city the minute the primary ends.
 
The Money Crowd
 "I hate to sound like that song," said Jim Armenakis, the New York State chairman for the Tsongas campaign. "But if you can make it here, you can make it anywhere." That may or may not be true. But if you cannot make it in New York -- at least with the money crowd that campaigns need to prosper -- you certainly cannot make it in other places for long. New York and Los Angeles are the mother lodes for campaign fund-raising, but when you are unable to stray far from New Hampshire the money primary takes place mostly in New York.
And although a candidate has to win votes to become a nominee, the money primary is at least as important as any other aspect of the race. With more than $5 million in the bank, Governor Clinton has emerged as the only candidate with enough money to cruise -- at least financially -- out of New Hampshire. His opponents have reported surges in contributions over the last two weeks as polls showed Governor Clinton's campaign faltering, and they hope that a good showing this week, will turn the faucets on to full force.
Even the amount raised by the Clinton campaign, a treasure-trove by the standards of his competitors, could evaporate in a few weeks of bitter campaigning in expensive states like Texas or Florida. The steady need for cash has turned New York, and its wealthy investors, into hallowed ground.
The figures for January have not yet been reported to the Federal Election Commission, but by the end of December Governor Clinton had opened a huge financial lead on his competitors, having raised more than $3.2 million. Campaign officials said that by the end of January the figure had grown to more than $5 million -- almost twice as much as the $2.2 million reported in December by the next most successful fund-raiser, Senator Harkin.
Senator Kerrey had raised slightly less than $2 million, according to the F.E.C., and Mr. Tsongas barely more than $1 million. By comparison, Michael Dukakis had raised well over $10 million by this point in 1988, and President Bush has already reported contributions of more than $9 million for his re-election bid.
Nearly a third of campaign contributions comes from dinners, breakfasts, drinks and "house parties" in New York, political consultants say. The F.E.C. has not yet released detailed reports on where each candidate's contributions have come from, so it is difficult to assess trends, but the Clinton event at the Sheraton Center Hotel last week, raised nearly $700,000 for the struggling candidate, and Kerrey officials said they raised more than $200,000 on Tuesday at their smaller, more intimate affair.
"New York is the best possible place to do these things," said Norman Adler, a political consultant. "People are concentrated in a relatively small place. There are a lot of big players who can fork out $1,000 whether or not they have committed themselves to one candidate or not. And if you can raise a bunch of money in a single night, you look good on television. It's a little bit of substance and a lot of shimmering."
The recession has made money scarce this year. Wealthy real-estate developers are disappearing fast, and many seem uninterested in supporting Presidential candidates -- reserving their money instead for local leaders who may be better able to scratch their backs in return.
 
The Cuomo Factor
 As with every other factor in the race for the White House, the long, dark shadow of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has also had its effect.
"Of course he's been a factor," said Richard Socarides, the state chairman for the Harkin campaign. "If you are a New York contributor and you think he may run, it can cause you to think twice about giving to the others."
New York's role as electoral money depot does not please everybody. Many politicians view the constant round of fund-raisers as distractions from more traditional political commitments.
"This process stinks," said John Marino, the state Democratic chairman. "They are running all over New Hampshire all day long, and they get on a plane and race to New York for dinner to grovel for money. They hardly see a normal voter. They don't go to subway stops, they go to Wall Street."

HEADLINE: Budget Shift Stirs Fears for Landmarks Panel

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Zero dollars. Zero employees.
Preservationists and planners in and out of New York City government were startled last week when City Hall presented those figures for the Landmarks Preservation Commission for the next fiscal year. 
 They had already warily greeted a proposal in January to shift some administrative tasks from the landmarks commission to the City Planning Department. That economy measure was developed without consulting either Laurie Beckelman, the chairwoman of the landmarks commission, or Planning Director Richard L. Schaffer.
And when the zeros appeared in the Mayor's Management Report last week, with the landmarks budget folded into the Planning Department's, suspicion grew that a more fundamental consolidation might be under way.
The issue is particularly sensitive because the landmarks commission won independent status only three years ago. Before that, it was part of the Parks and Recreation Department.
"I don't want landmarks to be subsumed or their mission to be diluted," said Councilwoman June M. Eisland, a Bronx Democrat who heads the Council's Land Use Committee.
Even Ms. Beckelman was at a loss to explain the bookkeeping. "I question how they can put our budget into that of another agency when we're a separate agency," she said Friday morning.
By Friday afternoon, Deputy Mayor Barbara J. Fife said the idea of merging the agencies' budgets "is no longer contemplated" and that the two commissions would "keep their independent units of appropriation."
"The implications, when you saw no dollars there, were of a very different nature than intended," Ms. Fife said.
She emphasized that the proposal involved only "housekeeping functions" and that there was "not the remotest" plan to place the policy-making powers of the landmarks panel under the planning agency.
Harvey Robins, director of the Mayor's Office of Operations, added, "We are not in any way intending to diminish the very important role the chair has in retaining control over policy and programs."
 
Touchy Bookkeeping Plan
 But the notion of having the Planning Department handle the landmarks commission's payroll, time sheets, supplies and vouchers remains a plan, although it has few supporters.
"I was worried that there was a total loss of independent landmark personnel," said Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan.
Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, a Brooklyn Democrat who heads the Council's landmarks subcommittee, said it appeared to be "a wholesale movement of the landmarks commission into city planning."
Christabel Gough, a private preservationist, asked: "Having lost its funding and having had its staff reassigned to another agency, will the commission really feel that it can retain control? Is this not a rather broad hint to forget about independence?"
Kent L. Barwick, the president of the Municipal Art Society and a former chairman of the landmarks commission, said, "It's one of those ideas that comes out of the minds of junior budgeteers at 11 o'clock on the night before the budget is due."
Ms. Messinger has proposed a separate office to handle administration for several small agencies like the landmarks commission, Board of Standards and Appeals and Department of Records and Information Services.
When told that city officials had dropped the idea of moving the landmarks budget, Ms. Messinger still expressed concern. "I think they're being put under the umbrella of an agency that has a different function," she said, "one that's sometimes at odds with the function of landmarks."
For example, while the landmarks panel has tried to preserve the small, 19th-century scale of the South Street Seaport Historic District, the planning commission has kept its zoning for fairly dense commercial development.
"There are some inherent tensions," Ms. Beckelman said. "That's why I believe it's much better, as a public policy, to consolidate unlike agencies to work together. It's much healthier to keep an arm's-length distance."

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Who Will Make a Mark on Pennant Races? Keep These Moves in Mind

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
When people sit around during the winter and predict the winners of the next season's pennant races, the "biggest mistake they make is focusing on the off season's comings and goings," Andy MacPhail says. "More times than not, it's things you don't foresee that determine the winners."
MacPhail, the highly successful general manager of the Minnesota Twins, probably is correct, but it's easier to anticipate the impact of the addition of Jack Morris to a pitching staff than divine the instant development of Chuck Knoblauch from a minor league Class AA player into a star major league second baseman. 
 This off season ends Friday when pitchers and catchers for 15 teams hold their first spring training workouts. For the most part, the major movement of players through trades and free agency has already been completed. Teams will spend the early weeks of spring training assessing the off season's comings and goings.
Checking some of those developments:
*Newly acquired players who are most capable of playing a significant role in the pennant races, or at least in their teams' possible rise in the standings: Bobby Bonilla and Bret Saberhagen (maybe Eddie Murray, too) of the Mets, Eric Davis (and maybe Tom Candiotti) of Los Angeles, Greg Swindell and Tim Belcher of Cincinnati, Morris and Dave Winfield of Toronto, Frank Viola of Boston, Danny Tartabull of the Yankees, Steve Sax of the Chicago White Sox, Kevin Mitchell of Seattle and Wally Joyner, Kevin McReynolds and Gregg Jefferies of Kansas City.
*The Fallen Angel: Whitey Herzog, California's $800,000 general manager, let Winfield go, was unable to re-sign Joyner and Kirk McCaskill and failed to sign the free agents Bonilla, Tartabull and Otis Nixon. He couldn't even persuade the Montreal Expos to take Lance Parrish for $1, with the added inducement of paying $1 million of the catcher's $2.25 million salary. As a consolation, Herzog added Von Hayes, Hubie Brooks and Alvin Davis to the Angels' lineup. Last season Joyner and Winfield together batted .282, hit 49 home runs and knocked in 182 runs; Hayes, Brooks and Davis batted a collective .228, hit 28 home runs and drove in 140 runs.
*Best moves without a checkbook: Bob Quinn of the Cincinnati Reds filled gaping holes in the starting pitching rotation by acquiring Swindell and Belcher and a vacancy at the top of the batting order by getting Bip Roberts.
*Best moves with a checkbook: Al Harazin of the Mets signed Bonilla and Murray in dramatic moves that woke up the team's slumbering fans. (The trade for Saberhagen was dramatic, too, but in economic terms, he comes cheaper than the departed Viola.)
*Gutsiest move: Herk Robinson's trade of Saberhagen.
*Most wholesale transformation of a team's appearance: Robinson acquired four and possibly five new players for Kansas City's starting lineup -- Joyner, McReynolds, Jefferies, Keith Miller and possibly Chris Gwynn. He also let shortstop Kurt Stillwell go as a free agent.
*Biggest shuffle of a division champion's roster: Six members of the Twins' World Series team plus a starting pitcher who just missed the post-season roster have gone elsewhere, some by the team's design (Junior Ortiz, Steve Bedrosian, Terry Leach, Allan Anderson), some by their own (Morris, Dan Gladden, Al Newman).
*Best use of management's newest gimmick for keeping salaries down: The Houston Astros have signed 13 major league players to minor league contracts, meaning the players have to make the team to get their major league salaries, which will be lower than they would have been had they signed major league contracts.
*Classiest move: Jim Leyland chose to sign a new five-year contract with Pittsburgh rather than wait until the end of the season and get out of the last year of his existing contract and flee to Florida and the expansion Marlins for what most likely would have been the biggest contract for a manager ever. Leyland decided to stay with the Pirates even though free agency threatens to devastate the team next year.
Some general managers and managers believe that even championship teams can't remain static. They say a team has to make at least a few changes to make sure complacency doesn't set in. But MacPhail said that no theory dictated the changes the Twins have undergone.
"We didn't have a philosophy one way or another," the general manager said. "The fortunate thing for us is with the young guys we have, we had the luxury of picking and choosing. The farm system was a safety net for us."
MacPhail did not include the loss of Morris, the World Series hero, in that explanation. "We pursued Morris and didn't get him," MacPhail said. The Twins also tried to re-sign Gladden, but the Detroit Tigers offered a better deal, including the prospect of more playing time.
Pedro Munoz, one of the young players MacPhail meant, will replace Gladden in left field. The Twins felt it was his time anyway. Gladden can run down fly balls better than Munoz, but Munoz has a better arm and should contribute more offensively.
Two other young players who will benefit from the roster shuffle are catcher Lenny Webster and pitcher Paul Abbott. Webster has played bits of the past three seasons with the Twins but is 27 years old and out of options. If he doesn't get a chance this year, he never will, at leaast not with the Twins.
Abbott will replace Steve Bedrosian in the bullpen. "There's no way we could keep Bedrosian around at 80 percent of what he made," MacPhail said. Even with the maximum cut allowed, the reliever would have had a $1.16 million salary. Bob Kipper, signed for $1 million, also will join the relief corps, which lost Leach as well as Bedrosian.
The Twins wanted to re-sign Newman for utility infield duty, but he didn't want to wait until they were ready to make that move, and he signed a minor league contract with Cincinnati.
The payroll race will heat up this week, with some of the largest salaries left in salary arbitration set to be decided. It appears to be a five-team race, with the tentative standings looking something like this:
Dodgers, $41.3 million; Athletics, $39.4 million; Mets, $39.2 million; Blue Jays, $39 million, and Red Sox, $38.3 million.
The totals are based on signed players who, at the moment, figure to be on the teams' 25-man rosters. Between now and opening day, the totals will change as more players sign and rosters change.
The Mets, for example, will take the lead as soon as David Cone's salary is determined -- his hearing is scheduled for tomorrow -- because at a minimum of $3 million, his pay will raise the Mets' running total to at least $42.2 million. If he wins his bid for $4.25 million, the payroll will reach $43.4 million.
The Blue Jays' total will rise to at least $40.8 million with the addition of Duane Ward's salary, and the Red Sox payroll will be at least $40.3 million when Ellis Burks's salary is added. The Dodgers and the Athletics, whose $39 million payroll was the highest last year, have no players left in arbitration. Oakland's remaining salaries will be meager while the Dodgers have only one more player, Ramon Martinez, who could command a sizable salary.
Other major cases scheduled for arbitration this week: John Smiley of Pittsburgh, Ruben Sierra and Rafael Palmeiro of Texas, Greg Swindell of Cincinnati and Tom Glavine of Atlanta.
One theory that has been advanced as a reason club owners oppose foreign ownership, particularly Japanese, is that cash-rich Japanese investors might escalate the salary scale to even higher levels. At least one owner disagrees.
"The theory that the Japanese would spend more money than present ownership is ridiculous," the owner said. "No one can spend more."

HEADLINE: A Long Run Down Vietnam's Memory Lane

BYLINE: By BARBARA BASLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Andy Anderson, a blunt, almost cantankerous Vietnam veteran who uses a wheelchair because of a war injury, showed the radiance of a man returning home today as he spoke of once again seeing the city that used to be Saigon.
"I haven't been here since Dec. 23, 1973, and when I went out through the streets here this week, it was like I left last Friday and came back on Monday," said Anderson, who is from Long Beach, Calif., and who is here for the Ho Chi Minh City International Marathon, the first major sports event to be held in Vietnam since the fall of Saigon in 1975. 
 Anderson, 55 years old, lived in Saigon for two years while working as an adviser to the Vietnamese navy. "I lived across the street from the presidential palace," he said with excitement. "I fished these waters. I ate corned beef and cabbage every Saturday in a place near here, and the city hasn't changed much."
 
70's Look, 90's Optimism
 This sprawling, often elegant city, with discos with names like Satisfaction and Queen Bee, may look much as it did in the 1970's, but the marathon, with 133 runners from 26 countries, represents a real change for a country that reopened its doors to tourists only in 1987. Because of its stumbling economy, Vietnam is eager to rejoin the international community -- to attract foreign investors and foreign loans -- and this event is a way for Vietnam to show its new attitude.
The field is tiny compared with those for the marathons in New York or Boston, where thousands take part. But for most Americans competing here, especially the veterans, this was a race that for a variety of emotional reasons, they simply could not miss.
"I grew up with the war in Vietnam -- it was a part of all our lives -- and I wanted to be in this marathon because it was taking place in Vietnam," said Paul Gallagher, an American stockbroker who now works in Hong Kong.
Jim Barker, a former United States Army intelligence officer who served in Vietnam, said, "I came here for this marathon because I saw it as a chance for reconciliation."
Barker, an elite runner from San Jose, Calif., said that Sunday's marathon offered a chance "for a healing experience, a way to bridge differences, and deal with the very intense emotional traumas we lived through here."
From the beginning, this promised to be a quirky, unlikely sporting event in a country where running is a new sport. The sight of aging Americans, Australians and Frenchmen running through the streets in the shimmering Saigon heat has left many Vietnamese openly gawking and pointing.
 
'Very Happy Time'
 "I saw some foreigners -- very old," said a middle-aged shopkeeper who was selling souvenir T-shirts from a small sidewalk stall. "The foreigners were very old, but still they run. They enjoy it. This is a very happy time for them and a very happy time for us."
This marathon, a strange spectacle staged by Vietnamese Communists working with American advisers and using capitalist money from foreign corporations, has old enemies facing each other on a new battlefield: the race course. And most find the combination a heady, happy one, though it is laced with sadness, a sense of poignancy.
When Anderson and three other disabled American veterans went out on the street, many older Vietnamese, survivors of the war, came up to greet them. Some shook their hands, others introduced their sons and daughters.
Anderson and other American wheelchair athletes came to compete, and there were able to do so in a preliminary "fun" event today. But the Vietnamese organizers decided that because they were not prepared to field wheelchair athletes, only runners would be included in Sunday's race. American veterans had donated three racing chairs to Vietnam's sports ministry in hopes of persuading the Vietnamese to allow the wheelchair athletes to compete.
 
'A Peaceful Moment'
 A runner from San Mateo, Calif., Linda Shinazy, said she had been opposed to the war and had protested it by writing letters on eye-catching red stationery, "to anyone and everyone."
This little marathon, she said, "was a chance for me to celebrate peace."
"It's a small moment in history, a peaceful moment," she said.
While hundreds of Vietnamese took part in the short "fun" races, only 92 will compete in the marathon, and only 8 of them have ever run a marathon before. The course winds through the center of the city, to the gritty outskirts, and into the green countryside before returning to Reunification Hall, the former presidential palace.
Since the war ended, Vietnam has remained mired in poverty. One official here admitted that while the Communists had "helped the masses" take part in more sports, the people literally "don't have the food, enough calories" to have large numbers of regular marathon runners.
"The few Vietnamese who were trying to train were running in running in rubber thongs," said Bruce Aitken, the American financial consultant who first suggested the marathon to the Vietnamese. He said that when Adidas, one of the major sponsors of the marathon, donated 1,000 pairs of running shoes, the Vietnamese, "who are really very competitive people," got very interested in training.
To open the marathon weekend, there were speeches by Communist officials wearing suits and ties and sunglasses. There were firecrackers, silky banners and dozens of red balloons released into the clear blue sky. There was even a live rock band and a special marathon song sung by Tran Tien, whom one Vietnamese explained was "a very popular singer, known in all of Vietnam."
A top Vietnamese sports official said that his country hoped that by staging events like the marathon, "We will someday be able to host something really big, like the Olympics."
In fact, the official, Le Buu, head of the Ho Chi Minh Sports Authority, said Vietnam planned to send a delegation to Barcelona, Spain, for the 1992 Olympic Summer Games. And while he was vague about what Olympic events the Vietnamese would compete in there, he said, "Definitely we will send a shooting team."

HEADLINE: SPRING TRAINING;
For Torborg and Mets, Attitude Is Everything

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 15

 BODY:
In early spring, baseball teams are all theory, statistical projections and elaborate constructs of the heart. As such, the Mets, perhaps the recession's most conspicuous consumers, are at the moment an extraordinary, even exquisite abstraction.
There is the image of Bobby Bonilla looping doubles into either gap from both sides of the plate. There is the confident calculation that Vince Coleman's speed and Willie Randolph's subtle mastery of the fundamentals of offense can create a perpetual threat at the top of the order. There is the perilous leap of faith that Howard Johnson can convert into a center fielder and the rather more secure assumption that he will continue to consistently convert men on base into runs scored. And then there is the enormous exercise in optimism that the entire organization is engaged in: that Dwight Gooden can return from surgery and return to form on the mound. 
 And so it will be on Friday that at last the abstraction begins its transformation into an identifiable and quantifiable reality. The checkbook signatures and salary figures will have exhausted their worth in promotional publicity. Formulas will become faces and lineups more than attractive assortments of names. Spring training opens for the Mets as pitchers and catchers report and 1992 takes shape.
 
'Preconceived Notions'
 "I'm going into it all with a certain number of preconceived notions," said Jeff Torborg, the manager who has a wonderful track record and absolutely zero history with the Mets. "But I don't know how it will all come down."
Torborg, though, insists that he knows how it will all start to come together for the Mets, and that is with the atmosphere in the clubhouse. Long distinguished as a kind of sinkhole of silence and cynicism, the clubhouse under Torborg could actually become a locus of respect for one another and authentic enthusiasm for the game.
"I'm going with the same approach as when I had the youngest team in baseball with the White Sox," said Torborg, who was the American League's manager of the year with that team in 1990. "I believe in attitude, and I don't care how old you are. I'm going to hit them over the head with attitude every day, every week. It's the only way I know how to do it."
But how the Mets will do it on the field in 1992 is a sizable, if intriguing, mystery. Johnson, the longtime third baseman and raw right fielder, is being asked to become the team's most influential outfielder. The assignment amounts to a complex and possibly combustible experiment.
"I want, obviously, to see how it will work, and that means probably playing Howard al lot more in the spring than you might otherwise ask of a veteran," said Torborg. "I told him I might ultimately decide to go another way, and that I was dependent on him being as honest as possible with me about how he felt out there.
"For me, it's going to be a real gut read," said Torborg, whose alternative is to return Vince Coleman from left to center and send Johnson to either left or right, with Bonilla taking up the position Johnson doesn't. "If I get to a point where I don't feel comfortable, I'll make the switch. It might be in the middle of March. It might be the last week before the season starts. But if he's making progress, my plan is to stick with him."
Another area of concern for Torborg is his catching situation. In what has been the most overlooked and possibly outrageous assumption, the Mets are trusting that Todd Hundley, the 22-year-old rookie who has hit a combined .173 in his bits of two seasons in the major leagues, can approximate an everyday catcher. Charlie O'Brien, after all, has demonstrated that he is a bona fide .200 presence at the plate, and Mackey Sasser, with his mental block about returning the baseball to the pitcher, is a partly disabled performer.
"I don't want to cast doubts on what we have," said Torborg. "I think we are adequately fortified. But I am concerned about our handling of our pitchers. I might wind up using a system of three catchers."
Torborg, meanwhile, has shown no particular inclination to employ only one third baseman. He has said that Bill Pecota is his current preference as a regular, but he has made it clear that Dave Magadan will earn himself starts there if he can stop baseballs with proficiency. There are those who believe that Magadan, a legitimate albeit light bat, has to be in the lineup consistently if the final third of the order -- Kevin Elster, Hundley and the pitcher -- isn't to be a daily and dramatic drag on the offense.
And then there is Gooden. The right-hander's rehabilitation from rotator cuff surgery is unfolding without incident, but also without any accompanying guarantees. Maybe he'll start the season with the Mets, maybe he won't be ready until May, maybe it won't matter if the accomplished Bret Saberhagen, the ambitious David Cone and the physically reconfigured -- that is to say thinner -- Sid Fernandez pitch up to potential.
"What I can tell you is that no ground rules have been handed down to me by the organization," Torborg said of Gooden's present and future status. "We're to go start by start, pitch by pitch."
 
Questions, Questions
 And of course, the Mets, piece by piece, will be defined through the spring by other evaluations. Will night close fast on Randolph and Eddie Murray, the right side of the infield that has clearly entered the twilight of its career? Will John Franco be the cocky closer he was or the tortured pitcher who last year finished 75th in the major leagues in the ratio of men allowed on base per inning pitched. Will Torborg, who has shown himself to be more comfortable answering questions on radio than Bud Harrelson was, be as polished handling crises in the dugout?
Time will tell. Time has also run out on the attractive abstraction that the Mets have been since they last left the diamond.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The Olympics Don't Need Us vs. Them

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

DATELINE: ALBERTVILLE, France

 BODY:
IN their red uniforms with "CCCP" in white, the Soviet Union hockey players once were the scourge of the Winter Olympics, a team that all but melted the ice under their opponents. In those years, the Soviets were the "enemy" that some Americans seemed to need in order to reduce international sports to a morality play.
In those years, the cold war of politics had created the gold war of the Olympics, Winter and Summer. 
 When the United States hockey team won the gold at Lake Placid in 1980, its "miracle on ice" momentarily cured America's inferiority complex about sports on ice and snow. The enemy had been conquered. Us against them, and us had won.
Hooray for the red, white and blue!
Now, with the collapse of the Soviet Union and its transformation into the Commonwealth of Independent States, and the formation of one Germany, there's no enemy in the Olympics for the American public. No they. No them. And that's the way it should be. The Olympics don't need an enemy.
But according to some American voices bouncing off the satellite into the Savoy region, from where these XVI Olympic Winter Games are being beamed to the world on television, the CBS network is still trying to create us-against-them theater for its United States viewers.
Hooray for the American who finishes 16th in the 1,000-meter Nordic combined bobsled biathlon slalom off the Alpine ski jump while shooting a hockey puck before spinning a triple axel!
After all, that's the us-against-them philosophy. And if this is the Olympics, it must be us against them. If only because it always has been. When the American athletes won all those gold medals in the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles that the Soviet Union boycotted, Americans cheered as never before. As if "we" were really that good.
But without the Soviet Union and most of the Eastern bloc nations, the Olympic track-and-field events in Los Angeles had resembled a U.C.L.A. invitational meet.
When the United States had boycotted the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow, Americans didn't bother to count who won all the gold medals. If it wasn't a real Olympics in Moscow, it wasn't a real Olympics in Los Angeles, either. But all that counted in Los Angeles was that we won big.
We, we, we. Us, us, us.
But for Americans and everybody else, we and us should be removed from the Olympic vocabulary. If they and them don't exist anymore, we and us don't. Without a cold war, there's no gold war. It's obvious now that the relation of Olympic strength to a nation's strength was always propaganda, never proof.
When the Kremlin folded after the Berlin Wall fell, the importance of those nations' Olympic medals melted. And all those United States medals in Los Angeles weren't able to prevent America's economic slide into its current recession.
What the Olympics means, and have always meant, is, quite simply, the opportunity for an athlete to say that he or she is the best in the world in that event on that day.
That's what Bonnie Blair of Champaign, Ill., has done twice, winning the women's 500 and 1,000 in speed skating. That's what Donna Weinbrecht of West Milford, N.J., did in winning the first women's gold medal in a new Olympic sport, freestyle mogul skiing.
That's what Patrick Ortlieb of Austria did in swooping to the gold medal in the men's downhill.
That's what Jacqueline Borner of Germany did in striding to the 1,500 speed-skating gold medal as Bonnie Blair, realizing she couldn't win, faded to 21st in order to save some energy for the 1,000 two days later.
On the medal stand, Borner, once an East German but now simply a German, could be seen smiling and sighing. Smiling at knowing she was the best in the world in that event on that day. Sighing at knowing she had not missed her only opportunity in these Olympics to be the best in the world in that event on that day.
That's what all those Unified Team athletes have done in maintaining the gold-medal tradition of the Soviet athletes. For them, there's also no us and them anymore.
That's what all Olympic athletes strive for. Simply to be the best in the world in that event on that day. To compete, as Bonnie Blair said, "for myself, not for anybody else." Certainly not for us against them. Because if there's no them, there can't be an us.

HEADLINE: Pat Buchanan's Politics of Pain

 BODY:
He started his New Hampshire primary campaign intending to push President Bush back to old-time Republican religion. Then he came to New Hampshire, where businesses have failed in record numbers, unemployment in some towns has exceeded 20 percent and welfare rolls have swollen. Meet the new Patrick Buchanan.
Now the archconservative journalist campaigns by assailing "vulture capitalism." Now the thundering apostle of free-market economics proclaims that "conservatism is about more than the constitutional right of big fishes to eat little fishes." 
 Pat Buchanan, the raging right-winger who once said AIDS was nature's retribution against homosexuals, now speaks sympathetically of AIDS victims. He who once denounced extending unemployment benefits, now favors doing so.
Faced with New Hampshire's pain, the man who started out trying to force George Bush to the right is now making campaign pitches worthy of a New Deal Democrat. He has rediscovered, and responds to, a political fundamental often forgotten inside the Beltway: People in pain want help, not ideology.
The new Pat Buchanan was on display during the last full week before Tuesday's primary. For instance, in Londonderry, N.H., he spoke on behalf of a couple who'd lost their jobs and then their home. Standing with Steve Embry in front of the condominium that the bank had taken away, he argued that bankers should be permitted by law "to carry their folks for a while the way the best of them did in the Depression."
His conversion to this new-time religion may or may not be sincere. But it is paying dividends. Barely three weeks ago, President Bush seemed destined to bury Mr. Buchanan, who had never been elected to anything. Now with the election two days away, the President is scrambling to preserve a convincing margin of victory.
Mr. Bush, having failed in his State of the Union Message to show New Hampshire voters that he grasps the extent of their economic travail, surely understands the potential erosion of support. He is putting in long, hard closing campaign days trying to show that he, too, hears the pain.
So far voters are repeating as their own some ideas heard in Buchanan advertisements. "We can't afford Bush for another four years," said a woman in western New Hampshire. In Portsmouth, on the coast, a man criticized the President because "He doesn't have a real economic plan."
Neither does Pat Buchanan, ideologue, but he does have an ear, and he is listening.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
For Want of A Nail

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
It may have been the greatest failure of American political imagination since World War II, the costliest abdication of leadership: President Bush's failure to join promptly in helping to build new societies in what had been the Soviet Union.
So we must begin to think as we see what is happening in the former Soviet republics today. There are devastating inflation and economic distress, social tension, political menace. People are asking whether Boris Yeltsin can survive in Russia or may be overthrown by a new authoritarianism of the right. 
 The stakes are enormous, not just for them but for us -- Europe, the United States, the developed world. Collapse of the democratic experiment in the republics would create a refugee crisis of large proportions. It could destabilize the new democracies of Central and Eastern Europe. It would turn a potential opportunity for world trade and investment into threatening uncertainty.
Weimar is the grisly example in history: the German democracy whose collapse led to war and the Holocaust. It was brought forcefully to mind when anti-Yeltsin marchers in Moscow shouted against Jews and called for the return of Communism.
The transition from the Soviet system to market democracy was inevitably going to be difficult. And of course it could not be an American responsibility. But what a difference U.S. help -- and as important, a visibly sympathetic American attitude -- could have made.
What President Bush has offered instead, over the last year, has been disregard. When Germany proposed a collaborative effort by the industrial powers to help economically, Mr. Bush said no. He would not even move last summer on emergency assistance, leaving it to Congress to come up with a $500 million plan to transport food and help disable nuclear weapons.
Political fear was no doubt the explanation for Mr. Bush's performance. He was being criticized for neglecting domestic affairs, and polls showed that Americans were increasingly skeptical about foreign aid when they themselves were suffering economically.
But a leader would have explained to the American people how large the stakes were, how great the opportunity. That is what Harry Truman did with Greek-Turkish aid, the Marshall Plan, the North Atlantic Treaty. And Americans responded, taking on those burdens.
The key to the Marshall Plan's success was not only, or mainly, American money. It was the political and psychological effect of the American commitment, and of the requirement imposed by the United States that the recipient countries of Western Europe draw up their own recovery plan.
It would not have taken -- it would not take -- huge amounts of U.S. money to help the former Soviet republics significantly. A favorable American response would have brought in the other developed countries. Economists say that $25 billion a year would make a great difference, and not much of that would have to come from the U.S.
The United States spent upward of $100 billion a year (in 1992 dollars) on the defense of Europe during the decades of the cold war. Now, for want of comparatively trivial sums, we may lose the hope that the end of the cold war brought: hope of the Soviet republics turned into productive and democratic participants in the world economy. And the hope of the former Soviet satellites is at risk, too.
President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia, when he spoke to Congress two years ago, said: "You can help us most of all if you help the Soviet Union on its irreversible but immensely complicated road to democracy." His Foreign Minister, Jiri Dienstbier, proposed a modest, sensible financial plan for the U.S.S.R. and its former satellites. But it got nowhere in the Bush Administration.
Prof. Richard Neustadt, the Harvard chronicler of Presidential power and its uses, expressed anguish the other day at this Presidential episode. "It just seems to me terrible," he said. "I fear for what is going to happen in Prague and Warsaw and all the Soviet capitals. If there had been just some show of American forthcomingness. . . ."
If things go wrong, George Bush will go down as the American President who saved the Emir of Kuwait and lost, for democracy, the great land mass between the Vistula and Vladivostok.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
