HEADLINE: A New Baja California

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD; ROBERT REINHOLD is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
WHEN Mexico's 1,059-mile Transpeninsular Highway No. 1 finally opened in 1973, Baja California Sur, one of the least traveled regions in the world, seemed ready to emerge from centuries of isolation. Until then, Baja, the world's longest peninsula, longer than the Italian peninsula, was reserved for rugged adventurers in four-wheel-drive vehicles for whom communing with cardon cactus in the desert or watching gray whales on magnificent deserted white beaches was sufficient reward for the arduous journey over rutted dirt roads.
But development came slowly. Despite its grand name, the "highway" was a narrow winding two-lane road without shoulders that quickly became pocked and rutted and easily washed out during rains, as it did during last January's downpours. Moreover, gasoline supplies were uncertain, accommodations limited and water scarce. For better or worse, Baja resisted tourists, much as it had Spanish explorers and missionaries and other invaders during its turbulent history. 
 To this day, Baja California Sur, or B.C.S., remains the most remote and inaccessible of Mexican states. It achieved statehood only in 1974, the year after the road opened. While fast growing, its population is only about 250,000, scarcely a tenth of that of Baja California, the state that encompasses the more-developed northern half of the peninsula that abuts the American border. Even Mexicans from the "mainland" remain a little hazy about it; they sometimes ask if they need passports to visit B.C.S. and what language is spoken there. In fact, given that most of the 600,000 visitors a year come from California, it is quite easy to get by with English.
Yet, fitfully and unevenly, this land of extraordinary beautyis finally showing signs of entering the age of tourism, but at a price not easily measured in pesos or dollars. New developments are concentrated mainly in three areas: around Loreto on the Gulf of California (or the Sea of Cortes as Mexican maps refer to it), in the capital city of La Paz, and in the Los Cabos area at the very southern tip of the peninsula. Clean, pleasant hotel accommodations, usually at moderate prices, are now available throughout Baja. And recreational-vehicle drivers, to the dismay of those who treasure the rugged magnificence of the Baja coasts, find they are all too welcome to park at water's edge at almost any beach for $3.50 or $4 a night, or even free at more remote spots.
As a result, some of the most beautiful beaches in the world, those along the western shore of Concepcion Bay near Mulege on the Gulf of California, have become squalid-looking encampments of house trailers from California and Arizona. Four hundred forty-fourmiles to the south, the fishing village of Cabo San Lucas at the spectacular rocky tip of the Baja pensinsula, is no longer the private preserve of wealthy yachtsmen and movie stars. Resorts are blooming along the 18-mile beach corridor between Cabo and San Jose; two sushi bars have opened in Cabo, and a massive hotel and condominium complex now squats on the once picturesque Cabo harbor, where aggressive time-share salespeople have replaced turista as the main scourge afflicting American visitors.
Mexican tourism officials and local hotel developers insist they will avoid the mistakes made at Acapulco, Cancun and other major Mexican destinations, saying they intend to control the size, density and architecture of Baja resorts and impose strict pollution controls. Whether one accepts such assurances, a natural factor does impose some tough limits on commercial exploitation: water. Unless desalination of sea water becomes economical, scarce supplies of fresh water will forever protect the peninsula from gross excess.
Even today, it takes little to find the old Baja, where electricity, television and telephones are still a novelty. Driving just a few minutes out of any town takes the visitor into a splendid, stark and arid land of rare cactus, snakes, date palms, Spanish missions, snow-white beaches, dusty villages, cafes under palapa roofs, and friendly, hospitable people.
Despite Baja's enormous beauty, it has not been easy for Mexico to develop the area. The National Trust Fund for Tourist Development, or Fonatur, is the 18-year-old Federal agency that builds the roads, docks, water and sewer lines, electric power plants and other elements of infrastructure meant to stimulate private investment in hotels, golf courses, marinas and other tourist facilities in Mexico. It has placed two of its five major projects in B.C.S. -- at Loreto and Los Cabos. The others are Cancun on the Yucatan peninsula, which gets a million visitors a year, and Ixtapa and Huatulco, on the Pacific Coast.
Fonatur's experience at Loreto illustrates the problems inherent in development in Baja California. Founded in 1697 by the Jesuit priest Juan Maria Salvaterria, Loreto was the site of the first of the chain of Roman Catholic missions established throughout the Californias and was the first capital of all California, including what is now the American state of California. Its spectactular setting on a dramatic bay edged with the craggy dark volcanic peaks of the Sierra de la Giganta made it a likely spot for tourism. Fonatur's Loreto plan has three elements: sprucing up the historic old town, building a resort area about 10 miles south at Nopolo, and development of a marina-hotel complex at nearby Puerto Escondido.
THE agency has gracefully restored the old mission, Our Lady of Loreto, the largest structure in town, with its gilded altar. Next door, an informative museum was added to illustrate life in the old missions. The agency also improved the waterfront, building a milelong sea wall for walking and two-line roadway divided by a grassy mall with palms, and a protected harbor for fishing boats and yachts. Three pleasant small hotels operate along the waterfront, and streets have been laid out anticipating that the town of only 8,000 will ultimately grow to 57,000 to serve the tourists. But there are few tourists yet.
At Nopolo, a beautiful seaside 18-hole golf course is nearing completion, there is a professional tennis center with eight courts, buildings ready for shops, water and telephone lines meant to serve condominiums and retirement homes. But so far there are few homes and only one hotel, the 250-room Stouffer Presidente Loreto, which is struggling. A few miles south, Fonatur has put new docks and a group of French and Mexican investors has agreed to put up two hotels, as well as a condominium-hotel and a marina, to attract the Newport Beach crowd.
But 10 years after the Loreto project began, only 455 of the 7,500 projected hotel rooms have been built, and they usually go begging. According to Manuel Martinez, the Fonatur director at Loreto, several factors have contributed to the sluggish pace, including investor worries about water supplies (a new 20-mile aqueduct has been built to bring in ground water) and resistance of airlines to providing service to the new international airport. It gets only one international flight a day, a daily Aero California jet from Los Angeles. The highway passes right by town, but brings only 17 percent of Loreto's visitors.
With its extensive underused facilties, Loreto makes an excellent low-cost base for exploration of the central Baja peninsula and the off-shore islands of Carmen and Coronado, where the fishing and swimming are unmatched. It is also near one of the finest of the restored Spanish missions, the Mision San Javier, in a steep remote valley 22 miles from Loreto. The drive on a rough, rutted dirt road seems more like 100 miles, but it takes the visitor through some of the most characteristic of Baja desert countryside, with occasional ranches, wild burros, barrel cactus, poppies and zalate and mesquite trees. Standing before this church, built of five-foot-thick volcanic stones in 1758, one can imagine the stark isolation and hardship those early padres endured.
The road is passable by a well-built sedan, depending on conditions, such as rains. Inquire locally before venturing forth. And, as ever in Baja California, even on the main highway, always carry water and food, drive slowly because hazards like potholes, ruts, rock slides or a herd of cows can appear around any corner. Given the often poor road conditions, it is best to avoid driving at night.
Loreto also offers convenient access to the exquisite white beaches of Concepcion Bay, about 50 miles to the north. The first beaches on the bay are much less likely to be crowded with house trailers than those closer to Mulege, like Santispac. The oasis town of Mulege, with another fine restored mission, is a favorite of American expatriates.
If Loreto has been slow to develop, one almost wishes the same could be said of Los Cabos. The two towns at the bottom of the peninsula, San Jose and Cabo San Lucas, were once the definition of isolation, without access by paved roads, without telephones and electricity. Mark Parr, whose father, Bud Parr, pioneered in opening hotels there and who manages the family's Hacienda Beach Resort on the beach in Cabo now, recalls his days as a child when his father picked up guests in La Paz in a private plane. That was when stars like John Wayne, Bing Crosby and Frank Sinatra sought privacy at the area's first hotel, the Palmilla. It opened in 1956 and is still operating.
Those quiet days are long gone. Two paved roads now connect Los Cabos to La Paz, the capital, 95 miles away, and an international airport at San Jose offers nonstop flights from San Francisco, Los Angeles, San Diego and Phoenix. Both towns are awash with hotel and condominium construction. For example, at the famed Hotel Finisterra, built in 1970 into the cliffs near land's end, a 10-story condominium complex is going up on the beach. Next door at the Hotel Solmar, Luis Bulnes, a Spaniard who came to Cabo to manage a fish cannery in 1954, when the population was only 300, is putting up condo units and time-share units to supplement the 66 stark white boxlike rooms he built into the cliffs in 1974. Wealthy Americans, mostly from California, have put up vacation villas in the Pedegal Hills above downtown Cabo.
That is only the beginning. With a loan from the World Bank, an ambitious master plan for the area has been developed by Fonatur. It envisions adding nearly 8,000 hotel rooms to the current inventory of 2,700 rooms by the year 2000 and another 4,000 by 2020. Another 100 holes of golf courses are due to open by mid-1993. A major part of the plan is development of La Playita, a megaresort next to the estuary in San Jose, to include two hotels, villas with 1,800 rooms, 1,000 condominium units, a beach club and water park and a 36-hole golf course. Two resorts are planned on the beach corridor between the two towns.
According to Luis Klein, director of the Los Cabos Tourism Board, the strategy is to market the area as a smaller, more exclusive version of Cancun, or "Palm Springs with an ocean," as he put it. "We are not looking for that kind of growth," he said. "We want to remain normal scale, which will not spoil it for all of us." Both Mr. Parr and Mr. Bulnes argued that since much of the land remains in the hands of a few families, they can prevent the kind of ungainly sprawl that has spoiled Acapulco and other Mexican resorts. They said limited water supplies, in any case, would impose controls.
That remains to be seen. But for now Los Cabos, for all the growth, remains an attractive if costly destination with stunning beaches and scenery, great sportfishing and some passable restaurants. The two towns are quite different. San Jose, the older one, has the feel of a colonial village, with its quaint main plaza with interesting shops and restaurants. Cabo is more for the youthful yachting set, with its noisy bars and discos.
But it is easy enough to get away from the commercialism. Just drive a few miles up Mexico 19, the route to La Paz on the Pacific side of the peninsula, to a stretch of desolate unspoiled beaches. Forty-four miles up the road is the delightful town of Todos Santos, a former sugar-cane center opened to visitors only since 1985 when the road was paved. With its graceful church and town square, it has become something of an artist's colony and retreat for expatriates like Ezio Colombo, from Milan, Italy, and his New Yorker wife, Paula, who have opened a very pleasant Italian restaurant on the square, the Cafe Santa Fe.
For a taste of real modern-day Mexico, a visit to La Paz, the state capital, is essential. This prosperous-looking friendly city of 150,000, where the Spanish conquistador Hernan Cortes first set foot in 1535, is one of the most appealing of Mexican cities. Set around a great curving bay, it has the virtues of offering all tourist amenities, including deep-sea fishing, while not being primarily a tourist town. It is the main ferry connection to the mainland of Mexico and serves as the administrative nerve center of the region.
La Paz offers a vivid glimpse of the vibrancy of Mexican street life, particularly along the malecon, or sea wall, on the picturesque harbor, where local youths nightly parade and cruise in their cars.
The city has a grand plan to develop marinas, golf courses, parks and other tourist facilities, but no money to implement it. It is just as well, for La Paz remains appealing as it is. La Paz also offers some intellectual fare in a region that is otherwise a domain of sports: Visit the Biblioteca de Historia de las Californias, which has a display of paintings and a good collection of books in both Spanish and English about the history of Baja California (Plaza Constitucion, telephone 682-2-01-62, Monday through Friday 8 A.M. to 8 P.M.). Also don't miss the Museo Antropologico de Baja California Sur, a small but informative museum displaying the geology, folk art and history of the region. (Calle 5 de Mayo and Calle Ignacio Altamirano, telephone 682-2-01-62, Tuesday through Saturday, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M.)
Moreover, it is only a 15-mile drive northeast of town along a nicely paved new road to the beaches of Balandra and Tecolote, two of the most serene and beautiful beaches on the face of this planet.
 
 
 
EXPLORING THE REMOTE MEXICAN PENINSULA
Getting There
 Baja California Sur is most easily explored by flying into Los Cabos, La Paz or Loreto, then renting a car. Most major American car rental companies are represented at the airports at San Jose del Cabo, which serves Los Cabos, and La Paz, the capital of the state, but not at Loreto. Most major hotels also offer car rentals. Jeeps are widely available.
Renting a car is expensive, about $575 a week for a midsized Mexican-made Volkswagen Golf, for example. That includes taxes and liability insurance, which is essential because American policies are not honored in Mexico and, if you are uninsured, having an accident can mean spending your vacation in jail until matters are sorted out. The drop-off fee for cars left in another city is about 40 cents a mile. Rent in advance and have the rental company send a confirmation, including the rate as well as the drop fee, if applicable. Drive with caution, carry water and food when leaving town and always keep the gas tank at least half full. Don't pick up hitchhikers. If they happen to be carrying drugs, you could be considered an accessory. Lead-free gasoline (magna sin) is usually available at government-run Pemex stations at about $1.65 a gallon. If you have car trouble or run out of gas, take advantage of the government-sponsored Green Angels who patrol the peninsula to offer tourists free mechanical assistance, in addition to gas, parts and oil at cost.
"Baja California," published for members by the Automobile Club of Southern California, is an invaluable sourcebook.
The arduous but spectacular 1,059-mile journey down the peninsula from the American border could easily take a week. Accommodations along the way are good, even in remote locations. Leave time for the return, as American rental cars cannot be dropped off in Mexico. Be sure your vehicle is in good repair, and don't fail to buy Mexican insurance at the border, at about $10 to $14 a day. Americans must also, under a new regulation, carry documentary evidence that their vehicles carry full United States automobile insurance, or post a bond based on the value of the car.
A third route is to take a ferry from the Mexican mainland to La Paz or Santa Rosalia.
 
The Cabos
 Los Cabos offers a wide variety of hotels. All rates are for winter and exclude 15 percent Federal tax and a service charge of 10 to 20 percent. The most luxurious is the 150-room Hotel Palmilla, on the beach five miles west of San Jose del Cabo. Doubles start at $250 a night. Telephone (684)-20155 direct, (800) 528-1234 in the United States. (The country code for Mexico is 52.)
In Cabo San Lucas, good choices are the Hacienda Beach Resort, on a calm swimming beach that is walking distance from the center of town, at $118 to $170 for a double, (684)-30123 or (800) 733-2226; the Hotel Solmar at $95 a night, (684)-30022 or (800) 344-3349, and its neighbor, the Hotel Finisterra at $100 to $115, (684) 30000 or (800) 347-2252. A budget choice is the 72-room colonial-style Hotel Mar de Cortez in the center of town, starting at $33, (684)-30032 or (800) 347-8821.
Among Cabo restaurants, a favorite of American expatriates is Mi Casa, with a large patio. It serves a tasty pozole (hominy soup) at $4 and an excellent chicken with mole sauce for $10.65. (On the main square, behind the Aero California office; telephone 31933). An old favorite is El Rey Sol, where fish filet Veracruzana is $8, including soup and salad. (Across from Marina Sol Condominiums; 31117). For steaks and seafood, try the Faro Viejo, situated, oddly, in a trailer park, at the corner of Abasalo and Rosario Morales (no phone). In San Jose del Cabo, the Damiana restaurant has a romantic garden. The imperial shrimp steak is $20. (18 Boulevard Mijares; 20499).
In the little town of Todos Santos, on the way to La Paz, is the Hotel California, on Benito Juarez. Doubles are in the $20 to $35 range; telephone (682)-40002 or, in the United States, (415) 768-0614.
 
La Paz
 Less touristy, La Paz offers some good hotel bargains. The best hotel in the center of town, the Hotel Los Arcos right on the sea wall, is $55 double, (682)-22744 or (800) 421-3772. For more isolation, there's the Hotel Las Arenas, 44 miles southeast of La Paz at the end of an 11-mile dirt road, so remote it has no phone, but miles of empty beaches. Rates start at $115 double, (800) 423-4784 in the United States or, in California, (800) 352-4334.
A pleasant local restaurant is Las Brisas, under a palapa roof opposite the beach on Paseo Alvaro Obregon at Heroico Colegio Militar (no phone). A meal of typical Mexican food is $10 to $15.
In Loreto, the best place to stay is the only luxury resort within 225 miles, the 250-room Stouffer Presidente Loreto, about eight miles south of town. Doubles are $70 to $100, (683)-30700 or (800) 468-3571. There are also three modest but clean hotels on the bay in town, all in the $40 to $50 range for doubles: Hotel La Pinta, (683)-30025 or (800) 336-5454, Hotel Mision de Loreto, (683)-30048, and Hotel Oasis, (683)-30112.
A favorite restaurant of American visitors is Caesar's, at the corner of Calle Zapata and Calle Benito Juarez (telephone 30203). A Mexican lunch or dinner is about $3.50 to $5.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 34; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 340 words

HEADLINE: Children and Video Games

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In her review of my book, "Playing With Power in Movies, Television, and Video Games," Marie Winn challenges my assumption that video games have cognitive value for children (a conclusion supported by virtually every book on the subject) and erroneously claims that the empirical studies I cite "do not, unfortunately, include the major users of video games -- healthy 8- to 11-year-old boys." If she had looked at the endnotes, she would have seen that 25 of the empirical studies I mention do in fact deal with this group -- along with healthy girls. And so do the ethnographic studies I did with my own 8-year-old son and with children at a video arcade and a day-care center, which are described at length in two appendixes. 
 Ms. Winn is probably so obstinate in denying the cognitive value of video games because this position is consistent with the sweeping denun ciations of mass media featured in her own book "The Plug-In Drug: Television, Children and the Family."
Although she fails to mention my book's central emphasis on how commercial supersystems like Nintendo and Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles commodify growth and how their popularity is related to the global economics of the 1980's and 90's, she gives great weight to one minor point: "Children heavily involved with video games may come to believe that athletes who win gold medals in the Olympics, or writers and scientists who win the Nobel Prize, are performing tasks that are no more important or difficult than winning at video games."
Undoubtedly she chose that point not because it is representative of my argument, but rather as a lead-in to her own dubious speculation (which I am criticized for omitting) that "children accustomed to the quick gratifications of video games may not be willing to put up with the arduous efforts necessary to learn to play a musical instrument well, or to excel at tennis." Anyone who has ever played video games knows that it takes practice to excel at Nintendo.
 
MARSHA KINDER
Los Angeles

SECTION: Section 10; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1213 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Downtown Houston;
Hines Renovating 2 Shell Towers He Built in 70's

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
GERALD D. HINES, the local developer who made a fortune building high-profile projects around the country, has begun his first major office project in downtown Houston since 1983. This time, however, it is rehabilitation, not new construction.
He has begun a major renovation of two Houston skyscrapers that he developed two decades ago -- the 50-story 1 Shell Plaza and the 29-story 2 Shell Plaza. The $95 million project is the largest of any kind in downtown Houston in the last five years. 
 Hines Interests Limited Partnership currently has more office buildings under construction than any other developer in the country, accounting for about a tenth of all the major development now under way. But times are changing.
Projects like the one in Shell Plaza are part of a new strategy for Mr. Hines to adapt to the recession: While looking for new construction projects abroad, he is focusing in this country on renovation of older properties and the acquisition of existing ones.
The real estate market of the 90's will be vastly different from that of the last decade, said the 66-year-old developer, whose empire spreads across 34 American cities. Mr. Hines believes overbuilding in the 80's and the industry's retrenchment in the 90's will cause demand for new commercial space to shrink by as much as 50 percent.
So just what does a developer do when demand for new construction dwindles? What does the future hold for the company that has grown from a one-man operation in 1957 to an 1,100-employee conglomerate with regional offices in Chicago, New York, San Francisco and Atlanta?
Mr. Hines believes development opportunities abound in Southeast Asia, Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. The company opened an office in Berlin last year and recently announced plans for a mixed-use project there in partnership with Four Seasons Hotel Ltd. of Toronto. The $280 million development, scheduled to start late this year and be completed in 1995, will include offices, apartments, a 225-room hotel and stores built around a landscaped courtyard.
Investors in the project include a group of German businessmen who own property on the block on Franzosische Strasse where the development will be built.
"We're looking at other opportunities abroad, but timing is of the utmost importance," Mr. Hines said. "We have to be careful not to move in to a market too early." The danger is putting up a building before a country's economy is viable enough to support it, he said.
Buying existing properties in the United States is another new direction for the privately held company, which is headed by Mr. Hines as chairman and his 36-year-old son, Jeff, as president. No properties have been purchased yet, but the company has spent the last two years cataloguing every property in every city that it would be interested in acquiring.
"We're doing detailed workups on each property so that when they become available, we'll be ready," Mr. Hines said. "But the timing isn't right yet. Prices are still falling."
The company is looking primarily at office and retail projects "that have outstanding reputations and locations," Mr. Hines said.
Meantime, as construction declines nationwide, large renovations are increasing. Mr. Hines expects the number will continue to grow over the next few years as more buildings constructed during the building boom of the 70's and 80's begin to age. Changes in building codes and new technology also make buildings obsolete and help spur the renovation boom, Mr. Hines said.
RENOVATIONS also are easier to finance than new construction because lenders consider them safer investments. Moreover, renovation costs about half as much as new construction.
The cost of the Shell renovation in Houston, which involves a total of 1.7 million square feet of space in the two buildings, is about $56 per square foot. New construction in downtown Houston (not including land acquisition) now runs from $100 to $120 per square foot, according to Mr. Hines.
The renovation, which began in August and is scheduled for completion late 1994, includes asbestos removal, new elevators and air-handling systems, installation of sprinklers, fire alarms and fittings for handicapped people and upgrading all public spaces.
The New York office of the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill is handling the renovation. The firm's Chicago office designed the sleek travertine-sheathed towers, which were built in 1971 and 1972.
The Shell Oil Company renewed its lease for 25 years for 1.1 million square feet of space in the two buildings, both of which have been virtually 100 percent occupied since their opening, according to Ann McGonigle Kifer, Hines vice president in charge of corporate communications.
During the renovation, she said, tenants are being relocated temporarily to a floor cleared for that purpose. Ms. Kifer declined to discuss Shell's leasing terms. Prime downtown space goes for about $14 a square foot.
Hines Interests has retained ownership of 20 percent of the Shell Plaza buildings. Deutsche Bank of Frankfurt, controls the remaining 80 percent.
The Shell Plaza buildings were Mr. Hines's first major high-rise development. At the time of its completion, the 50-story 1 Shell Plaza was the tallest building in the South and the tallest reinforced concrete structure in the world.
Mr. Hines, who was born in Gary, Ind., moved to Houston in 1948 with an engineering degree from Purdue University to work for an air-conditioning company. After building small projects on the side for several years, he started his own construction business in 1957. He began building small industrial warehouse centers in Houston's outlying areas and later moved on to office, apartment and retail projects.
IN 1974, Mr. Hines received national attention with the construction of Pennzoil Place in downtown Houston. The bold design by Philip Johnson and John Burgee of a pair of 36-story trapezoidal towers with pointed tops won international design awards.
The ensuing publicity and financial success of Pennzoil Place led Mr. Hines to select not only Johnson and Burgee but also other leading architects, among them I. M. Pei, Cesar Pelli and Kevin Roche, to design his structures.
But while innovative design has been part of the Hines formula for success, it is the company's conservative financial policies that have enabled it to weather the current national real estate slowdown. Hines projects are all built with the backing of financial partners such as life insurance companies and foreign institutions like Deutsche Bank and Shell pension funds that retain large equity positions. And construction does not begin on a Hines project until major tenants are lined up.
Hines projects currently under construction include a 50-story, one million-square-foot office building in downtown Detroit; a 35-story, 750,000-square-foot office building in Louisville, Ky.; a 40-story, one million-square-foot office tower above the restored Grand Central Post Office in New York City; a historic renovation of a 950,000-square-foot office building on Capitol Hill in Washington and three five-story buildings that will be the headquarters for Bristol-Myers Squibb Pharmaceutical Group in Princeton, N.J.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Gerald D. Hines, the developer, has begun his first major Houston project since 1983: the $95 million renovation of his 50-story 1 Shell Plaza, left, and 29-story 2 Shell PLaza. (Hines Interests Limited Partnership)

HEADLINE: All About/Martial Arts;
The Black Belts of the Screen Are Filling the Dojos

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
IN the 80's it was "Karate Kid." Before that it was David Carradine's "Kung Fu." But today it is the Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles who are sending their fans to the local martial arts school.
This rough and tumble world of martial arts schools and studios -- dojos to the initiated -- is one of the most fragmented segments of the highly fragmented health and fitness industry. Exactly how large it is remains open to debate. 
 Nicholas Cokinos, chairman of the Educational Funding Company, a Bethesda, Md.-based management and billing company that handles the finances of 500 martial arts clubs in the United States and Canada, estimates that the martial arts industry produces annual revenues -- mostly from monthly fees for instruction -- of between $720 million and $900 million.
But Fred Villari, president of Fred Villari Studios in Dedham, Mass., the country's largest chain with 123 franchise studios, estimates that the market is much larger. "The market for equipment alone is $2 billion," Mr. Villari said. He said the industry earns about $2 billion a year from lessons, though there is no way to verify his calculations.
Estimates also vary when it comes to the number of schools. Mr. Villari says about 4,000. But Peak Performance, a market research newsletter for health and athletic clubs published in Bellevue, Wash., estimates that there are 7,000. That number, the newsletter says, represents growth of 11 percent in the last two years, while the overall health club market has remained flat. The 7,000 schools include Y.M.C.A.'s that offer martial arts classes.
 
Warring Styles
Few Rules Govern A Splintered Sport
 The martial arts label is broadly applied and includes more than a dozen different disciplines or "forms," including karate, judo, taekwondo and kung fu, all of which trace their origins to Asia. Anyone can rent a room in a strip shopping center or an urban store front and hang a martial arts studio shingle. There are no formal industry associations and few formal sanctioning bodies to monitor or govern the field.
Few schools teach pure forms, preferring instead to teach a mix of the traditional martial arts. As a result, there are no longer any hard and fast definitions of a fighting style; nor are there any restrictions on opening a school, putting on a tournament or awarding the various belts that signify an individual's accomplishments.
"Any promoter can have an event and call it a world championship," said Michael James, publisher of Black Belt, the largest martial arts magazine.
Practitioners of one form commonly deride the others. There is the soft style versus the hard, and hybrids with official sounding names like Jeet Kune Do, Wing Chun or Hapkido. Many were created by black belt instructors seeking their own fame and a piece of the action.
"How does a customer know what they are going to get when they look for a school?" said Mr. James. "That's a question we've been asking for 30 years."
 
Paying to Learn
Fees for Classes And for Each Belt
 Even small studios can turn a tidy sum. According to Mr. Cokinos, the schools generate an average of $15,000 in revenues monthly from student fees that range from $55 to $65. Children's fees are generally $40 to $45 per month. The schools often sell equipment; uniforms sell for about $18, while head, hand and foot gear can cost as much as $40.
Martial arts schools also charge testing fees of up to $25 each time a student tries to qualify for a higher belt. While students in Japan, Korea or Taiwan are usually classified as white or black belts (novice or expert), in the United States each belt comes with a testing fee, and, not surprisingly, there are a range of hues, from white to yellow to purple to black.
Mr. James estimates that there are two million to three million serious martial arts enthusiasts in the United States. Upsurges in interest often follow exposure in the media, most recently via the ubiquitous Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles. Martial arts performers like Bruce Lee, Chuck Norris, Jean-Claude Von Damme and Steven Seagal have ridden their skills to movie-star cult status, and operators of dojos have happily tagged along on their coattails.
But there is disagreement on whether martial arts studios are hurt in an economic downturn. Jhoon Rhee, who runs a chain of 12 studios in the Washington area and licenses his name and fighting style to 50 studios around the country, said the recession brought a 10 percent decline in revenues last year.
Mark Grupposo, a vice president at the Fred Villari chain, said troubles with unstructured management and lack of controls forced Villari to downsize over the last two years, either closing or selling more than 75 schools to bring its total to 123.
"There were some people mismanaging a few schools and they were fired," he said. "And we sold 50 studios to someone on the West Coast. We have tightened controls and we are slowly building up again." He said the company had revenues of $12 million last year, up 20 percent from the year before. The company is privately held and does not report financial performance.
 
The 'Karate Kids'
Ninja Turtles And Some Serenity
 Steven Schiff, a second-grader from Manalapan, N.J, spends three afternoons a week at Taekwondo Plus, a dojo down the street from his home. "I like the Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles and they do karate, so I decided to see what it was like," he said. "Plus, I wanted to learn to defend myself if I got into a fight."
According to Mr. Cokinos, Steven is prime material for martial arts schools: 40 percent of the students are between the ages of 7 and 14; another 25 percent are 14 to 25.
While such things as the Ninja Turtle craze have sparked adolescent interest, dojo operators and others in the industry credit growth in the last 15 years to a switch in emphasis away from violence and toward discipline and a serene outlook, appealing to parents as well as kids.
Steven, reflecting this trend, said he must show his taekwondo instructor a note from his teacher verifying his grades in order to receive stars on his white belt. And before each session, he and his karate class recite vows not to misuse their skills.
Martial arts schools also market themselves by sponsoring competitions, often with official-sounding names. The Villari chain, for example, sponsors four regional tournaments each year and a large international competition. It expects 6,000 to 7,000 spectators for the international competition in Boston in May, each paying $6 to $8 for a ticket. Competitors will pay $25 and between 1,500 and 3,000 are expected.
Mr. Grupposo said costs for the competition will be about $25,000, with profits to be parceled out to the Villari studios. "It's a great motivational event," he said.
 
 
TRADITION AND COMPETITIVE PRESSURE
 Without industrywide standards, the martial arts community has little control over the quality of teaching and the awarding of belts.
Some schools, for example, are trying to cut the time it takes to achieve the coveted black belt in order to retain students. "I'm trying to create the teaching skills to do a black belt in one year," said Jhoon Rhee, owner of 12 taekwondo schools in the Washington area.
Two martial arts forms, taekwondo and judo, have governing bodies because they are Olympic sports. There is no requirement that schools join, but students with an eye on major competitions must take the organizations into consideration.
Some experts consider a black belt, and advancing from a 1st- to 10th-degree black belt, a lifelong pursuit. "I've been doing martial arts for 44 years and just achieved seventh degree," said Fumio Demura, a karate legend in Los Angeles who taught Chuck Norris, the film star, and performed the karate sequences for the "Karate Kid" movies.
Mark Grupposo, vice president of Fred Villari Studios in Dedham, Mass., is a seventh-degree black belt. He said Mr. Villari (10th degree) and the school's top instructors test students themselves and award the belts.
"Our system dates from 520 A.D.," Mr. Grupposo said. "There is a time-honored system of movements and a time frame for progress. It takes three to five years to get a first-degree black belt."
Others in the industry complain that proliferation is eroding a black belt's significance. "A 10th-degree black belt is supposed to be something honorary, something mystical," said Michael James, publisher of Black Belt magazine. "There are supposed to be only three in the country, but there are hundreds."

LENGTH: 1548 words

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
Cabaret Economics 101: Sing, Record, Then Hope

BYLINE: By JAMES GAVIN; James Gavin is the author of "Intimate Nights: The Golden Age of New York Cabaret."

 BODY:
The economics of cabaret today are so treacherous that most artists have to do almost everything themselves, including making records. Despite the success of Linda Ronstadt's and Natalie Cole's albums of standards, most cabaret singers find it impossible to interest a major label in their work. Those who want to record must either do so privately or sign with small companies -- notably DFG, Audiophile and the new Cabaret -- that care about a form of music whose artistic value exceeds its profitability. The singers may never make a cent in royalties, but the prestige of having a commercially available recording is more important.
Among recently released cabaret albums are titles by the female trio Betty, Jackie Cain and Roy Kral, Dixie Carter, Andrea Marcovicci, Amanda McBroom and Weslia Whitfield, a San Francisco-based singer who has created a profilic recording career through sheer determination. 
 Over the last decade, Miss Whitfield won acclaim from her hometown press. But when she began to solicit commercial labels, she found that a devoted cult following meant little to companies seeking million-selling artists. With her husband and accompanist, the English jazz pianist Mike Greensill, Miss Whitfield founded Myoho Records. To issue a recording in all three formats, she learned, would cost about $7,000. They raised the money, chose the songs and instrumentation, booked as much studio time as they could afford, hired a printer and pressing plant, then tried to get distribution. Tower Records in San Francisco bought large quantities, but, as Miss Whitfield reports, "Outside of San Francisco we have to resign ourselves to getting stores to take two or three at a time. We go there ourselves and try to convince the punk-rock guys who run the stores that they can sell our recordings."
By peddling the albums in clubs and by mail, Miss Whitfield and Mr. Greensill earn enough money each year to cover costs and make another album. Now Miss Whitfield records for Landmark, a small subsidiary of Fantasy, from whom she buys her own albums at wholesale prices to sell to fans. This has helped spread her reputation beyond San Francisco, with a happy consequence: next season she makes her debut at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel in New York.
Miss Whitfield's albums capture much of the charm of her live performances, which substitute a touching simplicity for histrionics. The quality of her warm, burnished alto is matched by perhaps the most refreshing choice of standards and first-rate rarities since the jazz singer Chris Connor's recordings for Bethlehem and Atlantic in the 60's. Miss Whitfield's two Landmark albums, "Lucky to Be Me" (L-1524; CD and cassette) and "Live in San Francisco" (L-1531; CD and cassette), as well as three earlier titles, are available through Myoho Records (128 Bayview Circle, San Francisco, Calif. 94124).
Amanda McBroom took the same approach as Miss Whitfield, even though she began with wider renown. The singer and songwriter has performed in clubs ranging from the Roxy and Cinegrill in Los Angeles, her hometown, to the Russian Tea Room in Manhattan. She first won national attention in 1979 with her Grammy Award-winning title song for the film "The Rose," which was an immense hit for Bette Midler but failed to open doors for the songwriter as a major-label recording artist.
Six years ago, with her manager, Garry George, Miss McBroom formed Gecko Records. Her first solo album, "Dreaming," combined country, folk and pop influences with a theatrical flair inspired by her background in musical comedy. The album has sold 125,000 copies, earning back its high production cost of $70,000 three times over.
On her new album, "Midnight Matinee," Miss McBroom's richly passionate alto, at once sexy and maternal, is heard in several originals that surpass "The Rose" in emotional depth. Most of them are heartfelt pleas to hold out for romantic dreams. Both albums are available through Gecko Records (8370 Wilshire Boulevard, Suite 210, Beverly Hills, Calif. 90211).
One of the hippest new acts in cabaret has made a winning transition to record. Betty, a sassy trio from Washington D.C., is a musical counterpart of such female stand-up comics as Judy Tenuta, Joy Behar and Carol Siskind. The group's members -- Alyson Palmer and the twins Amy and Bitzi Ziff -- are tough, unsentimental urban women whose original songs take a hard look at sexual ambivalence, superficial bar chatter and other obstacles to romantic bliss.
A typical song, "First Date," mourns a failed effort to get beyond first base: "Well I guess I shaved my legs for nothing/ I never shoulda cleaned the tub or the sink/ You said goodbye to me downstairs/ You didn't even want that one last drink." Another, "Bicycle," teasingly depicts sexual options: "I just can't make up my mind which to ride/ Boys or girls/ Bicycles, that is." Their sardonic wordplay is framed by complex vocal arrangements. The group's debut album, "Hello, Betty" (issued on their own label, The Man From B.E.T.T.Y., Box 339, Cooper Station, New York, N.Y. 10276), contains 21 numbers, all with the group's own accompaniment on keyboards, electric bass and cello. Betty brings cabaret full circle to a time -- about 60 years past -- when its intention was to shatter convention and ruffle a few feathers. Their success offers proof that it is still possible to do just that.
Yet there is a great challenge in capturing an art that depends more on a performer's physical presence than on polished vocals. When cabaret artists are recorded live, some of that communicative spark can be preserved. While no album could fully catch the flamboyant Southern gusto of the singer and actress Dixie Carter in a nightclub setting, her recent "Dixie Carter Sings John Wallowitch -- Live at the Carlyle" (Vining/DRG LL9001; CD and cassette), has many incandescent moments.
A tribute to the esteemed cabaret performer who in 1963 was her first coach, the disk collects 15 examples of Mr. Wallowitch's verbal virtuosity and tongue-in-cheek sophistication. "This Moment," a ballad about the relentless passage of time, and "I See the World Through Your Eyes," a remembrance of Mr. Wallowitch's late brother Edward, become masterpieces of dramatic revelation in Miss Carter's hands.
Trying to adapt a nightclub act to the recording studio, however, can have disappointing results. The lack of an audience is keenly felt on four DRG collections by Julie Wilson devoted to the songs of Stephen Sondheim, Kurt Weill, Cole Porter and Harold Arlen. Miss Wilson feeds on the presence of her listeners, for whom her coarse, limited voice can express a lifetime of hard-earned experience. The cold impersonality of the studio inhibits her, bringing her vocal deficiencies into focus.
Miss Wilson can be heard to better advantage on "Cole Porter Revisited, Volume V," on Ben Bagley's Painted Smiles label (PS-122; CD only). The record is the latest in his series of collections of obscure gems by the great theater composers. Mr. Bagley's recent recordings also feature underrecorded cabaret artists like Sandy Stewart, Ann Hampton Callaway and Arthur Siegal. A complete catalogue is available from Painted Smiles Records, 74-09 37th Avenue, Suite 420, Jackson Heights, N.Y. 11372.
Even a live session cannot convey the appeal of Andrea Marcovicci, a regular at the Algonquin, the Gardenia in Los Angeles and other clubs. In person she exudes a contagious enthusiasm for her material, sprinkling it with breathless, witty patter on the foibles and stolen joys of 90's romance. Heard on record, however, her reedy neo-folk voice falls gratingly on the ear.
Miss Marcovicci has issued three recent albums -- "What Is Love?" (DRG 91401-2; CD and cassette), "Marcovicci Sings Movies -- Recorded Live at the Plush Room" (DRG 91405; CD and cassette) and "I'll Be Seeing You: Love Songs of World War II" (Cabaret CA 6001-2; CD only) -- in which her singsong phrasing, excruciatingly flat pitch and inadequate breath control destroy the charm of her choice repertoire. Miss Marcovicci's vocal failings are compounded by frequently rushed tempos and cluttered arrangements; several tracks on "What Is Love?" feature the infelicitous pairing of cello and saxophone.
By comparison, the new collection from the veteran vocal duo Jackie Cain and Roy Kral is a joy. Remarkably youthful and energetic after 44 years of performing, the couple straddles the line between jazz and cabaret so effectively that they are sometimes overlooked by both camps. Their style, which has changed little over the years, incorporates tight unison lines, occasional scat fills and a vocal blend that has lost none of its lustre.
"An Alec Wilder Collection" (Audiophile ACD-257; CD only), their 26th album, salutes an American artist. "While We're Young," "Moon and Sand," "The Lady Sings the Blues" and 12 other Wilder songs lovingly commemorate a songwriter who championed Miss Cain and Mr. Kral from the 50's until his death in 1980. Audiophile's catalogue is available from 1206 Decatur Street, New Orleans, La. 70116.
If cabaret is a synthesis of worldly experience and a childlike fascination with the whims of romance, then Jackie Cain and Roy Kral are among its most eloquent voices.

(Michael O'Brien)(pg. 29); Andrea Marcovicci -- In person, she exudes contagious enthusiasm, but on record, her voice falls gratingly on the ear. (Daniel Adams)(pg. 31)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1075 words

HEADLINE: The Years of Little Sunlight

BYLINE: By Larry Wolff; Larry Wolff, the author of "The Vatican and Poland in the Age of the Partitions," teaches European history at Boston College. He is writing a book about the origins of the idea of Eastern Europe.

 BODY:

UNQUIET DAYS
At Home in Poland.
By Thomas Swick.
286 pp. New York:
Ticknor & Fields. $19.95. 
 THOMAS SWICK lived in Poland from 1980 to 1982, through the Solidarity revolution and after its suppression, and in this memoir he writes as one who has opted "to adopt the Poles as other writers had the Greeks." His book is framed as a literary appreciation of "the special character of people who live under harsher climates and regimes."
At the harshest moment of all, the declaration of martial law in December 1981, Mr. Swick goes to visit a Polish friend and finds him unexpectedly heartened: "You see, this is really the end of the myth of socialism. They've lost. There is nothing they can do to redeem themselves after this." When Mr. Swick observes that the pet hamster is "getting big," his friend replies, "he'll be meat for the winter." With fine journalistic self-effacement Mr. Swick, now the travel editor of The Fort Lauderdale Sun Sentinel in Florida, sets himself up as straight man to such displays of character in the face of political and economic tragedy. Under martial law he continues with his job as a teacher in the English Language College in Warsaw, surprised at first to find his Polish students in such strong spirits. His Polish wife gets the last word: "What are we supposed to do? Sulk?" "Unquiet Days: At Home in Poland" offers an intriguing picture of the details of daily life against a background of national crisis: we learn, for instance, that in December 1981 Polish television was showing "The Flintstones" every day.
The book's opening essay on Warsaw starts under "sullen skies" with the standard imagery of Iron Curtain Eastern Europe: "The city possessed a shabbiness that seemed to me heightened by its overcast sky." In "damp, dimly lit stores" one finds "cheerless produce," and the pathetic fallacy constantly comes into play. There are some fine observations as Mr. Swick watches the city from the windows of buses and trams, noting that the shops have no proper names: "I read in close succession, SHOES, CLOTHES, VEGETABLES, BOOKS -- signs that gave a street the somewhat nostalgic flavor of a storybook town in a grammar school reader." He comes to appreciate the city better as he turns from the shops to the shoppers, discovering that Warsaw was "the only city I knew where the women were more fashionable than the mannequins." There is also a rather charming chain of impressionistic associations with the names of Warsaw in different languages -- Polish, French, Yiddish, German, Russian -- though ending infelicitously with the observation that in English "Warsaw" is the city that "saw war."
There is an excellent piece on Mr. Swick's experience teaching English to Polish students. Here one gets a feel for his direct engagement as an American in Poland, telling his students about American high school life, about cheerleaders, about being chosen "most likely to succeed." One of the students comments, "And you tell Polish jokes!" It is here at the English Language College that Mr. Swick modestly experiences the Solidarity revolution; the teachers post their union demands: for instance, to reduce lessons from 50 to 45 minutes, and to be able to use American magazines in class. Mr. Swick's private pupils, outside the college, include the wife of a Japanese businessman in Warsaw: "I asked Mrs. Matsuda if she had heard of Walesa's claim that Poland could become a second Japan. She said politely that she thought it impossible." Mr. Swick watches his students taking their examination, and wonders about "their horribly uncertain futures." He rides the trams, and reads in people's faces "trauma and despair for the fate of the nation."
In the book's fascinating climactic piece Mr. Swick joins the nation on a walking pilgrimage from Warsaw to the shrine of the Black Madonna at Czestochowa. Marching out of Warsaw, he watches those who are watching him: "As the recipient of such an unexpected public outpouring of emotion, I was carried into a sort of ecstasy the likes of which I had never known before." The journalist-in-ecstasy is a somewhat suspect figure, and Mr. Swick, as a non-Catholic non-Polish pilgrim, never quite confronts what it means to seek one's ecstasies on other people's pilgrimages. He is not alone, for there are also Dutch, Belgian and French pilgrims -- and Italians, "kissing all the Polish girls." One of the Belgians remarks about the Polish pilgrimage: "We have nothing to compare to this at home. It's quite extraordinary, really, all these people, engaged in something like out of Old Europe." Clearly, this foreign experience of the pilgrimage is mediated by Western Europe's mythology of Eastern Europe.
Mr. Swick himself is caught up in this mythology as he marches, announcing "our departure from contemporary Poland, and our entrance into the sheltered and immemorial." A Polish village appears as "a make-believe hamlet of thatch huts and birch groves," like a model out of "natural history museums." Even in Warsaw Mr. Swick found that women in furs made him think of "the wild -- which seemed intoxicatingly near -- and a time (here, at least, not yet passed) when man by necessity clothed himself with its skins."
Though "Unquiet Days" may presume too much in offering entrance to time immemorial, it stands on much surer ground in its testimony to contemporary history. Apparently, the pace of history has outrun the pace of publishing, and this memoir of the Polish revolution of 1980-81 appears after the revolution of 1989. In fact, that earlier upheaval was intellectually charted with amazing speed; one has only to think of the superb work of foreign journalism and contemporary history of Solidarity by Timothy Garten Ash and the brilliant diaries of Kazimierz Brandys, so rapidly published in Polish and in translation. We must now take care not to overlook 1980 and 1981 as we seek to understand the significance of 1989; Mr. Swick offers a timely reminder to look back. Mr. Brandys in 1981 appreciated the awkwardness of Western Europe and America in the face of Poland's crisis: "It is not we but they who have a besieged-fortress mentality, and it is they who are drawing down the Iron Curtain within themselves." Today, when there is no longer an Iron Curtain without, books that speak from direct experience of Eastern Europe, like "Unquiet Days," can help us to confront the Iron Curtain within.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: UNQUIET DAYS: AT HOME IN POLAND (BOOK)

HEADLINE: 50 YEARS OF CROSSWORDS;
An Addict's Tale

BYLINE: By Jesse Green; Jesse Green is the author, with Meg Wolitzer, of "Nutcrackers: Devilishly Addictive Mind-Twisting Puzzles for the Insatiably Verbivorous" (Grove Weidenfeld).

 BODY:
WHEN I WAS STILL young enough to rise before my parents on Sunday mornings, I would run barefoot even in winter to the bottom of the driveway and lug in the loglike Times, which in those days came wrapped by the local distributor in colorful plastic bags left over from Wonder bread. Back in the house, I would peel away its outer sections -- the dread, perplexing news, the regimental financial tables -- to unfold the Magazine, so cold and flattened there in the middle that it hardly opened: the innermost bud. At once, I turned within it to the crossword, which was as yet promising and unfulfilled, like the day. For a boy from the suburbs of Philadelphia, the puzzle suggested the warrenlike mystery of New York City itself: a huge apartment block of tiny, numbered rooms, each with a uniquely apt, but missing, occupant.
I studied the puzzle carefully then, because it would be my last chance to see it unadulterated; indeed the adults were soon staggering in, coffee cup in one hand, pen in the other, ready to begin the ritual slaughter. For my father's method owed something to that of the weekend hunter: shoot at whatever moves first. He began the puzzle by answering as many Acrosses as possible, without reference to the Downs. Later, if the Downs contradicted his entries, he merely overwrote them. Occasionally he would call for help from my mother, whose answers, presumed accurate, were squeezed in faithfully, regardless of length. Within an hour the grid would be left an inky mess, half gibberish, half sense. "Finished!" my father would crow -- and indeed every last apartment was occupied: many, it seemed, by squatters. 
 I would survey the damage -- Diarist Anais? Why, Pin, of course -- and mourn for the mangled words strewn about. But on the other hand there was something deeply satisfying in the knowledge that errors as much as truths could be made to fit in the pattern. Everything has its place in a puzzle, and the place is communal. Solving means weaving the ups through the downs, the animals through the minerals, the obscure actresses through the dictators and czars until the whole world's trivia have been turned into a tapestry.
I wanted in. A family of economists in the neighborhood had bought a copier solely to solve the Sunday puzzle problem; the best we could do in my house was persuade my father to work his magic in pencil. That way, at least, I could come along later, busy myself cleaning the untidy room of his first attempts -- change "Pin" to "Nin" as necessary. But I could never make the whole thing right, and in that failure I discovered the true thrill inherent in the enterprise.
The thrill was pain. A crossword was not, like the rest of the paper, a monologue; it was a colloquy, albeit a sadomasochistic one. To solve the clues you bent your mind to the improbable patterns prescribed by the author. It hurt your head and was quite moving: Why, filling in crosswords, you actually got to write in the paper! There was something subversive about that act, and something democratic. A witty puzzle made it possible for anyone -- even a 10-year-old -- to contribute a witty weekly column to the hallowed New York Times.
For a while I was content with my father's leftovers, but becoming an adult means solving puzzles alone. If a crossword is a kind of weaving, eventually one must have a loom of one's own. What had delighted me as a child -- the symmetry, the rigidity, the honeycomb aura of industry -- was now less important than the task of filling in. In my own tiny, numbered New York apartment, I squinted and scrawled away Saturday night; what wasn't finished by midnight was looked up in the dictionary or thesaurus Sunday morning. I was calmed in some way by the weekly reassurance the completed grid provided: that mysteries were solvable, that the mind could grow itself toward answers through indirection and reward itself with joy.
But a sword lurks among the letters of "crossword," and a two-edged sword it is at that. To finish a puzzle, I observed, was to kill it. To solve is to dissolve, to make the enigma fade, and while the solution is satisfying, the enigma has its charms. And so, after a while, I put away the dictionary and thesaurus. Sometimes I only answered the Acrosses -- the Downs be damned! If some weeks I didn't manage to finish at all, well, that was fine, too; what was left unsolved would never be known -- which was just like life.
The Sunday Times puzzle has been my necessary fix for two decades now, but like the proverbial reefer that leads to a life of depravity, it prompted me to investigate darker vices. Or perhaps they came to investigate me. Lunching one day across the street from a movie theater, I watched in amazement as the word "cinema" transformed itself into "anemic" on the marquee. How cruel it seemed -- it must have been a marquee de Sade. Later, like a prodigal son, "iceman" would cometh to join the anagrammatic clan. It was useless to resist these visitations. Over the years, I had woven myself with the czars and emus into the web of words, and was now a prisoner within it.
I have not been in solitary confinement, at least. On New York subways, newspapers are opened as often as not to the crossword page. In England, cryptics have cultish followings. When a friend and I began writing American versions of the British puzzles for 7 Days, we found out what other puzzle makers already knew: that people are eager to be stymied, waiting to be bent. They crave so desperately the taste of another human mind that they are willing to be put through torture to get it. Though the taste is often salt, they come back.
I, TOO, COME BACK TO THE TIMES puzzle every weekend. Though I have long since been drawn into a life of advanced wordcrime, the original perpetrator retains its iconic glamour. No, it does not arrive like magic at the bottom of a driveway -- I pick it up from the corner newsstand now. But I still lug it home wrapped in a kind of transparent wonder, for it is as familiar to me as its answers are exotic. Everything is possible before you make your mark upon it, and even after. Come inside my New York apartment, it says: come visit a parallel Sunday universe of Aleuts and emus, yaks and Slavs, an odeon in which actress Merkel is starring forever in Capek's "R.U.R."; a fete where the drink is always ade, where the band's an octet and the tune's a rumba, where singer Edith is singing "You are ----" and Pin can dance with Nin all night long.

HEADLINE: Time to Reorganize Bloated Academia

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The budgetary problems of colleges and universities are, unfortunately, a consequence of a long overexpansion and reallocation of resources to "higher education," which began with the assumption that a college degree was the capstone of a complete education, to be made achievable for everybody. 
 This new vision had two immediate consequences: it devalued the high-school diploma, discarding the notion that blue-collar work was honorable and productive, and redirected students to seek professional academic careers regardless of ability.
In providing this new vision of educational achievement, resources were showered on expanding colleges and universities, inevitably leading to waste and bureaucratic bloat, while on the other hand less costly educational alternatives were rejected.
However, it is an economic truism that not everybody can have everything. Recent rises in tuition and costs are merely a reassertion of this old adage, which was long masked by the need for graduates in the economy's overexpanded service sectors. The relative success of community colleges shows how we can solve the problems of general public education and preserve the quality of our higher institutions of learning. The downsizing of colleges and universities should be accomplished by an immediate substantial raising of educational standards at all levels instead of financial restraints, and simultaneous introduction or expansion of alternative educational paths (apprenticeships, trade school), which will provide for the technical work force we so desperately need.
If we do this, we will restore on the one hand the value of a high school diploma and on the other we will curb the expansion of unneeded service careers. The process will undoubtedly be painful and extended, as any reallocation of resources always is, but as recent remarks from overseas make quite clear, it is absolutely necessary.
 
RICHARD HYSE
St. Petersburg, Fla., Feb. 3, 1992
 
The writer is professor emeritus of economics at SUNY, Oswego.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Democrats Join in Assailing Bush In Final New Hampshire Debate

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 16

 BODY:
The five main Democratic Presidential candidates met tonight in a bland and largely anticlimactic debate that focused on their common opposition to President Bush, rather than the differences among their own prescriptions for the national economy.
Although it took place less than 48 hours before the New Hampshire primary, the first in the nation, and had thus been considered a potentially pivotal event, the encounter produced little fresh enlightenment for the voters of this state, tens of thousands of whom say they remain uncommitted. 
 Only on nuclear energy were there any real fireworks. His rivals ganged up on former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, the current leader in the New Hampshire polls, attacking his insistence that some use of nuclear power was unavoidable. Once they patronized him. Tonight, for just a moment, they shook his habitual calm.
 
A Sensitive Issue
 "Don't come at me," he warned them, insisting that he had been a committed environmentalist since the 1970's and remained steadfast. Mr. Tsongas had lost his temper about the same issue 10 days ago at Dartmouth College. The protracted controversy over the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire, which started operation in March 1990, has made it an issue of great sensitivity in the state.
All of the Democratic hopefuls laid into Mr. Bush, and Mr. Tsongas in particular kept saying the choice was not among Democrats but between the President and whomever the Democrats chose -- a classic leader's tactic, designed to preserve as much unity as possible for the fall campaign. Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska summed up the consensus with the comment, "No political figure in America is more indifferent to jobs than George Bush."
For much of the rest of the 90-minute debate, staged at St. Anselm's College just south of here and carried by the Cable News Network, the Democrats were content to recycle their campaign speeches and punch lines.
Politicians here and in Washington had expected Mr. Tsongas to be taken to task on substantive issues and Mr. Clinton to be attacked on questions of character. It didn't happen. Unchallenged, the Arkansas Governor chose not to comment, or was prevented by the format from commenting, on the accusations that turned his once free-flowing campaign into a nightmare.
Mr. Kerrey may have sensed that the event was providing less-than-gripping television viewing. When Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa mentioned Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, whose name is not on the ballot here, the Nebraskan commented with a smile: "Did you have to mention Governor Cuomo's name? Now more people will write him in." Two Chicagoans have started an unauthorized write-in campaign on Mr. Cuomo's behalf.
In the debate, the fourth of the young campaign, it was clear that the Democrats consider the President vulnerable on many issues.
 
Call for 'a Clean Break'
 Mr. Kerrey, who seemed more focused than he had in earlier broadcasts, said early that "our President has his head outside of the cold war, but his entire body is still in it." Mr. Tsongas said Mr. Bush lacked "a core of principle." Mr. Harkin called for "a clean break with Reagan and Bush trickle-down economics."
And Mr. Clinton declared, "We've got a President who doesn't believe we need a national economic plan."
Earlier in the day, the Democratic candidates had wrangled off-screen about taxes, abortion and questions of honesty and character.
Mr. Tsongas took on the Democratic leadership in Congress. Senator Harkin took shots at two of his rivals, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kerrey, over their positions on abortion as well as on other issues. Mr. Clinton hit back at his critics, and Mr. Kerrey appeared to be trying to keep alive accusations of draft evasion leveled at Mr. Clinton.
Polls tracing the changes in voter sentiment day by day showed Mr. Tsongas holding a solid lead over Mr. Clinton, Mr. Kerrey in third place by a narrow margin over Mr. Harkin, and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California running well behind.
There were signs of stress in the campaigns of both Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Harkin as both sought to stave off possible elimination from the race.
After Mr. Kerrey's longtime poll- taker and strategist, Harrison Hickman, acknowledged anonymously sending a memorandum critical of Mr. Clinton's draft record to journalists, Mr. Kerrey disavowed him and said he was not, at least for the time being, working for the campaign. Mr. Kerrey added, "He betrayed me."
The Harkin campaign approved and paid for a hard-hitting flier, circulated by a women's group, implying that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kerrey were less than firm in their support of abortion rights. Among other things, the handbill asserts that Mr. Kerrey ran for Governor in Nebraska in 1982 as an opponent of abortion and that Mr. Clinton signed a bill in 1989 that requires young women seeking abortion to get parental consent first.
 
No 'Hollywood Women'
 In allusions to the accusations in a supermarket tabloid that Mr. Clinton conducted a 12-year extramarital affair, to Mr. Kerrey's relationship with Debra Winger and to Mr. Brown's romance with Linda Ronstadt, Mr. Harkin said in a speech to a labor group: "You won't be reading about me in the tabloids. I sure as heck won't be dating any Hollywood women."
Challenged about his tactics on the ABC news program "This Week," Mr. Harkin said, "I have a great deal of respect for Governor Clinton," but asserted that Mr. Clinton's conduct "raises questions in everyone's mind."
So much dirt had been thrown at him, Mr. Clinton replied, that he was "virtually a one-man landfill." He sought to turn the attacks made upon him into an advantage.
"One of the tests of a President is whether or not that man or woman can live with the pressure, take the heat and go on," he said. "I've learned some things about myself, I think, in the last couple of weeks, and I think the American people and certainly the people of New Hampshire know much more about me than anyone else."
 
Clinton as Outsider
 Mr. Clinton also sought to portray himself as the outsider, although he led the race here for weeks and won the endorsement of Democratic officeholders across the country. He suggested that Mr. Tsongas had always been the favorite here because he came from a neighboring state.
Mr. Clinton also railed against Washington. "You know, a lot of people in Washington may have given up hope on my campaign," he said, "but Washington has given up on the deficit. Washington has given up on the economy. Washington has given up on everything that's mattered for 10 years."
Mr. Tsongas rejected the middle-income tax cut that has been proposed by Democratic leaders in Congress, arguing that they would drop the idea if his campaign succeeds. Appearing on the NBC news program "Meet the Press," he said tax help for the middle class was needed but argued that his first job was stimulating the economy to create jobs, because if a working person was unemployed, "giving that person a tax cut is irrelevant."
"I'm not Santa Claus," Mr. Tsongas said, repeating a familiar campaign line. "If you want Santa Claus, you've got a lot of choices, Democrats and Republicans."
Mr. Bush's campaign manager, Robert M. Teeter, who was also interviewed on the ABC program, paid Mr. Tsongas a backhanded compliment with the remark that people were for him because he sounded like a Republican.
Alone among the major contenders, Mr. Kerrey avoided the television studios, campaigning instead at a suburban shopping mall and speaking at a rally in Manchester.
With him for the second time in eight days was Max Cleland, the former head of the Veterans' Administration, who lost both legs and an arm in Vietnam. Mr. Kerrey insisted that he was not trying to call attention to accusations that Mr. Clinton tried to avoid military service in Southeast Asia.
