HEADLINE: Canadians Defend Care System Against Criticism.

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 16

 BODY:
In announcing his plan for tax credits to try to make quality medical care available for all Americans, President Bush hit one of Canada's sacred cows. He labeled Canada's universal health insurance program "a cure worse than the disease."
Admittedly feeling national pride in their 26-year-old Medicare system, many Canadians insist that in rejecting it as a model for the United States, the President also misrepresented it. 
 "I was shocked by his comments," said Carol Clemenhagen, president of the 1,200-member Canadian Hospital Association. "He denotes an interest in looking only at the pitfalls of the Canadian system, which are far fewer than the pitfalls of the American system, while ignoring our success in providing free access to health care to the population at large."
Public opinion surveys consistently show that support for the taxpayer-financed system here is very high. "Our polls indicate it is the single most supported of all social programs," said Michael Sullivan, senior vice president of Decima Research Inc. of Toronto.
Some analysts say the basic difference between the two countries' approaches is that in Canada health care is considered a social right, while in the United States it is treated more like a commodity.
Under Canadian Medicare, every citizen gets an insurance card and number entitling the person to free medical and hospital care. The citizen has to pay a fee, which works out to $400 to $500 a year. Usually, employers make the contribution for their employees. The Government picks up the tab for those on welfare.
Doctors are reimbursed by the Government based on a standard fee schedule for services, and Canadians choose their doctors. Prescription drugs are not free, although many companies have special plans that lower costs of drugs for their employees.
 
What About the Costss?
 Although Mr. Bush assailed the high cost of nationalized health care, Canadian doctors and health officials pointed to studies that have shown much lower administrative costs here than in the United States.
Canada's health-care system is the second-most expensive in the world, but spending in the United States is still considerably higher. The costs in 1990 worked out to $1,991 for every Canadian in American dollars, against $2,566 for every American.
Behind the difference, said Dennis Timbrell, president of the Ontario Hospital Association, "is the overwhelming duplication of bureaucracies working in dozens of insurance companies in the United States, no two of which have the same forms or even the same coverage." In Canada there is a single payer, the Government.
"Whether the U.S. chooses to emulate some aspects of the Canadian system or not, to falsely describe the program to the American public will ultimately reflect badly on President Bush," said Dr. Michael Gordon, vice president of medical services for the Baycrest Center for Geriatric Care in Toronto.
 
Waiting for Surgery
 The President also spoke of long delays needed to get treatment in Canada, saying, for instance, that British Columbians wait six months for coronary-bypass surgery. But since 1990, when that estimate was compiled, the wait has fallen by more than half, to 14 weeks, according to the Fraser Institute, a Vancouver-based public policy research institute.
There have been reductions in other centers as well, helped by such developments as a new central registry for cardiovascular surgical candidates in Ontario.
While there are waiting lists for elective surgery, doctors here caution against exaggerating the impact. They say there are no delays for those who are seriously ill, or injured.
"It's worth pointing out that the vast majority, 98 percent, of all Canadians have access to a health-care system without impediment created by financial circumstances," said Dr. Hugh Scully, a professor of surgery at the University of Toronto and chairman of the council on health policy and economics of the Canadian Medical Association.
 
'That Doesn't Happen Here'
 Mr. Timbrell of the Ontario hospital association recalled that when he was Minister of Health in the Ontario Government about 10 years ago "the statistics that to me showed the starkest comparison of the two systems related to personal bankruptcies."
"Fifty percent of personal bankruptcies in the States were due to medical costs," he said. "That doesn't happen here. No one in Canada need mortgage his future because of a need for hospital services."
Medical practitioners here took umbrage at the implication from the President's speech that since some Canadians go to the United States for surgery the Canadian health system is flawed.
 
Going Through a Crisis
 "Seattle has more CT scanners than all of Canada," said Dr. Scully of the Canadian association. "That's nice for Seattle. Canada could have more than it has. But it's quite inaccurate to judge from something like that that the quality of Canadian medicine is inferior."
Measured by infant mortality, projected life span or other objective evaluations of the health status of the population, officials point out that Canadians are at least as healthy as Americans. Yet even the most ardent defenders of the Canadian system agree that with shrinking government revenues combined with exploding medical expenses, Canadian Medicare, which costs $60 billion a year and whose cost is rising faster than practically any other government program, is going through its own crisis.
Although no one talks of scrapping the system, the fiscal crunch has led a growing number of provincial and federal politicians to question one of the basic principles of Canadian medicare -- that it be free. The Government of Quebec has already proposed a $5 user fee for medical services. The ruling Progressive Conservative Party at its convention last summer in Toronto also called for user fees.
Conceding that he was trampling on "sacred burial grounds," New Brunswick's Prime Minister, Frank McKenna, from the oppositon Liberal Party, recently suggested a "major restructuring," in which wealthier Canadians would be required to pay some of their own health-care costs to insure that care continue for the poorest.
But user fees are strongly opposed by many federal politicians and health-care experts, who argue that they would polarize rich and poor and eventually hurt the poorest.

HEADLINE: An Indoor Plague in Albany

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 15

 BODY:
It might have been a swarm of infinitesimal bugs, or it might have been tiny shards of plastic -- no one knows for sure -- but whatever caused the mysterious skin rashes in State Building Eight two years ago was only the beginning.
Since October, one small disaster after another has befallen the aging Department of Taxation and Finance building in the middle of the state office campus here: an overheated elevator that choked the building with smoke; rotted refrigerator coils that released sulfur dioxide into the air; a leaking steam pipe that sent a deadly anti-corrosive substance surging through the building via an ancient ventilation system.
 
Odors Galore
 With each problem, more people got sick, and the rest of the workers began to feel a bit as if this was ancient Egypt and they were the withstanding the series of Biblical plagues. On Feb. 7, as investigators were trying to finish up a report on the building's earlier troubles, dozens more employees inexplicably fell ill with new symptoms, growing dizzy, retching and passing out as their horrified colleagues gathered in the cold to watch them carried away to the hospital on stretchers. 
 The most recent spate of illnesses was different from previous ones, in which employees reported feeling everything from disoriented, forgetful and semi-paralyzed to detecting a variety of out-of-place odors -- sweet smells, gas smells, metallic smells, rotting smells, fishy smells. And while the state had an answer for most of what happened before, it is stymied now. "We did air testing on Saturday, Sunday and Monday and nothing seemed not to be normal," said Tom Tubbs, a spokesman for the Office of General Services, which manages the building.
As the state frantically tries to figure out what is going on, some officials are suggesting that the current problems are more mental than physical. The employees unions, on the other hand, are denouncing Building Eight as a classic "sick building" and calling for its total closure. Meanwhile, the workers in Building Eight -- even ones who haven't come down with anything in particular -- are trying desperately to process the state's income-tax returns while staving off the feeling that they are somehow going crazy.
Only a small percentage of the people who work in the building have fallen ill, said Karl E. Felsen, a Tax Department spokesman, but the rest are pretty jumpy. "There's a range of people from those who think we're a bunch of malingerers to those who think Oliver Stone will be filming here next week," he said.
On the eighth floor, a clerk tried to explain what it is like to come to work and see the man next to you faint dead away. "Some days you feel fairly decent. But there are days when you get headaches and a flushed, hot feeling -- you get confused," she added, looking fearfully around, as if toxic chemicals were going to come spewing invisibly out of the walls at any moment. "You smell things that you have not really smelled before. It's hard to pinpoint exactly what it smells like or even to describe it."
 
A Bureaucrat's Labyrinth
 In some ways, Building Eight's problems are an extreme example of what can happen to a state infrastructure that is aging rapidly at a time when there is no money for real repairs. Several years ago, recognizing that many of the buildings in the state office complex needed work, the state decided to build a million-square-foot structure that would house the workers in each agency by turn while their buildings were renovated.
But the plan was scrapped because of money problems, and no one, it seemed, has suffered more than the 2,600 Tax Department workers in Building Eight. Built in 1964, when offices were big, open spaces, the building has adjusted to the realities of modern work needs with more and more partitioned cubicles, making it resemble a maze for laboratory rats.
It never underwent a major renovation, and many now regard that as a mistake. "There's no doubt that when a building gets to be 25, 27 years old, it has to be brought up to date," Mr. Tubbs said.
But the state is finding itself balancing the concerns of the workers with the needs of its treasury -- this is the department that, after all, does the work to bring in $35 billion in tax revenue a year -- and with the realities of the budget. So instead of closing the building down, it has opted to test and fix as best it can.
 
Time for a Cleaning
 This fall, a team of cleaners came in to scrub the building, and a new problem was discovered. The ventilation system, built during the Rockefeller Administration, was so clogged with filth and pieces of paper that some parts of the building never got any new air at all. That explained some of the respiratory ailments. And it also turned out that workers were using a pesticide that was making more people sick.
Mr. Tubbs said that the Office of General Services had already spent almost $2 million renovating, cleaning and testing the building. A multi-agency task force has been evaluating the situation and a consultant is to put out a report in several weeks.
No one wants to come out and accuse the most recently ill workers of making it all up. "There are people who are genuinely sick there," Mr. Tubbs said. "But if you're in the vicinity of a person who becomes ill, you may suffer sympathetic illness. I never knew anyone who liked to watch anyone else vomit."
Workers admit that the mood is so tense that any hint of an odd smell or feeling of malaise can throw them into a panic. Barbara Zgrzepski, a tax compliance representative who was taken to Builing Nine after she lost her voice and passed out in October, said that recently she smelled fish in the office -- a smell that accompanied her earlier problems. "I totally lost it," she said. But it turned out that somebody was having tuna for lunch.
Dr. James Melius, director of the Division of Occupational Health and Environmental Epidemiology at the State Health Department, said that the earlier problems -- eye irritations, respiratory ailments and dizziness -- were indeed caused by the building. But he said those problems had been fixed and that it was unclear what else was wrong.
"There's no evidence that anyone had an illness related to the building," he said of the recent outbreak. "Our sense is that anxiety probably played some role in what occurred there. For the symptoms were very real and they need to be addressed."
But all the tests, renovations and explanations will not be enough for workers like James McGinnis, a 29-year-old program analysis manager who began to feel dizzy, numb and disoriented last fall. He would forget what he was talking about; he would forget what projects he was working on. He got snappish and frustrated.
Mr. McGinnis said that he didn't want to cause trouble, especially with the economy so bad and everyone's job at risk, but his whole department felt just as weird as he did. Every day, it seemed, investigators would come in and unearth something more that they claimed was causing the trouble: a rotting orange peel in the garbage; a computer emitting a bad smell; an artificial Christmas wreath; some old coats.
"I was at the point where I literally would have quit my job if I could've found another job," said Mr. McGinnis, who now works in Building Nine.
Meanwhile, life goes on in Building Eight. Last Monday, 19 people were carried to hospitals on stretchers, and 70 more reported to the nurse's station. On Thursday the task force evaluating the problem removed five copying machines and six microfiche machines from the building. Workers started to joke that the fire department rescue squad should open an office in Building Eight because they were called in so often anyway.
And on the eighth floor, employees wondered when it would end. "Some people think I'm hallucinating," said one woman, a secretary who admits to amorphous feelings of disorientation, fatigue and anxiety. "You feel humiliated and very foolish, but you just don't want to come to work in the morning."

GRAPHIC: Photo: One small disaster after another has befallen State Building Eight in Albany. Some employees recently became ill while working in the building. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Benefits of Bank Mergers Are Disputed in 2 Studies

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Although bankers and investors expect great savings from recently announced bank mergers, two new studies confirm earlier findings that bank combinations do not tend to lower costs or raise profits.
Economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta concluded in a study published last week that "we have not found any evidence that mergers significantly lower expenses." 
 The economists found in their study of all mergers from 1982 through 1986 of banks with assets of $100 million or more that the acquiring banks were more efficient than banks in general before the mergers. They also concluded, however, that in the years after the mergers, costs rose more rapidly for the combined banks than for the rest of the industry.
 
'Dose of Skepticism'
 Professors at the Harvard Business School studied mergers among New England banks from 1982 through 1987 and concluded that merged banks had reduced costs compared with other banks but the lower costs "were more than offset by the loss of business and revenue to competitors."
Both the Atlanta and Harvard studies noted that Federal banking regulators have encouraged bank mergers. While the studies did not support the possible benefits of mergers, each included caveats in which the authors stopped short of predicting that recently proposed mergers would not benefit the banks involved.
The Atlanta Fed study noted that it did not include mergers comparable in size to the recently approved combination of the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, both of New York, or the proposed merger of the BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco and the Security Pacific Corporation of Los Angeles.
The study warned that although the mergers the Atlanta Fed reviewed might have been intended to reduce costs, the findings "should add a healthy dose of skepticism" to the claims about savings.
Banks generally contend they will be stronger after a merger because they can cut about 30 percent of the noninterest costs of the acquired or merged bank, while losing only a small amount of business. Such claims are important to the stockholders of banking companies involved in mergers because the acquiring banks often issue stock to finance the deal.
For Chemical Banking, the promise of $750 million of savings after its merger with Manufacturers helped it sell more than $1.5 billion of new stock in January, just a few weeks after the merger.
 
'Not a Settled Issue'
 To sort through the conflicting claims of economists and bankers, the Fed has started a long-term study of many large mergers that have been approved or proposed.
"There is not yet a lot of evidence to support the idea that there is much to be gained by mergers," said Edward Ettin, deputy director of research and statistics at the Federal Reserve Board. "But it is not a settled issue. It may be that the earlier mergers were in an environment where bankers were not emphasizing cost control as they do now."
Dwight B. Crane, co-author of the Harvard study, noted that "the quality of management makes a huge difference" in the outcome of a merger. He said that while "expense savings are very hard to achieve," some banks proved they were possible.
Mr. Crane said the industry's low profits were a clear sign that there were too many banks. He said there was not much evidence of banks overcharging for their services, "and the economy will clearly be better off if we have fewer financial instititons that are strong and profitable than if we have more institutions with weak profits."
The new emphasis on cost cutting by banks is not limited to banks involved in mergers. Citicorp, for example, is not involved in a merger but is about halfway through a two-year program to cut costs by $1.7 billion by the end of this year.
 
The Management Factor
 Mr. Ettin noted that one problem with many studies of past mergers is that they fail to recognize the differences in management.
A study in 1990 by David Humphrey, then an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond and now a professor at Florida State University in Tallahassee, found that the differences between well-managed and poorly managed banks of similar size were about four times as large as the average difference between banks of different size. That suggests that the acquisition of a poorly managed bank by a well-managed bank could produce benefits, while a merger of two poorly managed banks might not produce any, despite the increase in size.
Lowell Bryan, a partner at McKinsey & Company, a management consulting firm, said he remained convinced that there were potentially great benefits from bank mergers "when they are done well." He warned, however, that the benefits of spreading fixed costs over a larger base and the elimination of duplicated branches could easily be overshadowed by poor management.
Poor management can also undermine the benefits of mergers by allowing revenues to fall, Mr. Bryan said. "The biggest danger to revenues comes in mergers of two banks that regard themselves as equals, or cases where the dominant bank is not well run."

HEADLINE: Without the Money to Supply Prison Beds, Officials Consider Reducing Demand

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBION, N.Y.

 BODY:
The Orleans Correctional Facility was built here in the vast fields of western New York just seven years ago, part of the state's grand scheme to deal with the seemingly endless supply of inmates that the war on drugs sent pouring into its prison system.
But now Orleans and many other medium-security prisons around New York are themselves filled beyond capacity. And the state is struggling to confront a serious overcrowding problem that, if left unmanaged, will leave it with 6,000 more prisoners than beds by the end of the next fiscal year, March 31, 1993. 
 At Orleans, this has meant that 1,312 drug dealers, murderers and robbers are living, in dormitory-style double bunks, in a place designed for 742. The effects are clear. "It takes very little to get something started," said Robert Kotarski, a corrections officer. "Things can mushroom very fast."
No one wants overcrowding. It riles inmates, strains prison guards, encourages the spread of illness and generally makes prisons more volatile places. In the past, when there was money to spend, the solution to overcrowding would have been clear: create more space.
Not any more. With money scarce and a sense that more prison beds have not resulted in less crime, many lawmakers are being forced to conclude that they can no longer build their way out of the problem. Instead, they are taking a new approach: finding ways to reduce the prison population.
 
Money Shapes Philosophy
 "Economics has driven many of the nation's governors and corrections commissioners into a position where they have to tell people, 'We can't afford this any more,' " said James A. Gondles, executive director of the American Correctional Association, which represents prison administrators.
New York, along with California and Florida, was a leader in the unprecedented prison-building spree of the 1980's, in which hundreds of prisons were erected across the country. Between 1983 and 1992, the state built 29 prisons, for $2.1 billion in construction and debt service costs, increasing the total number of prisons to 68 and doubling the number of inmates housed to 57,862, from 29,253.
Some Albany legislators are still hoping the state will build the eight new prisons it planned a year and a half or so ago. But there is no more money to run those prisons.
"I think the fiscal realities have become painfully clear to everyone now," said Richard H. Girgenti, commissioner of the state Division of Criminal Justice Services.
In his budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposes to address the overcrowding problem not by increasing the supply of beds, but by reducing the demand for them. His proposals are fueled by budgetary necessities, but they nonetheless represent a philosophical break with the past, when tough sentencing laws were enacted to lock up as many offenders as possible.
By his own account, Governor Cuomo hardly wants to be remembered as the person who filled the state with prisons. "I am going to go down as having built more prisons than any governor in New York State history, and it disgusts me that they're going to put that on my tombstone," he said at a November forum.
Passed in the 1970's, the sentencing laws required, among other things, prison terms for people convicted of violent felonies, and prison terms for people convicted of any second felony. That means that a person convicted on two occasions for selling small amounts of crack, for example, would have to go to state prison.
 
Community Treatment
 The laws still apply. But in the meantime, drug convictions have filled the state prisons with drug addicts and low-level dealers, a far different population, corrections officials maintain, than was envisioned 15 years ago. It is these prisoners, argues Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, commissioner of the state Department of Correctional Services, who should be removed from the state prison system and instead treated in community-based drug programs.
"The question is this: can you treat a drug addict better and more efficiently in the community, or can you treat him better and more efficiently in prison?" Mr. Coughlin said.
The answer has been fiercely debated in Albany for the last several years. Democrats in the Assembly tend to agree with Mr. Coughlin that the laws should be changed.
But many Senate Republicans argue that it is naive to assume that people arrested for drug offenses are any less dangerous, or crime-prone, than violent felons.
"Drugs are the most serious problem that we have," said Senator L. Paul Kehoe, a Republican of Wolcott who is chairman of the Senate Crime and Correction Committee. "The bottom line is that by the time you get arrested for drugs, you have actually committed dozens, if not hundreds, of other felonies."
The Governor proposes a series of amendments to the second-felony offender law, including giving judges the option of sending second-time felons to drug-treatment programs rather than to prison and allowing some second-felony prisoners to be eligible for parole after a third of their sentence, rather than half.
 
'Needless Incarceration'
 The Governor also proposes to spend millions of dollars more on alternatives to state prison, including community corrections and expanded drug treatment programs. "We're not just dropping them onto the streets," Mr. Girgenti said.
The idea strikes a chord with people like Robert Gangi, executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, a nonprofit group that studies prison issues. He said that the second-felony laws, which he would like to see repealed entirely, fill the prisons with the wrong people. "These laws cause the needless incarceration of people who could be handled more cheaply and effectively through other means," he said.
The issue this legislative session will be whether the Governor and the Democrats can get the Republicans to agree. Last year, the Republican-dominated Senate rejected a similar package of proposals.
Senator Kehoe said that he might support offering earlier parole to some inmates, but, "My vote is 'no way' in terms of doing away with the second-felony offender law." He added, "I don't think that lenient sentencing is the way to go in terms of reducing the prison population."
Senator Dale M. Volker, a Republican from Depew in western New York who is chairman of the Senate Codes Committee, said the question was one of law and order.
"We're willing to do some rational things, but I'm not sure if they understand the repercussions of their proposals," he said. "We just have to be careful that we don't allow dangerous criminals to walk into the community on a regular basis."
Part of the reason for the Republicans' reluctance concerns a philosophical difference of opinion over who the second-felony offenders are, and part concerns questions about the effectiveness of community drug treatments and other alternatives to incarceration. And part of it seems to come from regional attitudes about the advisability of building prisons.
 
Prisons Bring Jobs
 New prisons, which cost $65 million to build and $15 million a year to run, are desirable things in some communities, particularly rural upstate areas that need jobs.
And some lawmakers are hoping to convert state mental hospitals, scheduled to possibly close soon, into prisons.
Many such places happen to be represented by influential Republicans, in whose interest it would be to insure a continued supply of inmates to populate prisons, Democrats maintain.
"The opposition to the second-felony offender reform has to do with the fact that the law fills these prisons," said Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly Correction Committee.
"But what's good for Plattsburgh or Oneonta isn't necessarily good for New York State," he added. "How can it make economic sense to have an ever-expanding pool of people who don't pay taxes, who are supported by the taxpayers, and who are guarded by people whose salaries are paid for by the taxpayers?"
Whatever the political debate, state officials agree that if something isn't done this year and the prisoners in places like Orleans are forced to continue sleeping in double bunks, the prison system could slide into crisis.
Prison-guard unions are warning that their members can't tolerate the double-bunking situation much longer. "At some point the prison system is going to blow," said Joseph P. Puma, executive director of Council 82, the union that represents about 18,000 prison guards.
Mr. Coughlin, the corrections commissioner, also considers the overcrowding destructive. "It starts to destroy what a number of governors and legislators have developed over time as policy," he said. "And if the Legislature decides that double-bunking is a long-term policy decision, then I think the system will get extremely shaky."

The prison, built seven years ago, was intended to accommodate 742 prisoners. (Mike Groll for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Island Nations Fear a Rise in the Sea

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Representatives of 37 island nations that fear they may disappear beneath the waves if the world grows any warmer are voicing their concern at the slow pace toward an agreement on stabilizing the global climate.
These nations, including Cyprus and Malta in the Mediterranean, the Caribbean islands and archipelagos around the Pacific, say their existence is threatened by the rise of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere that contribute to the melting of the polar ice caps, which raises the ocean's level. 
 Warmer climates can also intensify hurricanes and tropical storms and kill coral reefs that protect island coastlines and harbor rich shoals of shrimp and fish.
These nations, which make up the Alliance of Small Island States, came together on Friday to prepare for a session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee for a Framework Convention on Climate Change on Tuesday. The group wants to draft an agreement before the "Earth Summit" in June in Rio de Janeiro.
But square brackets indicating objections still surround almost every sentence in the draft agreement on stabilizing the quantity of carbon dioxide pumped into the atmosphere, mainly through the burning of fossil fuels.
"The Alliance of Small Island States members are doomed to ecological, social and economic catastrophe within the foreseeable future," Danielle de St. Jorre, the Seychelles Minister of Planning and External Relations, told the meeting Friday. "Some will even disappear. And if that happens they will take with them cultures, identities and values which are irreplaceable."
Robert F. Van Lierop, United Nations representative of Vanuatu, in the southern Pacific, said, "It's a question of survival, it's that simple. At the very least, sea level rises of a foot or so could wipe out island ecosystems. At worst, whole islands could disappear under water."
Noel J. Brown of the United Nations Environment Program, said, "We are facing a whole new category of ecological refugees."
 
4-Inch Rise in a Century
 Evidence suggests that sea levels have risen by 4 to 6 inches in the last century, and the median forecast is for a further rise of 8 inches by 2030 and 26 inches by 2100, said John C. Topping, president of the Climate Institute in Washington, D.C.
Already many of these islands are feeling the effects.
Mrs. de St. Jorre said tourist beaches are shrinking and noted that the Seychelles had to build special dikes to protect reclaimed land and sea-level industrial developments. Four tiny islands in the Maldives are being evacuated because of flooding.
The sense that they are already becoming the first victims of global warming gives the island states an urgency that they feel puts them at odds with the political priorities of the northern industrial countries and the larger developing nations.
All Western industrialized countries except the United States are ready to commit to stabilizing carbon dioxide emissions at 1990 levels by 2000, but many will only do so if the United States changes its position. Saudi Arabia and several other oil-producing states, for example, are lined up with the United States against setting any binding new targets for emission levels because they fear that this will reduce demand for oil.
Japan wants to stabilize emissions at about 9 per cent higher than in 1990 to allow for population growth.
And for the bigger developing countries, like India and Brazil, the top priority is to insure that any agreement does not restrict their economic development and that the industrial north, which is responsible for over 80 per cent of the carbon dioxide already in the air, curbs its own emissions.
Nevertheless, larger countries may have as much incentive to stabilize sea levels as small island states, according to Stephen P. Leatherman, director of the Laboratory for Coastal Research at the University of Maryland.
A three-foot rise in ocean levels would render 72 million people homeless in China, 11 million in Bangladesh and 8 million in Egypt, or four times the island states' entire population of 23 million, he said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Challenger;
For Buchanan's Campaign, Improvising Is the Strategy

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 16

 BODY:
Two days before voters go to the polls on Tuesday, the campaign of Patrick J. Buchanan in New Hampshire remains what it always has been: a nimble, often slapdash affair that is constantly thinking on its feet, and at times tripping over them.
At breakfast today, Mr. Buchanan and some of his aides realized that the day's schedule had no events that would get the candidate on the early evening news or that would occur in time to make the early Monday editions of many newspapers. The candidate's staff immediately scheduled a news conference and brought in dozens of young supporters to provide their own cheering section to the challenger's answers to reporters' questions. 
 It took fast footwork to put together the press conference. But because the idea was conceived at the last minute, it had to be held outdoors on a Manchester street, always a dicey proposition, since one never knows what street hecklers might be present.
In fact, the press conference was twice disrupted; once by a man who said he was homeless, and again by a man who said he was with Act-Up, a militant AIDS advocacy group. Both tried to ask the candidate pointed questions, but Mr. Buchanan ignored them and was able to continue fielding queries from reporters.
 
Lean Research Staff
 On Wednesday, Mr. Buchanan's sister, Angela (Bay) Buchanan, read an article in The Washington Post indicating that President Bush was not pushing Congress for quick action on his proposal for a $500 increase in the income tax exemptions for children. By Saturday, the absence of that proposal on the President's list of high-priority steps to energize the economy was the basis of a new Buchanan campaign commerical.
That turn-around time was relatively fast. But the reason the campaign had to rely on a tip about a newspaper article is because it has virtually no research staff to investigate issues.
Despite its late start and seat-of-the pants quality, Mr. Buchanan's campaign has caused jitters at the White House. In the view of some analysts, Mr. Buchanan has already achieved the threshold goal of any insurgency: knocking a more powerful opposition off its game and making it look slow and complacent.
"Ten weeks ago, this campaign didn't even exist," Mr. Buchanan said today on a talk-show broadcast from Boston. "It was a glimmer in the eye. It was a conversation between myself and my sister on the West Coast."
 
Trying for Good 'Spin'
 In recent days, Mr. Buchanan and his aides have said repeatedly that considering how far he has come since announcing his campaign for President on Dec. 10, he has already won a victory of sorts. Such talk -- "spin," in the jargon of campaigns -- has the benefit of allowing Mr. Buchanan to save face if he falls short of the 30 percent of the vote most analysts consider the minimum for him to remain viable.
Still, for Mr. Buchanan, who has never run for or held public office and who carries enormous political baggage, having written and said things that have offended some Jews, blacks and homosexuals, to be contemplating a third of the vote against a sitting President is testimony to the attractiveness of his message to many voters and to the anger of many Republicans toward Mr. Bush.
But it is hardly a testament to a well-oiled organization.
Mr. Buchanan has only two people researching issues for him in Washington. His poll taker is a 29-year-old college professor who says he believes he is the youngest in that role in the race. The campaign has so few people doing advance work that officers like Paul Erickson, the national political director, are at times pressed into duty to set up chairs or do other chores.
 
Writes His Own Material
 The candidate not only writes his own speeches, using a personal computer in his hotel room, but drafts most of the campaign's television and radio commercials.
But Mr. Buchanan's improvised operation might work well in a state like New Hampshire, where no place is more than a three-hour drive away, and where Manchester is the center of the single media market. The primaries in Georgia on March 3 and in 11 states on March 10, Super Tuesday, will present much greater logistical and operational challenges.
Mr. Buchanan has been aided by missteps by the White House. By not making the child tax exemption a priority for Congress after he emphasized it in his State of the Union Message, Mr. Bush gave the Buchanan campaign an opening to question his credibility.
"You can have a lean, mean, hungry organization, and we can surprise people," said Ms. Buchanan, who moved to the Washington area from Irvine, Calif., to serve as the campaign chairwoman. "But we know something else: we're up against the President of the United States, and we can't do well unless he makes mistakes."

HEADLINE: Gambling on Honesty on the Homeless

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
By documenting that crack use is widespread among the homeless in New York City, a mayoral commission is betting that leveling with the public about just how bad the problem is will pay off in support for new programs to treat the addicted and to train unskilled young people who have turned to drugs.
The commission's report, which is to be released later this week, is a blistering indictment of the way the city has spent $2 billion over the last decade to shelter the homeless without confronting the deeper social problems that enmesh them. 
 But in releasing the results of the survey, based on random urine tests, the commission risks setting off a backlash against the homeless from a public that is increasingly weary of panhandlers and suspicious of promised solutions to a problem that never seems to go away.
In other fiscally strapped cities, including Washington and Philadelphia, the response to the intractability of the problem has been to slash spending on the homeless in recent years.
Andrew Cuomo, chairman of the commission, says he is confident that the new evidence about drug use, as well as a range of other problems the homeless face, will prove that society must do more, not less, to help them, and thus become the basis for a new consensus on the issue.
"Perhaps the commission's most important finding is the existence of a substantial subgroup within the shelter population," its report said. "This group essentially consists of poor young people who have grown up isolated from mainstream social and ecnomic life and who now find themselves without the basic social and economic skills necessary to survive independently."
The survey by the commission, appointed by Mayor David N. Dinkins, found that two-thirds of homeless single men and 30 percent of adults in families who live in city shelters tested positive for drugs or alcohol. Mr. Cuomo said he thought that the news would not surprise most New Yorkers but instead would reassure them that government is finally facing facts. Advocates for the homeless eager to win public support for them have too long offered a sugar-coated version of reality, he contends.
 
'A Decade of Denial'
 "You have to be honest about a problem before you can do anything about it," said Mr. Cuomo, who runs a nonprofit agency that serves homeless families. "There was a decade of denial in the 1980's, an insistence on the simplistic 'housing, housing, housing' slogan. But the problem was always deeper than that."
The commission, which sent its report to the Mayor on Saturday, argues that the vast majority of the homeless need much more than an apartment to make it on their own. The city should use a new combination of carrots and sticks to help them, it says.
The shelter system was created in reaction to a series of lawsuits, with the city responding to requirements created by the courts.
The commission calls instead for the city to strike out on a new path of its own devising. Its report calls for the city to invest $280 million to move homeless men and women out of exorbitantly expensive, barracks-style shelters into small, intensive social-service programs that the commission says will actually cost less to operate. That money will also help develop more permanent housing.
Only when families and single adults have successfully completed the new treatment or training programs, depending on their individual needs, will the city provide them with that scarcest of urban commodities: permanent, subsidized housing, the commission says.
So far, the plan appears to have generated a startling degree of agreement among the city's usually contentious political leaders. Highlights of the recommendations, disclosed by panel members, have won praise from City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, Council President Andrew J. Stein and the Borough Presidents of Queens, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island.
All those officials had been sharply critical of the Mayor's plan for the city to build 24 small, service-enriched shelters in residential neighborhoods. Mr. Vallone vowed to stop that plan, and had the power to do it.
These same officials, sensitive to constituents afraid that the city was about to plop drug-using homeless people next door to them, much prefer the panel's plan to let nonprofit groups pick sites and develop programs for the homeless, many of them not in residential neighborhoods at all.
 
A Consent Decree
 The origins of the city's current homeless system date to 1979, when Robert M. Hayes, a 26-year-old lawyer who had never tried a case, sued the city in state court. Two years later, believing it would lose the case, the city signed a consent decree granting homeless men a right to shelter. In the next few years, advocates won similar rights for women and families.
Then, in the mid-1980's, crack, the cheap, smokable form of cocaine, went on sale all over the city and hooked thousands of poor people who were precariously positioned in society to begin with, helping tip many into homelessness.
Many who would have found shelter in cheap, shabby single-room-occupancy hotels had it been the 1960's or even the 1970's found themselves out of luck. Much of that housing had been torn down or gentrified.
They entered a shelter system with few rules and almost none that were enforced. In the huge armories for single men, now notoriously drug-infested, violent places, a crack addict could avoid paying for rent or food and spend what money he had on drugs. The city had little to offer in the way of drug treatment, and the shelters became places where drugs were sold openly.
Advocates for the homeless often emphasized a housing shortage as the root cause of homelessness. Mr. Hayes often repeated his comment that the problems of the homeless could be summed up in three words: housing, housing, housing.
Many advocates, including Mr. Hayes, are now pushing much more openly for services to help the homeless. He talks about not only the right of the homeless to shelter but also the need for a new contract between the city and the homeless, with the homeless agreeing to participate in rehabilitation programs in exchange for the promise of permanent housing. That idea is very similar to what the Mayor's panel has proposed.

HEADLINE: Energy Industry Takes Some Radical Paths

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Almost no one foresaw the oil shocks of 1973 and 1979 and the price collapse of 1986. Engineers in the 1950's were stunned by the idea that nuclear power meant cheap, limitless energy and stunned again in the 70's that it did not. New inventions, regulations and political developments rush onward, sometimes offering vast changes, but often doing no more than offering.
What is next on the horizon? 
 Here are three glimpses of the future, each of which might prove a turning point -- or a mirage. They are the large-scale direct production of electricity from sunlight, the establishment of workable agreements that would foster the use of renewable energy sources and the peaceful use of surplus plutonium from nuclear bombs.
 
Photovoltaic Cells
 Photovoltaic cells, which make electricity directly from sunlight without emissions, are waiting in the wings. While they are far too costly today to compete with conventionally made power, they are useful in devices that would be expensive to wire to the power grid, like irrigation pumps, roadside signs and emergency call boxes. And with breakthroughs in the laboratory and factory, the price of the cells is rapidly falling.
When and where will they reach the magic price level and begin to displace power from coal, oil and natural gas? With a little extra help in the form of research money, maybe next year, in White Pine, Colo. Advocates of "renewable" energy say a cluster of 33 houses high in the Rockies could become the Kitty Hawk of solar power.
White Pine, which is 110 miles southwest of Denver and 7 miles up a dirt road, is tied to the Public Service Company of Colorado's electric system by a line that crawls five miles over an 11,300-foot mountain pass. The 70-year-old line is still functional but perilously close to the tops of the winter snow drifts, and the utility fears that the wire will be a hazard to skiers. The utility wants something done by the end of the summer of 1993; replacing the line would cost $130,000.
The National Renewable Energy Laboratory, a Government research institution near Denver, and Public Service drew up an alternative: a 35-kilowatt solar cell array, coupled with batteries that would store the energy if it was not needed when the sun shone. The cells would provide two-thirds of White Pine's electric needs; the rest would come from a generator running on propane.
The cells and the generator are off-the-shelf parts. But the utility would have to develop a control system to keep track of how much electricity the cells produced, how much was in the batteries and how much was being consumed. The system would run the propane generator when needed.
"There is nothing quite like this in America, where a complete community in America would be serviced like this," said John Thornton, a photovoltaic expert at the Energy Department who works at the renewable energy laboratory.
According to Chuck Rhodes, senior planning engineer at Public Service of Colorado, the alternative system would cost $500,000. Photovoltaic cells are now most commonly found on pocket calculators, but White Pine, said Mr. Rhodes, would teach energy engineers more about utility-scale applications. The cells that would be used in the White Pine project would produce energy at a cost more than triple that of electricity from old-fashioned coal-fired plant.
The company does not think its other electricity customers should pay for the White Pine experiment and is looking for financing from the energy laboratory and others to make up the difference.
If the solar project is built, said Mr. Thornton, "it will give confidence to other utilities, so other people say, 'Yeah, that's possible.' " If the price of solar cells falls by half again -- as it has done several times -- it would be economical in some locations, he added.
Mr. Rhodes agreed. "It's inevitable that the price will come down," he said. "It's a question of how long, 5years or 20 years."
 
Renewable Energy
 Regulators have debated for years how to set prices for electricity in a way that gives appropriate advantage to power from renewable energy, like wind, sun or trees, which do not pollute or deplete natural resources. Now, the Bonneville Power Administration, which serves the Pacific Northwest, has taken a concrete step in that direction.
The administration, a Federal agency, announced in December that it wanted to sign purchase contracts with independent electricity producers, a common way for utilities to get new power supplies. But Bonneville said its contracts would specify that if over the agreements' 20-year lives Congress imposes a tax on pollutants, including one on carbon dioxide, which is believed to cause global warming, the tax would be paid by the electricity seller, and not by Bonneville. The possibility of such a tax might discourage a builder of conventional generators.
According to Gary L. Fuqua, deputy assistant administrator of Bonneville, if the generator bears the risk, "renewables" have an advantage in the bidding, because they do not emit carbon dioxide.
Energy experts say that most existing contracts are silent on the question of new taxes, and this clause represents a new direction, though Bonneville is not certain whether it will affect the bids it will receive.
But an independent producer who planned to use a conventional source like natural gas might go to Lloyd's of London for a policy guarding against a pollution tax, Mr. Fuqua said, and the price of that policy could give the edge to another technology. Or, as a precaution, a company that planned to use fossil fuels might add a few tenths of a cent to its price, giving an advantage to renewables. Or a company that specializes in plants that run on fossil fuels might decide not to bid, leaving the field open for renewables.
 
Surplus Plutonium
 A political shift, the end of the cold war, has produced a problem and an opportunity in nuclear power. The United States and the Soviet Union are disassembling thousands of nuclear weapons with tons of plutonium, which can power reactors as well as bombs.
Disassembly is a very small step because the bulk of the work involved in making nuclear weapons is in preparing the plutonium. In this case, the plowshare can be quickly converted back into a sword.
But the plutonium can be safely disposed of in a nuclear reactor. And while the precise amounts involved are classified information, it is clear that only civilian power reactors can do the job.
"We should do it damn fast," said Ersel A. Evans, a consultant and former vice president of the Westinghouse Hanford Company, which for years ran a big weapons installation for the Government. "There are hundreds of tons of plutonium out there," he said, raising the possibility that the owners could rebuild bombs, or some could be diverted by a third party. "If we're horrified by it, why don't we do something?"
On its face, this would also seem to be an opportunity, since making uranium fuel for utility reactors requires extensive, painstaking preparation. Like surplus k-rations, the bomb plutonium would seem to be available for peacetime use.
But no one is jumping.
"I don't think the utilities would be wanting to volunteer for that sort of thing," said John J. Taylor, vice president for nuclear power at the Electric Power Research Institute, a not-for-profit consortium in Palo Alto, Calif.
Loading plutonium fuel would require a license amendment, and that requires public hearings, something no utility relishes. And, experts say, many utilities are loath to make any connection between their plants and nuclear weapons. Several experts with long Government experience in plutonium-fueled reactors who now work in the civilian sector refused to be quoted on the subject.
And plutonium, unlike uranium, is highly toxic, so it must be converted into fuel rods in highly controlled circumstances. Fuel manufacturers would have to convert the plutonium from its current metal form to the ceramic form used in reactors, but plants to do this do not exist in the United States. If built, the plants and fuel would have to be guarded against anyone shopping for bomb fuel.
But no significant technical breakthroughs are needed. In fact, all American power reactors already run partly on plutonium. They convert uranium into plutonium every moment they run; plutonium is formed when a neutron freed by splitting a uranium atom crashes into another uranium atom and is absorbed by it, transforming it into a new element. When the new plutonium atom is hit again by a neutron, it splits and gives off energy.
With all the complications, Dr. Taylor said, "I wouldn't want to state that there's some economic advantage there." But if the Government put it forward as an important national problem that only the utilities could solve, he said, "I'm sure people would cooperate."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Cuomo and Write-Ins: Will Votes Be Wasted?

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
FED up with the hundreds of wrong numbers that have cost him time and money, Randall Wells finally changed the message on his telephone answering machine.
The phone number of Mr. Wells's R.G.W. Brush Company in Epping, N.H., is 1-800-922-6866. Since last month it has been flooded with calls from people who evince an interest in supporting Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for President but who cannot spell Mr. Cuomo's name. By dialing 1-800-92-COUMO, they mistakenly reach Mr. Wells instead. Bristling over the mix-up, Mr. Wells recorded a new greeting. It advises errant callers: "Mario Cuomo is a waste of time." 
 One day before the first 1992 Presidential primary, why hasn't Mr. Cuomo delivered precisely the same message to New Hampshire voters?
Mr. Cuomo's long goodbye in December was to his candidacy in the nation's first Presidential primary, not to ambition. Just before his address last week at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government, he was asked whether he regretted not running. "Only when I'm awake," he replied.
It seems indisputable that Mr. Cuomo believes that he would make a better President than either George Bush or any of the five announced Democratic candidates whose campaigns he continues to diminish by his sheer eloquence, and by killing them with kindness. (Responding to a request from former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, Mr. Cuomo directed New York Democrats to help Mr. Tsongas get on New York State's April 7 primary ballot -- help that may harm the campaign of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.) Mr. Cuomo's occasionally damaging public judgments suggest, perhaps, a petty impulse: if he cannot be President, why should they?
Some of the dreamers whom Mr. Cuomo stranded in New Hampshire have been working in the field for weeks promoting a write-in campaign, governed by unauthorized voices that whispered: If you draft him, he will come.
In 1964, enough New Hampshire Republicans wrote in the name of Henry Cabot Lodge to give him a primary victory with 35 percent of the vote. President Lyndon B. Johnson got more than 49 percent as a write-in candidate four years later, although Eugene J. McCarthy, with fewer votes, was pronounced the upset winner.
The outcome in New Hampshire has traditionally been less a factor of who gets the most votes than how close that figure compares to expectations.
"How do you define victory when there's no candidate?" asked John A. Marino, the New York Democratic state chairman, who then definded it this way: "Five percent is a high number. That's impressive to me."
Vincent Tese, Mr. Cuomo's Economic Development Commissioner and confidant, suggested that breaking into double digits would be even more impressive and that 15 percent -- the goal set by the draft-Cuomo campaign -- "would be incredible."
Mr. Wells estimated that his lead-paint-removal company had already received about 600 calls from people inquiring about the Cuomo campaign -- a number that itself represents fully one-half of 1 percent of all the people most likely to turn out tomorrow. (They may represent the less literate minority of Cuomo supporters who, nonetheless, defy the prescription from the musical "Fiorello" that nobody wants a candidate whose name they can't spell).
Anybody watching Mr. Cuomo's televised speech at the Kennedy School last week would have found it frustrating, as Mr. Tese said, because "any time he gets up and talks, there's a glaring difference in the quality of what he says and how he delivers it." For example, the Governor described the President's oratorical assault on welfare cheats as "the ultimate cheap shot" since the main Federal welfare program represents 1 percent of the Government's budget and saving 10 percent of that would be "a miracle."
If Mr. Cuomo has no intention of running, though, why not tell New Hampshire voters, as Mr. Wells has, not to waste their votes? Criticized at home, he asked how he could discourage committed volunteers in New Hampshire who want to say nice things about him. His response evokes what he said in October to a contributor who asked him to consider running: "What am I going to say, no?"
The Governor's graciousness is commendable. His concern that his voice would otherwise be lost in the din of declared candidates is understandable. But just as he finally disavowed a favorite-son candidacy on his behalf in January, why not reiterate his position as the deadlines approach for entering the California primary, with a March 19 cutoff, and for adopting a New York State budget, by March 31.
"Would you be willing to say that you'd believe it if I said I was willing to say I wouldn't change my mind?" the Governor asked after his Harvard speech.
"I don't know," his questioner replied.
"Me neither," Mr. Cuomo said.

HEADLINE: The Fed's Rate Cut Prospects

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
In public addresses that are as hard to decipher as hieroglyphics, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has repeatedly said the central bank would make deeper interest-rate cuts if they were needed to lift the economy out of its torpor.
But in his carefully crafted speeches, Mr. Greenspan has also said the Federal Reserve's recent series of interest rate cuts should suffice. 
 That leaves a big question: How long should Mr. Greenspan and the nation wait to see whether the recent rate cuts do the trick? With millions of households hit by unemployment, and the White House and Congress both worried about their re-election prospects, a lot of people inside and outside Washington say the Fed should not wait much longer.
 
Usually a Six-Month Lag
 It usually takes around six months for the stimulative effects of interest rate cuts to show up in the economy, most economists say. The hoped-for result is that people buy houses and cars, which, in turn, will increase sales of dishwashers, bookshelves and tires and encourage industry to order more steel, wood and rubber.
Thus, the Fed's aggressive December cut of the discount rate, to 3.5 percent from 4.5 percent, should be felt by June -- if, that is, the stimulus works on the same schedule that it has in other post-World War II recessions.
But this downturn is not behaving the way economists' hypercomplex models say recessions should behave. And that, some analysts say, is why the economy remains dead in the water some 18 months after the Fed began its long series of easings that culminated in the Dec. 20 cut.
 
'Balance-Sheet Recession'
 "At no time in the entire postwar period is there greater uncertainty over the issue of what the lag time is after Fed easing," said David M. Jones, chief economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York securities firm.
The previous postwar downturns were "inventory recessions," in which consumer demand fell, goods piled up at warehouses and output dropped. To get the economy out of recession, policy makers were usually able to rely, without much problem, on a straightforward stimulus, through interest rate cuts, increased spending or tax cuts, to get consumers buying again and industry humming again.
But the current downturn is a "balance sheet recession." The economy drooped because consumers and businesses were weighed down by debt and banks by bad loans.
With any significant fiscal stimulus unavailable because of the yawning Federal budget deficit, monetary policy has become the main gun in the anti-recession arsenal.
The Fed's rate cuts made it easier for consumers to handle their debts by encouraging them to refinance their mortgages and by fattening up their assets, thanks to the soaring stock market. To lighten their debt burden, businesses can issue equity or lower-interest-rate bonds to replace high-interest-rate bonds.
Policy makers hoped that once household balance sheets improved, consumers would start spending again. Consumer confidence remains stubbornly low, however, and Mr. Greenspan has said this reluctance to spend reflects nagging concerns about layoffs, sluggish income growth and the less-than-brilliant long-term outlook for the American economy.
Thus, it is proving more difficult to lift the nation out of this recession than previous postwar ones.
To determine whether interest rate cuts are really powering a recovery, economists usually look to several indexes: auto sales, housing sales, retail sales and purchasing orders.
The biggest bright spot is the jump of six-tenths of 1 percent in January retail sales, reported Thursday. Car sales also rose in early February, although from a low base, and real estate agents reported a pickup in the number of people shopping for houses.
In addition, the M-2 money supply is starting to grow, and economists say that that growth means households with money left after paying debts or compensating for the loss of other income are moving it into checking and NOW accounts and out of illiquid long-term deposits held for a rainy day.
But these robins do not necessarily make a spring, analysts say. Negatives include the drop in industrial output in January of nine-tenths of 1 percent and the 5 percent drop in durable-goods sales in December, the biggest monthly decline since 1982. Consumer confidence slid in December, as did the index of leading indicators, and the 7.1 percent jobless rate remained unchanged.
 
No Imminent Rebound Seen
 Little wonder that many economists see no imminent rebound, although Mr. Greenspan has predicted that growth will pick up in the second quarter.
"My belief is the monetary input to date has probably stopped the significant erosion in economic activity but is not enough to produce a significant rebound," said Henry Kaufman of Henry Kaufman & Company, a New York money management firm.
Complicating the picture is the recent upward drift of long-term interest rates. This rise could hold back growth by hurting business investment as well as home sales, since rates for 30-year mortgages have increased.
Analysts give numerous reasons for the rise in long-term rates. Some investors believe that the economy and interest rates have bottomed out. They also worry that wrangling between the White House and Congress will push the huge budget deficit even higher. In addition, Germany's high interest rates affect rates here.
Some economists say the Fed should push down short-term rates once more to offset the higher long-term rates. But Mr. Greenspan said that a further cut in the discount rate could ultimately push up long-term rates because lower rates often spur inflationary fears. In his testimony, he was quick to add that inflation was firmly under control.
With the economy as well as Mr. Greenspan giving out mixed messages, analysts say it is a close call whether the Fed will ease further. But some economists say one additional factor might just weigh in favor of further easing: this is a campaign year, though the Administration, while not letting up the pressure, is not jawboning too hard at the moment.
"The Fed tries to be above politics, but it doesn't usually succeed," said David Wyss, research director at DRI/McGraw Hill, an economics consulting group. "Nobody inside the Beltway can be outside politics. I think you'll see the Fed try to keep its head down so it doesn't look as if it's trying to influence the election. They'd like to get any easing over early in the year."

HEADLINE: You Can Too Buy the American Car You Want;
Who Can Afford It?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was sitting at my kitchen table when I read "I Tried to Buy a U.S. Car (Sigh)" (Op-Ed, Jan. 24) by Verne W. Newton. It strikes me that Mr. Newton has hit upon the problem in the auto industry. Not in his experience in trying to buy American and not in the indifferent way he was received by the dealers. 
 But, like many Americans, he was buying a car for the first time in 15 years. Therein lies Detroit's problem. No one anticipated that Americans wouldn't be buying cars every two or three years. Where were the economic planners? With automobile prices going the way of prices for homes, who could afford to buy any car -- foreign or domestic? You can't blame the auto industry: it just followed the Government, retailers and everyone involved in setting prices.
When someone like me earns the same salary for the last 10 years, or when people who have been laid off and are working again at lower wages are not included in the statistics for unemployment, there is no accurate gauge to determine what the buying power of the American people really is.
 
DOREEN VITTI
West Bloomfield, Mich., Jan. 24, 1992

 BODY:
Croatians, Outer Mongolians and British soccer fans need look no further than campaign '92 in the United States as they struggle to master the techniques of democracy.
Democratic Consultant: Let's get away from the smears and back to issues confronting the middle class. 
 Republican Consultant: Right, Clinton roomed with the Vietcong when he was at Oxford.
Press to Governor Clinton: There are reports that you roomed with the Vietcong at Oxford when you were dodging the draft.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Memo;
Voters Want Candidates To Take a Reality Check

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 16

 BODY:
For many years now, Americans have turned away from root-canal politics. They did not want to be told to eat their peas, tighten their belts or pull up their socks.
Jimmy Carter's malaise, Walter F. Mondale's tax increase proposals and Michael S. Dukakis's austere and sanctimonious style all sent voters fleeing. They much preferred Ronald Reagan's sanguine message of "morning in America" and the blithe spirit of George Bush, whose press entourage in 1988 adopted the song "Don't Worry, Be Happy" as a campaign anthem. 
 But now, the mood has changed. Worn down by recession, Americans appear to have a lower threshold for sugar-coated promises and economic siren songs.
 
Time for Something New
 In polls and interviews, voters say they are ready for something new in politics: the truth. They say they want leaders with candor, not leaders who pander.
"I don't want any sweet talk," said Donna Ash, the owner of W. H. Ash and Daughter Antiques in Goffstown, N.H. "We have tried all the easy solutions. They don't work. We need to spend money and save it, too. And we need somebody courageous."
Like her father, Ms. Ash is a lifelong Republican who voted for George Bush. She says they are both bitter about Mr. Bush because they believe he neglected the economy and now "the bubble is going to burst and the bottom is falling out of the country, as it has fallen out of the state."
She is leaning toward crossing party lines in the primary on Tuesday and voting for Paul E. Tsongas, the Democrat with the least-sweetened economic message, because "he seems to realize that our pain is real."
Republican campaign workers in Washington say that their secret polls reflect a yearning for a politician who is willing to offer the public hard truths, not inflated promises.
Mr. Tsongas says he is not running with a red hat, white beard and bag of presents. Unlike some of his Democratic rivals, he has not baited his economic program with middle-class tax cuts and protectionist sentiments.
With more hair shirt than blue sky, he says that his fight to overcome cancer has made him especially qualified to offer the American public some reality therapy.
 
An Uphill Climb
 Unlike President Bush, who says everything will be fine if the nation just waits for an economic upturn, Mr. Tsongas says it will be a tough, uphill climb to recovery.
"There are two roads, one is easy, one is comfortable, but it's downhill," he said in the debate here tonight. "The other is the road to economic prosperity for a great America, a healthy America, a vibrant America."
Mr. Tsongas added: "I think what you're saying to us is: 'We are ready. Tell us the truth. Give us the economic truth. We can deal with it. We can prevail We are a great nation. Treat us that way.' George Bush has not."
Mr. Tsongas's approach is reminiscent of the cry of Howard Beal, the mad prophet of the airwaves, in the Paddy Chayefsky movie "Network": "I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it any more."
Ted Van Dyk, a Democratic strategist who has decided to offer his support to Mr. Tsongas, hopes the public is in "the 'Network' mood," adding, "We're fed up and we're not going to take Reagan and Bush and the Democrats promising voters what they think they most want to hear and fitting their messages to polls."
Even Michael K. Deaver, one of the architects of Ronald Reagan's "morning in America" theme, agrees that "people want some real answers, someone to tell them how we're going to solve these problems."
Mr. Deaver, who turned the telegenic good-news Presidency into an art form, said he does not think Mr. Tsongas's sad-sack appearance and blurry diction will hurt him, if he wins the New Hampshire Primary and tries to mount a national campaign.
"He looked down the barrel," Mr. Deaver said, referring to Mr. Tsongas's illness. "When people look at him, they believe they're getting the real stuff."
Some analysts said that the criticism that Gov. Bill Clinton was too slick would hurt him with an electorate that may be tired of slick deliveries and excessive promises.
From the Great Depression until the 1980's, the Republicans were seen as the party of denial. For decades, the battle of imagery pitted Franklin D. Roosevelt against Herbert Hoover, and the Democrats found it hard to lose. Ten years ago, Ronald Reagan and abundance replaced Hoover and denial as the Republican symbol.
But there are signs that the public may be willing to embrace the pain, as therapists put it, and acknowledge Mr. Tsongas's claim that "there is a morning after" and "this is when the brutal part starts.
Mr. Mondale, whose proposal to raise taxes in 1984 badly hurt his campaign, said that people have begun coming up to him recently to tell him he was telling the truth, and that they regretted not voting for him.
"Maybe the public is waking up and getting skeptical about simple public relations, effortless, happy-talk rhetoric," he said. "Maybe the public is finally saying we've got to look at basic questions. We're slipping. We're losing our edge. We don't hve savings or work habits or a good educational system."
Gerald Rafshoon, Jimmy Carter's media adviser, said that voters always want the antithesis of what they have had before.
"Reagan was the antithesis of Carter because he offered blue skies and a big sleeping pill," Mr. Rafshoon said. "Now the public is desperate and they are not getting turned off by politicians who talk about sacrifice and pain. They want someone who is not connected with the establishment or the media or power brokers or any form of organized slickness."
Mr. Tsongas knows that he is benefiting from this factor. "After eight years of me," he joked, "Americans are really going to want someone telegenic."
 
Same From Republicans
 The Republicans are continuing to cleave to the politics of abundance, not sacrifice.
Patrick J. Buchanan's message is that Americans have already made enough sacrifices to end the Great Depression, win World War II and achieve victory in the cold war. The conservative commentator now offers voters the palliative that by cutting taxes, firing Federal bureacrats and cutting regulation their economic troubles will end.
Mr. Bush has engaged in mostly upbeat rhetoric, as well, scorning rivals who talk of an "America running scared."
And after years of accusing the Democrats of over-promising, Mr. Bush is trying to spur his campaign here by repeating his off-again, on-again promise of a increase of $500 in the tax exemption for children.
Mr. Bush once blithely made pledges about stopping the scourge of drugs and saving the children of the inner cities and promising that American students will be first in the world in math and science by the year 2,000. But now Americans say they are skeptical of such rosy promises.
Mr. Tsongas says that such campaign pledges will fall victim to a "fool me once, shame on you, fool me twice, shame on me" mentality.
The essence of Mr. Tsongas's bad-news philosophy is summed up in his line "The cold war is over; Japan won."
 
Voice of Voters
 Fred Kelley of Kelly's Kars in Goffstown, said that he used to make his decision on gut instincts, or by voting for the Republican. But not this time. This time he has studied the economic plans of all the candidates.
"I'm realistic," he said. "It's going to be four or five more years before we are out of this. So I think I'm looking for the guy who recognizes that the most and will help us the best."
Talking about the economic blight that has cast New Hampshire into misery, he said he went through a few stages.
"At first I didn't care, didn't think it would last," said the 70-year-old car dealer. "Then I thought it wasn't as bad as they said. But it's been a long time since we could sell some cars. Now I'm scared."
John Gilman, 59, a truck driver from Bedford, reflected the mood of cynicism. "They all say they are going to save us and I don't even know if we can be saved," said Mr. Gilman, who drives a yellow Chevrolet with a bumper sticker that says, "Made-Bought-Paid For By Americans."
"I'm not a cynic, but you get a little desperate after a while," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 19, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A "Campaign Memo" article on Monday, about the Presidential candidates' economic messages, misstated rules for voting in the New Hampshire primary. Voters could take part only in the primary of the party in which they are enrolled; they could not cross party lines. The deadline for changing party affiliation for the primary was in December.
