HEADLINE: Exponent of Government-as-Business Is Gaining Bigger Audience

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
In Florida, Gov. Lawton Chiles followed the advice of a little-known political consultant and freed some of his largest state agencies from their cumbersome rules, quickly raising productivity.
In Massachusetts, Gov. William F. Weld listened to the same consultant and made money-saving changes in the state's Medicaid program. 
 On the Presidential campaign trail, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas salts his stump speeches with phrases from the consultant, like "paying for performance."
Democrats like Governor Chiles and Governor Clinton and Republicans like Mr. Weld are among the many state and local officials around the nation who are quietly experimenting with the ideas of David Osborne, a 40-year-old journalist who has become a proselytizer for more efficient government.
Mr. Osborne, in a series of articles, books and speeches, has started a movement to revolutionize government through what he calls "entrepreneurial government."
 
Different Realities
 His latest book, which chronicles hundreds of successful examples of making government more effective, was published last week, titled "Reinventing Government: How the Entrepreneurial Spirit Is Transforming the Public Sector From Schoolhouse to Statehouse, City Hall to the Pentagon" (Addison-Wesley). The co-author, Ted. A. Gaebler, is a former city manager of Visalia, Calif.
Behind Mr. Osborne's work is his belief as he stated in an interview last week that "with the transition from an industrial domestic economy to a global, postindustrial, knowledge-based economy the realities government has to deal with are different."
Government as it evolved in the late 19th and early 20th centuries was based on the same principles as Detroit's assembly line style manufacturing, and is just as outmoded, he said in the interview here, near his home in the suburb of Dedham.
This traditional form of government meant sluggish centralized bureaucracies preoccupied with rules and hierarchy, Mr. Osborne said. They worked well at the time, but today they cannot deal with the new problems like international competitiveness, shrinking tax revenues, deteriorating public schools, soaring health care costs and persistent welfare rolls.
"The fact that we are in a global market has meant a shrinking pie" as once-strong American industries have lost jobs and governments have therefore lost tax revenues, Mr. Osborne said. The central event in this turnabout for government was the tax revolt that started with Proposition 13 in California in 1978, Mr. Osborne said.
Mr. Osborne insists that what he is advocating is neither liberal nor conservative in the conventionial sense.
"Our fundamental problem is that we have the wrong kind of government," he wrote in "Reinventing Government." "We do not need more government or less government, we need better government."
What Mr. Osborne would do, at a time of widespread fiscal crisis, is to cut costs without eliminating essential services through a more imaginative and efficient approach to government. To some extent, he wants to make government run more like business.
 
Good Business Management
 He would introduce principles of good business management into government. Hence Mr. Osborne calls for more competition in government -- including school choice plans and schemes for privatization of services -- greater decentralization, more emphasis on performance instead of regulations and attempts to enlist local support by making people feel they own their government.
But Mr. Osborne, a Democrat by inclination, argues that it is misleading to think government can or should ever work just like business, because their purposes are funadamentally different.
One of his proposals, implemented by Governor Chiles in Florida and Governor Ann W. Richards in Texas, is intended to get around the problem of government agencies' spending their budgeted money before the end of the year so they are not given less the next year. Mr. Osborne's answer is to have agencies that save money turn back part of it to the state and keep the rest, using it for bonuses or new equipment.
 
Ideas Termed Borrowed
 Mr. Osborne is not without his critics. Harry P. Hatry, the director of state and local government research at the Urban Institute in Washington, notes that Mr. Osborne's has borrowed many of his ideas from other writers and even President Ronald Reagan. "Osborne has just done a good job of packaging and marketing them, so we've now got an express train going instead of a local," he said.
Mr. Hatry also cautions that it is more difficult to measure performance in government than in business. "I think most of his principles are good, but a lot of people are a little glib in talking about making government run more like business," he said.
Al Bilik, the president of the Public Employee Department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in Washington, is concerned that Mr. Osborne's stress on competition and privatization is just a subterfuge for laying off government workers. "When he talks about promoting competition between government and the private sector for the same service, I think he is naive," Mr. Bilik said. "What he is saying is that the only way to keep people on their toes is to threaten their jobs."
 
Anti-War Journalist
 Mr. Osborne, a native of San Jose, Calif., began his career as a journalist for Pacific News Service, an avowedly left-wing organization that opposed the Vietnam war. But after the passage of California's tax-cutting Proposition 13, he became interested in how state goverments were responding to what he saw as the end of the era of the New Deal and the Great Society.
His first book, "Laboratories of Democracy" (Harvard Business School Press, 1988), explored how several governors were developing ways to provide services and spark economic growth in the Reagan era. The most successful governor in the 1980's, Mr. Osborne says, was Mr. Clinton.
In a state with the worst record of support for public schools, for example, Governor Clinton dramatically increased spending for education. He also won a battle to force testing of teachers for competency and greatly decentralized decision making authority down to school principals.
Mr. Osborne acknowledged drawing some of the ideas for his new book from Gov. Clinton's work. In turn, Mr. Clinton has picked up some of his campaign themes from Mr. Osborne's writing, like the need to reform government.
Two other governors whom Mr. Osborne touted in "Laboratories of Democracy" have not done so well. The are Michael S. Dukakis, the former Governor of Massachusetts and the Democratic Presidential candidate who lost to George Bush in 1988, and Dick Thornburgh, the former Republican Governor of Pennsylvania and Attorney General who lost his bid for a Senate seat last fall in a stunning upset to Harris Wofford. Mr. Wofford called strongly for national health insurance.
Mr. Thornburgh's loss was a good illustration of the new reality of politics, Mr. Osborne said. "People don't want passive government," Mr. Osborne said. "What they want is a government that does more and spends less."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 25, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Feb. 17 about David Osborne, a political consultant, incorrectly described the Pacific News Service, for which he once worked. The service provides articles from countries around the world about social policy and international issues; it is not an avowedly left-wing organization.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press;
Turf Wars Becoming More Fierce

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
ALL over the nation, newspaper executives have been gathering at winter meetings of their state press associations to fret, worry and try to figure new ways to outflank competitors.
But as never before, a sizable part of the competition is probably in the same room with them. Though direct mailers, broadcasters and yellow pages still top the newspaper enemies lists, papers are increasingly going outside their traditional markets to compete with rivals farther away from their hometowns. 
 And while these newspaper wars may be taking place in small towns, the battles can be as fierce as the few remaining urban newspaper wars in such cities as Chicago, New York, Houston and Denver.
Indeed, the widely believed notion that a community's only hometown daily has a monopoly in its market is now often wildly misleading.
The advertising drought has pushed all newspapers to seek new sources of revenue, prompting some friendly neighboring publishers to poach on each other's turf, and turning hitherto gentlemanly competition into the more cutthroat variety.
For instance, perhaps the battle royal of all the newspaper wars is taking place in Chapel Hill, N.C., the charming village that is home to the University of North Carolina.
"On some corners around here, there are 20 or 25 paid and free newspaper racks," said Robert W. Parks, publisher of The Chapel Hill Newspaper, the 69-year-old hometown paper owned by Ottaway Newspapers Inc. that has repeatedly been chosen as the best small daily by the North Carolina Press Association.
By conventional wisdom, as the local daily The Chapel Hill Newspaper should dominate the market.
But Chapel Hill, which has many well-educated and wealthy residents, has proved very attractive to a plethora of local newspaper entrepreneurs and equally irresistible to the dailies in Durham, 8 miles away, and Raleigh, 18 miles away.
The Durham Morning Herald now publishes a special zoned edition called The Chapel Hill Herald and both The Herald and The News and Observer from Raleigh have big bureaus in Chapel Hill.
Add to the melee The Village Advocate, a well-established weekly shopper that has almost no news content; The Spectator and The Independent, two alternative weeklies; The Daily Tar Heel, the 20,000-circulation university daily that scours the town for ads, and a host of niche publications on sports, real estate and the like.
And competing for circulation, though not advertising, are the nationally circulated dailies: The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times and USA Today.
While Chapel Hill is an extreme example of newspaper competition, it is far from unique.
Metropolitan papers, facing dwindling readership and depressed business conditions in their home cities, are trying to steal the readers -- and ads -- of suburban dailies.
Suburban dailies, many of them in old towns that were once outside the shadow of the closest big city, are now being squeezed by metropolitan dailies on one side and swarms of often-free weeklies on the other.
"What it does to me as the hometown daily is to have to compete on two frontiers," said Richard V. Stevens, managing editor of The Olathe Daily News, a 10,000-circulation in Olathe, Kan., the seat of Johnson County, about 30 miles from downtown Kansas City, Mo.
Until relatively recently, the proximity to Kansas City was not a problem for The News, which is owned by Harris Enterprises Inc.
But Johnson County's population more than doubled to 65,000 in the last decade, and The Kansas City Star, owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc., aggressively invaded the area.
Similarly aggressive is Sun Publications Inc., a chain of free weeklies that publishes different editions of its papers tailored to individual communities. In Olathe, its paper is called The Olathe Sun.
The competition is fierce.
"Day to day, it's straight up; if we're at the courthouse, they're at the courthouse," Mr. Stevens said.
In areas of the country like New England that have been hit particularly hard by the recession, intense newspaper competition can push a hometown daily into unprofitability, which would have been almost unimaginable only three years ago.
Certainly no metropolitan daily has been more aggressive in going after outlying markets than The Hartford Courant in Connecticut, which is owned by the Times Mirror Company. For instance, The Courant invaded Middletown, about 15 minutes from downtown Hartford.
"We are under the guns of Hartford," said Michael G. Miller, president of the Eagle Publishing Company, which acquired The Middletown Press in October from the family that had owned it.
The circulation of The Press is now 18,500, compared with circulation of 21,000 in 1984, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
Though newspaper publishers are reluctant to give specifics, many small, long-established hometown dailies in New England are thought to be losing money and, in some cases, may cease publication because they cannot find a buyer.
Often in such cases, the paper is in a decaying mill town and has been under a family ownership that has difficulty coping with the sophisticated marketing and costly investment in news coverage that metropolitan dailies and big weekly groups are able to mount.
But hometown papers need not necessarily be the loser in competitive battles with other papers.
"If you have an alert, vigorous, close-to-the-market suburban daily, it is likely to prevail," said Lee Dirks, president of Lee Dirks & Associates, a newspaper brokerage.
And for some hometown papers, the old monopoly concept still applies.
"Our major competitor is the yellow pages," said Wayne E. Schile, publisher of The Billings Gazette, in eastern Montana.
The Gazette owns both local shoppers in Billings, and the nearest daily in the state is The Bozeman Daily Chronicle, almost 100 miles away.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
It's His Baby: Publisher Thrives on Family Fun

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
With advertising pages plunging, magazines closing, and the birth rate declining for the first time in four years, guess what Jake Winebaum did last year.
He started a magazine for parents. 
 He called it Family Fun, put out two issues with a circulation of 200,000 each and last week sold the magazine to the Walt Disney Company. (Don't think the beleaguered magazine industry doesn't eat up stories like this.)
Mr. Winebaum, who was previously senior vice president of marketing at U.S. News & World Report, is 32 years old. What he did was look around and come to the conclusion that -- statistics notwithstanding -- everyone he knew was having babies.
 
Fast-Paced Magazine
 "We had five couples we were very close to in Washington, all of them in their mid- to late 30's, all married for over 10 years," he said. "Within an 18-month period, they all went from no kids to everyone having one. Two of the couples are already moving on to their second child."
With help from U.S. News & World Report that included the use of advertising and circulation staff, Mr. Winebaum started Family Fun last April, investing a "substantial sum" of his own money in it. A colorful, fast-paced magazine aimed at parents of children 3 to 12 years old, it focuses on family leisure-time activities, ranging from trips to the zoo to ways to divert a bedridden child.
Enter John Skipper, vice president of magazine publishing at Disney, who has repeatedly said he is looking to expand the magazine division. Disney owns Disney Adventures, a digest-sized children's magazine started in October 1990, and Discover magazine, a science magazine acquired from Family Media Inc. last summer that will be completely redesigned with the next issue.
"We think Family Fun is a fairly key acquisition; we are a family magazine publishing company and it will become our standard bearer," Mr. Skipper said. "It's such a good fit with our own magazines that it was almost a magazine we had to have."
He declined to disclose the terms of the sale except to say that Disney bought all the assets of Family Fun. Mr. Winebaum will continue as publisher and editor. Disney plans to publish six issues a year at first and increase the frequency to 10 issues a year by 1994.
 
Magazine's Advertisers
 The acquisition puts Disney in the position to sell joint advertising for Family Fun and Disney Adventures, which is aimed at 7- to 14-year-olds. Mr. Skipper said Disney planned to create some kind of a spinoff of Discover for children next year.
Family Fun has been attracting advertisements for products like children's clothes and toys, as well as cars and life insurance. Mr. Skipper said children's advertising was among the ad categories the least hard hit by the recession.
"Remember that most of our advertising is still for fairly low-ticket items -- cereal, candy bars, blue jeans, video games," he said.
Mr. Winebaum explains the rationale for starting his magazine by saying that while many women baby boomers waited to have children until they were in their late 3o's so they could get their careers under way, the next generation is having babies at a much younger age.
"The 'baby busters,' who were born after the end of the baby boom in 1964, are having kids earlier," he said. "All the surveys of that generation show that they place kids at much higher importance than baby boomers did. But both generations are having more kids. All of a sudden, they are saying that maybe this career stuff is not more important and the size of families is going up again."
But Martin O'Connell, chief of the fertility statistics branch of the United States Census Bureau, said there was no indication from the 1990 census data that the three-child family would be the norm by the year 2000. The last time that the three-child family was the norm was in 1964, the last year of the baby boom, he said.
 
Smaller Family Size
 There is a significant difference, between then and now in terms of family size, even though the birthrates for the two periods were almost the same. In 1964, there were 4,027,000 births, compared with about 4,100,000 in 1991. But in 1964, there were 35 million women of child-bearing age. In 1991, there are 60 million.
And once again, real life is sticking out its tongue at statistical projections. The birthrate has turned out to be higher than that projected five years ago. So, Mr. O'Connell said, "The projections report is not really useful at this point."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jake Winebaum started Family Fun for parents with young children like his daughter Jenna. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BAKER AND YELTSIN AGREE ON U.S. HELP IN SCRAPPING ARMS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Russia today accepted a broad range of United States assistance for dismantling its nuclear arsenal, including 25 specially fitted American railroad boxcars to transport its nuclear warheads to storage sites and $25 million to set up an institute employing former Soviet nuclear-bomb designers in projects with peaceful uses.
The Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, also announced after three hours of talks in the Kremlin with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that he and President Bush would hold a summit meeting in the United States in July, although the precise date has not yet been determined. 
Mr. Yeltsin also surprised Mr. Baker with a request for further loan guarantees so that Russia can borrow money to buy American grain. In the last two years, the Bush Administration has extended a total of $3.75 billion in such guarantees for grain purchases.
 
Little Grain Left
 Mr. Yeltsin said that by early April, Russia will have used up all credits; he asked Mr. Baker for $600 million more to keep sufficient bread in the stores.
"I appreciate that the Secretary is not in a position to respond to that request because he has to report that to the President and Congress," Mr. Yeltsin said during a joint news conference with Mr. Baker, "but I have no doubt that there will be a positive response on the U.S. side."
Mr. Baker said that the Administration would consider the grain request, but he emphasized to Mr. Yeltsin that the republics of the new Commonwealth of Independent States, the Soviet Union's rough successor, must continue to pay principal and interest due on credits already extended.
Otherwise, American officials said, Congress would be prevented by law from authorizing any further grain assistance.
In recent weeks, American officials have grown worried that because of the economic turmoil in Russia, Mr. Yeltsin's Government might be unable to meet its grain-debt payments.
The officials said Mr. Yeltsin made no other requests for economic help -- like a currency-stabilization fund -- despite earlier statements implying that Washington was not doing enough to support his economic reforms.
The Yeltsin-Baker talks today focused on how the United States could help Russia and other former Soviet republics gather, dismantle and destroy the nuclear, chemical and biological weapons that they have agreed to eliminate either on their own, or in compliance with the terms of recent strategic-arms and chemical-arms-reduction treaties.
Congress has granted the Bush Adminstration $400 million to assist the commonwealth in this regard, and Mr. Yeltsin today accepted a variety of American proposals.
He and Mr. Baker said the United States, Russia and Germany would establish in Russia "an international science and technology center that would support scientists and engineers of the former Soviet Union to redirect their talents to non-military endeavors."
By financing peaceful research or commercial endeavors, the center seeks to minimize the temptation for nuclear experts in need of income to sell their services to aspiring nuclear powers like North Korea, Iraq, Iran or Libya.
The United States will contribute $25 million, out of the $400 million appropriated by Congress, to finance the center and its projects.
Germany and the European Community are expected to announce similar amounts for the center, which will be established in one or more of the military-industrial cities of Russia where nuclear scientists are concentrated. It will be open to scientists from all over the commonwealth.
 
A Capitalist Venture, Too?
 A meeting of experts is being scheduled next month to work out details of the institute, which the co-sponsors hope will attract private investors as well.
Then, the Russians have agreed to accept from the United States "25 safe, secure railroad cars designed to transport nuclear weapons" to be collected, dismantled and destroyed, a senior Administration official said. The boxcars will be modified to fit the republic's railroads.
As the nuclear weapons are taken to storage sites, they will be placed under bulletproof blankets that will also be supplied by the United States.
In addition, Washington will provide 250 large specialized containers for the overland transport of nuclear weapons, as well as smaller secure containers for weapons components.
When these arms are dismantled and destroyed, the highly enriched uranium and plutonium will either be entombed in underground bunkers to be monitored by the International Atomic Energy Agency or converted for use in nuclear reactors or research.
All these programs will be paid for by the $400 million, which was urged on the Administration by Congressional Democrats last year. At the time, President Bush did not push for the funds, but the Administration is now actively spending them.
 
No Decision on Space Defenses
 Mr. Baker and Mr. Yeltsin also discussed proposals for cooperation in their space programs, as well as in developing space-based defense technologies -- "Star Wars" equipment, in American terms. They reached no final agreement. Mr. Baker told Mr. Yeltsin that any such Russian-American cooperation would first have to be discussed with the Western allies.
At the news conference today, Mr. Yeltsin assessed his relationship with Mr. Baker, saying, "We are coming to know each other, and the Secretary and myself feel much more comfortable with one another than we used to be one year ago."
Bush Administration officials had at first been quite cool toward Mr. Yeltsin -- because of his less than fully successful first trip to Washington in September 1989, and later as he unseated the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in whom Mr. Bush had invested great faith and support.
In recent months, though, American officials seem to have grown slightly more comfortable in dealing with the Russian leader, though some still complain that his staff is occasionally chaotic and does not always work together.
On Tuesday, the Secretary of State is to meet with Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, and try to bridge differences in their countries' separate proposals for unilateral reductions in long-range nuclear missiles, beyond the levels already agreed to in the recently signed strategic arms treaty.

HEADLINE: War in 1990's: New Doubts;
Pentagon Plans Evoke Skepticism in Congress

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
By spelling out potential foreign conflicts that might draw United States forces into combat, the Bush Administration is headed for confrontation with a skeptical Congress over national security assumptions at the end of the cold war, analysts and Congressional aides said today.
In recent months, Congressional leaders like Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, have pressed the Pentagon to provide its analysis of specific threats to American security in coming years, but the Pentagon leadership has declined.
 
'The Real Threat'
 When Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, sent their 1993 fiscal year budget request to Congress last month, General Powell said in an accompanying "national military strategy" document that "the real threat we now face is the threat of the unknown, the uncertain." 
 With the disclosure by The New York Times on Monday of internal Pentagon documents detailing the seven Pentagon "scenarios" for future foreign conflicts, Congress now has a working understanding of the underlying assumptions of Pentagon spending plans until the end of the decade.
The hypothetical conflicts include an Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia; a North Korean attack on South Korea; simultaneous assaults by Iraq and North Korea; coups affecting American citizens or vital interests in Panama and the Philippines; an attack on Lithuania by Russia, and the emergence of a new and aggressive superpower by 2001.
The scenarios, which are described as "illustrative" and "not predictive," are used internally by the military services to examine their needs and provide the underpinning for annual budget requests to maintain levels of forces and weapons to support worldwide American military and political aims. As such they become Administration policy, though the scenarios themselves may not be specifically approved by the President.
Though the Pentagon controls the war scenarios as part of its planning process, Congress controls the financing for forces and weapons through the military budget. The ultimate test of the Pentagon's view of potential conflict in the world thus is whether it will sell on Capitol Hill.
Pivotal factors in the Pentagon's planning are the projected intensity of the conflicts and and the Pentagon's anticipation that more than one could occur at the same time.
Some scenarios will draw criticism and others are likely to find support, analysts said.
A member of the House Armed Services staff said today that the prospect of Iraq's rebuilding its military and invading both Kuwait and Saudi Arabia in this decade, for example, "really strains credulity" and that a less intense Persian Gulf scenario might be more appropriate for force planning.
"We watch Iraq solely on a nuclear proliferation basis," the expert said, adding that planning for a contingency response in Panama or the Philippines seemed more sensible. "Any force has got to be able to deal with that."
 
'Base Force' of 1.6 Million
 A Pentagon official said Mr. Cheney presented Congress with his vision of a "base force" military of 1.6 million members in August 1990 and now, with the end of the cold war, he is apparently developing new war scenarios to justify that force.
The base force concept called for reducing the "force structure" of the cold war military by 25 percent and then modernizing it with a new generation of high-technology weapons. But after an initial budget saving between now and the middle of the decade, military budgets have to grow by tens of billions of dollars a year to keep up with Mr. Cheney's menu of forces and weapons, according to Congressional Budget Office estimates.
Several military experts who work on Capitol Hill said today that the major issue for Congress was whether to accept the Pentagon's view that the military ought to be large enough to fight two major regional wars simultaneously, in the Persian Gulf and Korea.
In the Kennedy Administration, Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara developed the two-and-one-half war scenario, which held that the United States should be prepared to fight the Soviet Union in Europe while also fighting a regional war in Asia or the Middle East and a smaller war in Latin America. The Nixon Administration, however, based its defense planning on a one-and-a-half war scenario, assuming the United States might have to fight the Soviet Union in Europe while also taking on a regional foe like North Korea.
 
'Major Adversary' Gone
 One expert asked, "If during the cold war we did not have to worry about fighting Iraq and North Korea simultaneously, why do we have to worry about it now when the major adversary has disappeared?"
A Senate staff member said General Powell had been making public statements indicating that the military did not see the need to plan for major and simultaneous regional contingencies. This expert said Congress was likely to seek either copies of the scenario documents or extract details them from Administration witnesses.
With the diminution of major military threats in the world, some members of Congress also are reluctant to cut too deeply or too quickly into military programs that provide jobs in their districts.
In an election year and with the economy still sour in many states, it may be that the Pentagon's scenarios will be judged to be quite believable, even too conservative.
Whatever the effects, as one House staff put it, "There are a lot of people up here who want to get this debate on a sound analytical footing to talk about specific threats." The disclosure of the scenarios, "makes it awfully tough for them not to," he added.

HEADLINE: Milken to Pay $500 Million More In $1.3 Billion Drexel Settlement

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Michael R. Milken has agreed to pay an additional $500 million and a number of his former colleagues at Drexel Burnham Lambert have agreed to pay $300 million to settle many of the civil lawsuits arising from the failure of the brokerage firm.
Drexel's insurers have agreed to pay $100 million to settle the claims. With the $400 million that Mr. Milken previously put in a fund to compensate victims of his securities frauds, the total settlement is $1.3 billion. 
 Lawyers representing Mr. Milken, other Drexel executives, Drexel's insurance companies and the various parties suing them -- which include the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and many small investors who joined in class-action suits -- reached a tentative agreement on Friday. Federal District Judge Milton Pollack, who is presiding over the Drexel case, had ordered the negotiating parties not to discuss the matter until it was approved by the court.
But Judge Pollack confirmed the agreement in a telephone interview yesterday, after The Los Angeles Times reported that a tentative agreement had been reached.
"What we have is a term sheet that gives us the heads of agreement, and that's all we have at the present time," Judge Pollack said. "A final signed paper is to be delivered to me on or before March 2." He said terms of the proposed settlement had been mailed to more than 9,000 people affected by the Drexel Burnham Lambert bankruptcy.
How the settlement payments will be shared by the various claimants has not yet been determined.
Drexel, which came to symbolize the fast-money era of the 1980's, filed for bankruptcy protection on Feb. 13, 1990, in the largest collapse ever of a Wall Street firm. The firm had provided fuel for many of the biggest corporate takeovers of the preceding decade, often in the form of speculative debt known as junk bonds, which are corporate obligations of companies with low credit standing.
By making huge borrowings possible, secured by no more than rosy forecasts of future profits, Drexel helped transform the mentality of Corporate America.
 
Junk Bond Evangelist
 And Mr. Milken, an evangelist for junk bonds, became America's highest-paid executive. In 1987, he took home more than half a billion dollars from Drexel and succeeded in convincing investors that the extra-high interest rates on junk bonds more than offset the risk that they would not be paid.
Mr. Milken, now 45 years old, was sentenced last year to 10 years in prison for violations of securities laws and was barred for life from the securities business. Mr. Milken is expected, in some quarters, to try to use this settlement to seek a reduction of his sentence. Whether he will succeed is far from clear.
Assuming the proposed settlement is completed, Mr. Milken would pay a total of $900 million to various parties who contend they were injured by his business dealings. The $400 million he previously paid was part of a settlement of charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Of the additional $500 million, some will come from the liquidation of Mr. Milken's interests in various private partnership investments he controlled while at Drexel. He would also relinquish any counterclaims he might have against Drexel.
Another $300 million would come from other former executives of Drexel who have already been sued or expect to be sued. These include Leon Black, Peter Ackerman, Warren Trepp, Joshua Friedman and Marc Rapaport, among others. They have not disclosed how they will share the payment they have agreed to, half of which is due upon court approval and the other half a year later.
These men are also expected to draw on their private partnerships to raise cash.
The timing of the tentative deal is especially crucial for Mr. Milken and his fellow defendants. If they could settle the lawsuits as part of Drexel's re-emergence from bankruptcy, the bankruptcy code would afford them blanket protection against further lawsuits.
"That was the object," Judge Pollack said.
Without that legal protection, they could face numerous other suits and would have far less incentive to settle the charges against them.
A court hearing on Drexel's plan to emerge from bankruptcy is scheduled for March 5. Unless an agreement was reached this weekend, there would not have been adequate time for everyone involved in the case to be given reasonable notice, as bankruptcy law requires.
And since any postponement of the hearing would have caused lengthy delays in the bankruptcy case, the other parties in the bankruptcy would not have welcomed rescheduling the hearing just to accommodate Mr. Milken.
"We have written out something called 'a terms of agreement' that provides for basic payment terms and security and collateral, and it leaves some things open for drafting," said one lawyer who insisted on anonymity because of Judge Pollack's gag order. "You never know whether you'll get a definitive agreement till you've gone through that drafting exercise. But I think everybody thinks it's more likely than not this will carry through to a definitive agreement."
One sticky issue that still appears unresolved concerns how Mr. Milken would be allowed to satisfy the $500 million obligation he is assuming.
Mr. Milken must put up half the cash when the agreement is approved by the court, one-quarter a year later, and the final installment a year after that, under the terms of the agreement.
His lawyers fought hard to allow him to use his interests in Drexel's private partnerships, which they valued at $300 million, in lieu of cash, but they ultimately had to drop that demand when the other lawyers valued the stakes closer to $200 million and insisted on getting cash or cash equivalents.
 
Milken's Down Payment
 The understanding now is that Mr. Milken will pledge his entire interest in the partnerships as a down payment on his portion of the settlement. He would then sell the partnership stakes to raise some of the cash he will need for the settlement.
In a key concession, Mr. Milken agreed that it was his responsibility to make up any shortfall that might result when the assets are liquidated.
"That's really one of the big things we were fighting over, our insistence that it be all cash," said one lawyer who sued Mr. Milken.
Lawyers said it was that and similar issues that caused the settlement talks to become so protracted. After weeks of intensive negotiations in New York, where the case is based, the talks moved to Houston on Thursday. Judge Pollack has been in Houston for two weeks, because his wife is ill with the flu and had to be hospitalized there.
"The parties felt they had made about as much progress as they could without his intervention and decided there were some serious open issues and decided they'd see if by having him available to knock heads every now and then we could make some breakthroughs," said one of the plaintiffs' lawyers.
Another footnote to the deal is that if the settlement is completed it would let off the hook nearly half the former Drexel employees who had been sued last week by Drexel over the lavish compensation packages they received days before the brokerage firm went bankrupt.
The reason is that they were involved in the Drexel partnerships and would be relinquishing any claims to those assets as part of the deal. Employees who were not part of the partnerships, however, would still be liable if the lawsuit is successful.
For all the complexity of the negotiations, the Drexel case has moved along at a remarkable pace, largely because of Judge Pollack, an impatient jurist who takes a hands-on involvement in his cases.
"What I want to do is see if I can't complete the cycle I created in reaching a plan of reorganization in the bankruptcy, and to tie this into the bankruptcy," he said. "All of this is for the purpose of bringing about a substantial contribution to the Drexel bankruptcy estates so that it can be distributed to the people entitled to it."

International
 The U.S. and Canada are headed into a phase of confrontation, accusing each other of protectionist ways. The battlefield is beer, lumber and automobiles. Prime Minister Mulroney has complained, "We're getting sideswiped by American Japan-bashing," and has said Washington is playing "low-level politics." [Page A1.]

Michael R. Milken has agreed to pay an additional $500 million and a number of his former Drexel colleagues have agreed to pay $300 million to settle many of the civil lawsuits arising from the investment firm's failure. [A1.]

The Economy
Regulators are preparing a new strategy of investing in some failing banks and savings and loans rather than taking them over and closing or selling them. Their goal is to find a less expensive way to deal with ailing institutions. But the plan carries financial and political risks because it would also bail out the owners. [D1.]
Hispanic factory and industrial workers get hurt on the job more often and more seriously than non-Hispanic white and black workers employed in similar jobs, according to state health officials, private research groups and the doctors who treat them. [A1.]
Files are routinely sealed in product liability suits, medical malpractice suits and suits involving toxic chemicals, and the information is not made available to agencies like the F.D.A. [D10.]
The Administration attacked the House Democrats' tax bill as a bad deal for the middle class that would bring them "25 cents a day for two years" in exchange for cuts in Medicare, farm and veterans' payments and, eventually, tax increases. [D1.]
 
Today's Columns
An enduring idea of modern finance is being challenged. Two scholars say they have disproved the theory, common among investors, that stocks more volatile than the market as a whole are the best performers. Market Place. [D1.]
Health insurers are adopting computer programs that are increasingly sophisticated to use in their struggle with doctors over procedures and fees. The newer programs create records called physician profiles, which insurers and health maintenance organizations cite to influence, reward or dismiss doctors in their discount networks. HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Week;
New Hampshire Brings Tough Lessons Home

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.H., Feb. 17

 BODY:
Even before the first votes were cast, let alone counted, New Hampshire had taught the candidates and the nation some home truths about 1992.
Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator-turned-candidate, may take a big bite out of President Bush's hide or he may take a small one. Much will be made of the exact figures, without a lot of justification; in his 10-week campaign here Mr. Buchanan has clearly demonstrated the President's political vulnerability. What will become evident on Tuesday night is the extent of Mr. Bush's problem. 
 Mr. Buchanan's effort has also exposed the ineptitude of the White House political operation, at least in the eyes of the political professionals of both parties gathered here. With near unanimity, it has been faulted for poor advance work, pedestrian advertising and unimaginative themes.
Clearly, the storied Bush luck was missing this year. No incumbent would relish coming to New Hampshire to ask for renewal of his mandate in the midst of a devastating recession. But the President "ought to be able to take and hold the initiative against a neophyte," as a Republican consultant said, "and this President hasn't quite been able to bring that off."
The Bush campaign is stocked with skilled, experienced political operators, like Robert M. Teeter, the poll taker, who heads the team, and Richard N. Bond, the chairman of the Republican National Committee. So what is the matter? Some say Mr. Bush does not listen to them. Some say they have lost their touch. And some suggest, perhaps more persuasively, that techniques developed in the service of the master communicator, Ronald Reagan, simply do not work in the campaign of George Bush, a mangler of message.
Even if he goes no further than New Hampshire, Mr. Buchanan has already softened the President up for the Democrats by suggesting two avenues of attack: Mr. Bush is rich, indifferent and out of touch with the harsh economic realities of ordinary people; Mr. Bush has no core of beliefs.
In 1972, when the Vietnam War was highly controversial and Watergate was becoming so, President Richard M. Nixon sought re-election. He seemed vulnerable in February, and a pair of Republican Representatives challenged him in New Hampshire -- John Ashbrook of Ohio, a conservative, and Paul N. McCloskey of California, a liberal. Between them, they took 30 percent of the vote.
But Mr. Nixon went on to a landslide victory over Senator George S. McGovern of South Dakota in November. The Democrats had torn themselves apart in a nominating battle that went down to a procedural vote on the convention floor, never really rallied around their candidate and then were forced to replace their Vice Presidential nominee.
Whether the Democrats will be able to exploit the openings Mr. Buchanan has shown depends heavily on whom they nominate and how they do it.
None of this year's Democratic candidates is as divisive a figure as Mr. McGovern was, and the party is not split the way it was in 1972 over Vietnam. Things are always easiest for post-Franklin D. Roosevelt Democrats when hard times are the problem, as they are at the moment, because Democrats agree, in general terms, on what to do.
The party's biggest problem this time is that its best-known figures are not in the race. That may change, though the odds are still probably less than 50-50. But whoever is confirmed as the front-runner by Tuesday's results -- there cannot really be a front-runner until some votes have been cast -- will develop a lot of name recognition. Unknown when he started out, Jimmy Carter found himself hailed after Iowa and New Hampshire by hard-hat construction workers in New York City who had just seen him on television.
Probing questions and muckraking investigations follow notoriety, but so does money. Ask Bill Clinton.
That doesn't mean that he who wins New Hampshire wins the Democratic nomination. Estes Kefauver (1952) and Edmund S. Muskie (1972) and Gary Hart (1984) all found it impossible to transfer their popularity here to other states. Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts obviously faces difficult problems in doing that, even if he wins a commanding victory here, because he will remain a New Englander who has never won elsewhere.
This week many questions will be asked. Can any of the candidates develop an effective appeal to blacks and other minority groups, who play no role at all in New Hampshire? Which ones will be able to find new, sharply drawn issues to set them apart from their rivals? Who will get the best start on raising the huge amounts of money needed on Super Tuesday, March 10, when 11 states vote, including dollar-draining places like Florida and Texas?
Whoever finishes first among the Democrats will have his work cut out, because none of the candidates and none of their organizations seem as fully developed as is usually the case by this stage of the race. The campaign started late, and so far it has not produced a candidate with a demonstrable capacity for growth or its share of backroom wizards like Eugene Pokorny and Richard Stearns in 1972 and 1976. But then there are still months left.

HEADLINE: The Bronx Accentuates the Positive

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Although Marlene Reynolds shares a condition common to 1.2 million people, she'd just as soon keep it to herself.
"I don't want people to know I'm from the Bronx," she protested with a laugh as she leaned over the counter of the Bagel Cafe where she works in Co-Op City. "Everybody who is not from the Bronx thinks it's like that movie, 'Fort Apache.' " 
 Her neighborhood, the nearby residential enclave of Country Club, is closer in both spirit and geography to Westchester County than to the infamous 41st Precinct in the South Bronx. Nonetheless, a date recently told her that he was scared to leave his new luxury car on the street outside her home because he feared it would be stolen.
"That's the image they have of the Bronx," she lamented.
Her gentleman caller is not alone.
 
Population Increases
 In the years since it became America's pre-eminent popular symbol of urban hell, many things have begun to look up in the Bronx. Many things, but not the borough's image.
It does only so much for the Bronx's civic self-esteem to know that neighborhoods once leveled by arson and abandonment show strong enough stirrings of life that the borough's population increased from 1.1 million in the 1980 Census to 1.2 million last year. Or that entire communities have weathered the last two decades untouched by blight, functioning quietly and out of the glare of television cameras that venture into the borough to cover murders and mayhem.
Progress or no progress, many Bronx residents say they still feel like New York's municipal stepchildren -- natural father, Rodney Dangerfield. The latest insult came last month, when they learned that a drug-ravaged section of Manchester, England, was dubbed "The Bronx," prompting a chorus of protestsfrom civic groups and Borough President Fernando Ferrer.
"People still have the mental image of devastation and rubble strewn and abandoned buildings with decals on the windows," said Mr. Ferrer. "There had been a conditioning that nothing happened."
To help break that conditioning, some groups have begun efforts to burnish the borough's image. Positively Bronx, an association of business, cultural and educational leaders and the Bronx Tourism Council hope to bolster borough pride and attract investors, businesses and tourists to the Bronx. Next month, the city will unveil a program where each borough will receive the pro bono services of a major public relations company to help spur tourism.
"We have to do a better job of explaining to people the positive things that are in the Bronx," said Genevieve Brooks, the deputy borough president and a longtime community housing advocate. She was one of the moving forces behind the transformation of Charlotte Street from a rubble-strewn photo op for politicians to a quiet neighborhood of ranch-style houses. "If people cannot give us the credit we deserve, they should stop using us as their stomping grounds in movies," she said. "We are not a fictional borough."
Michael Gill, a management consultant who heads Positively Bronx, said the borough continues to attract immigrants and others seeking to carve their niche in society as part of the city's changing work force. "If you allow the Bronx, or any other inner-city area to be demeaned, we are ruining the strengths that made this nation great," he said. "The future of the city is very dependent on the future of the Bronx."
Turning around the image may prove more daunting than reviving moribund neighborhoods. "I wish whoever is doing it a lot of luck," said Roy Grace, the Bronx-born chairman of Grace & Rothschild, an advertising agency. "I think it's between the Bronx and Poland as to who has been the center of more putdowns."
But that could be used to the borough's advantage, he said. "When the expectations are so grim, the upside is very high if you just juxtapose it with the unexpected." For example, one could show pictures of attractive homes, then tell people the houses were in the Bronx.
"That gives you an enormous potential to get people involved and interested because their expectations are so different," he said. "They haven't been told the good things in so long."
The best place to begin changing the borough's image may be with its own residents, said Clive Chajet, chairman and chief executive officer of Lippincott & Margulies, a corporate image consulting firm. "The Bronx is more than the South Bronx," he said, fondly recalling a wedding he attended last year in the New York Botanical Garden that was as glamorous as any he attended in Europe. "Have the Bronx's people begin to develop some sense of identity and pride in the totality of the Bronx. One can't lie about the reality of the South Bronx, but put the reality of it in perspective with the rest of the Bronx."
While Mr. Chajet counseled patience to perceived slights like the recent Manchester flap, others have fought back with a sarcastic sense of humor. Mr. Ferrer recently urged Bronxites to decide which of their neighborhoods would like to assume the mantle of "Little Manchester."
"You know what?" he asked. "I don't think there'll be any takers."
Burton B. Roberts, the former Bronx District Attorney and presiding judge of State Supreme Court in the Bronx, recalled when fellow judges at a convention in Buffalo kidded him about the borough's crime rate, he bluffed and rebuffed them with an off the cuff reading of "An Ode to the Bronx." He claimed it was a lesser known work of Edgar Allan Poe, who lived for a while in a cottage off Kingsbridge Road:
 
I see thee in my dreams my dear beloved Bronx
 Thy face is to me fairer by far than the face of Yonkers.
 I love thy charm I love thy grace
 I love the beauty of thy face
 I love thee Bronx I love thee well
 Anywhere else? A living hell.
The stature of Poe notwithstanding, Sherwin Cloth said any efforts to boost the borough should focus on its current residents and attractions, with an emphasis on its ethnic diversity, suggesting a Bronx cookbook or tours into ethnic neighborhoods.
"Everybody in the Bronx is passionate," said Mr. Cloth, a Bronx-born public relations consultant and comedy writer. "But everything that has been done to promote the Bronx has been very Waspy. For example, the Hall of Fame for Great Americans is an area that people don't know anything about. It's about dead Americans that have nothing to do with the residents of the area." Don't ask him about Woodlawn Cemetery.
George Lois, chairman of the Lois/USA advertising agency, agreed that the borough should emphasize its successful native sons and daughters, as with the recent homecoming of the Mets slugger Bobby Bonilla. Mr. Lois, who grew up in Kingsbridge, flaunted his roots for a while when, inspired by Charles de Gaulle, he called himself "George of the Bronx."
"It didn't have that much of a ring to it," he admitted.
Of course, the ultimate in image changing would be to rename the borough, a step which Joel Portugal, a corporate identity consultant, warned strongly against. "The Bronx is a great name," said Mr. Portugal, a partner in Anspach Grossman Portugal. "It's a lot shorter than Manhattan and it's got a good sound at the end. No way anybody should change that name."
Call it what you want, Marlene Reynolds has decided she wants to move somewhere with less of an image problem.
"There's nothing for me here," she said. "I'm looking at possibilities in Las Vegas."

HEADLINE: For Hispanic Immigrants, a Higher Job-Injury Risk

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Hispanic factory and industrial workers in the United States get hurt on the job more often and more seriously than non-Hispanic white and black workers in similar jobs, according to state health officials, private research groups and the doctors who treat them.
Most of the workers are immigrants and like immigrants historically, they take the hazardous, low-paying jobs that other Americans spurn. But studies in Illinois, California and New Jersey show that Hispanic workers, both legal and illegal immigrants, also have injury and illness rates that are two or three times higher than non-Hispanic white Americans who take the same jobs. Black workers suffer higher rates than whites, too, but lower rates than Hispanic workers. 
 Experts on health and safety in the workplace say that many Hispanic workers are young and inexperienced, usually with only grade-school educations and little knowledge of English. Employers rarely provide training in Spanish, so when operating complex machinery and handling chemicals, the workers run greater risks than other Americans. Being weak in English also makes it harder to find other work, so the workers are less likely to quit unsafe jobs than other Americans.
The safety experts say the workers invite exploitation. The workers often do not understand their rights in the workplace as well as other Americans, and the illegal immigrants among them fear deportation if they complain. And when illegal workers are injured on the job, they are less likely than other workers to get good care. Illegal or not, workers are entitled to medical treatment under the workers compensation insurance system. But illegal workers fear that a doctor or a hospital will report them and so they seek less-qualified care, the experts say.
"What we have here is a fairly vicious economic situation where employers are chasing lower costs, which leads them to Hispanic workers," said Joseph A. Kinney, head of the National Safe Workplace Institute, an organization here that promotes safer working conditions and closer government regulation of the workplace. "Part of the dictum of lower costs is to squeeze the people on wages, benefits and safety. Their expectations are low, so abuse is invited."
No one keeps national figures on the ethnic origins of workers who get sick or are injured. But several doctors and agencies have conducted studies that show the same phenomenon:
*Sidney J. Blair, the chief of hand surgery at Loyola University Medical Center near Chicago, conducted a study last year showing that 57 percent of Hispanic patients who came to him had the most serious kinds of work-related injuries, like crushings and amputations, as against 22 percent for non-Hispanic white workers. The study examined 103 Hispanic patients and 110 non-Hispanic patients.
*The New Jersey Department of Health found that the finger amputation rate for Hispanic workers was 52.8 for 100,000, as against 28.9 for 100,000 for blacks and 9.5 for 100,000 for non-Hispanic whites and that the fatality rate for Hispanic construction workers was 34.8 for 100,000 workers as against 24 for blacks and 10.6 for non-Hispanic whites. The studies involved finger amputations in 1985 and 1986 among a random sample of 134 workers in many industries, and 200 fatalities among construction workers in the state from 1983 through 1989.
*The California Department of Health, which requires that medical laboratories report blood tests showing elevated levels of lead, found that 49 percent of the workers in such reports had Spanish surnames, a proportion nearly double the state's 26 percent Hispanic population, said Linda Rudolph, a doctor with the department. The reports were on 4,000 workers with excessive lead levels at 328 businesses from the years 1987 through 1990.
*The Los Angeles County District Attorney's office has prosecuted 45 employers for serious workplace health and safety violations over six years, with most of the cases involving injuries to Hispanic workers, said an assistant district attorney, Jan Chatten-Brown, who added: "There's no question that a disproportionate numbers of workers who were non-English-speaking -- and most of them have been Hispanic -- got these injuries."
In Chicago, where about 20 percent of the population is Hispanic, Francisco Calito, a 40-year-old Guatemalan, is unable to work and collects $386 a week in worker's compensation for a shoulder injury he sustained at the Tommy Armour Golf company here, where he assembled golf clubs for that division of Hanson Industries. Mr. Calito slipped across the border at Brownsville, Tex., in 1970 in a van; five years later, he gained legal status.
Mr. Calito carries his left arm folded at waist level, and grimaces as he slides off his jacket. He tells a story of injury, intimidation and discrimination that differs only in the details from those told by other injured Hispanic workers.
"I made 2,300 golf clubs a day," he said. "I worked there 40 hours a week for 10 years." His job involved attaching golf club heads to their shafts. A machine, driven by rapid-fire pulses of compressed air, pounded the shafts onto the heads, which Mr. Calito held in his palm, against his shoulder.
After seven or eight years, he said his shoulder, which took the blows of the machine, began to ache. "I told them about the pain," he said. "They said, 'If you don't work, you'll be fired.' My supervisor would shake his finger at me. He would kick me. He would tell me, 'I don't like you because you're a Latino.' "
Mr. Calito said he stuck with the job because he needed the $5.50 an hour he was paid to support his family. "I worked for two years with the pain," he said.
One day in November 1990, he said, bending his arm, "my arm was like this."
"They sent me to their doctor," Mr. Calito said. "The doctor gave me a shot and uncrooked my arm. He sent me back to the company. Then the company told me I could not work. I went to another doctor who told me that little by little the bone had worn away. He said I have a frozen shoulder."
 
'Standard Operation'
 James Phillips, vice president for manufacturing at Armour, said there was no question about the seriousness of Mr. Calito's injury. "But I'm not sure what caused it," he said. "Other workers have been doing that job for longer than he has. It's a pretty standard operation done by a lot of companies, not just us."
Mr. Phillips said he had never heard Mr. Calito's charges of race-baiting. He said the company had a harmonious work force of white, black and Hispanic employees. "Kicking?" he said. "That's impossible. We're not running a sweatshop here."
No one may ever establish whether Mr. Calito was simply careless or whether he was driven too hard or improperly trained and supervised. But Kenneth S. Lewis, a lawyer at Lewis, Davidson & Hetherington, a firm here that specializes in minority-group workers' compensation claims, said, "What we see in many of these cases are unsophisticated workers put into situations that are extremely dangerous and put under pressure where they have to perform."
Molly Coye, director of the California Department of Health Services, said Hispanic workers were more vulnerable because of employers' reluctance to provide training and instructions in Spanish.
"Even in the same workplace, Hispanic workers have both more dangerous jobs and a higher risk of injury in the same job," she said. The state has begun several programs to persuade employers to provide training in Spanish, she said.
Illegal aliens are exploited the most, occupational health officials say, because an employer can threaten them with dismissal, reporting them to the Immigration and Naturalization Service and deportation.
Often these threats are empty, because employers face civil and criminal penalties for hiring illegal immigrants. And the employers can be fined hundreds of dollars a day for not carrying workers' compensation insurance. But the workers are usually not informed enough to call their employers' bluff, or they think that protecting the employer serves the interests of the worker as well.
"They are the type of workers who are threatened by exposure or other problems if they raise safety and health questions, or any other questions," said John B. Moran, an official of the Laborers Health and Safety Fund, a research group supported by business and labor unions.
 
Touch It and It Hurts
 David Perez, a 45-year-old legal alien from Mexico, has the scars of four operations on his left hand from an industrial accident. He lost his left little finger down to the second knuckle from an earlier accident at the same factory, which has since gone out of business.
Mr. Perez points to the spot where the thumb joins the inside of his wrist. "Just touch it with a finger, just a little, it hurts," he said. "My sleeve rubs against it and it hurts. Any movement I make hurts.
"I always keep it a little covered so people can't see it," Mr. Perez said. "I have problems with my family, my wife. How do I say this: She never wants to be with me because she's afraid she will hurt me. She's very different than she was before. The children always want to play with me, and I because of the pain am not in the mood to play with them."
Mr. Perez set dies into punch press machines that stamped out metal parts. He described the accident that mangled his hand this way:
"I was repairing a machine because the part was coming out wrong. I accidentally hit the pedal. My hand was pressed and it stayed there. I called the operator to help me get my hand out. They put it in reverse and it hit my hand again. I told the guy to get the boss, so that manually they could lift the machine and get my hand out.
"The boss, and he was a Latino, would always give the worst jobs to Hispanics and cut their salaries. According to him, they didn't give the same production as the ones who spoke English, which was a lie. We didn't know how to defend ourselves.
"After my accident, all the time I had discrimination. They would fire me, then call me back. When I went back, I did the same work, but it was impossible to do it well. They switched me to a job that was harder and paid less money."
Mr. Perez received about $200,000 in workers' compensation for the permanent damage to his arm and for the settlement of a lawsuit against the maker of the machine. Despite the injury to his arm, he still works, driving a small truck part time and earning about $190 a week.
In some cases, the workers and the employers do serve one another's economic needs. Together they have created an underground cash economy. It can invite more exploitation and injury, but also offers opportunity.
Now, a new group of illegal immigrants is entering Chicago and getting hurt at work.
"We see a fair number of undocumented Poles," said Dr. Steven Hessl, director of the Cook County Occupational Medicine Clinic, which caters to the poor. "I just saw one. He worked with chemicals and didn't want us to call the company. He was afraid the company would get him deported."

(Peter T. Kilborn/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEW JAPAN ENVOY SEES CRISIS IN U.S.

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Japan's newly appointed Ambassador to the United States described the relationship between the two countries today as teetering at "a rather crucial period of mutual adjustment," as the United States only slowly gets used to the idea of sharing power with an economically resurgent Japan.
The comments by the Ambassador, Takakazu Kuriyama, an Amherst-educated expert on the United States who until last year was deputy foreign minister, underscored the growing view here that relations are nearing a crisis because of growing trade tensions and the difficulty the United States has in accepting its diminished influence in the post-cold-war era. 
 President Bush's attempts on a trip to Japan last month to persuade the Japanese to buy more American automobiles and parts led to complaints in the United States about Japan's trade practices. That was followed by remarks by Japanese political leaders questioning the work habits and competence of American workers.
 
Places Burden on the U.S.
 Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa even characterized American workers as lacking a work ethic, a comment that reflected a widespread view in Japan that America has lost its way economically but has yet to face up to the seriousness of its decline. These exchanges have brought to the surface an unusual level of bitterness and disillusionment that some leaders have tried to paper over, but which Mr. Kuriyama acknowledged.
Mr. Kuriyama, who assumes his post in mid-March, suggested that the burden for improving relations rests largely on the United States. He indicated that Japan was well on its way toward opening its economy, while the United States had yet to come to grips with its economic troubles or the implications of its dependence on Japan.
He said the United States needed to address two key economic problems: overconsumption, as exemplified by the yawning Federal budget deficit, and under-savings, as indicated by the level of indebtedness and the need to import capital to finance the deficit.
 
'Managing' Trade
 While some Japanese business leaders have been critical of the agreement reached during President Bush's visit for Japan to import a specific amount in automobiles and parts, Mr. Kuriyama said he accepted such "managed trade" as a way to tame the growing difficulties in the relationship.
Mr. Kuriyama also warned that campaigns in the United States to have consumers purchase only American-made goods could harm the relationship. "If buying American becomes a widespread discriminatory practice, our whole relationship is going to be in trouble," he said.
Mr. Kuriyama offered no short-term solutions. He said he wants to pursue three aims at once: better management of the periodic crises in the world and in the bilateral relationship, help for each side to understand the other better, and enhancing what Japan likes to call the "global partnership," which often means greater consultation with Japan before it is asked to finance United States initiatives.
"If we fail to work together and cooperate with each other, I think the whole world will suffer," he said.

HEADLINE: Poll Shows Deeper Roots in New York Region

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
After two turbulent decades of moving in and out of the New York region, its residents have grown less restless as they have aged and become more attached to their homes and communities, according to a New York Times Poll.
The new sense of roots in the region is most evident in the suburbs, where 53 percent of respondents in the poll said they had no plans to leave their communities. In contrast, when they were asked the same question in 1978, 43 percent of the region's residents outside the city said they had no plans to leave. 
 New York City residents expressed a stronger inclination to move, with a majority saying they planned eventually to leave the city. Their responses, compared with those in previous polls, suggest that dissatisfaction with their lives in the city has grown since the 1980's.
 
Demographic Shifts
 But in a region of 17.3 million people -- about 10 million of them in the suburbs -- experts said the poll results reflected deep, long-term demographic shifts that might have buttressed the area's social and economic base, even as it struggled through the most protracted recession in decades.
They point first to the aging of the huge generation born after World War II, which has matured from its adventuresome years of young adulthood into a era of heightened concerns about family living and financial security.
"People who have children have become more committed to their communities, and that is good news for the region," said Barbara Lawrence, vice president of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit research organization based in Manhattan. She added that a sharp increase in the number of families where both spouses are dedicated to their jobs and careers has made relocation more disruptive and less frequent.
For some respondents, the reduced level of mobility reflected in the Times poll may merely result from financial frustration. If fewer people plan to move, the experts said, it may be because they are unwilling to sell their homes during a steep real estate slump, because their job opportunities elsewhere have narrowed, or both.
Still, the economic repercussions of a more stable population bode well for a region that suffered steep losses in the 1970's and that as recently as the late 1980's was unsettled by fear of a flight of highly educated professionals as a consequence of thousands of layoffs on Wall Street and widespread business failures.
"Retaining our labor force is critical if we are to generate a proper rate of economic growth," said Regina Armstrong, an economist who specializes in the New York region. In an appraisal echoed by other economists and urban planners, she said the results of the poll were "on balance, good news."
Some of those who participated in the poll said their heightened commitment to the New York region resulted from skepticism over opportunities elsewhere, and a growing faith that the grass at home was as green as it gets.
"A decade ago I thought New England was such a wonderful, funky, high-tech area," said Richard Sauerhaft, a 35-year-old marketing representative who lives north of the city in Hastings-on-Hudson. "But now we've seen what happened to the economy up there, and I'll stay where I am."
The telephone poll was conducted from Nov. 2 to 12 with 824 adult residents of New York City and 1,726 adult residents in the 14 counties immediately surrounding the city in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut.
The margin of sampling error for both the city and the 14-county region is plus or minus three percentage points.
More than 20 of the participants were re-interviewed for this article.
When the people in the poll were asked if they had "any plans to eventually leave" their communities, 53 percent of the people who now live in the New York region outside the city said they had "no plans to leave." In contrast, when the same question was asked in a 1978 poll, 43 percent of the suburban participants said they did not plan to leave.
For those in the recent poll with plans to move, 5 percent said they would move closer to the New York; 18 percent farther from New York, and 20 percent to other parts of the country.
 
Moving 'Somewhere Else'
 Residents of New York City were asked: "Looking ahead four years, if it were entirely up to you, would you want to be living in New York City, or would you want to be living somewhere else?" Sixty percent said they wanted to be "somewhere else."
The restlessness of city residents was measured in three previous polls in which the same question was asked. In 1981, 48 percent said they would prefer to move. In 1985, near the height of an economic boom, the percentage who wanted to leave had dropped to 42. In 1990, it had increased sharply, to 59 percent.
To be sure, people's perceptions of mobility and future changes in their lives often miss the mark of practicality. Several of the city residents said in interviews that even though they would prefer moving away, it was not likely to happen.
"Unfortunately, this is home," said Beth Diker, a 39-year-old psychologist who lives in Hollis Hills, Queens, and was one of the poll participants who said she would move if she could within four years.
"New York City comes down to the basic hassle of parking, shopping and renewing a driver's license, and it's more intense than any place I know," she added. "But I'm not going any place."
Another question in the poll, designed to gauge people's sense of roots, asked if they could easily "pull up stakes" if they found themselves in a position where they "had to move."
 
Deeper Roots in Suburbs
 The responses revealed slightly deeper roots in the suburbs, where 53 percent said moving would be "a problem." In the city, 47 percent said they would have a problem moving.
To whatever extent the attitudes reflect a long-term shift in mobility, the poll comes after a sweeping reversal in population patterns over the last two decades, particularly in New York City.
According to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the region lost 961,000 residents during the 1970's, with by far the biggest outward migration from the city, which lost 823,000 people. Experts say the largest losses came during the mid-1970's, when the city was near bankruptcy, crime and drug use were rising sharply and other serious urban problems emerged.
But from 1980 to 1990, the agency said, the region regained nearly a third of what it had lost, with New York City emerging once again as a magnet. The city gained 252,000 residents, an increase widely attributed to its robust economy in the mid-1980's, which attracted many from elsewhere in the United States, and to a sharp increase in foreign-born immigrants.
Other studies show that the frequency of moves into and out of the New York region has begun to taper off from a high rate in the mid-1980's. In an analysis of its own business, the Allied Van Lines Corporation, a major moving concern, said its shipments to and from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut fell to 26,805 in 1990 after exceeding 30,000 during each of the previous four years.
 
Restless Residents
 Experts attributed the restlessness of New York City residents to a combination of forces that have always made it one of the most transient of urban environments.
"If you had data from 50 years ago it would be consistent," said Kenneth Jackson, professor of history at Columbia University who has written extensively on the evolution of New York and its region. "This is a city of renters, which attracts people who don't sink roots and who eventually move on."
Perhaps typical is Patricia Fall, a 25-year-old advertising sales representative who is living in her fourth studio apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan since moving to the city from Washington, D.C., in 1988. In the poll, she said she would prefer to be living in the city in four years.
"It is easy to fall in love with New York," she said in an interview. Nonetheless, she said she has reached a conclusion that is shared by many of her friends: "Marriage and children would make a big difference, and I would refuse to raise kids here."
The experts said a growing sense of stability in the suburbs may have more important and longer-term implications for the region.
"Some of the reasons will be with us for a long time to come," said James Hughes, a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University in New Jersey. He said that many of the suburbs around New York had entered a "third phase" since the mass migration that followed World War II.
 
The 'Ozzie and Harriet Years'
 During those "Ozzie and Harriet years," he said, a preoccupation with family life melded with frenetic economic growth that gave middle-income people a high degree of mobility. By the 1970's and 1980's, he added, the most restless of generations had entered the job market of transcontinental transfers and career moves, and a real estate market that encouraged people turn over homes quickly.
But now, he said, "the suburbs of the 1990's have become a place where people want to raise kids and grow old."
The perception of permanence is not shared by everyone.
"Most of the people I know are itching to get out, but they are stalled because they can't sell their houses," said Michael Smith, an envelope sales representative who has lived in West Babylon since 1950. He sold his home this month and is planning to leave the region.
 
List of Complaints
 Topping his list of complaints about Long Island living are its traffic jams and property taxes. Mr. Smith and his wife, Virginia, are considering moving to the coastal area of North Carolina or Florida, and he said they would rent another house for a year while plotting their move.
The only constraint now, he said, is finding a job he will accept in one of the areas where he wants to live. "At the moment, things are tough all over," he said.
In Hastings-on-Hudson, Mr. Sauerhaft and his wife, Doreen, have two toddlers and a mortgage to pay on the house they bought in 1989, near the peak of the region's real estate boom. He said he did not want to move, even if he could.
"I do get the sense that all that shuffling of people in and out has slowed down, and maybe that's a good thing," he said. "The New York area is a still a hub, and I think it's as good a bet as any."
