HEADLINE: In Minnesota, Pressure Builds for a Health-Care Insurance Plan

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Feb. 15

 BODY:
As politicians in Washington jockey for advantage in the debate over access to health care, Minnesota is working toward its own solution, a universal health-care plan that would subsidize the working poor, force insurers to cover people in high-risk groups and require greater cost efficiency.
For weeks, Democrats and Republicans here in the Minnesota capital have been negotiating a compromise measure to introduce during the legislative session that opens Tuesday. 
 Protests and opinion polls suggest that Minnesotans worry about health care more than about education or taxes, although only about 7 percent of Minnesotans are not covered by some sort of health insurance. And legislators fear that if they do not come up with some kind of plan this term, voters will get back at them in November, when all 201 seats in the Minnesota Legislature are up for grabs.
"There is a sense that the Legislature has to act," said Lois Quam, an insurance executive and the chairwoman of a state advisory committee set up to recommend legislation.
"There is enormous pressure to take something home for the '92 election. There is a sense of urgency from Minnesotans because people feel vulnerable and unprotected."
About 200 people showed up Friday in the Capitol Rotunda for a rally demanding action on health care. Many told stories of losing coverage or facing premiums that had grown to half their income.
About 30 other states have health-care legislation under consideration. Some measures would create state-run insurance programs and others would require employers to either buy coverage for their workers or contribute to a state insurance pool.
 
Last Year, a Veto
 But Minnesota has come closer to enacting such a sweeping measure than any other state in the three years since Oregon created a plan, now awaiting Federal approval, to expand eligibility for Medicaid, ration medical services and require employers to buy coverage for their workers.
Proposals in most other states are still being studied or are stalled in committee. But last year, the Democratic-led Legislature in Minnesota approved by fairly wide margins a bill that would have gradually introduced an optional state-run insurance program with a low-cost benefits package, put limits on private-market premiums and directly subsidized the working poor.
The bill was vetoed by Gov. Arne H. Carlson, a Republican, who said it would cost too much.
The first-term Governor is one of the few state politicians not up for re-election this year, but he has his own problems with the voters. A Minneapolis Star-Tribune poll taken last month found that he had a disapproval rating of 55 percent, the highest such rating of any governor in the 48 years the poll has been taken. The poll has a margin of sampling error of 3.5 percent.
Governor Carlson made it to the executive office by the quirkiest of circumstances. He became the Republican nominee in the final days of the 1990 gubernatorial campaign when the original nominee, John Grunseth, dropped out after accusations of sexual improprieties. Mr. Carlson campaigned for only nine days and defeated Rudy Perpich, the Democratic incumbent, 50.1 percent to 46.7 percent.
With his own popularity slipping, Governor Carlson now appears willing to work out some kind of agreement on health care.
 
The Governor's Goals
 He told the negotiators working on the bill that he wanted to increase access to the private insurance market rather than see the state go into the insurance business. He has endorsed subsidies and state income tax deductions for low-income Minnesotans and price controls on private premiums. He also has endorsed so-called healthy lifestyle discounts for people who, for example, exercise regularly or do not smoke.
Otherwise, he has essentially left the Republican negotiators to represent his views and has left the legislators alone to do their job.
"He's committed to getting something passed this year," said Jill Sammon, the governor's legislative relations director. "He feels there is a need to get health care to everyone but that we can't bankrupt the state to do it." The state Government is facing a $340 million budget deficit.
Much of the bill he vetoed, however, is still on the table along with the more modest proposals from insurance groups and the governor.
Whatever comes out of the session this year will not go so far as to put all health coverage immediately in the hands of the state, principal negotiators say. Although employers would be encouraged and enticed to provide insurance for their workers, the legislation is unlikely to require it, as Hawaii has done since the 1970's.
The Minnesota plan will likely be a hybrid, negotiators say, one that involves state subsidies for low- to moderate-income people, strict cost controls and a prohibition of underwriting practices that either effectively lock out small businesses and very sick people.
Under the Democrats' bill, insurance companies would no longer be able to refuse to cover people on the basis of such things as gender, occupation or preexisting condition, a provision that most of the negotiators agree upon.
The emphasis on underwriting practices is a distinctive feature of the proposals in Minnesota. Speaking of last year's vetoed legislation, Ronald Pollack, executive director of Families U.S.A., a consumer health advocacy group in Washington, said the state went further in trying to change health care insurance than any other state. "Minnesota is not just prohibiting the denial of insurance but is seriously trying to prohibit discriminatory pricing," he said.
The loudest critics of such a plan are insurance companies who say that price controls will send many insurers out of the state and that assigning all residents to the same risk pool regardless of age or health status will make the healthy bear the burden of the sick.
The private insurance lobby proposes a stripped-down benefits package for small businesses, arguing that most uninsured people are not covered because they work for small businesses that cannot afford to insure them.
"The key is to help the Main Street merchants -- the bakery shop, the hardware store, the transmission shop with six to eight employees -- to buy insurance for their workers," said Ralph J. Marlatt, president of the Insurance Federation of Minnesota, a trade group of private insurers.
The pressure for change is strong n a state that has a reputation for social innovation and already has one of the highest insurance participation rates in the country. The state has been a leader in the movement toward health management organizations and 93 percent of Minnesotans carry some type of health insurance, compared with a figure of 86 percent for all of the United States.
But about 370,000 Minnesotans still are without health coverage at any given time. In 1990, 11,000 were denied treatment because they did not carry insurance. And many people with insurance are not adequately covered or cannot afford premiums that sharply outpace inflation and wage increases, legislators and health care experts say.
Legislators say that because the state is already further ahead than most, it should be easier to fill the gap. The main question facing legislators is how to pay for the plan.
The sense of urgency in Minnesota reflects the turns the debate has taken nationally. "We are no longer talking about whether we need a national health-care plan but rather what type is needed," said Dr. Joel Weissman, an instructor in health-care policy at Harvard Medical School. "We are no longer talking about mending the safety net, but rather providing more insurance opportunities for people so they don't fall in the net to begin with."

HEADLINE: New Plans For S.& L.'s And Banks

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Federal regulators are preparing a new strategy of investing in some failing banks and savings and loans rather than taking them over and closing or selling them.
The regulators, whose goal is to find a less expensive way to deal with ailing institutions, are being prodded by a law passed by Congress last year that requires the authorities to step in earlier when lending institutions are troubled. 
 But the plan carries high financial and political risks because it would also bail out the owners of troubled institutions.
"The bottom line is we want to save taxpayers money in a reasonable way and perpetuate rather than liquidate institutions," said John E. Robson, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury. "This is being offered as an alternative to liquidation."
 
High-Level Meetings
 The new approach, to be outlined this week in the Federal Register, was developed in several meetings last week between regulators and top Administration officials.
By investing in weak institutions, the Government hopes to nurse them back to health and make them attractive to buyers. This approach might also ease the nation's tight credit by keeping the banks and savings associations operating and under Government supervision.
When some institutions have been shut or merged, outstanding loans have been called in, and some say that has contributed to tight credit.
 
Rights of Shareholders
 Under the new plan, the Government would get a substantial stake in an institution in return for its investment. Whether the Government would hold voting rights in these companies and how the plan would work is still being discussed, but it is clear that existing shareholders would have the right to decide whether to accept the investment.
A Government investment would dilute the value of existing shareholders' stock, but at the same time would strengthen the company, helping to protect private investments.
The financial risk, some critics say, is that the Government stake in the future of such institutions could ultimately prove more costly than traditional bailouts if the economy slumped further and if already shaky real estate holdings brought down even more banks and savings institutions.
Government protection of shareholders is also expected to encounter sharp political challenges on Capitol Hill and from some Presidential candidates, who might argue that taxpayer money should not be used to protect investors from what may have been their own poor judgment. Other critics might be healthier institutions and those already seized.
But senior regulators say there is already significant momentum for the new approach, which is known as "early resolution assisted mergers." Congress laid the groundwork for the approach when it approved legislation in November directing regulators to intervene more quickly to rescue weak institutions.
The plan is still at least a few weeks from being implemented, with some details to be ironed out. In recent days, an agreement in principle appears to have been reached.
"I think you can now say it's a likely approach," said T. Timothy Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, which oversees savings associations and has advocated the plan for many months. "It will be controversial because anything that is new and at all bold in Washington is controversial, and not without some risk."
 
A Looming Deadline
 Mr. Ryan said the program would be for institutions that "are heading south" but not yet insolvent. He said the regulators were motiviated to adopt the new approach by a looming deadline. They are required to clean up the industry by September 1993, when the cost of the cleanup switches from Treasury borrowings to the savings and loan insurance fund, which is financed by premiums paid by the industry.
While none of the officials planning the new strategy have expressed objections to it, some have privately expressed concerns about the political fallout of rescuing shareholders in an election year. The fear is that some shareholders of troubled institutions could be involved in wrongdoing that contributed to the problems.
Other experts are clearly troubled by the new strategy.
"It's obviously difficult for the regulatory authorities, but their short-run goals are competing with their long-run goals," said James R. Barth, a former Government economist who has written extensively on the bailout and now teaches at Auburn University.
"What they are trying to do is prop up institutions and keep existing credit arrangements intact," he said. "But many people think there are too many banks. How is this supposed to faciliate an exit from the industry if the Government is pumping money into them?"
Variations on the Government investment approach are already being experimented with. Last month, regulators decided to put $1.2 billion of capital into the Crossland Savings Bank of Brooklyn rather than sell or shut it, with the hope that its plight would improve in two to three years and it could be sold. In that case, however, the shareholders lost their investment because the institution was already insolvent when the Government stepped in.
While regulators say the new approach could be applied to scores of institutions that are solvent but ailing, they are looking first to several of the nation's largest savings associations, all in California, that have fallen below the regulatory requirements for adequate capital, the investment cushion used to make up for losses.
These include two big Los Angeles institutions, Glenfed Inc., which has $21 billion in assets, and Calfed Inc., with $19 billion. Another large California savings association in trouble, the Homefed Corporation of San Diego, is not considered a candidate for the program because by some measures it has already become insolvent.
 
Sharing Profit and Risk
 Outlining how the program might work, Mr. Ryan said the Government would provide infusions of capital and give existing stockholders either "hope certificates" or stock warrants that would enable the stockholders to enjoy any profits if the institutions were turned around by allowing them to buy more stock at a lower price. The Government would also share in any upswing and bear the risks of further losses.
"You need to leave the shareholders with some tangible inducement in order to get them to participate," he said.
Mr. Ryan said the new capital would make shaky institutions attractive to prospective buyers, which have preferred to wait until institutions fail and then pay less for them and have their worst loans taken off their books.
 
Hearing Is Planned
 The notice in the Federal Register will give the public 30 days to comment on how such institutions should be selected and the best way to treat the shareholders. Officials are also planning to hold a hearing, but no date has been set.
Officials said the new effort was not intended to resemble the mission of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the agency set up during the Great Depression that spent billions of dollars to prop up some 6,000 banks by buying their stock.
"I don't think anyone here has proposed restarting the R.F.C.," Mr. Robson, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said. "It's not something we're prepared to do."

HEADLINE: Building Jobs Underpaid, Officials Say

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Taking advantage of hard economic times, when many people will work for less pay, a growing number of New York City contractors are slashing their bids to win public works contracts and then paying illegally low wages on public works projects.
The contractors, who are competing for scarce work in a depressed region, avoid losing money on their bids by paying wages that are drastically below prevailing rates, city officials said. 
 In one case under investigation, the officials said, a New York City contractor underpaid more than 100 construction workers, including laborers, steam fitters and carpenters, by $2.5 million. The workers were paid from $10 to $12 an hour, when they should have received $20 to $24 an hour at the prevailing rate, investigators said.
The city declined to name the contractor while the investigation is under way.
State and city labor laws require that wages and health benefits of workers on public construction projects be no less than those provided under local collective-bargaining agreements with unions, even if the workers are nonunion. Contractors who pay wages below prevailing rates can be fined or barred from doing business with the city and state.
 
A Tripling of Complaints
 "These contractors are getting sleazier and sleazier because they know that in this weak economy people will work for close to nothing just to put food on the table," said Rosaria Esperon, New York City's assistant deputy comptroller for claims and adjudications, who is responsible for enforcing wage rules on city contracts.
Last year, the Comptroller received 261 complaints of underpayment, compared with 163 complaints in 1990 and 89 complaints in 1989.
Outside New York City, other areas in the region have also seen a rise in underpayment complaints. Mark Molisani, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Labor, said that in the last year the agency's Public Works Bureau has received a growing number of complaints from asbestos workers who work on public construction projects on Long Island.
To Frank McArdle, managing director of the General Contractors Association, a trade group for the heavy construction industry, "Workers are being mistreated -- forced to do very dangerous work for very little pay."
Some contractors are going to great lengths to hide illegal underpayment. The contractors often pay workers in cash to avoid any record, or they pay full wages by check but require workers to give back a portion in cash, city officials said. In one instance, a contractor paid construction workers half the prevailing rate by requiring two workers to split one paycheck.
Construction workers often feel they have little choice about pay rates.
Simone Peele, a 30-year-old Manhattan construction worker, said that VMT General Construction paid her $8.25 an hour to do rehabilitation work on city buildings in Harlem in 1989. While the prevailing wage for such work was $28.17 an hour, Ms. Peele said she accepted the lower wage because she needed the money.
"I complained to the foreman but he pointed out that I was not in the union and that I was black and that I was a woman and that I should be lucky to have the work," Ms. Peele said. "I felt humiliated and violated but I needed a job."
 
Many Illegal Immigrants
 Ms. Peele and 18 other construction workers have filed a complaint with the city's comptroller, charging VMT with underpayment. Ms. Peele, who is a spokeswoman for the group, said many of the complainants are illegal immigrants from Mexico and Poland who were paid $5 an hour for the work.
A person who would only identify himself as an official with VMT said in a telephone interview that, as a matter of policy, the construction company pays employees who work on city contracts the prevailing union wage and that VMT is cooperating with the Comptroller's investigation.
The city's Comptroller Office has been flooded with so many complaints of underpayment in the last year that its staff has been delayed in investigating them, Ms. Esperon said.
The agency currently has eight people who process the complaints, which take from six to eight months to resolve. A few years ago, before the sharp increase in complaints, the time was three to four months, Ms. Esperon said.
Traditionally, about half of all complaints prove to be valid, Ms. Esperon said, but in the last year about 75 percent of underpayment complaints received have resulted in contractors' losing the city contracts, being fined or being barred from further business with the city.
 
Asbestos Company Cited
 The Comptroller recently found, for example, that the Apex Contracting Company had substantially underpaid employees who worked on contracts to remove asbestos from city buildings in Queens, Staten Island and Brooklyn from 1989 to 1990. The contracts were worth $1.3 million, Ms. Esperon said.
While the prevailing union wage for asbestos removal is $22 an hour, Apex paid its workers between $10 and $16 an hour and refused to give the workers benefits worth an additional $5 an hour, Ms. Esperon said. Several workers filed complaints against Apex, and the Comptroller, after reviewing the company's payroll records, ordered the concern to pay employees $113,000.
A former Apex asbestos worker, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he is an illegal immigrant, said that despite the potential hazards of removing asbestos materials, which can cause lung cancer, he agreed to work for $12 an hour because he has to provide for a wife and four children. "I decided to file a complaint when my wife said to me: 'Honey, you are risking your life to do that work. The least they can do is pay you what you're worth,' " the worker said.
Apex, which has filed for protection from its creditors under the Federal bankruptcy law, has yet to reimburse the employees, the Comptroller's office said. Repeated telephone calls to Apex's offices in Brooklyn duringin the last week were not returned.
Prevailing wage rules have been controversial with many contractors and builders, who maintain that the rules inflate the costs of public projects by millions of dollars because they set an artificially high floor on wages. Still, more than 30 states and the Federal Government have some kind of prevailing wage law.
 
Many Construction Setbacks
 The problem of illegally low wages is only the latest setback for the city's ailing construction industry, which has been racked with unemployment in recent years because of dwindling public and private projects. Union and industry officials estimate that half of New York City's 90,000 construction workers are unemployed.
The construction industry has also been hurt by the city's inability to put major capital spending projects out for bids. As a result, delays have meant the loss of at least 15,000 jobs in the last year, industry officials said.
The city's Environmental Protection Department, for example, failed to let more than $600 million in budgeted contracts last year to repair sewers and water mains. Local economists estimate that the water and sewer contracts could have created 8,000 jobs.
At the same time, industry officials said that Mayor David N. Dinkins's recent proposal to cut the city's capital budget by $3 billion would cost the construction industry from 21,000 to 35,000 jobs in the next four years.
"There are so many unemployed construction workers out there that many people are forced to take whatever work is available at whatever prices," said Mr. McArdle of the contractors association.
Mr. McArdle expressed concern that the city's Comptroller was not doing enough to enforce the prevailing wage rules. He said more investigators and case workers were needed to process the growing number of complaints. "Where's city government when you need it?" he said.
Ms. Esperon of the Comptroller's Office said that the agency's budget was limited, and that it could not afford to hire more case workers and investigators to look into underpayment complaints.

HEADLINE: From L.I. Teller Machines to Gas Stations, Suburban Robberies Are on the Rise

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Feb. 14

 BODY:
When Kevin Dowd peered over his shoulder and saw the dull gray glint of an automatic pistol, his fingers began to tremble.
He had been standing at an automatic teller machine, withdrawing $100, when two youths buzzed themselves in behind him. It was 8 P.M. 
 "What about it," one youth said and pointed the gun. Mr. Dowd began thinking of his wife, Lorinne, and his year-and-a-half-old son, Chris, and wondered whether he would ever see them again.
But in a moment it was over. The youths took Mr. Dowd's cash and ran to a waiting car. And when he was safe once more, what struck Mr. Dowd was that the most terrifying instant of his 34 years occurred not on the mean streets of New York City but on a genteel village shopping strip in a placid suburban neighborhood where his family had lived for a quarter of a century.
A mugging in the city is still far more likely than a robbery in the suburbs. But while the number of robberies is on the decline in the city, suburban robberies -- from gas station holdups to purse snatchings to armed thefts of luxury cars -- are on the rise, in some cases to record levels.
And the rise in suburban robberies -- a pattern seen in the last year across the New York metropolitan area and around the country -- is raising concerns by criminologists and victims alike of a creeping urbanization of life in the suburbs as big-city problems, as well as city criminals, follow the middle class to the suburbs.
During the first 11 months of 1991, the number of robberies reported in New York City, which had ranked first in robberies among the nation's large cities, fell by 1.6 percent, compared with the year before.
But across the city line, the number of reported robberies last year showed a rise of 17 percent in figures covering most of Long Island, where the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, regularly decries the "New York Citification" of suburbia by city "thugs and hoodlums."
In New Jersey, the state police reported a 5.6 percent decrease in robberies in urban areas and a 10 percent increase in suburban areas. Robbery is the crime most closely watched by many criminologists because it usually involves what people fear most about crime -- sudden violent attack by a stranger.
 
'No One Feels Safe'
 "No one feels safe anymore," said Jeannette Caccavale as she shopped on Rockaway Avenue in Valley Stream, across the street from the Home Federal Savings Bank, where Mr. Dowd was robbed. "The suburbs aren't what they used to be."
After 34 years in the neighborhood, Mrs. Caccavale said, she now thinks twice before going to the local mall alone and spends much of her afternoon chauffeuring her grandchildren to places her own children felt safe enough to walk to on their own.
In Nassau County, where the police recorded 1,762 robberies last year, a record, the use of guns in robberies has been rising sharply for several years. Last year shots were fired in 44 Nassau robberies, almost double the number the year before. In areas covered by the Suffolk County Police Department, 1,571 robberies were recorded last year.
Detective Sgt. Michael Fleming, commander of the county robbery squad, said: "I don't think any community is as safe as it used to be, and we are no exception. But by and large we are a safe community comparatively speaking, and I think the criminals stand a very good chance of being caught, convicted and heavily sentenced."
The pattern in Nassau County first surfaced in October, when the Federal Bureau of Investigation released crime statistics for the first six months of 1991. These showed an increase of 6 percent in robberies in large cities and a 13 percent increase in suburban areas.
In New Jersey, state police figures from the same period showed a decline in urban areas and an increase in suburban areas. While New Jersey counties often include a mix of urban and suburban areas, Essex County, a predominantly urban county that includes Newark, reported a 10.5 percent drop in robberies, while Middlesex County, a predominantly suburban area, reported a 15.3 percent rise.
Planners and criminologists attribute the increase to the spread of urban ills like drug addiction, which has taken hold in the suburbs, coupled with a deep local recession that weakens the social fabric and makes the wealthy suburbs attractive prey for city criminals.
"It's like what Willie Sutton, the great sage of American criminality, once observed when asked why he robbed banks," said Lee Koppleman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "That's where the money is."
Richard H. Girgenti, the New York State Director of Criminal Justice, said interpreting a one- or two-year trend is often difficult. But he said crime patterns in the suburbs tended to follow by a year or two similar patterns in the city.
A plateauing or small decline in crack use in New York City might be responsible for the drop in robberies there, he said, a decline that has not yet been felt in drug cultures in the suburbs. Eventually the suburban crime rate might fall as well, he said.
But he also said that the tough economic times might be bringing more city criminals to the suburbs. According to the Nassau County police, 65 percent of the suspects arrested by the county's robbery squad lived in New York City.
Thomas A. Reppetto, the president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a private New York group that monitors crime and law enforcement, said that while the differences in crime rates between the city and the suburbs were shrinking, "the suburbs are nowhere near as dangerous as the central cities are."
In 1990, he said, a New York City resident was more than 10 times as likely to be a victim of a robbery than a Long Islander, and six times more likely than a resident of Westchester County. Nationwide, a city dweller was almost eight times more likely to be robbed than a suburbanite.
"If New York City had the murder rate of Nassau and Suffolk, we would declare a civic holiday," he said. "The suburbs are beginning to get a little more like the city, but by no means are they like our great cities."
A day after he was robbed last week, Mr. Dowd, an assistant branch manager at a Manhattan stock brokerage firm, stayed home, at his white frame house in Lynbrook, to take care of his son Chris, putter about the house and brood a bit over what happened.
He had stopped by the bank on his way home from the Valley Stream station to pick up some cash. It was not late at night, and he had not given security a second thought. Then he saw the gun and heard a voice tell him to face the cash machine and not turn around.
 
A Security Camera
 Mr. Dowd knew that a security camera was built into the machine, and he moved slightly to one side so the camera could record the faces of the robbers behind him. When they ran out of the bank lobby, he ran after them, not knowing quite why, and saw them jump into a small dark sedan and drive away.
"I'm shaking and not as mad as I thought I would be," he said. "Living so close to the city you hear about drug problems and crime rising and things like that. You hear it happening all around you, but you never think it would happen here."
Suddenly he began to worry about safety and pay attention to some of the signs of decline in the neighborhood -- graffiti near the Valley Stream train station, shoplifting at lthe mall -- and listen more closely to relatives who are urging him to move out to the East End of Long Island, far from the city.
He began to wonder why he did not see more police officers patrolling Rockaway Avenue -- at a time when county budget cuts were forcing reductions in the number of county police officers.
"I used to get that warm cozy feeling coming home," he said. "Now I feel it is not as safe."

HEADLINE: Despite Pact, 2 Yale Unions Go On Strike

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Classes were canceled, library hours curtailed and dining halls closed today after two unions and a group representing 1,300 graduate students at Yale University went on strike to force the university to bargain with the graduate students.
It was an odd alliance, since the unions had reached a settlement with the university on new contracts at 7 A.M. today, and the graduate-student organization is not a recognized union. 
 But officials of the unions, which represent 3,600 clerical, technical, maintenance and cafeteria workers, had said they would strike through Wednesday in a show of sympathy for the graduate students represented by the Graduate Employees and Students Organization, who complain of low wages, lack of representation and other problems with the university.
The strike had loomed for weeks. The 2,200 graduate students at Yale, like those at many other universities, often seek work as teaching assistants in undergraduate courses as a way of meeting their tuition costs.
The custom creates a mutually dependent relationship for professors, undergraduates and the graduate students, said a professor of English, Hazel Carby, who was circulating a faculty letter today that called on Yale to recognize the graduate-student group. "They're indispensable to our teaching," Dr. Carby said.
Yale officials have said repeatedly that they will not recognize the graduate students' organization as a bargaining unit, although the group is welcome to join regularly scheduled issue-related talks that are to resume on Tuesday.
"We do not regard collective bargaining as the proper relationship between an academic institution and its students," Yale's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., said at a news conference this afternoon.
A noon rally on Beinecke Plaza attracted several hundred protesters, chanting slogans like "Yale, Yale, negotiate/You're becoming second-rate!" Many wore buttons signifying their membership in the unions and wore protest placards across their chests.
Gordon Lafer, a spokesman for the graduate-student group, said 75 percent of teaching assistants canceled their classes or moved them off-campus today to honor the picket lines.
 
'We're One for All'
 Martha K. Matzke, a university spokeswoman, said about 70 percent of clerical and technical workers reported for work today, and 25.37 percent of maintenance and cafeteria workers did so.
Some union members said they were surprised to find themselves on picket lines shortly after hearing there was a new contract.
Others were more supportive. "We're one for all and all for one," said Hattie Minor, an administrative assistant in the department of epidemiology and public health. "They supported us, and I wish them well."
Many undergraduates watched the rally from the sidelines.
 
'Immature and Selfish'
 "I'm not sure I completely agree with the stoppage of teaching," said a freshman, Stephen Chang, whose English 120 class, normally taught by a graduate student, was canceled today. He said he was sympathetic to many of the demands from the graduate students, but added,"If it goes beyond this week, I might begin to lose sympathy for them."
Douglas Beck, a senior, opposed the strike, saying: "It's immature and selfish for the graduate students who are looking toward a Ph.D. that's going to take them to some sort of lucrative profession to expect Yale workers to lose three days of wages, in the middle of February, in the middle of a recession.
"I agree that graduate students are treated very poorly at Yale, but I don't think forcing others to go out on strike is the way to go."
The last major strike at Yale occurred in 1984, when dining hall workers left their jobs for 10 weeks.

Students and workers rallied on the campus. (Gale Zucker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Democrats' Tax Plan Under Attack

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
The Bush Administration attacked the House Democrats' tax bill today as a bad deal for the middle class that would bring them "25 cents a day for two years" in exchange for cuts in Medicare, farm subsidies and veterans' benefits and, eventually, tax increases.
In an interview, Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, amplified the attacks President Bush has made in recent days on the Democratic measure, which is destined for a House vote next week. 
 Democrats argue that a temporary two-year tax credit of up to $400 a year for families, paid for by permanent higher taxes on individuals with taxable incomes of $85,000 and up, would result in higher taxes for only the top 1 percent of all taxpayers.
But Mr. Darman contended there would inevitably be pressure to extend the tax cut beyond two years, even though it would have little value to recipients. Each member of a family of four would be getting only about 25 cents a day, he said.
 
'The Heart of the Middle Class'
 While House Democrats have maintained they want only a two-year bill as a way to help stimulate the economy. The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said Sunday on the NBC television program "John McLaughlin's One on One" that he felt any tax credit given to the middle class should be permanent.
After two years, Mr. Darman predicted, the Democrats would extend the reach of the 35 percent maximum tax rate proposed for individuals with $85,000 of taxable income and couples at $145,000. "It will take them another nanosecond," he said, to reduce the $85,000 minimum "right toward the heart of the middle class."
Mr. Darman said the Democratic measure would necessitate cuts in other domestic programs because it would break the 1990 budget agreement by failing to raise as much money as it paid out in each of the first two years. Democrats do not disagree, but they say that the plan is acceptable because it would balance out over six years.
Besides, the Democrats say, without accounting tricks the Bush Administration's proposals for a large capital gains cut and accelerated depreciation for business investments would also create an imbalance.
The dispute is another example of the opening long-range fire that attends the tax and growth debate in its early Congressional stages, where each side is looking at least as much for winning political arguments as for legislative solutions.
No one, in fact, expects the House Democrat's measure to become law as now written, even if it passes in the House, which is not a certainty. Some degree of compromise with the Bush Administration, and with the Senate, await the measure if any of its provisions are to end up in the tax code. The Senate Finance Committee is scheduled to begin writing its version of the measure on Feb. 25.
But ultimately, the budget director has the last word in the accounting judgments of whether the terms of the 1990 budget act are met, and Mr. Darman said the Democratic bill "would trigger a very large sequester -- 27 to 30 billion."
A sequester requires offsetting spending cuts. The cuts "would have to come from entitlement programs, excluding Social Security," he said. "They would come principally from Medicare, from farm payments, from veterans, from student loans."
Mr. Darman also criticized the one percentage point corporate tax cut in the Democratic proposal, saying he doubted that one economist in a hundred would consider that an effective way "to stimulate jobs and growth."
Most economists, he said, would prefer either a tax credit for business investment, or the type of accelerated depreciation for new business investment that the Administration has proposed.
Democrats have argued that investment credits cut unevenly between industries and companies within industries, and distort rational economic thinking. Cutting the maximum corporate rate from 34 to 33 percent and the corporate alternate minimum tax from 20 to 19 percent, they maintain, gives all businesses some benefit.
Mr. Darman argued that the Administration's investment proposal and another proposed measure that the Democrats have rejected, a $5,000 tax credit for first-time home buyers, would "accelerate purchases" and stimulate the economy.
He also criticized the Democrats' proposal for taxes on capital gains, which would index such gains for inflation. He said the approach was not as likely to stimulate investment in high-growth industries as the Administration's proposal to make 40 percent of any capital gain exempt from taxation.
Mr. Darman said, moreover, that by accepting a capital gains cut that was anything more than trivial in scope, the Democrats "are abandoning their so-called issue of principle."
"They have decided, in their terms, to favor the rich," he said.
Democrats argue that their plan has a targeted, even more generous approach intended to encourage investment in small business. Indexing for inflation is only fair, sound tax policy, they say, to make sure that people are not taxed simply because of inflation that does not represent income. Mr. Darman acknowledged that indexing was "desirable."
Still, he ridiculed the bill as a whole: "The middle class gets a chance to get 25 cents a day for two years in exchange for Medicare cuts, student loan cuts, farm payment cuts, fewer jobs and eventually higher taxes. This is not a good deal."

HEADLINE: Saudis Are Close to Deal for Big Part of Fina

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
A group of private Saudi investors is close to an agreement to buy half of the refining and marketing system of Fina Inc., including 2 Texas refineries and 500 gasoline stations, for more than $500 million.
The refineries are in Port Arthur and Big Spring, with a capacity of more than 200,000 barrels a day. The gas stations, about 200 of them owned and the rest franchised, are in Texas and Minnesota. 
 If the deal is completed, it will be the first big Saudi investment in the American refining and marketing industry since Texaco Inc. and the Saudi national oil company, Saudi Aramco, announced in June 1988 that the Saudis would buy half of Texaco's refining and marketing network in 23 Eastern and Gulf Coast states. That deal, for which the Saudis paid $812 million in cash and an additional amount in oil that Texaco said was worth $1 billion, covered 3 refineries, 49 terminals and 1,450 service stations bearing the Texaco name.
Experts said the Texaco deal, like the proposed sale by Fina, gives the Saudis a hedge in oil profits, which sometimes come from producing oil and sometimes from refining and selling it, and provides a more secure outlet for Saudi oil. During oil shortages, the deal would increase the security of consumers because the jointly owned American refineries would have first call on oil supplies.
Fina, based in Dallas, issued a statement yesterday confirming its talks with the Arabian Petroleum Company, the private Saudi group, whose main shareholder is Delta International, an investment group based in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, with offices in Dallas and Vienna, Va. Fina is 85 percent owned by Petrofina S.A., based in Brussels. The deal apparently would not include Fina's petroleum reserves or its chemical division.
"At this time, it is premature to say when conclusion of the negotiations can be anticipated," the statement said. But a Saudi executive involved in the proposed deal, who refused to be identified, said the transaction was "close to confirmation."
Fina's headquarters was closed yesterday. Attempts to reach the company's public relations officials were unsuccessful.
The talks were reported yesterday in Petroleum Intelligence Weekly and Middle Eastern Economic Survey, prompting the Fina statement.
The proposed investment comes at at time of uncertainty for the American refiners because of progressively stricter specifications on gasoline required by the Clean Air Act and a crackdown on refinery emissions.
 
Big Costs Ahead
 "It doesn't surprise me that Petrofina would want to sell," said William Randol, an oil analyst at First Boston. "The industry is facing huge capital expenditures for reformulated gasoline." He predicted that refiners would have negative cash flow for the next few years.
Buying a refinery would be unattractive for the Saudis, he said, "unless they just think it's a nifty way to tie up a place for their crude."
Some experts say that in the next few years the refineries will have to spend $1,000 on average for each barrel of capacity to meet the new requirements. But analysts say the refineries that survive, probably the most modern, may prosper in years to come because they will face less competition. Fina spent heavily on its two refineries in recent years.
The Saudi executive said the deal would have the tacit approval of the Saudi Government because it would conform to the Saudi's long-term goal of providing outlets for their crude.
"Obviously, an international company with access to crude in Saudi Arabia and access to gas stations in Texas and Minnesota is a company that will support maintaining supply," the Saudi executive said.
Any deal would come with a crude-oil supply contract, ostensibly offering oil at the same price that other buyers receive. But experts in the field say that crude-oil supply contracts to companies partly owned by the supplier often offer price guarantees or other breaks that lower the risk to the refiner.
Separate from the joint venture with Fina, Arabian Petroleum is considering building a plant in Saudi Arabia that would make methyl tertiary-butyl ether, a gasoline additive that can be used to meet the Clean Air Act requirement for higher oxygen content in fuel. The additive, which is made from petrochemicals, could be sold on the open market or supplied to the joint venture with Fina.

HEADLINE: It's Al vs. Mario, and Truce Is Off for a Day

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Vying over one microphone, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato went head to head yesterday in a spontaneous debate that was more like a verbal prizefight than the usual political discourse.
A surprised audience at the annual meeting of the Association of Towns of the State of New York joined the fray, hooting, hollering and jeering, as "Al" and Mario" -- as they oh-so-sarcastically called each other -- clashed over government spending policies. 
 "It was kind of explosive," said Michael Erlandson, the town clerk of Ellicott. "A couple of women said they thought they might have come to blows."
It wasn't New Hampshire, where Mr. Cuomo's supporters are waging a write-in campaign to draft him for president. It wasn't Harvard University, where Mr. Cuomo spoke recently so close to the New Hampshire media market. But it was very New York, with the state's leading Democrat and Republican -- whose one-time informal non-aggression pact has frayed in recent months -- going at each other with the politesse of two cabdrivers who had just crunched fenders .
The brief confrontation occurred in front of nearly 2,000 town officials gathered at the New York Hilton for an annual meeting and training session, usually devoted to rather dry subjects like tax assessment or solid waste management. Mr. Cuomo, Mr. D'Amato and Democratic Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan were all scheduled to give consecutive welcoming speeches.
 
No Holds Barred
 The fight for the microphone started as Mr. Cuomo took exception to the earlier remarks of Mr. D'Amato, a Republican. As the Governor spoke, the Senator marched up to the microphone, the audience gasping and laughing. "I'm delighted to be here," the Senator said, interrupting Mr. Cuomo. He added, "Anytime the Governor finishes his speech and wants to give me ----."
"I'm finished," Mr. Cuomo interrupted.
"Are you really finished?" Mr. D'Amato shot back.
Then it was no holds barred: two politicians literally grabbing for a common mike, and a common audience. Mr. D'Amato rolled his eyes and shook his head as the Governor spoke. Mr. Cuomo kept his hand wrapped around the Senator's shoulder. Gestures flew. Organizers seemed confused.
"It was so spontaneous and unexpected, our officers all started getting up because they didn't know what to do," said Patricia M. Walsh, the association's manager of education and training. "Our president was trying to get close to the mike but couldn't because the two of them were at the mike. We just backed off."
 
'A Really Good Discussion'
 Mr. D'Amato drew cheers as he said: "At the Federal level and at the state level we've got to cap spending. We've got to make workfare and not welfare and we've got to cut the fat out of the bureaucracy . . ." As the Governor attempted to get the mike back, he shouted, "Mario, I thought you were done!"
Mr. Cuomo moved in. "Let's have a really good discussion," he said. "O.K., you suggested you would like to cut federal spending ----."
"No. Cap. Cap. CAP the spending," the Senator retorted.
"Does that mean, Al, that you will not give us any more help than you're now giving us at the state and local level?" the Governor asked.
"Mario, it means that across the board we can't say cut spending but don't cut my favorite program, because that's what we've been doing," the Senator replied.
"No, no you didn't answer me," Mr. Cuomo insisted. "When you say cap, that means you're not going to give the state or the locals any more money?" Then his voice slowed down for emphasis: "Are you also going to cap the aid to foreign governments? Just tell us clearly." This parry brought the Governor his own round of cheers.
 
Rave Reviews
 At another point the Governor chastised his audience for approving Mr. D'Amato's cry of "workfare, not welfare."
"Of course, you cheer. You're not on welfare," he told the audience.
Together, the two debated welfare spending, the Federal deficit, recession, bureaucracy. Then Mr. Cuomo left the hall and spoke of his regrets that he was not competing in the Democratic presidential primary in New Hampshire. "If I had a budget I would be running," he said. "It's as simple as that."
For years Mr. Cuomo and Mr. D'Amato have maintained close ties despite their partisan differences. But their relationship took a decided turn for the worse over the past few months as the Governor considered whether to seek the presidency and the Senator geared up for his own re-election campaign.
Yesterday, the audience enjoyed the show. "I haven't seen anything even closely resembling it," Ms. Walsh said.

HEADLINE: U.S.-CANADA RIFTS GROW OVER TRADE

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Despite a three-year-old free-trade agreement, the United States and Canada are headed into a new phase of confrontation, accusing each other of protectionist ways. The battlefield is beer, lumber and automobiles.
Even as the neighbors negotiate with Mexico about expanding the agreement to include all of North America, the tensions are growing, heightened by political sensitivity about jobs lost through imports. The lingering economic slumps and approaching elections in both Canada and the United States add more pressure. 
 Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has complained, "We're getting sideswiped by American Japan-bashing." He has also said Washington is playing "low-level politics."
One Canadian fear is that in response to complaints in Washington, Japan will shift to the United States investments it intended for Canada.
But for all the recent tough talk, most trade analysts still expect the free-trade agreement to hold, even though either side can end it with six months' notice. Trade between the two countries was $200 billion last year, the greatest volume between any two countries, and many economists say the trade accord has been an important factor in increasing trade. They also say the pact has been beneficial to both sides.
Canadians are troubled by what they see as continued American trade harassment -- complaints motivated by domestic politics -- when they thought they had bought an era of peace under a trade agreement that would end all barriers by 2000.
Mr. Mulroney, whose Conservative Government is still fending off opposition charges that the free-trade agreement has not been good for Canada, has long argued that his special relationship with President Ronald Reagan and then with President Bush would safeguard fair play by the United States.
 
Using Tough Language
 Now he is using tough language to criticize Washington. After the United States Customs Service ruled earlier this month that Hondas made in Canada were subject to a special duty, Mr. Mulroney promised a "shin-kicking campaign" to get the ruling reversed.
Simon Reisman, the man Mr. Mulroney appointed to lead the Canadian free-trade negotiating team, said recently: "The Americans are bastards. They're behaving like real thugs these days in protecting their interests."
Mr. Reisman, now a private consultant, has long been critical of American trade policy, but his blunt outburst, made in a newspaper interview here and widely reprinted in the Canadian press, underscores Canada's feelings of resentment.
The auto dispute began with a Customs Service complaint that Honda Civics assembled in Alliston, Ontario, lacked the required 50 percent content of parts made in North America to qualify for duty-free export to the United States.
A preliminary ruling now subjects those cars to a 2.5 percent import duty. The Alliston plant makes about 105,000 cars a year, of which 75 percent are exported to the United States.
In the Canadian view, Washington is signaling that if the Japanese want to avoid such harassment in the future, they should build their Hondas in the United States.
The Bush Administration has also threatened to impose punitive duties on Canadian beer.
The Stroh Brewery Company and the G. Heileman Brewing Company brought a formal complaint against Canada that led to findings against Canadian beer-selling practices by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the organization of more than 100 nations that oversees world trade.
 
Punitive Duties Planned
 Armed with a GATT report citing Canadian limits on outlets where imported beer can be sold and the imposition of higher costs and markups for imports, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, sent a notice to the Federal Register a few days after Christmas that the Administration intended to impose punitive duties on Canadian beer by April 10.
But Ottawa has a countercomplaint pending at GATT, asserting that beer distribution laws in some states and some Federal and state taxes unfairly curb Canadian beer sales in the United States.
The Canadians say the tax credits that many states offer companies, based on annual production of beer in the state, discriminate against them. The Anheuser-Busch Companies, controlling nearly half the beer market in the United States, for example, gets $21 million of annual tax savings from a brewery in Columbus, Ohio, the Canadians complained to GATT.
Canadian beer executives say a GATT panel has now ruled in favor of the Canadians. The ruling has not been made public, and officials of GATT and of the United States and Canada have declined to comment. If the reports are true, it would be the first time that American state laws were found in violation of international trade laws.
 
Lumber in Dispute
 Another dispute involves lumber, with the United States complaining that Canadian producers get unfair subsidies through low tree-cutting fees on Government land, even though the fees were completely altered after earlier American complaints.
Washington has already begun a regulatory investigation that could result in duties of up to 15 percent on Canadian lumber. Ottawa has reacted angrily and taken its case to the GATT watchdogs in Geneva.
Administration officials stoutly deny that they are waging any campaign of harassment against Canada. They agree that there are some problem trade sectors but stress that the bulk of the huge trade is untroubled.
"Our view is that the U.S. is observing the letter and the spirit of the free-trade agreement," said an American official, who insisted on anonymity. "We are, of course, defending U.S. interests in the context of U.S. trade laws, but perceived disparities are being investigated under the normal process of U.S. law."
During a recent visit to Washington, Canada's Minister of External Affairs, Barbara McDougall, said she had taken up Canadian complaints with the State Department and had served notice that Canada would retaliate "by using exactly the same tools they are using."
In both countries, it is illegal for imported goods to be sold below the cost of production or home-market prices, a practice known as dumping. Punitive duties may be assessed against foreign companies found to violate these rules.
The United States has traditionally applied antidumping laws very aggressively against Canada and other countries. Yet Canada's International Trade Tribunal found in October that Heileman, Stroh and the Pabst Brewing Company were dumping in British Columbia, causing Canadian brewers to suffer losses.
Lawyers for the American companies said they intended to challenge that finding, which lifts the price of American six-packs in British Columbia by $1.
Canada's tit-for-tat strategy both through GATT and the use of its own dumping law could hasten a settlement in the beer dispute, many analysts here think, or at least cause the United States to defer its planned April 10 retaliation.
 
Consumers May Benefit
 "Once the two GATT panels have ruled," said Mike Palmer, an analyst at Sanwa McCarthy Securities, "the general view is that the two countries will hammer out some kind of agreement."
This could be good for consumers in both countries. Beer prices have farthest to fall in Canada, where, because of provincial selling restrictions and other forms of protection, as well as generally higher alcoholic-beverage taxes, prices are nearly twice as high as in the United States.
One reason for the higher Canadian prices is a ban on selling beer in a province if the beer is not produced in the province. Moosehead beer, for example, brewed in New Brunswick, is available throughout the United States but not in Ontario.
"No Canadian brewer will deny that the market has to open up here," said Barry Joslin, senior vice president of Molson Breweries, Canada's leading beer company. "But we need a little time."

3-Way Meeting Starts
DALLAS, Feb. 17 (Reuters) -- Negotiators from the United States, Canada and Mexico have begun their biggest push yet to finish a North American free trade agreement. For the first time since the countries started serious talks in June, the chief negotiators and their 19 subgroups that concentrate on specific issues are meeting in the same place for a week.
 Their chief task in the meeting that began today is to resolve several hundred disputes they wrote into a first draft of the pact last month.
 "The environment is excellent," said the top United States negotiator, Julius Katz, the deputy trade representative. "But I have to say frankly I don't think we will have resolved all of the issues by the end of the week."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Study Shakes Confidence In the Volatile-Stock Theory

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
One of the most enduring ideas of modern finance is facing its most serious challenge. Two scholars of finance say they have disproved the theory, common among investors, that stocks more volatile than the market as a whole are the best performers.
Eugene F. Fama and Kenneth R. French, business professors at the University of Chicago, traced the performance of thousands of stocks over 50 years but found no link between relative volatility and long-term returns. The many investors who try to beat the market by buying widely swinging issues are misguided, they say. 
The importance of "beta," the investment community's term for a stock's volatility relative to the market, has long been under challenge. But it is still closely watched by analysts, and business students are still taught that they can earn higher returns by buying stocks whose swings are wider than the market's.
"The fact is," Professor Fama said in a recent telephone interview, "beta as the sole variable explaining returns on stocks is dead."
Some still favor relatively volatile stocks, among them William F. Sharpe, a retired Stanford University professor who won the 1990 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for theories based on beta. "It is a remarkable set of empirical results about what happened in the past," he said of the University of Chicago study. "But I am not willing to make investment decisions based on the theory that there is no relationship between beta, properly measured, and expected returns."
If Professors Fama and French are right, however, the impact could be far reaching. Some highly volatile groups of stocks that have enjoyed wide followings -- airlines, for example -- could lose a portion of their appeal if beta-believing investors side with the professors.
Additionally, many executives of publicly held companies have taken the view that if their own company's stock is more volatile than the market as a whole, any project they invest in -- from a lowly piece of new equipment to a huge joint venture -- must generate an extra high return to compensate investors for swings in the stock's price and earnings. The professors' work could force many companies to rethink the way they approach capital spending, finance scholars say.
Finally, many publicly held utilities have used beta to justify rate requests. They figure the returns that investors demand, given their companies' betas, and develop rate structures that allow them to earn these returns. But recognizing that their low betas tend to argue against large rate increases, a growing number of utilities had already turned to other approaches. More will probably do so if the research of Professors Fama and French gains currency.
And if investors decide to quit following betas, other theories of market behavior are likely to gain influence. "What we are really taking about is opening the floodgates to a whole new generation of research into what truly drives stock prices," said Anthony B. Sanders, an Ohio State University professor of finance who is currently a visiting professor at the University of Chicago. "Once you hammer a model like the old one closed, you generate all sorts of additional academic interest."
Professor Fama has already won worldwide recognition for his efficient-markets theory -- the notion that because investors all have essentially the same information it is impossible to consistently earn returns greater than those justified by the risks.
Professor Sharpe used Professor Fama's theory as an assumption to develop the capital-asset pricing model, which links returns to risk, as measured by beta.
Professor Sharpe says that a diversified portfolio can reduce the risks peculiar to individual companies -- that General Motors stock, for example, will be hurt by a strike. Investors, therefore, earn no rewards for bearing this risk, according to the Sharpe theory.
But investors do earn higher returns for bearing the other type of risk, known as market risk, Professor Sharpe says. This risk, which remains even after an investor diversifies, depends on how much an individual stock is dragged up or down by the market as a whole. Stocks like that of the biotechnology company Genentech, which have betas of more than 1.0, are more volatile than the market, while stocks like that of the power company Consolidated Edison, which have betas of less than 1.0, are calmer than the market.
To calculate market risk, or beta, finance professionals compare changes in the prices of individual stocks with changes in market indicators like the Standard & Poor's 500- stock index. Professor Sharpe and his followers say that in general, the higher a stock's beta, or volatility relative to the market, the greater its long-term returns.
Professors Fama and French disagree. Their paper, just published by the University of Chicago's Center for Research in Security Prices, says that long-term returns depend not on beta, but on company size and price-to-book ratios. Smaller companies, as measured by the market value of their shares, and those with low prices relative to their book values have in fact outperformed the market, they say.
The professors theorize that investors view smaller companies as more vulnerable to economic downturns and therefore demand higher returns. They also say that low price-to-book ratios typically reflect financial problems, another reason for investors to demand higher returns.
Professors Fama and French are by no means the first to fire an intellectual salvo at the capital-asset pricing model. Since Professor Sharpe developed the model in the early 1960's, a broad array of rival theories has emerged to explain stock price movements: the January effect, which says that stocks usually gain at the beginning of the year, to the weekend effect, which says stocks generally perform poorly on Mondays. Most recently, the arbitrage pricing theory says that stocks are driven by powerful economywide forces like unanticipated inflation and spikes in interest rates.
But finance experts say that Professors Fama and French have presented the most conclusive evidence against beta.
"What they have proven fairly rigorously is what other academics have been talking about for some time," said Richard Roll, a finance professor at the University of California at Los Angeles, who with others developed the arbitrage pricing theory.

HEADLINE: For Farmers, a Boom in Blooms

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST GREENBUSH, N.Y., Feb. 14

 BODY:
At Becker's Farm here, flowers, house plants and seedlings fill five greenhouses, with red and pink geraniums flourishing in the 80-degree moist heat. Outside, a new parking lot has been completed and a new greenhouse is under construction.
Becker's Farm is part of the fastest-growing segment of agriculture in New York and the Northeast -- supplying trees, shrubs, plants and flowers for homeowners. 
 "In the Northeast, it's the only segment of agriculture that is growing, and it is growing by leaps and bounds," said Dr. Carl F. Gortzig, professor of horticulture at the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at Cornell University in Ithaca.
In New York, greenhouses and nurseries are the second biggest cash producers for the state's farmers, behind the state's dairy industry. But they are the largest segment of agriculture in New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island.
With $343 million in farm income from nursery and greenhouse products, New York ranked fourth in the nation in 1990, behind California, Florida and Texas, according to Federal statistics. New Jersey was 10th, with sales of $227 million and Connecticut far down on the list, with sales of $134 million.
 
New Houses Need New Trees
 The nurseries grow trees and shrubs outdoors for planting outdoors. Greenhouses, which occupy much less space, produce potted plants for hanging in homes as well as seedlings of flowers and vegetables for home gardeners.
The United States Department of Agriculture reported a combined national farm income of $8.1 billion in 1990 from growing trees, shrubs and plants, up 11 percent from $7.3 billion the year before. The figures for 1991 are not yet available.
The major reason for the growth of the industry is that the sales of nursery and greenhouse products are tied directly to housing starts, which boomed in the 1970's and 1980's, according to Dr. George J. Wustler, specialist in floriculture at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J.
In addition, the environmental movement has brought about a renewed interest in planting trees by both individuals and corporations, and supermarkets are selling large numbers of potted plants and cut flowers.
"There is a strong link in the sale of plants through landscaping architects to new offices and corporate headquarters," Dr. Gortzig said. "Today, any business instead of paving up to its front door is landscaping to give it an environmental image."
The current recession has affected the nursery business more than greenhouses, said Dan O. Barnhart, executive director of the New York State Nursery and Landscape Association. Because of the drop in housing starts and a consequent decrease in planting of trees and shrubs, he estimated that nursery sales might be down as much as 17 percent last year and so far this year.
But greenhouse sales have proved to be more immune to the economic downturn, experts said, because people continue to buy plants and flowers on holidays and other occasions and to work in their home gardens.
"Oddly enough, it seems that when times are difficult, people find flowers an attractive but modestly priced product," Dr. Wustler said.
Despite the economic cycles, more young people are entering the nursery and greenhouse business, said Robert Mungari, director of the Plant Industry Division of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.
He reported 2,729 wholesale growers and 5,016 retail sales outlets in New York State, up slightly from last year.
Becker's Farm here is an example of the changes new young farmers can bring. The business is on 82 acres on Routes 9 and 20, a major four-lane highway, surrounded by shopping centers, restaurants, motels, shops and a few residences here in one of a rapidly growing area of Rensselaer County, four miles southeast of Albany. It is operated by David Becker and his wife, Karen, and his father, Frank Becker Jr., and his wife, Cynthia.
It was started as an apple orchard by the David Becker's great-grandfather, but converted into a greenhouse operation by his father.
At the age of 37, David Becker returned to the farm in 1990 with his wife after working for 17 years as a manager of various Agway farm supply stores upstate. "Being self-employed attracted me the most," he said.
The Beckers immediately began to expand and make plans to stay open all year. They converted the old cold-room where apples were once stored into a germination room where plants are grown from seeds under fluorescent lights.
Last year, they sold 7,500 geranium plants; this year they have planted 12,500.
Now, in mid-February, they are growing 50 varieties of house plants in pots, as many varieties of bedding plants for gardens, herbs and vegetable seedlings like tomato, pepper and cucumber. They also plan to sell fruit and vegetables, seeds, fertilizer and other garden supplies.
At this time of year, all the Beckers are busy inside the greenhouses, putting soil in pots, planting seeds, transplanting seedlings, hanging potted plants and labeling the plants in preparation for opening day.
Looking up as she sorted boxes of labels for the plants in one of the greenhouses, Cynthia Becker said, "It's always springtime here."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Becker potting geraniums at Becker's Farm in East Greenbush, N.Y. His family-owned operation is part of the fastest-growing segment of agriculture in New York and the Northeast -- supplying trees, shrubs, plants and flowers for homeowners. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Analysts Fear That 1992 May Turn Out Like '91

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Despite recent indications of economic revival, signs that have helped to push long-term interest rates to their highest level in nearly three months, many credit market analysts continue to question whether any kind of expansion can be sustained.
Indeed, they say the risks remain great that the economy's performance in 1992 will prove little different from the recession-like pace of activity in the year just past. 
 "There is plenty of reason to think that 1992 could turn out to be a repetition of 1991," said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International.
 
A Number of Parallels
 As they did a year ago, expectations of an incipient recovery are pushing up interest rates, Mr. Resler said, and money growth, more often than not a good harbinger of economic trends, has been expanding at a very healthy clip.
But the consumer is not in much better shape this year than last, Mr. Resler argued. The size of the labor force continues to contract, and incomes remain under pressure. For those reasons, confidence remains at close to historically low levels.
"We have been here before, most recently last summer," Mr. Resler said, adding that unless long-term interest rates fall fairly significantly from just under 8 percent currently, the odds of 1992 turning out to be little different from 1991 are close to 50-50.
 
Sputtering Housing Market
 Before they began to rise again in mid-January, interest rates, which declined in 1991, especially in the fourth quarter, had provided a modest stimulus to the residential housing market. But developments in the credit markets that have taken place over the last six weeks or so are slowly choking off that demand.
The half-point rise in mortgage rates that has occurred so far this year probably trimmed by 50,000 the number of single-family homes that will be built this year, said Michael Carliner, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders in Washington.
Still, Mr. Carliner said he was not yet willing to change his forecast that slightly less than a million single-family homes would go up this year, an increase from just under 850,000 in 1991. The forecast was made using the assumption that tax-law changes proposed by President Bush to stimulate demand among potential first-time home buyers would not be enacted. The package of tax proposals put together by Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee did not include the tax credit for first-time buyers that Mr. Bush had proposed.
 
Commercial Construction Outlook
 Any upturn in residential housing activity may well be more than offset by a collapse in the commercial construction market, said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence Inc.
"Commercial construction has already crashed in terms of pricing and rents," he said. "This year I think actual construction will crash simply because financing has completely dried up."
Analysts are also concerned that major export markets, which were practically the only source of consistent growth for the economy last year, are on the verge of contracting.
The current situation in Europe and Japan "probably means they won't buy as much from the United States as they did last year," said Alan Sinai, president of Boston Company Economic Advisers Inc. He added, "Exports are a risk."
Joseph G. Carson, chief economist at Dean Witter Financial Services, said he was also concerned that a slowdown in export growth could stifle a recovery.
But Mr. Carson added that there have been major changes in the financial landscape over the last year. He said those changes should be sufficient to get the economy growing again.
The sharp slide in short-term interest rates over the last year has allowed individuals and families to pare debt levels, Mr. Carson said. That, in turn, is allowing household liquidity ratios -- the amount of total liquid assets held compared with outstanding liabilities -- to stabilize and start to improve. And a stronger household balance sheet is needed to support any rise in consumption.
 
Lower Corporate Debt Costs
 For corporations, the decline in interest rates has lowered their debt costs, thereby improving prospects for greater profitability once the economy turns up.
Last, and perhaps most important, Mr. Carson noted that fiscal policy on the Federal level would almost certainly be expansive this year, while it was restrictive in 1991.
Until earlier this month, Mr. Carson had been very pessimistic about the economy's prospects, and he is still forecasting a 1 percent decline in first-quarter output.
But the combination of a modestly stimulative fiscal package and what he sees as much-improved financial flows caused him to raise his projections for growth and interest rates for the remainder of the year.
"For the year ending in the fourth quarter of 1992, we are now forecasting a 1.8 percent advance in real gross domestic product," Mr. Carson wrote in a letter to clients, "one percentage point more than our prior estimates."
The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, who has said repeatedly in recent weeks that the Fed believes it has provided enough monetary stimulus to spark a recovery, will very probably reiterate those views this week during his semiannual testimony to Congress on the economy and money supply.
Mr. Greenspan is just as likely to add in the next breath that the Fed stands ready to lower short-term interest rates further if warranted.
"The Fed's comfort with recent glimmerings of recovery can be no stronger than the evidence," Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, wrote in the firm's weekly Comments on Credit. "And such proof remains tenuous."

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

Hard Times, Continued
The winter freeze is far from over on Seventh Avenue, where many companies have been holding on by their fingertips. Some are slipping off. 
 Mary Ann Restivo, a designer who tied her fate to a large public company, Leslie Fay, was dropped from that company's roster of labels last week. And Rebecca Moses, who has been in and out of business before, broke with her Italian backers.
On Friday, Argenti, a medium-sized Seventh Avenue dress and sportswear house that specialized in silk prints, announced it was filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, after 12 years in business.
"We had a tremendous amount of debt," said Pat Argenti, the company's chief executive. "That was the real problem. Our interest payments were huge." Sales, which were as high as $100 million in 1989, slumped to about $38 million last year.
"The stores pulled back tremendously," he said, adding that the R. H. Macy bankruptcy was a factor, but not an overriding one.
 
Armani's Expansion
 Giorgio Armani, who is better known for expensive clothes, has ambitious plans for his A/X stores, based on the Army's PX stores. About 80 percent of the items -- from T-shirts and jeans to parkas and cotton dresses -- cost under $100 each.
He plans to open A/X stores all across the country, including within larger retailers, which have been falling all over themselves trying to come up with ways to promote the concept. The Armani label, with worldwide sales of $654 million last year, has a nice ring at the register.
Saks Fifth Avenue, which opens its first A/X boutique on Saturday, will mount a six-story slide presentation on the store's facade, with black-and-white photo images projected from Rockefeller Center. Bloomingdale's, which opens a similar boutique the same day, will feature a dry cleaner's conveyor rack with Armani clothes moving through its Lexington Avenue windows. There will also be an electronic billboard flashing the advertising copy:
Store. Men's. Women's. Clothing. Jeans. Basics. Period.
The words, spit out like an old telegram message, give an idea of what fashion is coming to: utilitarian, economical, splendidly null.
 
From Men's to Women's
 Sabato Russo, a designer known for his spirited men's wear, has decided to jump into the women's clothing business.
Mr. Russo, who recently signed a contract with Hilldun Corporation, a Seventh Avenue financial company, for backing, said he would begin showing women's wear in just a few weeks, for fall 1992.
The women's clothes will be like his men's, he said: tailored and original, with unexpected fabrics.
 
Fashion on Cable
 More fashion on cable TV: VH-1, the music-video network, has hired the model Christie Brinkley to be the host of "VH-1's Top 21 Fashion Countdown." The show will highlight 21 musical performers who have influenced the way people dress.
For instance, to illustrate the influence of ripped jeans and leather jackets, Ms. Brinkley will introduce the video "Freedom" by George Michael. For the little black stretch dress, it will be Robert Palmer's "Addicted to Love," with its mechanized chorus line of live mannequins. The retro look will be shown by Harry Connick Jr.'s "You Didn't Know." And so on.
Ms. Brinkley's performance will be taped on the third floor of Saks Fifth Avenue on Feb. 28, from 2 to 5 P.M. The public is invited. The program will be broadcast on April 3 at 7 P.M.
