HEADLINE: S.E.C. Plan For Small Businesses

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Promoting the economic agenda of the White House, Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, proposed measures today to make it cheaper for small companies to raise money.
The proposals would reduce, and in some cases eliminate, the public disclosure requirements for small companies that issue stock. They would also make it easier for mutual funds to invest in small and new businesses. 
 Mr. Breeden said the measures were an effort to put into practice the White House's recent call to "curtail unnecessary regulatory costs." He said the changes would also assist small companies in obtaining financing just as they are having difficulty getting loans from banks hesitatnt to make new loans because of the slumping economy.
While the details of the proposals will take several months for the commission to iron out, some state regulators have expressed concern that the measures could make it more difficult for shareholders and the authorities to combat fraud in the penny-stock market.
 
'A Delicate Balancing Act
 "The devil will be in the details," said Lewis W. Brothers, the director of Virginia's securities division and the president of the North American Securities Administrators Association, an industry group based in Washington. "It really is a delicate balancing act between investor protection and capital formation."
Some S.E.C. officials have also raised concerns privately about the effect of such changes on the Government's effort to prosecute fraud in the penny-stock market. But Mr. Breeden discounted the concerns today, insisting that the proposals will ease what he called a credit crunch without inhibiting fraud cases.
"While any system must continue to provide a high quality of disclosure and vigorous anti-fraud efforts, there are many aspects of the current system that may add to the difficulty of raising capital without necessarily contributing to good disclosure," Mr. Breeden said in a speech in Washington before the National Press Club, where he disclosed the proposals. "The steps that I have outlined today represent in some cases a significant new approach to the registration procedures in use today.
"For the long run, we should seek to maintain investor protection and the quality of disclosure, while cutting costs, reducing barriers and improving flexibility."
Agency officials said the changes would probably not take effect for at least six months, following a comment period and several hearings.
These were the main proposals:
*Increase to $1 million the amount that can be raised through stock offerings without registering with Federal or state authorities for "seed money" to start a new company. Existing law permits new companies to raise $500,000 without registering, plus another $500,000 that must be registered with state regulators; further offerings require registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
*Increase to $5 million, from $1.5 million, the amount that can be raised in limited public offerings that are offered mainly to big investors and require less disclosure than regular offerings.
*Allow small companies, generally those considered to be worth $20 million to $25 million, to file less detailed quarterly and annual financial disclosures with the commission.
*Make it easier through various changes for mutual funds to invest more money in smaller companies, and loosen the rule that requires mutual funds to offer daily stock redemptions.
Today's announcement was the second in five days by Mr. Breeden on changing the rules of corporate disclosure.
Last Thursday, he announced a proposal that would require publicly traded companies to provide more accurate and detailed information to shareholders about how much is paid to executives and directors.
The commission also ordered companies to give stockholders the right to take pay issues to a vote, although such ballots would not be binding. But they are expected to provide a powerful incentive to corporate managers to reconsider their pay policies.

HEADLINE: U.S. Weighs New Limits on Asylum

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is considering a plan to curtail sharply the rights of foreigners to seek asylum in the United States.
In a draft document now circulating in the Justice Department, the Administration is proposing to introduce the concept of "summary exclusion," which would give immigration authorities the power to forbid entry to foreigners with fraudulent documents. The plan, an amendment to the immigration law that would need Congressional approval, would also allow authorities to deport immediately any applicant for asylum who is declared ineligible. 
 No review or appeal would be allowed in such cases.
The Administration's draft includes proposals similar to those introduced by the Reagan Administration in the 1980's. None ever became law.
 
Political Motive Suggested
 In Congress today, staff members said there was no indication that the new amendments would be introduced immediately. Several members of Congress suggested that the legislation may be politically motivated in an election year. The Administration would appear to be strictly limiting illegal immigration and extensive asylum during a recession when jobs are already scarce for Americans.
Lawyers representing refugee groups argue that the amendment would be unconstitutional because it would deny people the right to due process. These refugee advocates also say that such a law would be incompatible with international humanitarian standards.
Under present practice, thousands of foreigners who enter the United States with suspect documents -- or no documents at all -- or with what are considered insufficient grounds for asylum claims, are nevertheless allowed hearings and often repeated appeals.
 
Difference in Status
 To gain asylum, a foreigner must be on American soil. To apply for refugee status, which is governed by other procedures and laws, a person must be outside the United States. An asylum seeker can be ordered deported if the claim fails, even under present laws, though the applicant now has the right of appeal. A refugee arrives in the United States with legal status and does not have to clear further hurdles.
About 177,000 asylum cases are pending in the United States.
The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act would deal with two immediate problems, according to the Administration's draft document. The first provision, denying entry to foreigners with fraudulent documents or no documents at all, "is designed to deal with the increasingly common practice of presenting fraudulent documents to common carriers and then destroying or discarding them prior to immigration inspection."
The second part of the proposed amendment, allowing for the immediate deportation or repatriation of asylum seekers who do not qualify, the draft says, would "alleviate the present situation in which aliens encountered on the high seas must either be given pre-asylum interviews and processing aboard vessels or on foreign soil, or brought to the United States and effectively allowed to remain indefinitely."
The first provision would address directly the several dozen foreigners in custody at Kennedy Airport in New York or other ports of entry.
 
Blocking Haitians From U.S.
 The second provision is intended to plug the route through which many Haitians hope to enter the United States to make applications for permanent asylum.
Exceptions to summary deportation would continue to be made for people with a credible fear of persecution, according to the draft, which also accepts that some foreigners will arrive with false documents because they were necessary to leave a dangerous situation safely.
Warren R. Leiden, executive director of the American Immigrations Lawyers Association, said in an interview today that the Administration's proposals may sound good in concept but will run into problems "in the practical world."
Mr. Leiden said the Administration seems to be restating current law but making it more extreme, and questions why so much effort is being put into seeking news legislation when current laws could do the same job.
At the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. Arthur C. Helton, director of the refugee program, said that when asylum rules were last adjusted in 1990, there was an understanding between the Government and independent organizations representing foreigners that new centers would be set up around the country to handle asylum cases expeditiously.
These centers are not functioning as promised, he said, and "deficiencies still keep the asylum system from being capable of dealing with cases in any meaningful way."
The new amendment, he said, would contradict the agreement and in a sense acknowledge that the system was not working.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Tuna and Trade: Whose Rules?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
SHOULD the European Community have the right to bar meat from America because it contains traces of hormones that it finds scary, but Washington says are harmless to human health?
A blatant protectionist trick, you say? Well, America stops imports of tuna from Mexico because Mexican tuna fishing nets accidentally drown more dolphins in the eastern Pacific than are permitted under American law. If Americans get to decide how Mexicans should catch tuna, perhaps Europeans have the right to decide how their meat is treated while still on the hoof. 
 Or try this one on for size. Almost everywhere in the third world, industry keeps costs down by spewing nasty chemicals into the air and water. Should the products have open access to American markets, where competing domestic businesses are obliged to spend tens of billions annually to keep pollutants out of harm's way?
A new report from the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based organization that referees trade disputes for much of the world, offers some clear advice on how to answer these murky questions. But more important, perhaps, the report is a pragmatic plea for tolerance. Erring on the side of open trade, suggests its principal author, Jagdish Bhagwati of Columbia University, is more likely to serve the environmental interests writ large.
GATT does not have specific environmental rules. But it does codify some principles useful in mulling the member nations' treaty obligations.
At the heart of the legal matter is nondiscrimination. Any policy that applies equally to domestic and foreign businesses is fine; otherwise not. Thus when Thailand tried to bar imported tobacco products, a GATT panel said that banning all cigarettes would be fine -- but not just those with the smooth taste and chic foreign labels. When Canada stopped salmon exports on the ground that the species was overfished, GATT asked why Canada did not also limit domestic consumption.
And then there is the slippery matter of the Pacific dolphins. United States laws intended to limit the slaughter of marine mammals do indeed apply to American fishing boats as well as foreign fleets. But in January a GATT panel ruled that America could not use the trade lever to alter practices that had no direct effect on America's environment.
If America, which buys most of Mexico's tuna, could set Mexico's dolphin policy, the panel suggested, any major importing country could bend any dependent exporter to its environmental will. For example, nothing could stop France from barring imports of sewer pipe from Poland because the air in Polish steel mills rots the bronchia of Polish steelworkers.
But the Bhagwati report points out that the GATT treaty certainly does permit countries to agree on common standards for protecting dolphins in international waters, and to enforce the agreements with trade sanctions. Indeed, the GATT diplomats plainly believe the dolphin-tuna imbroglio is the trade issue from hell -- one almost guaranteed to advance the cause of those who care more about raising the price of chunk light than making the Pacific safe for Flipper.
More generally, the report argues that environmentalists have a stake in freer trade. Open borders, for example, would encourage more efficient use of potentially damaging chemicals. European farmers use 10 times as much fertilizer and pesticides to grow a bushel of wheat as their Argentine and Australian counterparts. But thanks to subsidies and trade barriers, Europe still grows its own grain.
Freer trade, the report also asserts, would serve the environmentalists' cause by speeding economic growth. That is not an intuitive notion: Compare the tidy, if bitterly impoverished, small-town life of pre-industrial England with the Dickensian filth of Victorian Manchester. But it makes sense when one thinks of a clean environment as a luxury that the rich can best afford. And a landmark study by Gene Grossman and Alan Kreuger offers some hard evidence to support the case.
The two Princeton economists used World Health Organization data to compare levels of sulfur dioxide in urban air across a range of countries. Moderately poor cities were more polluted than the very poor places that consume little electricity and have yet to replace donkey power with the internal combustion engine. But city air seems to turn the corner at an income of about $5,000 per person -- a level, presumably, at which people who can afford to trap emissions or switch to cleaner fuels. Stockholm is far less polluted than Seoul, but perhaps not for long.
Jagdish Bhagwati and most economists buy such arguments. But to judge by the budding alliance between protectionists and environmental groups, it is not an easy sell. And unfortunately, much hangs in the balance.

HEADLINE: Pitching a Defunct A-Plant: Shoreham Nuclear Power Station

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHOREHAM, L.I., Feb. 18

 BODY:
To hear the sellers talk, it is a creampuff: one owner, well maintained, exceptionally low mileage. Terms negotiable.
But the representatives of a dozen major companies in the energy business who came out today to kick the tires on the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station and consider bids on converting it to natural gas were not too quick to bite. 
 "All the plants look alike," admitted Walt Peseckas, a project development manager at Bechtel, which used to build nuclear reactors, as he toured the plant that cost more than $5.5 billion but is already partly disassembled. "Sometimes they have a little different color scheme, or a drip here, a drip there," he said.
Mr. Peseckas was one of about 40 executives on the tour led by the Long Island Power Authority, a state agency that is looking for a post-nuclear use for Shoreham since it closed because of public opposition. Conversion to gas poses no technical obstacles, experts say, but Mr. Peseckas pointed to another problem.
"Each state and region has its own economic factors that are driving it," he said. "The question is if it is economically feasible compared to other options." Those include buying hydroelectric power from Quebec or building smaller gas-fired plants when and where they are needed.
 
Life After Reactor
 The Long Island Power Authority has a more perplexing problem. Under the terms of an agreement worked out by New York State and the Long Island Lighting Company, which built Shoreham, the authority will soon acquire the plant for $1. To the victor go the spoils, but what does the authority, composed largely of longtime opponents of nuclear power, do when the spoil is a reactor?
"When you see all the equipment down there, it makes you feel like we should do something here," said Richard M. Kessel, the authority's chairman.
But if life as a reactor has been ruled out, it is far from clear what should be done. After scrambling to make up for the loss of Shoreham, Long Island no longer has a need for power in the short term. And as the tour progressed today, it was apparent that most of the $5.5 billion invested was irrelevant. The land can be re-used, of course, as well as some of the equipment.
The authority thinks a rebuilt Shoreham could replace aging plants that Lilco runs on oil, but other options include performing major maintenance on those plants to extend their lives, or replacing parts of them to make them run on gas too.
 
'Low Mileage'
 Still, the authority's request for proposals has drawn strong interest. Bechtel has formed a team with General Electric, CMS Energy and Long Lake Energy to devise a bid for conversion of the plant; another team was formed by the New York Power Authority, United Engineers and Constructors, Siemens and Enron, and Westinghouse and Stone & Webster have a third team. Several other companies also sent representatives.
With a little bit of the atmosphere of a used car lot, Mr. Kessel prompted plant officials to describe how various plant systems are kept oiled, dehumidified and otherwise ready. "To some extent, it's like new equipment, isn't it?" he asked the day watch engineer, Alexander M. Bodan, as Mr. Bodan showed the sales prospects around the control room.
"To some extent, it's like low mileage," Mr. Bodan replied.
For the record: Plant officials say they turn the turbines for 15 minutes every week. The generator is filled with dry air, and the major electric pumps have been lifted off their bearings to relieve the pressure. Interested parties should apply to the Long Island Power Authority, Garden City, L.I. No reasonable offer refused.

HEADLINE: Hate Groups Seen Growing As Neo-Nazis Draw Young

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The number of white supremacist hate groups increased significantly in 1991, a private nonprofit group that monitors such activity says.
The annual report by Klanwatch, based in Montgomery, Ala., noted that the trend was accompanied by more violent oratory from the newer and more militant groups. At the same time, the Klanwatch report said many of the more traditional groups were stressing political action in some of their new appeals and avoiding talk of hatred and violence. 
 The study prepared by Klanwatch, an arm of the Southern Poverty Law Center, found a 27 percent increase in the number of white supremacist groups, mainly in northern Georgia, Florida, Southern California, along the Northeast corridor and around Chicago. There were 346 groups with mailing addresses or publications or involved in sponsoring meetings or demonstrations around the country, said Klanwatch's director, Danny Welch, adding that there may be more. Last year the study showed there were 273 such groups.
Several researchers involved in the study said the increase in such groups was largely a result of the discontent caused by the recession.
 
Rise in Hate Is Doubted
 But the Georgia Bureau of Investigation, a highly regarded intelligence-gathering agency of the state police, says it is skeptical of Klanwatch's conclusions. John Bankhead, a spokesman for the agency and its anti-terrorist unit, which issues annual reports on terrorist activities in the state, said that the membership of white supremacist groups in Georgia had been pretty stable over the last few years and he doubted that there had been any increase in the number of such groups in the state.
"The problem is that every Klan member wants to be a Klan leader and so they break off and start their own groups, but the numbers of people involved overall changes very little," Mr. Bankhead said. "It might be accurate to say the number of groups increased, but it might not be accurate, based on what we see in Georgia, to conclude that the number of people involved in the groups has increased."
The Klanwatch report comes as the Justice Department is nearing the end of the first year of gathering statistics nationally on the number of hate crimes committed in the United States. A 1990 Federal law, the Hate Crimes Statistics Act, which directs the Justice Department to gather data on bias-related crimes, was enacted after a decade-long increase in race-related violence, anti-Semitic attacks and attacks on homosexuals. It was intended to help law-enforcement analyze how best to combat such crimes.
Tom Jones, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said the agency's uniform crime reporting unit had completed initial training of law-enforcement officials in all 50 states who would be charged with identifying the bias crimes covered by the law. The gathering of the data did not begin until April 1991, he said, and the first report is not due until August 1992.
 
Prosecution Data Sought
 While the law's supporters generally like the progress the Justice Department has made in gathering the data, Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said through a spokesman that he was still troubled that the statistics would not reflect actual prosecutions of bias cases.
"That would not only give us a better sense of the extent of the problem but a better sense of the extent to which it is going unpunished," said Bob McCarson, the spokesman for Mr. Schumer.
Mr. Welch said that the survey indicated that the number of groups espousing anti-Semitic, anti-black philosophies like those of the Ku Klux Klan had risen to 97 in 1990 from 69 the previous year. Similar increases were seen in the neo-Nazi, "skinhead" and "Aryan race" groups, to 203 from 160.
In recent years there has been a leveling off in the number of Klan-type groups, said Mr. Welch, as younger people rejected the robes and ritual in favor of paramilitary type groups like skinheads and neo-Nazis. He also said the newer groups with "the glamour leaders" like Shawn Slater, a skinhead, attracted attention in news reports.
But more recently, Mr. Welch said, the two groups have converged as the skinheads have aged and the Klan groups have adapted their message.
In the last year, said the report, Thom Robb, the head of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, repeatedly asserted that the group did not hate anyone but "loved the white race." The Florida leader of the Invisible Empire, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, a different group, urged his members to "become a group known for hating evil, instead of being a group known for hating Negroes," while his North Carolina counterpart in the same group barred violent neo-Nazis from its gatherings.

HEADLINE: Libya, Fearing Attack, Braces for Clash With West

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 18

 BODY:
In the face of threatened sanctions and possible military action over the 1988 terrorist bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, Libya is bracing for what it apparently believes is an inevitable confrontation with the West.
Along the coast, bulldozers have gouged out huge trenches to thwart what officials say might be an invading force. Machine-gun nests have been set up outside communications centers and Government offices. Merchant ships from Italy, China and Turkey clog the harbor unloading grain and goods, including spare parts for the country's industries, to be stockpiled in the event of an embargo. 
 And telegrams of support for the country, from groups as obscure as the participants in the Palestine Cup marathon race in Morocco, are broadcast daily to bolster morale and assure the populace of international solidarity.
The Government, rejecting assertions by Britain and the United States that two of its citizens were behind the December 1988 bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland, which left 270 people dead, has refused to comply with a demand last month by the United Nations Security Council that the two men be extradited for trial.
 
A Libyan Hearing
 Libyan officials have instead offered numerous theories for the plane's destruction, including one put forth by the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who contends that the jet crashed into a Scottish gas station in bad weather rather than exploding in midair.
The Libyans havealso denied charges that they were involved in the 1989 bombing of a French U.T.A. airliner, Flight 772, over the Sahara that left 170 people dead.
Apparently in an effort to help bolster their case, Libyan officials invited "the world's journalists" to attend a court hearing today with the two suspects in the Lockerbie bombing, who are accused by the West of being Libyan intelligence agents. The Libyans say the men, Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi and Lamen Khalifah Fhiman, are civilian employees of Libyan Airlines.
 
Court Without Evidence
 But Judge Ahmed al-Tawer al-Zawi, appointed by the Libyan authorities to oversee the case, announced -- after a three-hour wait in which two described as the suspects were whisked past the press by police officers toting machine guns -- that it was never his intention to hold a hearing since there was no evidence against the men.
"This is a press conference," he said, seated at a desk as some 100 bewildered foreign journalists who had flown in from Europe and other Middle Eastern countries stood packed together in a small room in the court. "I know nothing about a public hearing."
When asked why the two men had been brought to the court, he said he did not know.
"They frequently come in for questioning," he said.
He said that the two men were not allowed to travel outside the country or leave their homes at night.
"This is so they can't run away," he said, "or perhaps commit suicide."
The brief appearance of the two men -- during which one said "we are not guilty" but neither was allowed to answer reporters' questions -- seemed intended in part to put to rest reports that Libya had hidden or executed the suspects to forestall Western attempts to have them tried abroad. This was the first time Libya had publicly presented the men.
[In Washington, the State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, dismissed the Libyan presentation, saying: "We don't put much faith or credence in what a Libyan judge might say. We think that a Libyan investigation or a hearing is a travesty of justice, amounts to nothing more than another attempt by Libya to delay and to evade its responsibility."]
 
Prospect of Sanctions
 This country is now riveted on the prospect of economic sanctions, a possibility raised by Western nations as the next step if Libya fails to comply with the United Nations resolution.
The United States and Britain also have not ruled out military action, and people here have hardly forgotten the 1986 American bombing raid on this capital city after an earlier instance of a terrorist attack blamed on Libya, a discotheque bombing in West Germany.
Thus the palpable nervousness here. The state-controlled press is full of messages of support for Libya's fight against "neo-Christian colonialist aggression." Public meetings and marches take place almost daily.
One of the latest rallies to denounce the proposed sanctions was held by the Club of the International Communities Women that assailed "the new colonialist campaign" from a podium at the College of the Martyrs of the Failed American NATO Barbaric Aggression.
The Arab Libyan community in Chad, the Vietnamese chairman of the Telecommunications Trade Union and the Islamic Cultural Center in Togo all stand firmly behind the Libyan regime, according to local press reports.
In a state where dissent is not a wise idea, few Libyans speak openly against either the regime or its leader.
But in Tripoli's old market, which was opened two years ago for private trade, one young man stood and surveyed dozens of Somalis squatting over small piles of clothing and trinkets for sale.
"Most of us have given up trying to understand what our Government is doing," he said.
The erratic and often inexplicable Libyan response to the prospect of sanctions includes a detailed plan to call for a special session of the United Nations General Assembly "to define international terrorism" and address what the Libyans say are a "host of other serious issues."
The four-page proposal begins with a call to ban all offensive weapons in the world, including warships and warplanes, especially those that can "refuel in the air." It also calls for the placement of medical crews on all planes and boats as well as the prohibition of boxing and "races exhausting to animals." It demands the elimination of the world's locusts and "the establishment of an international irrigation system banning the flow of rivers, rain and snow into the sea and oceans."
This is nothing new for the Libyan Government. Colonel Qaddafi's whims, like his flamboyant wardrobe and political bible, the Green Book, are often puzzling.
The Libyan leader was a frequent public supporter of what he defined as "liberation movements," including organizations like the Irish Republican Army and the Basque separatist group E.T.A., until a few months ago.
But lately he has disavowed those groups, saying he was duped.
Diplomats contend that the country's foreign policy is as capricious as its ruler and can, without warning, suddenly be reversed.
"People had thought there was a new Qaddafi," said a European diplomat, "more mature -- someone who was beginning to behave like an international statesman. It is as if he can only be held back so long and then he lets loose."

Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, at left above, and Lamen Khalifah Fhiman, in center at left, were escorted yesterday by security guards to a hearing in Tripoli. (Photographs by Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Hoboken to Decide Future of Waterfront

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J., Feb. 18

 BODY:
Hoboken voters will soon decide the fate of their city's soul.
At issue is the future of Hoboken's waterfront, the crusty spirit of this mile-square city on the Hudson. Next month, for the second time in less than two years, the public will vote on a proposal to develop the once-bustling port, renewing a bitter debate between City Hall and a citizens' coalition that was largely responsible for defeating the first proposal. 
 Under the city's plan, a scaled-down version of one defeated in July 1990 by only 12 votes, nearly two million square feet of land would be leased to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which would develop it. The initial phase would include a 33-story office tower and a hotel on Hoboken's southernmost pier, adjacent to its busy PATH, bus and ferry terminals, and a new park. City officials say the first phase of the plan would create 1,000 permanent jobs and stabilize property taxes by increasing revenues.
But the group lobbying against the plan, the Coalition for a Better Waterfront, charges, among other things, that the city's proposal gives too much control to the Port Authority, closes off part of the waterfront and overwhelms Hoboken's small-town character and quirky charm.
 
Voters Are Tired
 Many people here say the voters are tired of hearing about the moldering waterfront and will probably approve the city's plan. But in a move that will probably intensify the debate, on Wednesday the coalition plans to present an alternative that will give voters a choice to consider before the March 31 referendum.
A coalition spokesman, Ron Hine, said the unwrapping of a 12-foot model of the group's plan, which involves Hoboken's entire mile-long waterfront, from the old Erie-Lackawanna terminal at the southern end of town to the Weehawken Cove on the north, will end doubts about the coalition's commitment to development.
While maintaining the water's edge as a public walkway the length of the city, the coalition plan calls for 19 blocks of commercial and residential development that its proponents describe as being in character with the city's existing architecture. It would also add 24 acres of parks to Hoboken's 12 acres of existing green space.
"This," said Mr. Hine, "is precisely what the city lacks: a vision. It could not be more symbolic that they have created a plan that goes from First to Second Street, after spending over $1 million over the last three years to study it."
To Craig Whitaker, a Manhattan architect hired by the coalition to design its plan, the city's proposal encompasses the "worst of the 80's building frenzy and urban renewal."
"What is important is bulk, scale and height," he said. "We want to have low-rise high density, in keeping with Hoboken, as opposed to high-rise high density, the mistake many cities made along their waterfronts during the 80's commercial boom."
 
One Advantage: A Tenant
 But some Hoboken residents say the city's plan has one undeniable advantage, a committed tenant. Peggy E. Thomas, director of the city's Department of Planning and Community Development, said that while both plans endorse development, a goal most residents favor, only the city's plan has a backer, the Port Authority, "ready to sign a 50-year lease as soon as the plan is passed."
The Port Authority has leased the city's piers since 1952, when it signed a 50-year agreement with the Federal Government to run a maritime shipping terminal. It first expressed interest in developing the waterfront more than a decade ago and in 1984 successfully lobbied the legislatures in New York and New Jersey to pass a law allowing it to get involved in such a project. But it has since contended with deep community opposition and negotiations with three city administrations.
After much debate, there is little elected opposition to the current plan. Anthony Russo, the only one of the nine City Council members who voted against the plan, said politics has interfered with objectivity. "The Port Authority comes out ahead much further than the city," he said. Mr. Russo objects to the agreement that would give the authority the first option to develop as well as the right of first refusal. He also objects to the city's giving the Port Authority a $10.2 million lien on the pier.
The city, which spent a $7 million upfront payment the authority gave the city as part of the abortive earlier plan, is practically giving its land away, Mr. Russo argued.
 
Eagerness for a Deal
 Public uneasiness over the decaying, almost abandoned port has made some people here eager for a deal, especially since the Maxwell House coffee plant is about to close, tentatively on April 1. Chris Onieal, president of the Hoboken Food and Beverage Association, a group of bar and restaurant owners, said a hunger for "something to be built" has swayed him to endorse the city's proposals.
"Five years ago, there were all kinds of people eager to build on the waterfront," he said. "Now, there is no one left."
But Mr. Onieal added that his organization has been heavily lobbied by those on both sides of the issue, with no consensus from the members. "We're polling our membership right now to see whether they should endorse a plan," he said, "and if so, which plan. I know how I feel, but not everyone feels the same way."
With hundreds of members, both newcomers and longtime residents, the coalition hopes to sway the undecided. Mr. Hine said the group has registered 1,000 voters, has put 3,000 names on its mailing list and plans a telephone campaign.
"The community is still bitterly divided over this issue," Mr. Hine said. "You would think that politicians, if they saw that half the public was so opposed to this, would adjust it to meet their constituents."
But Ms. Thomas contended that the community is not quite so divided. "I haven't seen" the new plan, she said.
"But I know they are endorsing development," she said. "So are we. So is everybody. We all want basically the same thing."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Fall Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A move by the Federal Reserve Board intended to spur commercial bank lending was received poorly in the fixed-income markets yesterday. Bond prices fell sharply and interest rates rose as market participants, already nervous about recent signs of an incipient upturn in the economy that could ignite inflation, viewed the Fed's action as another potential source of strength.
Around noon the Fed surprised the market by announcing that it would reduce bank reserve requirements to 10 percent from 12 percent, effective April 2. 
 The announcement came one day before the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, issues the semiannual report to Congress on the economy and monetary policy. Traders said they did not like the timing of the move any more than they did its implications.
"This just shows the Fed needs to do whatever it can to get the economy going, even though they have recently said they have done enough," one government securities trader said.
 
More Money in the Economy
 "This will put another $10 billion to $20 billion back into the economy, even though there are some signs that the economy is picking up. And it also means that the next thing they are going to do is ease short-term rates again."
Even though most data released since the start of the year portray an economy that is still wallowing, for the last six weeks credit market participants have chosen to focus on signs that a quick rebound may be coming, and in the process have pushed bond yields up sharply.
Analysts said they were somewhat surprised by the Fed's decision, but added that market reaction to the step was overblown.
"I would have thought the market reaction would have been positive, not negative, because the Fed's move shows it is still concerned about the economy," said Darwin L. Beck, an economist at the First Boston Corporation.
Jay N. Woodworth, senior domestic economist at the Bankers Trust Company, said the move would do something to stimulate bank lending, although not as much as cuts in short-term interest rates already engineered by the Fed.
"This is one more in a series of efforts by the central bank to help the American economy," Mr. Woodworth said. "But this does not radically transform the outlook."
The Fed move transformed what up to that point had been a generally sleepy post-holiday trading session.
Reaction to the announcement was primarily telescoped into prices of long-term notes and bonds, securities that are most susceptible to shifts in sentiment about future movements in the economy and inflation.
By late yesterday, the 8 percent 30-year Treasury bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 1007/32 , down 27/32 to yield 7.97 percent, compared with 7.90 percent late Friday, the last trading day before the Washington's Birthday holiday on Monday.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 1007/32 in late trading, down 18/32 , to yield 7.46 percent. But prices of the 4 7/8 percent two-year notes were unchanged, at 9910/32 , to yield 5.24 percent.
Rates at the regular auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills rose from levels recorded at last week's sale.
 
Treasury Bills Auctioned
 Three-month Treasury bills were auctioned yesterday at an average discount rate of 3.83 percent, up from an average rate of 3.72 percent a week earlier.
Bids on the new six-month bills generated an average discount rate of 3.93 percent, compared with an average rate of 3.80 percent at last week's auction.
New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by the sale of $400 million worth of five-year noncallable notes by the General Motors Corporation.
The 7 5/8 percent notes, which mature Feb. 15, 1997, were priced at $99.976, to yield 7.63 percent, one percentage point over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 1/4 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Baker Hughes Inc. offered $150 million worth of seven-year notes through an underwriting group led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 7 5/8 percent noncallable notes, which mature Feb. 15, 1999, were priced at $99.438 to yield 7.73 percent, 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
 
In the Secondary Market
 The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said prices of most issues dipped by 1/8 of a point to 1/4 of a point in light trading.
A flood of new tax-exempt securities expected to be priced today dampened activity in the secondary market for municipal bonds.
By far the largest issue scheduled to be priced today is a $1.3 billion offering from the State of California. But an additional $800 million or more of new securities are expected to be offered by other states and localities.
In advance of the California offering, traders said the new securities were expected to be offered with a maximum yield of around 6.60 percent.

HEADLINE: The Soundings From Reading

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: READING, Pa., Feb. 13

 BODY:
Since the autumn of 1990, when the nation's ninth and longest postwar recession was beginning to unfold, The New York Times has been taking periodic soundings of developments in Reading and surrounding Berks County, an old-line industrial area with a modern mix of retailing, manufacturing and services that is fairly typical of the Northeast.
The occasional articles, consisting mainly of interviews with business people, workers and shoppers, have sought to capture current economic reality and, by extension, some idea of the immediate future. 
 The first one, 15 months ago, found Reading in malaise and braced for recession, an economic condition formally designated by the National Bureau of Economic Research the following April. The next look, last February, found this city of row houses and blue collars clearly mired in the reality of recession.
By April, however, some hopeful signs had emerged as The Times focused on the Glen-Gery Corporation, a Reading-based brick maker that reported an upturn in demand that it thought might be more than seasonal. But here and elsewhere, the spring recovery proved elusive.
In June, amid mixed signals, Reading was expecting a rebound by Labor Day but after school started and many of the nation's economists said recovery was at hand, people here said they did not think so.

HEADLINE: Still Awaiting Proof in Reading, Pa.

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: READING, Pa., Feb. 13

 BODY:
Ronald K. Buckley, vice president of a furniture store on Penn Street here, says his customers are gradually beginning to return again, which he sees as a sign that the long-delayed economic upswing is poised to begin.
"Those that are ready are going to do business," Mr. Buckley said, referring to his fellow merchants here and around the nation. "Those that are not are going to miss the boat." 
 Reading and its Berks County environs, the subject of periodic visits by The New York Times since the recession started in 1990, shows other signs of an economic pickup. One place is the housing market, which at the national level President Bush says will lead the economy's revival.
This return to Reading found that the dominant view remains one of wariness and skepticism, with people inclined to await proof of an upturn rather than anticipate it.
But discussions here with a wide range of business executives and other residents found frequent expressions of somewhat higher confidence in the economy. The feelings seem to reflect the presence of money freed up by large-scale mortgage refinancing. And, less tangibly, there is an attitude among many workers that if they have not yet lost their jobs -- 19 months after the recession began -- perhaps they no longer need hold their breath.
Automobile dealerships say more people are coming in. And aided by generous rebates and other incentives, sales are higher at some showrooms.
"We saw a tremendous rebound in January," with 73 cars sold, said Bill Ramsey, fleet manager for Lindgren Mazda, which also deals in Chryslers and Plymouths.
Bernard M. Markstein 3d, economist for Meridian Bancorp, the area's biggest bank, suggested that "people are just tired of feeling bad."
Yet Mr. Buckley's own behavior, like that of many executives and workers here, is doing little to help hasten the elusive upturn. While his family-owned Gilbert's Furniture managed to limit its 1991 sales decline to 1 percent, neither he nor many other local retailers or manufacturers are building the inventories that would be needed to meet any stepped-up demand.
That, in turn, means few companies are hiring workers whose wages and renewed spirits would help lift the local economy. Carpenter Technology, a large producer of specialty steel that is one of the area's leading employers, drew more than 1,500 applicants last month for two dozen entry-level jobs paying $8.50 an hour.
 
Waiting for Proof
 Lack of consumer confidence is a main factor in the recovery's delay, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has said repeatedly. A sense that one's job is secure -- or at least that there are others to be had -- is essential if consumers are going to open their wallets.
Mr. Buckley, for example, says he has no incentive to add to his stocks of furniture, because in the current slack period Thomasville and his other suppliers can deliver case goods, such as tables and beds, in as little as a week or two. And upholstery deliveries, he said, take only three to six weeks, compared with six to eight weeks a year ago and as long as 22 weeks in booming 1988.
Nor is Bill M. Sheeler adding to inventory at his computer store out on Perkiomen Avenue, southeast of town, despite brisker demand recently from his business customers. Because computer prices tend to decline, the equipment loses value while awaiting buyers.
 
A Plant Will Soon Close
 Meanwhile, Black & Decker last month began laying off the 115 employees at its suburban Temple plant, which makes Molly fasteners, a type of wall anchor. This operation came with the company's 1989 acquisition of the Emhart Corporation, but did not fit Black & Decker's strategic plan. The plant will be shut by early April and the company has no other plants in the area to which employees could be transferred.
And just up the pike, the used-car lot formerly occupied by Frank Borek, who in September vowed that "I'm out of here" if business did not pick up, now stands vacant. Real estate brokers report a substantial rise in people looking -- and a small increase in sales. But they complain of tighter loan rules by banks and of super-choosy buyers taking full advantage of a wide selection of homes at steady or declining prices.
One broker, Jean A. Schwenger of Wertz, Hoffman, Parks, said she had shown 37 houses to a man moving here from Illinois, so far without a contract for her efforts. "There's no such thing as an easy deal," Ms. Schwenger said.
Over the winter, the deal under which a downtown landmark, the vacant Abraham Lincoln Hotel, was to have been sold and converted to low-income housing fell through, a victim -- at least in part -- of government budget cuts. The main activity in commercial and industrial space is bargain-hunting by "vultures" with ready cash, according to Sidney G. Knoblauch, a leading real estate broker and one of the few business people hereabouts who say they are extremely busy these days.
While the national news media are now giving much attention to the prospect of legislation to spur the economy, Reading seemed to be paying little attention as the House Ways and Means Committee began its deliberations last week. Whereas economists have been fretting, lest the uncertainty inhibit decision-making by consumers and businesses, the inclination here was to dismiss any Washington actions as not likely to help much.
Indeed, talks with people at the unemployment office suggested that Federal efforts in recent months to extend benefits have helped prolong jobless spells as well as ameliorate the pain. Ronald Good, a 27-year-old roofer, said he had been unemployed for about a year but was reluctant to look for other work, despite being forced to sign his house over to his sister and move back in with his parents. He cited the risk of losing standing with the roofers' union if he were to take up other work, but his idleness was sustained by what is now a maximum of 46 weeks of benefits.
"The job market's still soft," observed Louis F. Lauer, manager of the Pennsylvania State Job Service office here. He now has 6,500 Berks County people on his roles compared with about 5,000 last fall. The average spell of joblessness has climbed by about a month, to 16 weeks, matching the national average.
Three employment casualties are from the Berks Products Corporation building materials store in Temple, where Glenn Unger, the manager, has cut his 15-member staff to 12 in the last couple of months. He says business will have to get "a lot better" before he considers hiring again.
At the same time, however, Mr. Unger says he is cautiously raising his stocks in response to the pickup in new housing construction and to a tightness in supplies of lumber caused partly by environmental disputes.
"The key," he said, "is who is going to have inventory" to meet resurgent demand.
 
A Little Less Skeptical
 Paul R. Roedel, chairman of Carpenter Technology, describes his business as "turning up a tad," with strength in components for cars and appliances not shared by its military, aerospace and oilfield products. The company is holding its inventories of finished goods -- 70 percent of billings are shipped from the shelf -- but continues to reduce inventories of work in process.
"I'm a little bit skeptical" that recovery is on the way, Mr. Roedel said, "but less so than two months ago."
And a vice chairman of Meridian Bancorp, Terry L. Troupe, said there was was as yet no significant demand from business for loans, either to rebuild inventories or to expand operations.
"To really say we are turning the corner, we like to see greater consumer confidence," Mr. Troupe added. "One thing would be just getting the consumer to feel his job is secure."
 
A New Liquidity
 One heartening thing, however, is that an "unbelievable" volume of mortgage refinancing is putting money in consumers' hands, Mr. Troupe said, adding that this money is being kept highly liquid and available for spending instead of being tied up in, say, certificates of deposit.
Goodwill Industries, not surprisingly, reports brisks business at its thrift shops here but so does Helene G. Singer, president of Singer Travel. She called last month the best January she ever had, with business travel "gone crazy" even though the leisure market remained spotty.
And officials at the Crompton & Knowles Corporation, the biggest American-owned producer of fabric dyes, say their business has steadied after a drop-off late last year that contributed to a mostly involuntary inventory buildup.
"It's a fashion business," said David S. Alcorn, a vice president at the company's nearby plant in Gibraltar, the company's largest factory. "Most encouraging to us," he added, contemplating the possible lifting of economic gloom, "is the continued popularity of black." Black, he explained, uses more dye than other colors.

GRAPHIC: Photos: In Reading, Pa., there are some signs that economic recovery is in sight. At the Lindgren auto dealership, Bill Ramsey, left, the fleet manager, saw a rebound in sales last month. But at a local employment office, a hand-lettered list of local companies that are not accepting applications provides evidence that many companies are not hiring workers, whose wages would give the local economy a much-needed lift. (Sal DiMarco Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Democrats' Tax Plan Gets Going Over by Republicans

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Republicans turned up the volume of their verbal assault on the House Democrats' tax plan today, saying it did little for the middle class and less for economic growth.
Coordinated, but not entirely consistent, attacks were issued from the White House, the Treasury and House and Senate. 
 Marlin Fitzwater, President Bush's spokesman, said that when Mr. Bush met with House G.O.P. leaders today, they agreed that the public and the Democrats would soon "realize that they have got an empty shell on their hands, or a turkey, as the case may be, and I suspect that they'll start changing the baby pretty quickly."
Echoing criticisms Monday by Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, Mr. Fitzwater said: "The Democratic plan has little if any economic stimulus; it breaks the budget agreement; it would cause a sequester that cuts Medicare, student loans and farm payments. It raises taxes by moving the top rate to 35 percent. It does nothing for home building. It provides 25 cents a day for two years to a family of four in tax cuts at a cost of $90 billion a year in tax increases."
 
The Calculation
 The 25-cents-a-day figure was derived by taking the two years of tax credits -- up to a maximum of $400 for families with incomes of about $26,000 a year or more -- and dividing that $800 by the 731 days of the two years and then by all four members of the "typical" family.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate G.O.P. leader, did the arithmetic a bit more precisely when he said the cut would give "a dollar-ten a day to the average Ameican family." Actually, it works out to $1.09 a day, or 27 1/4 cents per family member.
Senator Pete V. Domenici Republican of New Mexico, put it more casually, saying it would be worth "a couple of candy bars a day."
Another set of Republican charges concerned the additional tax increases they contended would follow when the Democrats tried to extend the credits in another two years.
While the Democratic plan violates the budget agreement by not paying for itself on a year-by-year basis, it is balanced over six years by increasing maximum tax rates to 35 percent for couples with taxable income of $145,000 and individuals at $85,000, and providing a 10 percent surtax of taxable income over $1,000,000.
 
Fitzwater Agrees
 But Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, said that to make the credit permanent Democrats were "going to have to raise the marginal tax rate up to 50 percent."
Mr. Fitzwater agreed, saying that was "what we've always said about the Democrats -- they just want to get their foot in the door, permanent taxes, and then turn it all to spending."
At the Treasury, Secretary Nicholas F. Brady calculated it somewhat differently, forecasting a Democratic scheme to keep the same maximum rate but to impose it on couples with taxable incomes of $50,000 and individuals at the $35,000 level.
Mr. Brady argued, moreover, that no economists believed the Democrats had "an economically sound program that will create jobs." And he insisted that Mr. Bush still eagerly supported a $500 increase in the personal exemption for children, a part of his larger package, but "at this particular point in time what he wants is his seven points," which include a capital gains tax cut, accelerated depreciation, but not the increased exemption.
A spokesman for Mr. Brady later said that the Administration would be happy to see the exemption added, but only if it were paid for through cuts in spending.

HEADLINE: C.D. and Bank Fund Yields Continue to Fall

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit continued to ease in the week ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, which tracks bank rates.
"Short-term certificate of deposit yields -- three and six months -- continue to flatten out, but the strongest signal that the down cycle may be ending is that yields on longer-term accounts, such as five-year certificates of deposit, have begun to inch upward," Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said yesterday. "That reflects the usual pattern of short-term yields lagging the long-term numbers, which generally indicate the next trend." 
 It appears that the Federal Reserve's announcement yesterday of a reduction in the reserve requirements of its member banks, from 12 to 10 percent on transaction acccounts, could be a way of easing credit conditions without having to cut the discount rate again, according to Mr. Heady.
Among New York area commercial banks, the average money market account yields rose by a basis point, to 3.52 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of 1 percent.
Among the New York-area savings institutions, money-market account yields averaged 4.06 percent, off 6 basis points from a week ago.
For money market accounts, the steepest cut among area banks was by the Brooklyn-based Crossland Savings F.S.B., which lowered its money market rate by 37 basis points. For the sharpest drop in three-month certificates, the Bank of Tokyo Trust led again, with a cut of 22 points; it also cut its six-month certificates by 25 points, more than any other New York area bank.
The Bank Rate Monitor said the average yields at 20 large banks outside the New York area declined by a relatively small amount, down 2 basis points, to 3.62 percent, for money market accounts, and down 1 basis point for six-month certificates, to 3.83 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls By 21.24, To 3,224.73

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
A weak bond market and concern over inflation, which could halt further easing of interest rates, helped undercut stocks yesterday in hectic afternoon trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.24 points, to 3,224.73. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, at 234.3 million shares, up from 221 million on Friday. The Big Board composite index was off 2.51 points, to 225.65, with losing issues outnumbering gainers by 1,080 to 714. 
 The decline in the Dow was limited because of strength in transportation issues, which rose smartly as oil prices fell on the news of a smaller-than-expected cut in production by OPEC nations. But oil stocks fared poorly, because lower oil prices usually mean lower profits.
 
Effect of Fed Announcement
 Stocks slid in the afternoon as bond prices fell in reaction to an announcement by the Federal Reserve that it was lowering the amount of money banks are required to hold in reserve against losses. It is hoped that this move will make more money available for lending, but it raised concern among investors about the inflation implications and as to whether it would keep the Fed from lowering interest rates further.
Robert C. Walberg, equity analyst for MMS International, an economic analysis and research firm, said the market's initial reaction to the Fed's announced cut was positive because historically the market rises an average of 22 percent in the 12 months following such a cut.
"In 1990, the last time we had a reserve requirement cut, the market trended lower for about a month before coming back and making the 22 percent," he said. "But keep in mind that was during the gulf war period."
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 5.10 points, to 407.38, with international oils, drugs, health care and food stocks among its weak sectors.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said the market was subjected to two buy programs in the morning and seven sell programs in the afternoon, which had a total net effect of pulling the Dow down 28.86 points. The sell programs alone pulled the index down 42.28 points.
Heavy trading was also apparent on the American Stock Exchange, as the composite fell 5.07 points, to 409.20. The Nasdaq index fall 10.02 points, to 626.41 points, while the Russell 2,000 dropped to 210.08, down 1.48 points.
The OPEC production cut hurt oil stocks but helped airline issues. Mobil was off 2, to 61 7/8; Exxon 1 1/8, to 57 1/8; Royal Dutch Petroleum 1 3/4, to 77 1/2; ARCO 1 1/2, to 103 7/8; British Petroleum 2 3/8, to 55 7/8, and Texaco 2 3/4, to 57 3/4.
 
Gains for Airline Stocks
 But airline stocks led the transport index up on the prospects of lower fuel costs. AMR rose 2, to 76; UAL was up 2 1/4, to 148 1/8, and Delta Air Lines gained 1 3/4, to 70.
Shares of Walt Disney, which scrapped plans to build a movie theme park in Tokyo near its existing Disneyland and announced a 4-for-1 stock split, rose 3 1/2, to 146 1/2.
Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette cut two stocks from its recommended list: the Imcera Group, a maker of health-care products, off 4 1/8, to 34 1/8, and Wheelabrator Technologies, a pollution control concern, down 2 1/4, to 32 1/2. The firm added to its list Showboat, an entertainment concern, up 1 5/8, to 11 1/4, and Rasterops, a software company, up 1 7/8, to 20.
 
Barron's Article on Marvel
 Marvel Entertainment Group fell 11 3/8, to 54 5/8, following a negative article about the comic-book publisher in Barron's over the weekend. Terry Stewart, Marvel's president, who disputed the article, is said to have had conversations with a number of analysts yesterday.
Reebook International rose 2 1/4, to 35, as Margaret Gilliam, an analyst with First Boston, repeated a strong buy recommendation. The maker of athletic shoes said its newly formed Reebok Sport unit to market performance sporting equipment would be headed by Robert Muller, former president of Champion footwear's parent.
Van Dorn shares fell sharply, to 13 5/8, down 5 3/8, after Crown Cork and Seal ended its offer to acquire the packaging and container company for $20 a share, traders said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Hopes of Stronger Economy Push Dollar Sharply Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved up sharply yesterday amid a growing perception that the United States economy is getting stronger.
Gold prices closed lower, falling 30 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, to $353.40 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $352.80, down 45 cents. 
 Analysts said the dollar rose as more traders became convinced that the economy was recovering and that interest rates would remain stable or move higher.
The dollar, like all currencies, tends to rise along with interest rates. Higher yields make United States investments more attractive to foreigners, who must buy dollars to make their purchases.
Traders' confidence in the economy was bolstered by, among other things, a stronger-than-expected increase in retail sales in January that was announced last week.
Analysts said traders' enthusiasm overshadowed concerns that central banks might enter the currency markets to stop the dollar's advance. The Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan intervened for the second time in a month on Monday, selling dollars against the Japanese yen.
Mike Faust, a currency market analyst with MMS International, said the market was "a little bit leery of pushing the dollar" above 128 yen, but also wanted to see the dollar move higher.
He noted that the dollar was reaching the levels where the Fed and the Bank of Japan stepped in Monday, but that traders might bid it higher if there was no widespread intervention involving banks of other countries.
Analysts said the market would be watching today for the release of data on consumer prices and housing construction in January and for testimony by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, who will tell Congress about the state of the economy.
The dollar closed at 128.00 yen in New York, up from 127.80 yen late Friday, the last trading day in the United States before the Washington's Birthday holiday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to 127.17 yen, from 126.93 yen late Monday, and in London, it was quoted at 128.00 yen.
The British pound fell to $1.7545 in New York, from $1.7715 Friday. In earlier London trading, sterling fell to $1.7500, from $1.7740 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.6440 German marks, up from 1.6265; 1.4860 Swiss francs, up from 1.4650; 5.5905 French francs, up from 5.5370; 1,233.25 Italian lire, up from 1,221.25, and 1.18915 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18665.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Price of Crude Oil Plunges On Smaller OPEC Cutback

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Crude oil futures prices plunged more than $1.30 a barrel yesterday after OPEC agreed to cut production less than the market expected.
Gasoline and heating oil futures also fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange. 
 Crude oil for delivery in March dropped $1.34, to $18.12 a barrel; March heating oil fell 3.17 cents, to 51.32 cents a gallon, and March unleaded gasoline fell 2.40 cents, to 55.08 cents a gallon. March natural gas rose 0.2 cent, to 1.045 cents for 1,000 cubic feet, but all other natural gas contracts retreated.
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed late Saturday to cut 1.2 million barrels of daily production for the spring, when worldwide demand for oil falls with warmer weather.
 
What Was Expected
 Traders had expected the group to make cuts of 1.5 million to 2 million barrels a day in a bid to raise prices.
OPEC was unable to make cuts as big as some members would have liked, because Saudi Arabia insisted on maintaining most of the huge market share it gained after it began pumping to capacity in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August 1990.
"That doesn't bode well for the cartel in the near future," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "The cartel's function is to try to stabilize prices."
In other markets, coffee for March delivery sank 2.40 cents, to 66.70 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York. It was the lowest daily settlement of a near-term coffee contract since the summer of 1975.
Coffee prices tumbled amid indications from an International Coffee Organization convention in Florida that the United States would not support a return to limits on coffee exports to support prices.
The last International Coffee Agreement specifying export quotas collapsed in July 1989, when green coffee was priced near $1.40 a pound. Prices have rarely risen above $1 since then.
Coffee futures were also under pressure from weak demand, abundant supplies and expectations for a record-large Colombian crop this year.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
TV Journalists' Urge To Prettify the News

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The report this week that more than two-thirds of the single men and almost a third of the adults in families housed in New York City's shelters are on drugs or alcohol may startle people who are addicted to television news. More often than not, a news story or documentary on the homeless will feature a hard-working, straight-living young couple or an attractive teen-ager and her child who have run into a spell of bad luck.
The reasons for the choices are not obscure. If you want to arouse sympathy for the homeless, you do not put forward off-putting specimens. Television news producers can count on advocacy groups to supply them with model victims for viewing purposes, people who may even be untouched by the other afflictions discovered in the recent survey of the homeless: mental illness, AIDS, domestic violence and lack of education and skills. And why should a producer focus on 1 of the 50 percent of single homeless people who have served time in jail when he can just as easily find someone without a record? 
 Whether the intention is to make a more moving show or build support for programs to help the homeless and possibly reassure viewers about having a small shelter in their neighborhood, the result is a prettifying of reality.
This journalism of the heart is not the greatest sin of the profession. In these tough times, national and local news programs have been reporting almost nightly on people battered by recession. Television has rubbed in the extent and depth of the hardships until even Washington has been compelled to address them, at least with words. Good. The problem comes when advocacy upends journalism, when the facts are drowned in the compassion.
Reports on the homeless often tend to imitate depression-movie scripts: hard-working folks in heart-wrenching situations. If only jobs and housing were provided, they would be like you and me. But suddenly it turns out that the reality for many of the homeless is something different, something much more complicated and less susceptible to easy imagery or quick remedies.
The people who have to bed down in New York City's foul shelters of course deserve sympathy, whether they are hooked on cocaine or not, but how can they be helped unless addiction is taken into account? Any plan to address the pathologies that rage through America's cities requires a sustained commitment, and that requires public understanding and acceptance of what is sure to be a heavy long-term burden. Pretending just won't do.
No journalist, despite the air of authority conferred by the screen, has the solution to any tough subject. The reporter's job is not to prescribe or even to diagnose, but simply to lay out the situation. The rules are elementary: Don't shade reality in the interests of policy or drama; don't round up the usual villains; don't become the accomplice of any interested party. If a journalist wants to make an additional contribution to the homeless, let him do it on his own time.
Maybe viewers will not react to the new picture of the homeless in a welcoming way. Maybe Andrew Cuomo, the chairman of the mayoral commission that dug up the bad news about the people in shelters, is being optimistic when he expresses confidence that the truth will rally a new consensus for action. But that cannot be the journalist's prime professional concern.
Increasingly, it seems to this loyal viewer, news programs and documentaries are putting the power of the camera and the language of melodrama to the service of some cause. Reporters shoot up with chutzpah and turn themselves into advocates. The impulse is understandable and may at times seem admirable, but the tendency is subversive of the journalist's main job, a difficult one to do well in the best of circumstances and the only one a journalist is competent to do or should aspire to do in a democracy, where the populace is supposed to be informed, not manipulated: Tell what is, and let others take it from there.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By Ron Alexander

 BODY:
DEAR Diary:
The other Saturday I agreed to take my 2-year-old to see "Beauty and the Beast" at a local theater in Hastings-on-Hudson. (Twice had not been enough for him). On our way to the theater he fell asleep; nevertheless, I put him on my shoulder and stood in line. Nearing the ticket booth, a selfish plan came to mind. "Two for 'Grand Canyon,' " I said wickedly. I bought my popcorn and sat down, my son still asleep in my lap.
Twenty minutes into the film he woke up. For a few minutes, he watched Danny Glover and Kevin Kline, while silently munching on my popcorn. Suddenly, it hit him. "Where's the beast?" he yelled to me in the quiet auditorium. "Where's the beast?" 
 After a few minutes of rather loud negotiation, we slipped into the theater next door, where we caught the rest of "The Beast." So much for selfish aspirations. -- JOSEPH SCUTIERI

 	 	 		. . .	 	Dear Diary:
The scene is a card store in Bronxville, N.Y. The time, a week or so before Valentine's Day. The cast, a couple, apparently married; they are examining valentine cards in the Husband and Wife section. After making selections, they exchange and read the cards.
He: It's really beautiful. Thanks.
She: How very thoughtful. Thank you, dear.
They wish each other Happy Valentine's Day and kiss. Then they return the cards to the rack and walk out. --JOSEPH A. COYLE

AREN'T YOU GLAD
YOU'RE NOT WEST 81st STREET?
 In New York City
 Amsterdam Avenue
 Is One Way Going
 North.
 It is crossed by
 72d Street, 79th Street
 86th Street and 96th Street.
 They are two-way streets.
 All the others are one way,
 Going East and West.
 Except West 81st Street.
 81st Street is a
 Two-way, one-way street.
 When you drive up Amsterdam Avenue
 On your left, West 81st Street is
 One way West.
 On your right, it's
 One way East
 Until it reaches Columbus Avenue
 Then it becomes
 Two way, and disappears
 Into Central Park
 And comes right out again!
 You think you're confused?
 What about West 81st Street? -- JACK SHOR

 	 	 		. . .	 	Dear Diary:
After years of chewing on murder mysteries as my form of "brain candy," I thought I'd sample westerns for a change of pace. Not sure that a highbrow literary establishment like Shakespeare & Company would even deign to carry that genre, I approached the information desk with some embarrassment.
"Do you have any westerns?" I asked the college-age employee behind the desk. He thought about it for a moment. "Have you read 'All Quiet on the Western Front?' " he asked.
I'm no longer ashamed of my choices in literature. -- STEVE LANCE

 	 	 		. . .	 	The sign stopped Ruth Humleker, among others, in her tracks. It is in the window of her neighborhood dry cleaner, and this is what it says:
"Currently Unemployed? We Care. Let us help you look your best while interviewing for new opportunities. We will clean one suit or one dress per week FREE until you find employment. Call Alan. All arrangements will be kept strictly confidential. (Must present proof of current employment from N.Y. State Unemployment.)"
Alan Rappaport is the current owner of the shop, Julius Klein Cleaners, at Third Avenue and 21st Street, which has been in business for more than 50 years. He told Ms. Humleker, "When you take, you have to put something back." Owning a business in New York City "has become a give-and-take situation," he said, adding, "Over the years I've been on both sides of the fence, and I know too well what it's like to eat macaroni and cheese."

 	 	 		. . .	 	Dear Diary:
He was a hip young messenger in black leather (jacket and Reeboks) and headphones; she, a Murray Hill matron with matching coat and hat. The three of us were waiting to cross Park Avenue. She tapped him on the shoulder.
"Your shoe is untied," she pointed out. "You'd better tie it. You know, you could trip and hurt yourself." Would he do it? I wondered.
He nodded in some bewilderment and bent down to tie his shoe with just enough time to catch the green light.
And they say New Yorkers don't care. -- ELIZABETH A. SPENCER
