HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Another Name for Columbus Day

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Black Hills/White Justice
The Sioux Nation Versus the United States, 1775 to the Present
By Edward Lazarus
Illustrated. 486 pages. HarperCollins. $27.50.
 
Native American Testimony
A Chronicle of Indian-White Relations From Prophecy to the Present, 1492-1992
Edited by Peter Nabokov
Illustrated. 474 pages. Viking. $25.
Some American Indians would like to rename Columbus Day in 1992 National Native American Day because they consider the quincentenary of the landing of Christopher Columbus in the Western Hemisphere a day of mourning, not celebration. The reasons can be found in two books that offer essential and often exciting reading about the struggle to preserve Indian life, land and rights. 
 Circling the wagons of history, Edward Lazarus in "Black Hills/White Justice" and Peter Nabokov in "Native American Testimony" bring the story of the checkered relationship between Washington and the Indian tribes up to the present. The shoot-outs are now taking place not with weapons on ancient hunting grounds but with briefs in modern courtrooms.
During President Franklin D. Roosevelt's first term, the Indian Reorganization Act was passed, reversing the longstanding policy of forced Indian assimilation and providing for increased tribal sovereignty. But the fate of the Indians was changed in 1950 when Dillon S. Myer was named Commissioner of Indian Affairs. The symbolism was not lost on the increasingly sophisticated Indians that Mr. Myer had directed the detention program for Americans of Japanese descent during World War II. Mr. Nabokov writes that to Commissioner Myer, Indian reservations were "akin to concentration camps." Without their consent, he wanted to Americanize the Indians and force them to abandon their traditional ways.
During the Eisenhower Administration, this policy of termination, as it was called, reversed the generous benefits of the Indian Reorganization Act. The resulting friction between the Indians and the Federal Government -- and among some Indian leaders themselves -- continues to this day. The attitude of many Indians in their battles against the Federal Government is still best summed up in the bold title of Vine Deloria Jr.'s 1969 book, "Custer Died for Your Sins."
In "Black Hills/White Justice," Mr. Lazarus emphasizes the United States Supreme Court decision in 1980 that resulted in a $106 million award to the Sioux Nation because of the Government's seizure of the Black Hills in South Dakota in violation of an 1868 treaty. Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun, the strongest voice on the bench for the Sioux, wrote the 8-to-1 opinion on their behalf. Later, Mr. Lazarus was a law clerk for Justice Blackmun and taught constitutional law at the Cardoza School of Law at Yeshiva University. His book is full of inside information because his father, Arthur Lazarus, pursued the case against all odds for more than 20 years and convinced the high court of the justice of the Sioux cause.
The Sioux have let the award sit in the United States Treasury, accumulating interest, because they fear that if they take the money they will give up their claim to the Black Hills. The spectacular Black Hills, a 4,000-foot high ridge 110 miles long and 40 miles wide, once sheltered the great Sioux tribes and are considered a holy place. The legal legacy has grown to more than $300 million. The author sympathizes with those Sioux leaders who want to use the money to build an "economic foundation" for the tribe rather than to continue to make "rhetorical claims" that he says lead only to a victim mentality.
Mr. Lazarus's story of the Sioux Nation is particularly well organized and edited. It includes informative maps, a detailed chronology covering everything from the egomaniacal General Custer at the Little Big Horn to the massacre at Wounded Knee, S.D., to all the Congressional legislation and the futile struggles to save the Indian heritage. Of particular note, an appendix on the Treaty of 1868 between the Sioux and the United States -- the basis for the winning lawsuit in 1980 -- is a remarkable document that provides a vivid picture of life on the Great Plains in the time of the buffalo.
"Black Hills/White Justice" is a book filled with such riches, one of the most original accounts of the Indian past and present in recent years.
The voices of the Indians themselves are heard in "Native American Testimony," an anthology that spans nearly 500 years of Indian and white relations. The book includes hundreds of stories and experiences, from the time of the first encounters with European explorers to the second battle of Wounded Knee in the turbulent 1970's, when armed members of the American Indian Movement began demonstrations, to the current attitude of Indians about Columbus Day celebrations. Mr. Nabokov, the editor of the collection, is an assistant professor of anthropology and American Indian studies at the University of Wisconsin.
The anthology picks up where the well-intentioned but romanticized film, "Dances With Wolves," leaves off. In a foreword, Mr. Deloria tells why so many of the tales read like laments. He writes: "Some of the voices contained herein may appear to be complaining about the loss of land, the loss of a way of life or the continuing propensity of the white man to change the terms of the debate to favor himself. But deep down these are cries about dignity, complaints about the lack of respect." And then he quotes Sitting Bull: "It is not necessary that eagles should be crows."
Mr. Nabokov's own intelligent commentary threads through the pieces in the book. At one point he cites the words of Felix S. Cohen, the eminent legal scholar and a strong advocate for the Indians, who in 1953 said, "Like the miner's canary, the Indian marks the shift from fresh air to poison air in our political atmosphere . . . our treatment of Indians, even more than our treatment of other minorities, reflects the rise and fall of our democratic faith."
N. Scott Momaday, who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1969 for his novel, "House Made of Dawn," has the final say in the collection about the future of the American Indian: "I grew up on Indian reservations, and then I went away from the Indian world and entered a different context. But I continue to think of myself as Indian, I wrote out of that conviction. I think this is what most Indian people are doing today. They go off the reservations, but they keep an idea of themselves as Indians. That's the trick."

HEADLINE: Save Haiti From Its Army

 BODY:
Last September's coup in Haiti brought staggering consequences: more than 1,500 people murdered in the streets . . . tens of thousands fleeing in small boats to the U.S. and other neighboring lands . . . military conspirators emboldened throughout the hemisphere. These disasters derive from one narrow source, Haiti's brutish army, just 7,000 soldiers who terrorize a population of six million.
Haiti's neighbors, working through the Organization of American States, have tried to pressure army leaders. But their economic embargo has proved porous and their diplomatic proposals have been mocked. This month a blundering State Department eased some of the remaining pressure, inviting even greater contempt from Port-au-Prince. 
 To retrieve the situation, a more tough-minded approach may be required: Send in armed O.A.S. peacekeepers to restore order and democracy.
Foreign intervention in political disputes is usually a bad idea. But in Haiti's case, it deserves serious consideration.
One reason outsiders can play a constructive role is that they would be supporting a basic choice already made by Haitians. A million and a half voters overwhelmingly elected Jean-Bertrand Aristide as President 14 months ago. By all accounts, he still commands majority support.
A significant and economically powerful minority, however, opposes President Aristide and fears what might happen if he returns. An O.A.S. force could reassure these people, essential to Haiti's economic functioning, that their rights will be protected from vengeful Aristide partisans.
The army might not politely step aside. But it could, being small, be pushed aside. Should the army resist, to protect its drug and other smuggling rackets, it would find little popular support.
The O.A.S. traditionally dislikes intervening anywhere because Latin American states fear setting precedents that could weaken their own sovereignty. Those fears would be eased if no U.S. troops took part. Most Latin governments now have an equally strong stake in avoiding a different precedent, a successful military coup. Events in Venezuela this month sent shudders through several presidential palaces.
As long as the Haitian army thwarts all attempts at diplomacy, it's hard to see any political remedy for Haiti's suffering. The first need seems increasingly clear: Neutralize the army's tyrannical power.

HEADLINE: 'C'mon Along and Listen To . . .'

 BODY:
In the next three months, something like the old hip hooray and ballyhoo are coming back to Broadway. Twenty-two shows will have opened, almost as many as opened in the entire 1990-91 season. Some of them will probably have the life span of a mayfly. Still, better a brief run than none at all, and besides, who knows?
Among the nine musicals are revivals of "The Most Happy Fella" (already here), "Guys and Dolls" and "Man of La Mancha," none of which employ armies, crashing chandeliers or hovering helicopters. They don't need them. When a show's got "Standin' on the Corner," say, or "Fugue for Tinhorns," scenery recedes. 
 Several of the plays feature big screen stars, some of whom may twinkle very faintly, if at all, on stage. Even so, those names are going to look very good on Broadway marquees -- and Broadway is going to look very good on their resumes.
That's because Broadway is embedded in countless songs, countless books and the memories of countless Americans. For a century tourists coming home from a visit to New York have been greeted with, "Did you take in any Broadway shows?"
Broadway by now is sometimes as much myth as reality. Ticket receipts are way down; ticket prices are still way up; half a million fewer people have shown up so far for this season's offerings than through the same period last year. Maybe one can't fight a recession with singing, dancing and a new Neil Simon play. Never mind. It's optimism that counts, and that will now radiate from 22 marquees.

HEADLINE: Buchanan Shock

 BODY:
Once again, Americans have suddenly been plunged into a cram course in the odd form of calculation called New Hampshire Arithmetic.
In 1968, Senator Eugene McCarthy lost the primary yet his 42 percent shook Lyndon Johnson out of office. In 1976, Ronald Reagan's 49 percent against President Gerald Ford was seen as a defeat. Jimmy Carter's 28 percent, meanwhile, certified him as nationally viable. 
 Pat Buchanan's showing against President Bush belongs on the same seismic scale, the more so considering that he is a newspaper columnist, challenging an incumbent whose popularity recently verged on 90 percent. For three distinct reasons, the outcome produces Buchanan Shock.
One shock is that his showing will be taken, especially abroad, as a sign of ugly nativism and thinly varnished hostility to minorities. Mr. Buchanan denounces being characterized as racist or anti-Semitic. His record, however, remains his record; it now requires searching scrutiny.
He would have no quarrel with the second kind of shock -- that his vote total shows support for a greatly altered American relationship with the world. To call this sentiment isolationism only gives it a dirty name; there are few subjects Americans more sensibly need to thrash out.
The third, indisputable layer of shock comes from yesterday's demonstration of how urgently many voters wanted to protest their economic distress. Exit polling showed, for instance, that voters with unemployment in their families gave Mr. Buchanan a 10-point margin. Half his supporters said they voted for him to send a message. Taken together, the several forms of Buchanan Shock thus ignite either alarm or at least serious and searching attention; the earthquake's not over.
There was New Hampshire Arithmetic on the Democratic side, too. What was Paul Tsongas to most Americans a year ago? Someone with an unpronounceable name. Not even those who presumed he would win, as a favorite-cousin candidate from neighboring Massachusetts, could have confidently predicted he'd win fully a third of the vote.
Yet "A Call to Economic Arms," the title of his cogent 85-page rationale for running, turned out to sound the dominant theme of the campaign. The appeal of Mr. Tsongas's rational approach was especially noticeable among better-educated voters, who favored him almost 2 to 1 over Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
New Hampshire Arithmetic probably brought Mr. Clinton some good news, also. His second-place showing, despite the shadow of personal issues, probably discourages the immediate entry of other potential candidates. To plunge in now would risk looking like a predator, whereas if no clear leader emerges in coming weeks, a new candidate might, instead, look like a savior. New Hampshire Arithmetic may be odd, but it counts.

HEADLINE: Massachusetts to Open a Public Science School

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Citing the need to act quickly to inspire high school students to choose math and science careers despite tight school budgets, Massachusetts officials plan to open a public academy focused on those subjects at Worcester Polytechnic Institute this fall.
The new Massachusetts Academy of Mathematics and Science would be the first such nonresidential, state-financed school of excellence to be housed at an existing college, said one sponsor, State Senator Arthur E. Chase, a Republican from Worcester. The academy would serve high school juniors and seniors, who would compete for admission. 
 Unlike students attending the 10 other statewide academies across the nation specializing in mathematics and science, Massachusetts Academy students would commute rather than live on campus, making the program more economical, Mr. Chase said.
"It's unique," Mr. Chase said. "Where others have spent millions, we'll be spending very little to establish this, and we think we'll be winding up with a better quality program because we're tapping into the resources of one of the finest private colleges in the country."
Worcester Polytechnic Institute is a private engineering college with an undergraduate enrollment of 2,600.
At the North Carolina School for Science and Mathematics in Durham, which was founded in 1980 and is considered the model for such schools, 68 percent of the school's graduates have gone on to major in mathematics or science in college. Nationwide, about 40 percent of high school graduates ranking in the nation's top 10 percent go on to major in those subjects. But the cost per student at the North Carolina school is $13,225 this year; in Durham's public high schools, the cost is $4,517.
Under contract with the state, Worcester Polytechnic Institute would receive a fee to run the academy. The fee for each student would be in the "same range" as the $5,000 average spent per pupil by Massachusetts's public high schools, Mr. Chase said.
 
Little Opposition
 Gov. William F. Weld, a Republican, included $500,000 in his fiscal 1993 budget to start the academy this September with a limited number of students. The financing has not yet been approved by the Legislature, but Lieut. Gov. Paul Cellucci, also a Republican, said he expected the measure to pass.
"If this is effective, we intend to expand it so we can have other programs like this in the state," Mr. Cellucci said.
While the Democrats control both houses of the Legislature, they have expressed no significant opposition to the proposal.
Some education specialists have reacted cooly to the plan, saying that public officials should focus on improving standards in mathematics and science for all students, not just the talented.
"The reform and the financial commitment to all students is extremely important," said Ray Shiflett, executive director of the Mathematical Sciences Education Board, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences. "The potential good for our society and nation in raising the expectations and standards for the rest of our children far outweighs the benefits of any special education program for the gifted," he said.
John P. Polidori, spokesman for the Massachusetts Teachers Association, said: "Governor Weld has hit the right note, but on the wrong key. Math and science education deserve priority attention, but for all children, not an elite few. Public monies should be used at public schools and public colleges. This experiment should be funded by a private source."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1904 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Hampshire;
BUSH JARRED IN FIRST PRIMARY; TSONGAS WINS DEMOCRATIC VOTE

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.H., Feb. 18

 BODY:
President Bush received a jarring political message in the New Hampshire primary today, scoring a less-than-impressive victory over Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator.
 With 99 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Bush had 58 percent of the vote and Mr. Buchanan 40 percent. 
 On the Democratic side, also with 99 percent of the vote counted, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts was the winner with 35 percent. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas was comfortably in second place at 26 percent and in a position to take his resilient candidacy on to the string of primaries in his native South.
The Democratic results left the race for the nomination unsettled, and seemed likely to fuel talk of another candidate's entering the race. The Bush-Buchanan battle also brought Mr. Clinton some relief by taking him out of the glare of the political spotlight, where he has been trapped for the last two weeks in the debate over his draft status during the Vietnam War.
 
Clinton Looks Ahead
 Reflecting Democratic glee over the President's showing, Governor Clinton said, "In November, we will win a great victory against Pat Buchanan."
Mr. Bush, in a statement tonight, said his opponents in both parties had "reaped the harvest of discontent with the pace of New Hampshire's economy" and added, "I understand the message of dissatisfaction."
The signal to Mr. Bush was unmistakable. Even though Mr. Buchanan's support represented more than 63,000 actual votes, it amounted to a roar of anger from those who voted in the Republican primary, and it showed the power of a "send a message" campaign against him in times of economic distress.
Mr. Bush now faces a galvanized Buchanan campaign in one state after another, with the battle to be joined on March 3, when the Buchanan forces hope to make another stand in Georgia. Down the road, Mr. Bush will confront a Democratic Party that has now been given a road map of his vulnerabilities.
 
No Big Push for Cuomo
 In the Democratic race, Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska apparently emerged from the voting neck and neck -- as they were in the polls during the past few weeks. But former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California was right with them, after polls suggested for weeks that he was well behind the pack.
And one "surprise" that some had predicted simply did not materialize: the write-in effort for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York did not break out of the single digits.
Republicans loyal to Mr. Bush tried to play down the results. The President's political advisers asserted that New Hampshire, with its battered economy and sensitivity to taxes, would be Mr. Buchanan's "high water" mark. But there was alarm in the White House, as the euphoric Buchanan campaign prepared to move ahead, hoping that the New Hampshire result would bring a flood of contributions.
The voting today carried many ominous signs for Mr. Bush. Mr. Buchanan won half of the men who voted in the Republican primary and half of those who identified themselves as conservatives, according to interviews with people leaving the polling places.
Mr. Bush held on to a majority of the Republicans, but Mr. Buchanan carried more than half of the registered independents who chose to vote in the Republican primary. Taken together, the unrest of men, conservatives and independents showed deep fault lines in the coalition that carried Ronald Reagan to power, kept him there and elected Mr. Bush as his heir.
There was much historical irony here: It was New Hampshire that resurrected Mr. Bush's candidacy four years ago, after the then-Vice President placed third in the Iowa caucuses and came limping to this state desperate for affirmation from the voters.
Mr. Buchanan's constant urging to send a message to the White House clearly paid off: three in 10 of those voting in the Republican primary said they wanted, first and foremost, to do that, and they overwhelmingly backed Mr. Buchanan, the survey showed.
Moreover, Mr. Bush was clearly punished for breaking his 1988 pledge to forswear new taxes. Nearly a third of the Republican primary voters said that was "very important" to their vote, and most of them gave their support to Mr. Buchanan.
 
Reading His Lips, Again
 This anti-tax sentiment, some analysts said, was fed by the Bush Administration's decision not to include a $500 increase in the tax exemption for children in a list of high-priority proposals to energize the economy -- a decision that Mr. Buchanan also pounded upon.
Mr. Buchanan began his campaign as a plea to put "America first" and radically redirect the nation's attention to home front concerns, but it was a commercial attacking Mr. Bush for breaking his tax pledge that was the hallmark of his campaign here. Again and again, New Hampshire voters were greeted with the image of Mr. Bush declaring, "Read my lips, no new taxes" in 1988, and were reminded that he broke his promise.
Mr. Buchanan also clearly benefited from his intensive campaigning here, in contrast to the largely long-distance courtship of Mr. Bush.
The wounds suffered by Mr. Bush today made many Democrats agree with Phil Angelides, the California Democratic chairman, who asserted that the Democratic nomination in 1992 was the most valuable since 1976, when the Republicans were reeling from Watergate, and Jimmy Carter defeated President Gerald R. Ford.
But New Hampshire did little to sort things out. Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said tonight, "It's a wide-open race. This was the starting gun, not the finish line."
Mr. Tsongas has seen New Hampshire transform his campaign from one accorded little attention, and even less chance of success, to one that is treated as a serious drive for the nomination. But he still needs to demonstrate that his candidacy can travel well.
He promoted his underdog victory as an affirmation of his message: a "bitter medicine" appeal to restore the economy, through such measures as a cut in the tax on capital gains to encourage investment. The polling of voters today suggested that much of his support was from people who wanted a candidate with specific ideas, as well as one who has shown strength and courage. The survey also showed that he had strength among upper-income voters, drawing half of those with incomes over $50,000.
But many Democrats still see his showing here as a reflection of his regional roots, his months of painstaking organizing, and the stumbles of the rest of the field.
Mr. Clinton managed to get some breathing space from the New Hampshire results, after three weeks when his standing suffered amid questions over whether he tried to avoid the draft, and accusations from a supermarket tabloid that he had a 12-year extramarital affair.
Mr. Clinton denied both charges, and voters in the polls today seemed to consider them unimportant. Only one in 20 said the assertions about Mr. Clinton's character were very important in their vote.
Still, in a troubling sign for the Democratic candidates, nearly a third of the voters in the Democratic primary said they wanted to see someone else in the race.
 
Decisions Made Late
 Emblematic of this confused Democratic race: 45 percent of the Democrats made their voting decisions in the past three days, or today, accoring to the surveys of those leaving voting places. This compares with 29 percent of the Republicans who decided during that time frame.
The poll was conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, an organization created in 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN and NBC News.
The results are based on interviews with 1,918 voters in 60 randomly selected precincts who voted in the Democratic primary, and on 1,848 voters in 60 precincts who voted in the Republican primary. The findings for the full samples have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
As the results finally settled in tonight, the candidates reacted with a mixture of exhaustion and relief. Mr. Clinton, who finished several points ahead of what the final polls had predicted, seemed thrilled to have gotten out of New Hampshire in fighting shape.
He gave a preacherly speech, a mixture of pride and gratitude, telling a rally, "This has been a tough campaign, but at least I've proved I can take a punch." He asserted that the voters here had made him "the comeback kid" and said he looked forward to "taking this campaign across the country." Mr. Clinton is clearly hoping to use his financial and organizational edge for a long march to the nomination.
 
'Are You Listening?'
 Mr. Tsongas cast his victory as a triumph over Washington and the conventional wisdom: "Hello, Washington, this is New Hampshire calling. Are you listening?" He said the voters here were saying, "Just tell us the truth, tell us the truth."
Mr. Buchanan, at a wild rally tonight, promised to "take our party back from those that have walked away from us." While his audience chanted, "God bless America, God bless Pat," Mr. Buchanan called for recruits and said he would take his campaign on to Florida, Maryland, Georgia "and points beyond."
As the race moves to the South, Mr. Bush will also have to contend with David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader who mounting campaigns in several states in the region.
Mr. Duke, a former Louisiana state representative, is on the ballot in South Carolina, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma and Tennessee. His best chance of making an early showing may be in South Carolina, which has a March 7 primary and where he has made several campaign appearances.
 
No Rest for Tsongas
 For the Democrats, New Hampshire begins a wave of primaries and caucuses that will, by March 17, produce 55 percent of the delegates to the Democratic convention in July. The Maine caucuses will be held this Sunday, and Mr. Tsongas is probably the favorite there, given his regional roots and the bounce he will get out of New Hampshire. On Tuesday comes the primary in South Dakota, where both Midwesterners in the race, Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Harkin, are desperately looking for a lift.
But the next major struggle for the Democrats comes on March 3, when primaries or caucuses will be held in Colorado, Georgia, Idaho, Maryland, Minnesota, Utah and Washington. This is the day that will suggest whether Mr. Tsongas has national appeal that could help him generate more money and credibility before the daunting round of 11 primaries and caucuses to be held one week later, on March 10, Super Tuesday.
The Tsongas campaign says it is emphasizing Maryland, Colorado and Washington and is particularly hopeful of winning Maryland. "Maryland is wide open," said Nate Landow, the state Democratic chairman there.
Mr. Clinton is hoping for success on March 3 in Georgia, where he has the support of Gov. Zell Miller. The Arkansas Governor badly needs some victories to steady his candidacy and is counting on his native South to provide them. Like Mr. Tsongas, however, Mr. Clinton needs to show strength outside his region, and he will be counting on his superior resources to keep him in the mix almost everywhere.
There is a real possibility that March 3 could produce a muddle, with Mr. Tsongas showing strength in Maryland and Mr. Clinton in Georgia while Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Harkin pop up elsewhere. "We could have a very indecisive day," Mr. Landow said.

A chart in some copies yesterday giving results of a poll of Democratic primary voters in New Hampshire misstated the response to one question. Among those who said they voted for Gov. Bill Clinton, 58 percent said that the economy and jobs were among the issues that mattered most in determining their vote.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

HEADLINE: Hard Times in the Schools -- A Special Report;
In Classrooms, the Economy Is Teaching a Harsh Lesson

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
Hard times are reaching into the American classroom.
Just when politicians are calling for a revival in American education, the recession is leaving principals and teachers across the country with less money for more students. 
 The toll is uneven, and not all the cuts are dire. But reports are somber across the economic spectrum. Schools in the hardest-hit areas have no art, no music, no librarians and no counselors. Teachers comb rummage sales and attics for supplies. School districts stop running buses and hold Bingo nights to pay for sports programs.
"A year ago we received the nation's education goals and I was told to post them on my wall," said Jane Gaskell, principal of Pembroke Hill Elementary School in Pembroke, N.H., referring to the six ambitious education goals President Bush has said he wants achieved by the year 2000. "We're not even getting close. I read my education journals and hear about these innovative programs and I laugh and say, 'The band's playing on.' "
There are no up-to-date national figures on public school spending cuts, but interviews with experts on school finance, national education groups and principals of 27 schools in 13 states suggest that this year is bad and that next year will be worse.
The latest estimates available for spending on elementary and secondary education from the National Center on Education Statistics project a 5.8 percent increase by Federal, state and local governments for the school year that began this fall.
But the notion of an increase may be misleading because these estimates were made as the recession was just unfolding. In many cases, rising school enrollments, local reluctance to raise taxes and state fiscal problems have meant that schools actually have less money than before.
So far this year, 30 states have reported budget deficits or revenue shortfalls, according to Anthony Hutchison, a fiscal analyst for the National Conference of State Legislatures. States and towns pay 94 percent of all education costs. Although surveys show that most state legislatures had planned to increase spending on education this school year, Mr. Hutchison said he expected that the recession would pare those increases or force actual cuts in many cases before the end of this year. Rising school enrollments have meant that a small increase can actually be a cut. Even more than states, cities and towns appear to be cutting education spending as voters worried about the economy reject tax increases.
The worst-off schools are in the Northeast and California, according to Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany. In a survey conducted this December by the National Association of Elementary School Principals, 74 percent of the 650 principals who responded reported budget cuts. Forty percent of the principals said teachers had been let go. Nearly half the principals cut back music, art, and programs for gifted children; 80 percent have eliminated field trips.
Critics have long contended that money's role in education is overrated. It is clear that some school bureaucracies absorb too much money before it reaches the classroom; the National Center for Education Statistics has found that nearly 40 percent of money for education does not go directly to the classroom but is spent on administration, guidance counselors, transportation and other services.
But it is equally clear that in many places schools are hobbled. In rural Hancock County in eastern Tennessee, schools depend on fund raisers to buy all school supplies. In Belington, W.Va., teachers run booths at the local fair to raise money so that they can attend workshops. In Los Angeles, the Aragon Avenue School had to cut playground hours in a neighborhood where children have nowhere else to play.
Young as they are, children in these schools notice. "I think we're cheated out of a lot of things," said Cathleen Miles, a fourth-grader who is organizing a bake sale to raise money for Public School 243 in Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn, one of New York City's poorest neighborhoods. "We used to go to science class and learn about animals. We haven't got to a computer class yet this year, or a music class."
Here are three case studies of what budget cuts have meant to individual schools.
 
 
Mount Healthy, Ohio
A Leaking Roof And No Scissors
 When money got so tight that the kindergarten teacher had to scour garage sales for Lego sets and the nurse was cut back to once a week, the teachers at Rex Ralph Elementary School put the ad in The Wall Street Journal.
"Invest in America's Future," the headline read, inviting benefactors to adopt the school in Mount Healthy, a middle-income suburb of Cincinnati.
No one did.
So the eight leaks in the roof keep dripping, the copier and computer stay broken, the missing "F" volume in the school's only set of encyclopedias goes unreplaced, and teachers continue without a pay raise for a third year.
Times are bad in Mount Healthy, and over the last year and a half voters have rejected four requests for local tax increases to pay for education. The district now spends $4,376 per student, below the national average of $5,240.
State cuts are looming on top of local ones. The district's treasurer, Rebecca Brooks, said the state, which supplies much of Mount Healthy's education budget, held education aid below the inflation rate last year and will cut aid next year.
 
'The Worst I've Ever Seen'
 That means more trouble ahead for Rex Ralph Elementary, where the principal is already making do with one-quarter the money for supplies he had two and a half years ago. "This is my 24th year in education, and this is the worst I've ever seen it," said the principal, Clifford A. Strefelt, a tall, hearty man whose voice these days sounds permanently mournful.
The librarian is gone, and a school aide darts between the computer room and the library. The music teacher now spends half her day at the high school, so instead of music every day, the children have 35 minutes twice a week. Class sizes have risen from 23 a few years ago to nearly 30 now. Wanda Tucker, the school secretary, bought her own thermometer and bandages for the four days a week she doubles as school nurse.
In a country pledged to be the best in math and science by the year 2000, the students at Rex Ralph Elementary use patched-up science textbooks dating from 1981, have no beakers or hot plates for science experiments and saw their computer time cut in half, from four hours a week to two.
"They have nothing special -- no field trips, no paper, no equipment," said Karen Schneider, who praises the school but is nonetheless considering switching her two children to parochial schools. "Our athletic department is raising money through Bingo."
Many parents have rallied behind the school. But the campaign for local tax increases has divided the community, parents say, pitting neighbors who send their children to parochial school against those who chose public schools. "For what people spend on cable TV, we could finance the levy," said Gerry Gutfreund, a children's book writer whose daughter is in first grade at Rex Ralph Elementary.
The local Parent-Teacher Association has tried to fill the biggest gaps, buying a copying machine (now broken) and donating money for library books. But as much as the obvious cuts, teachers mourn the extra touches that they believe make the difference between excelling and just getting by.
Jan Brown has no scissors for her first graders. Catherine Thomas, a fourth-grade teacher, cannot afford the extra paper it takes for the packages of puzzles and games she used to create to help children learn math.
And Beverly Chrisanthus has had to abandon her cherished second-grade play because there is not enough paint, paper or staples for scenery or enough rehearsal time now that the school has to close one evening a week to trim heating and electricity bills.
"I'm drained some days," Mrs. Chrisanthus said. "I wish someone could come in and see how my day starts, with tears, lost money, 'Mom's mad at me' -- then we're supposed to sit down and train these little minds to be the best at math in the world."
Sitting in the library, a group of sixth graders reeled off a list of problems: Old books, big classes, outdated maps, no field trips, no student council.
"Money's more important than us," said Sadie Gaston. "We're left out," said Michael Hill.
 
Brooklyn
A Proud Tradition Lost to Cutbacks
 Once, Joyce Washington saw her school as a testament to the promise of urban education. Now it speaks more eloquently of loss.
Mrs. Washington is principal of the Weeksville School in the heart of Bedford-Stuyvesant, one of New York City's poorest and most crime-ravaged neighborhoods, which nonetheless boasts a proud history as a free black community and a stop on the Underground Railroad for escaping slaves.
The Brooklyn school built much of its curriculum on that history and created a small museum filled with mementos from Weeksville's past. With the help of the Bank Street College of Education, the school retrained teachers, published student writing, and adopted the Follow Through program, designed to insure that the gains of the Head Start preschool program did not fade once children entered elementary school. The Weeksville School, also known as P.S. 243, was chosen as a national model, and helped develop similar programs at 100 other schools.
But after 23 years, the programs are gone.
Mrs. Washington's school has a high percentage of foster children, scarred by abusive or drug-using parents and then bounced from one foster placement to another. The students are familiar with violence. One parent, Marcella Mobley, tells of hitting the ground the other day across the street from the school, unable to reach her son as shots rang out.
A previous cut eliminated the social worker who used to help children, families and teachers cope with these horrors. And with the end of the Follow Through program this fall, the Weeksville School lost a teacher trainer, a neighborhood worker who got parents involved, extra money for books and field trips, and a rich collaboration with Bank Street that sought to recreate a public school along the lines of the institution's nationally renowned private one.
On top of those cuts came others forced by the recession's blows to New York's economy. New York City spends $5,915 on each elementary school child, above the national average, and $16,746 for children in need of special education. The city had to trim school budgets by less than 1 percent this fall, but much deeper cuts are expected next year.
Now a nurse gets to the Weeksville School just once a month. There is no longer a special science teacher to set up a room that children vividly recall as full of animals and science projects. With three school aides gone, it is hard to control children in the lunchroom. Class sizes range between 30 and 35 because the school lost three teachers.
Children are not being taught in closets here. Plants still line many classrooms, and on bright days the sun streams through, creating an aura of cheer. But the contrast between what was and what is rankles parents, teachers and students. For a school with high ambitions, making do is not good enough.
"We'd like to have extra math and science labs, and we do not have access to things like that," said Elmen Meggs, whose grandchildren attend the school and who used to work with the Follow Through program as a parent coordinator. "We know that science and math are important for our children."
 
Difficult Choices
 Maurice Rosenthal used to spend three periods a day with gifted math students. But in one example of the difficult choices posed by cuts, he is now assigned full time to the slowest math students. By giving up his own preparation periods, he manages to see the gifted students twice a week.
"They could use much more than that," he said. "People don't see the beauty of a child who says, 'I really solved this problem."'
The school's students are acutely aware of what they are missing. Their conversation is peppered with lists of what they had last year: a full-time science teacher, a creative writing teacher, a school store, smaller classes, clean bathrooms.
"We're just overwhelmed," said Martha Smith, whose class of 32 sixth graders cannot take science books home at night because there are not enough to go around. "We don't have the supplies we need. We do a lot of group activities in class, and it's hard to keep it under control. When everyone is here, we don't have enough seats." So far this year, Ms. Smith has already spent $400 of her own money to buy supplies such as paper or chalk.
Her class has been thinking about why so much has changed. "Maybe they think we're not worth it," said Bryant Adderley.
 
Montebello, Calif.
Used to Plenty, Shocked by Cuts
 When Vivian Hoorn walked into her classroom this fall, she could not believe what she saw: 45 children staring back at her.
"I thought, 'Surely they will take half these children away,' " she said.
But the children were not going anywhere. Budget cuts have pushed class sizes near 40 at Montebello Intermediate School, a school for fifth to eighth graders just east of Los Angeles.
Ms. Hoorn's class shrank to 38 after several children moved out of the district. She and other teachers are trying to continue the creative teaching methods that have won their school praise in the past. But teachers and students say there is a price.
"You're too stuffed in," said Danny Nunez, as he sat in his sixth-grade class of 42 students. "You can't get as much attention as you did last year," said Julie Franco. "There are so many kids the teacher has to give to," said Jeannette Sanchez.
The Montebello school district, struggling with state budget cuts and its own fiscal problems, had to slash spending by 20 percent this fall and may need to cut an additional 10 percent next year. California, especially hard-hit by this recession, has cut education spending by 12 percent after inflation in the past three years, according to Roger Rasmussen, director of the independent analysis unit of the Los Angeles Unified School District.
Like many other school districts in a state that experienced explosive growth in the 1980's, Montebello drew up its budgets and negotiated multi-year raises with teachers expecting that the good times would roll on. When the recession struck, the district was not prepared for the decline in state aid and is now cutting deeply, according to Montebello's acting superintendent, Darline Robles.
The district now spends about $4,000 per student, below the national average. Montebello's overwhelmingly Hispanic students come from six towns that range from very poor to affluent.
The cuts have jolted Montebello Intermediate, which belonged to a district once known for lavishing moeny on its schools. Class sizes soared because the school lost 12 of 58 teachers, including several bilingual teachers whom the principal, Judith L. Petersen, ranked among her best. Clerical and custodial help was cut. A special art program that took children to local museums had to go.
To Ms. Petersen, who was a student at Montebello in the prosperous 1950's, the cuts are particularly frustrating because she believes that schools now must aim higher than in the past, when many teachers assumed less talented children would drop out.
"We're keeping kids in schools that when I went to school we didn't manage to keep," she said. "It really breaks my heart to lose our funding when I honestly believe we are so close to making it happen."
These days at Montebello, truancy is up because the lone remaining attendance officer, Virginia Garcia, is so overrun keeping track of 1,700 students, and the students are betting their parents will not find out they have played hooky.
Art Revueltas, an assistant principal, dumped an envelope on his desk, and out spilled a gun, several bullets, and a pile of switchblades. So far this year, he has seen three students who told him they had tried to kill themselves, and held up their scarred wrists to prove it.
"These things still go on, and we have fewer people to deal with them," he said. "We have said we can handle all this if you just give us more money. The public is saying that we still want you to do that, but we are going to give you less. Maybe the social contract we've been living under has been cancelled."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
BUSH CONSIDERING A SHIFT IN TACTICS TO FIGHT BUCHANAN

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Despite the discontent evident in the New Hampshire primary results, the White House and the Bush campaign plan no changes in the economic policies of President Bush and focused today on the tactical question of how hard to attack his challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan.
Although Mr. Bush himself still seemed to waver over how far he should go in that direction, the President began his assault on Mr. Buchanan by citing quotations his aides have amassed from the columnist's prolific writings to suggest that Mr. Buchanan wants to make Social Security a voluntary system. 
 Bush aides acknowledged that the President's efforts to sell his economic program had fallen flat in New Hampshire. Mr. Bush's margin of victory over Mr. Buchanan was smaller than the Bush campaign had hoped, although it was larger than early projections from the polling of voters had indicated. Those early figures left the impression that Mr. Bush had barely defeated his rival.
 
Official Results of Vote
 Official results today from the New Hampshire Secretary of State showed that Mr. Bush received 53 percent of the vote and Mr. Buchanan 37 percent, and that 2 percent went to minor candidates and 8 percent to Democratic Presidential contenders whose names were written in on the Republican ballot as a protest. The write-ins were not counted on primary night. Counting only Bush and Buchanan votes, the President defeated Mr. Buchanan by 59 percent to 41 percent.
The results alarmed the White House, but Administration and campaign officials argued that the proper response was to fine-tune and sharpen their political message, and not to make basic policy changes advocated by some Republicans.
For the Democrats, New Hampshire provided Paul E. Tsongas and Bill Clinton with new credibility and set the stage for a tough nomination struggle, with the candidates forced to spread out and appeal to voters from a broader spectrum. [Page A21.]
 
Faith in Economy
 Robert M. Teeter, Mr. Bush's campaign chairman, said, "I'm convinced and the President is convinced that the economy is going to get better in the fall."
This view received some support today from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, who said he saw "stirrings" of an economic recovery, and from figures showing that in January, new-home construction reached its briskest pace since May 1990.
But some disgruntled party regulars complained that Mr. Bush needed an overhaul of both his message and his policies. The campaign's self-inspection, some of which was conducted in public by Mr. Bush himself, reflected broad concerns within the Republican Party about why the President and his high-powered campaign team had stumbled so badly in New Hampshire.
Republican strategists and campaign officials said Mr. Bush had to go beyond the tactical concern of blunting Mr. Buchanan and find his own voice as the primary campaigns broaden into the South, then the West and then the Midwest, and then for the general election.
Mr. Bush's effort in New Hampshire to cater to the right wing of the party, salting his essentially moderate policies with conservative social messages and holding his fire to avoid a party rift, clearly did not work, strategists said. They said it would be of even less use as he tried to appeal to a broader section of the party and to conservative Democrats as the campaign goes on.
The President's own lackluster performance on the stump in New Hampshire also raised questions about the wisdom of basing the campaign's plans on a barnstorming tour of the South that will keep Mr. Bush on the road for most of the next three weeks.
 
Bush's Aloof Stance
 Clearly vexed at Mr. Buchanan's successes in New Hampshire and under pressure from Republican leaders to abandon the aloof stance toward his challenger that had cost him votes there, Mr. Bush today acknowledged that he had allowed himself to "lay back and get hammered" without defending himself.
Mr. Bush told reporters during a visit to Tennessee, one of 11 states that will hold primaries on March 10, Super Tuesday, that he was eager to "roll up my sleeves and go after" his Republican and Democratic adversaries.
But he seemed uncertain about how aggressive he was prepared to be to accomplish his current strategic objectives: to lock up the Republican nomination by early May and then to prevent Mr. Buchanan from hanging on long enough to go to the June 2 California primary, where the Bush campaign fears a nomination struggle would hurt Mr. Bush next November in a hard-to-win state.
"We might have to define the opponent," Mr. Bush said, referring to him by name -- as "Pat" -- for the first time in the campaign and using a common political euphemism for attacking another candidate. "I've been very kind and gentle," Mr. Bush said. "I'll still be kind and I'm now debating how gentle to be."
One issue that continued to vex the Bush camp was Mr. Buchanan's clear success in New Hampshire with commercials that accused Mr. Bush of abandoning a $500 increase in the tax exemption for children because he did not include it among the seven most urgent measures that he wants passed by March 20.
But Administration and Congressional officials said that the White House did not plan to revise its seven-point list, worked out after the State of the Union Message, to include the proposal, or to make any other major shift in economic policy.
"If the message didn't get through, we've got to articulate it better, but fundamentally the message is the same," a top campaign official said today. "It's that he does understand, he had the message long before New Hampshire, that we've got some economic problems in the country that are severe."
Bush aides contend that voters were angrier in New Hampshire because its economic situation was especially bad and that voter dissatisfaction in general is not with Mr. Bush personally, but with the Federal Government as a whole.
"I think people feel that the economy is poised for recovery," Mr. Bush said.
 
'The Gloves Are Off'
 Campaign officials said today Mr. Bush's spokesmen would have a freer hand in criticizing Mr. Buchanan. "I think it's fair to say that the gloves are off," said Charles Black, senior adviser to the Bush campaign.
He added: "Pat made a good showing and he deserves attention, but we know from a lot of history that heavy negatives, not responded to, cost you a lot of votes, and we won't let him get away with that again. We will be discussing some of the issues he's interested in, such as isolationism and protectionism."
A senior Bush campaign official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, focused on Mr. Buchanan's opposition to the war in the Persian Gulf.
"If he wants to debate whether or not the war was a good idea, if he wants to debate whether going into Kuwait or not was a good idea and having Desert Storm, which he didn't support, was a good idea, fine," he said. "We'll debate that with him."
Mr. Bush himself made some indirect swipes at Mr. Buchanan. Asked by reporters in Knoxville, Tenn., how he would define the differences between himself and his challenger, Mr. Bush pushed one of the hottest political buttons there is: Social Security.
"Well, I don't think Social Security ought to be voluntary," Mr. Bush said. "That's the Bush position."
Asked about Mr. Bush's remark, Mr. Buchanan said, "I wouldn't touch Social Security." Asked whether he had ever advocated changing Social Security, he said: "I don't know what I wrote 27 years ago. They are probably digging through the files."
The Bush campaign said the reference came from a 1983 syndicated column in which Mr. Buchanan wrote: "Why not make Social Security voluntary? For black Americans and all Americans. Why not allow young black and white workers to opt out, on condition that they set aside -- in Individual Retirement Accounts -- amounts equal to what they would have given in to Social Security?"
 
How Hard to Fight
 But when it came to attacking Mr. Buchanan directly, Mr. Bush pulled his punches today. Officials were still debating how aggressive Mr. Bush should be, as well as whether to use negative television commercials like one that was prepared for New Hamsphire but never broadcast.
In New Hampshire, Mr. Bush held his fire out of fear of dividing the party. But Mr. Black suggested that the campaign was willing to take that risk for the short-term goal of eliminating Mr. Buchanan. "We'll get the party together," he said. "It just might take us a little longer."

LENGTH: 1144 words

HEADLINE: FED CHIEF UPBEAT ON THE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, today gave his most optimistic assessment in months of the economy's near-term prospects, but he said the signs of an upturn could still peter out.
Testifying before a House subcommittee, Mr. Greenspan said that "we are beginning to see stirrings" of a recovery as he pointed in particular to a pickup in retail sales and in home building, including a 5.5 percent jump in construction of new homes in January that was announced today. [Page D1.] 
 He also said, as he has in other recent testimony, that an economic recovery should take hold in the second quarter.
 
Stresses Lower Inflation
 With his testimony coming in the politically charged atmosphere after the New Hampshire primary, Mr. Greenspan's heavily hedged "on the one hand, on the other hand" testimony seemed to take special pains to avoid partisanship. But his forecast of a recovery in the second quarter, however circumscribed, would seem to reassure White House strategists worried about President Bush's poor showing in the primary because of the economy.
With an eye to the bond markets, which have pushed interest rates up in recent days partly on concern that economic growth could feed inflation, he emphasized that inflation was falling, adding that the nation would soon "have attained the lowest rates of inflation in a generation."
The Labor Department today, in fact, said that consumer prices last month rose only a tenth of 1 percent. Bond prices rallied and interest rates fell in response to that report and to Mr. Greenspan's remarks.
Analysts said that the recent signs of a pickup in economic growth that Mr. Greenspan mentioned today indicated that the Fed was not likely to cut interest rates further anytime soon to stimulate the economy.
Even so, Mr. Greenspan said that the central bank was closely monitoring the economy. He has said several times in recent weeks that the Fed would ease monetary policy further if the economy continues to stall.
Mr. Greenspan said that although the nation's industrial production dropped in January, the Fed's data show an end to that decline in February, as well as improvements in new orders and inventory backlogs.
In addition to the gain in housing construction reported today, which pushed new-home building to its highest level since the middle of 1990, the Government last week reported an increase of six-tenths of a percent in retail sales in January.
 
Could 'Peter Out'
 Saying he was "somewhat more optimistic" about an upturn than he was a few weeks ago, the Fed chairman said: "I don't wish to overemphasize it. It's a series of weeks, and it could just as easily peter out as indeed the much more vigorous recovery of last spring petered out."
He acknowledged that he was wrong to forecast six months ago that the recovery that began last spring would continue. The Fed and most economists were surprised when the modest recovery stalled, largely because of a fall-off in consumer confidence and a new buildup in inventories.
Looking to the nation's long-term prospects, Mr. Greenspan pointedly criticized the White House and Congress for not doing enough to reduce the Federal budget deficit. He said that for the first time in years, the Administration's forecasts did not see the budget reaching a surplus within five years. He noted that current estimates call for a $200 billion Federal deficit in 1996.
The Fed chairman said these levels "are higher than we should be willing to accept" and added that "the large stocks of Federal debt" have "adversely affected our economic prospects by putting upward pressure on real interest rates and thus stunting the growth of the capital stock, on which our future incomes depend."
 
Debts Are the Drag
 In discussing why the economy has not picked up faster, Mr. Greenspan said the main force holding back recovery was that households and businesses were still struggling to reduce the huge debt loads they acquired during the 1980's. Only when households feel they have reduced their debt sufficiently, for instance by refinancing mortgages at lower interest rates, will spending take off again, he said.
"What we do not know," he said, "is how far the adjustment process for balance sheets must proceed prior to the renewal of the normal forces of economic activity."
Making the Federal Reserve's semiannual presentation on monetary policy and the economy before the House Subcommittee on Domestic Monetary Policy, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed believed the nation's economy would grow by 1.75 percent to 2.5 percent this year. The White House has forecast 2.2 percent growth. He said the jobless rate, currently 7.1 percent, would edge down this year to between 6.75 and 7 percent, and that core inflation would decline this year, with inflation registering between 3 and 3.5 percent. That compares with 3 percent inflation in 1991 when weak oil prices pulled down the rate.
As he has before, Mr. Greenspan said he supported President Bush's proposals to reduce the capital gains tax and to restore certain tax breaks for the real estate industry to help it climb off the floor. In the past he has warned against other tax cut proposals promoted as providing short-term stimulus, saying they might push up the deficit.
 
Questions from Schumer
 When Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, asked him whether raising taxes for one portion of the population and lowering them for another would have a stimulative or negative effect, Mr. Greenspan responded that "most economists would say its effect would be negligible."
Mr. Greenspan said the Fed's announcement Tuesday that it was reducing banks' reserve requirements should help increase their profits and ultimately encourage them to lend more to help lift the economy. The decision to cut reserves on checking and other transaction accounts will allow banks to invest some $8 billion to $9 billion that was not earning income. This move is expected to increase bank profits by about $400 million a year, analysts said.
Mr. Greenspan disclosed that the central bank had voted to reaffirm the 1992 monetary growth targets it had tentatively decided on last July. He said this year's growth target for M-2, a broad definition of money, was between 2.5 percent and 6.5 percent, the same range as last year.
Representative Schumer asked the Fed chairman why he had said, "There are reasons to believe that business activity should pick up," when the official text of his speech said, "There are reasons to believe that business activity will pick up."
Mr. Greenspan said that when he read the text of his speech this morning: "I said to myself that this is an inappropriate statement. 'Will' presupposed necessity. And in that type of context the appropriate word is 'should' so I edited it."

LENGTH: 1234 words

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
By Trip's End, Moscow Looks Good

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 18

 BODY:
It began as a low whisper among aides to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. But as the plane taking them to Moscow at the close of Mr. Baker's grueling tour of former Soviet republics took off, the whispers grew into a vigorous chant: "Penta, Penta, Penta, Penta."
The Penta is the deluxe German-run hotel in Moscow where Mr. Baker always stays. After a week of sleeping often two or three to a room in seedy, run-down former Communist Party guest houses in the wilds of Ashkhabad and Dushanbe, Mr. Baker's aides were desperate for the down comforters, hot water and efficiency of the Penta. It was the first time any of them could recall longing to get to Moscow. 
 But few expressed regrets about being on Mr. Baker's whistlestop run through Moldova, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and the Russian hinterland, for it provided a broad look at life in the former Soviet empire.
The trip was symbolized by the buttons in the elevator of the October Hotel in Yekaterinburg, formerly known as Sverdlovsk, in the eastern foothills of the Ural Mountains in Russia. The buttons were listed as follows: 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 2.
Evidently, the elevator technicians forgot about the second floor and decided to add the button for it later. And that was pretty much how Mr. Baker found life on the road from Kishinev to Samarkand: haphazard and at times incomprehensible, very often pleasing to the eye from afar, but just a little bit off kilter upon closer inspection.
There was a pool table in Mr. Baker's guest house in Tashkent, but four balls were missing, including the cue ball. There was a discotheque in the guest house in Baku, Azerbaijan: a man-made grotto with concrete stalactites dripping from the ceiling and a bizarre music video of alleged Armenian atrocities in the contested enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh.
There were guest houses with no baths and guest houses with no showers. And there was the guest house in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, with no shower or bath -- only a sink with a shower attachment where the faucet belonged. People were showering on their knees.
The Dushanbe hotel also had no heat in half the rooms. On one side of the hall people were sleeping in their overcoats, but on the other side the rooms were so overheated that people were sleeping with their doors open. It was hard to believe that this was where privileged Communist Party officials once came to relax.
The five-star award, though, definitely went to the Seabaco Hotel in Kishinev, Moldova, which offered a 24-hour pedicure service, which several reporters traveling with Mr. Baker sampled at 2:00 A.M. The reporters were up because the hotel front desk had chosen that hour to call the rooms of the press contingent to ask them all to come downstairs to pay their room bills.
 
Phone Deregulation
 Nothing was more diverse than the prices, as some republics seem to have quickly jumped on the free-market bandwagon and others appear not to have caught on to even the rudiments of capitalism. In Yekaterinburg, the hotel charged 36 rubles, or 3.6 cents, per minute for an international direct-dial phone call to the United States. In Samarkand, Uzbekistan, the managers of the former Communist Party guest house informed reporters that an international phone call would cost $26 a minute -- cash only, please. After reporters shouted in protest, the price was reduced to $7 a minute. Why $7? Why $26? No one could explain.
Food, even fresh fruit, seemed to be available everywhere from Armenia to Uzbekistan, but at prices far beyond anything affordable to the average worker. In Armenia, only a few meager pears and grapes were on sale in the market, but in Uzbekistan, the market appeared to be rich with fruit and vegetables.
The real shortages everywhere are not of food but of medicines, American officials say. The Soviet Union used to import most of its disposable medical supplies -- from syringes to aspirin to antibiotics -- from its former Eastern European satellites. Now they are demanding hard currency and the commonwealth governments simply cannot pay.
In the barter market in Yekaterinburg, where people come each day to swap anything for anything, reporters found a man holding up a flimsy piece of cardboard upon which were displayed a few adhesive bandages, some packets of aspirin and several unidentifiable medical items. He was apparently bartering them for food.
 
The Czar's Skull
 With the collapse of the Soviet Union, little signs of a monarchist revival are beginning to appear. In Yekaterinburg, Mr. Baker was taken to the site of the house, now marked with a simple wooden cross and a few stones, where the last czar, Nicholas II, and his family were held and later killed by the Bolsheviks in 1918.
A freelance monarchist in a floppy fur hat tends the site and for no charge will describe the killing of "those whom God had chosen to lead Russia." Anyone who stands in the cold to listen to his lecture is rewarded with a free picture of the Czar's son, Aleksei.
The governor of the Yekaterinburg district, which local officials described as a hotbed of monarchism, took Mr. Baker to a pathology lab to examine the skulls and bones that local authorities believe are the remains of the Czar's family. Their bodies had had acid poured on them before being buried in a forest outside the city, but 10 years ago local monarchists, using acid tests on the soil, discovered what they believe were the family remains.
Mr. Baker described being shown what is believed to be the head of Czar Nicholas II with its gold teeth still in place. Others had visible bullet holes through their skulls, he said. In the first known joint venture between the United States and local monarchists, Mr. Baker offered to send American forensic experts to Yekaterinburg to help them test conclusively whether the bones are those of the last czar.
 
Cable-Ready Republics
 In Baku, Azerbaijan, one of President Ayaz N. Mutalibov's bodyguards was standing outside his doorway when a horde of American reporters arrived for a news conference. The mustachioed Azerbaijani guard just stood there, arms folded across his chest, shaking his head back and forth as if to say, "This rabble is not entering the President's office." But after a standoff of about five seconds, he was literally stampeded by the reporters.
It seemed to symbolize the way in which some of these newly independent states were overwhelmed by their first real encounter with the Western press. At each stop, republic leaders would share a news conference with Mr. Baker. For most of these leaders it was their first Western-style grilling.
Some, like Rakhman N. Nabaiyev of Tajikistan, found it torture. He summarily cut off the news conference after the second question, one about Iran's influence in his republic. Mr. Nabaiyev promised the reporters traveling with Mr. Baker that before the Secretary departed, "Of course, we will have the possibility of meeting you once more." But he was never seen again.
Nevertheless, usually one of the first questions Mr. Baker got from all these Central Asian leaders was: "How do I get CNN?" The Central Asians were obsessed with being able to get their news from sources independent of Moscow. Having CNN, they explained, was the symbol of such independence, as well as a real membership card in the club of Western states.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Hampshire;
Democratic Candidates' Next Three Weeks: a Scramble Around America

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.H., Feb. 19

 BODY:
The race for the Democratic nomination rolled out of New Hampshire today with a newly credible Paul E. Tsongas, a revived Bill Clinton and a far more complicated course ahead, with primaries and caucuses in 25 states over the next three weeks.
Mr. Tsongas, a former Senator from Massachusetts, got the opportunity to build a national campaign on his New Hampshire victory and demonstrate that he can carry his message beyond his region. Declaring that he had "great potential to move," he began a trip to Maryland, New York, South Dakota, Maine and Georgia, a scramble emblematic of the days to come, and the challenge he faces in quickly and substantially expanding his campaign. 
 New Hampshire gave Governor Clinton of Arkansas a second chance, after two weeks of harrowing publicity over allegations about marital infidelity and his draft record. A variety of Democrats also agreed that Mr. Clinton's performance in the primary freezes talk of new candidates entering the race any time soon. Those signals came from several party members including Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley, who told reporters, "I personally don't expect to see it."
 
A Long, Tough Struggle Ahead
 Beyond that, New Hampshire simply set the stage for a long, tough struggle for the nomination, when the candidates will have to spread out, target their opportunities, appeal to voters from across a much broader spectrum, and rely to a much greater extent on money and news media than they did in the confines of this tiny state.
"We'll know a lot more by mid-March," said Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee. Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the chairman of the House Democratic Caucus and a supporter of Mr. Clinton, said, "Clinton did well enough to be in a holding pattern and not be written off, and Tsongas did well enough to make him a real factor."
Most Democrats look to March 3 for the next sorting out, when primaries and caucuses will be held in Colorado, Georgia, Idaho, Maryland, Minnesota, Utah and Washington. An additional 11 states will have contests a week later, on March 10. First, however, come the Maine caucuses on Sunday and South Dakota primary on Tuesday.
 
Mixed Verdicts
 The verdicts were less clear for the rest of the field, which finished well behind Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton. The two Midwesterners in the race, Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, will be hustling for a victory in the South Dakota primary. Mr. Kerrey acknowledged today that he needed to "do very well" in South Dakota to stay in the race, but felt that he was "hitting my stride" as a candidate.
Mr. Harkin said he also hoped to "pick up steam" in South Dakota and indicated he planned to escalate his already aggressive attacks. Referring to Mr. Clinton, the Iowa Democrat asserted, "I'm going to start talking about the Arkansas mirage. If that's the way he runs Arkansas, God help us if he ever gets to the Presidency."
Former Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California did better than most of the polls here had predicted, finishing in the neighborhood of Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Harkin.
The final results in New Hampshire showed Mr. Tsongas with 33 percent, Mr. Clinton with 25 percent, Mr. Kerrey with 11 percent, Mr. Harkin with 10 percent, Mr. Brown with 8 percent, and the write-in effort for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo at 4 percent.
 
Splitting Delegates
 Both Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton emerged from New Hampshire with 9 delegates each. None of the other candidates cracked the 15 percent threshold that, under party rules, is required to qualify for delegates. Because of the Democratic rules apportioning delegates based on Congressional districts, both Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton ended up with the same number of delegates even though their overall vote totals differed.
Surveys of voters leaving the polling place showed that Mr. Tsongas did particularly well among the most educated voters, getting 47 percent of those who had more than a college education. He also got four in 10 of those with income over $75,000, while three in 10 from that group went for Mr. Clinton.
The polling data also showed that Mr. Tsongas ran well among those voters who said that a candidate having specific ideas was important to them; 43 percent of that group went for Mr. Tsongas, and 22 percent for Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Tsongas predicted today that he and Mr. Clinton would, at some point, "go head to head on economic issues." Mr. Tsongas cites his economic proposals as basic truth-telling and a bold challenge to Democratic orthodoxy; he rejects a tax cut for the middle class and endorses a cut in the tax on capital gains to encourage investment. How well that will play among Democratic primary voters around the country, some analysts said, is an open question.
 
Chilly Reception Predicted
 Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's polltaker, asserted, "This is an ecnomic plan that I don't think many Democrats will warm to."
The candidates are still making decisions on how to direct their resources in the coming weeks, although Mr. Tsongas has clearly targeted Maryland and Mr. Clinton will focus on Georgia. Mr. Greenberg said the Clinton campaign recognizes it needs to do well both inside and outside the South. "This is not going to be a bunker campaign," he said.
Money will be critical in the weeks to come. Rahm Emmanuel, Mr. Clinton's finance director, said the campaign will have raised $7 million by the end of February, adding, "We had always raised money and garnered resources based on a long-term strategy. Our worst day is Paul Tsonga's best day in terms of money."
A spokesman for Mr. Tsongas declined to furnish fundraising totals, but said that in the wake of the New Hampshire victory, the money was beginning to flow in.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul E. Tsongas, the Democratic winner in New Hampshire, began searching yesterday for the money and votes to continue his campaign. He responded to cheers at a fund-raising event in Astoria, Queens. (Nick Malter for The New York Times)
