HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Bush Supporters Try to Figure Out How Their Campaign Went Wrong

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.H., Feb. 19

 BODY:
Last week, President Bush's strategists here made a television commercial featuring a retired state police major, who recalled that when Mr. Bush was making the decision to send American troops to the Persian Gulf, "Pat Buchanan stood with Teddy Kennedy, Alan Cranston and the liberal Democrats, and said our boys couldn't fight."
Arguing first that negative advertising was un-Presidential, then that the ad was too late, the White House refused to put it on the air, 
 The decision not to "go negative," said a ranking official of the Bush campaign here, was one of two mistakes that together cost Mr. Bush his chance to knock Patrick J. Buchanan out of the race, or at least slow him down. The other mistake, the official said, was the President's failure to include his proposal for a $500 middle-class tax benefit, a popular feature of his State of the Union message, in the tax bill he sent to Congress.
 
11 Points Lost?
 One local strategist, who spoke on condition that he not be named, said the campaign's private polls, as well as some aspects of polls taken for news organizations, convinced him that Mr. Bush lost 11 percentage points as a result of the missteps. Had the President added those 11 points to his total, he would have defeated Mr. Buchanan among voters who chose those two candidates by 70 percent to 30 percent, the kind of landslide that would surely have deflated the Buchanan campaign.
In a telephone interview, Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire agreed that the President had made serious errors, including failing to send moderate Republicans like Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico to the state. But even if he had done everything exactly right, Mr. Rudman argued, Mr. Bush would still have had trouble gaining a two-to-one victory in a state where he has never been terribly popular and where the economy has been devastated.
Mr. Bush's showing here might have been even worse had the White House, warned of budding disaster at midday, not ordered a redoubled effort to get Bush supporters to the voting booths. According to a senior Republican here, the Bush camp learned from news reporters that polls of people who had voted Tuesday morning showed them splitting almost evenly, with women much more pro-Bush than men. Ron Kaufman, the White House political director, then ordered a major telephone effort to insure that women cast ballots.
 
'Enormous Second Hurdle'
 For all of Mr. Buchanan's success here, he acknowledged this morning that with 13 primaries scheduled in the next three weeks, he faced a daunting prospect -- "an enormous second hurdle to overcome, even higher than the first one." His problems are complicated by his lack of a convenient place to challenge the President before Georgia votes on March 3.
The plan had been to compete in South Dakota, which votes on Tuesday, but the Bush forces, Mr. Buchanan asserted, "successfully kept us off the ballot there."
Buchanan aides said he had no plans to mount major campaigns in Maryland, which also votes on March 3, or in the Colorado primary and Washington caucuses that same day, although he intends to visit Colorado next week.
 
South Toward Georgia
 That makes Georgia crucial. The Republican party there has traditionally been a country-club party, to use the local phrase, meaning that it has been dominated by affluent white suburbanites. But election rules in the state permit anyone to ask for a Republican ballot and Mr. Buchanan will no doubt try to appeal to conservative Democrats as well as Republicans.
If Georgia goes well, and state party officials say the challenger could easily pull a third of the vote or more, Mr. Buchanan hopes his protectionist views will prove popular with textile workers in South Carolina, which is to vote on March 7.
After that, Mr. Buchanan has laid plans for a major effort on March 10, Super Tuesday, when eight Republican primaries are scheduled. According to his strategists, he will contest the primaries in Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma and Tennessee on that day, and will take the President on as well in a number of the Congressional districts in both Florida and Texas.
How many districts will depend on how much money he can raise, because only television can take his message into the dozens of major cities and hundreds of small towns that form the political target for Super Tuesday.
According to campaign officials, Mr. Buchanan has only $150,000 to $200,000 in cash on hand, having spent $1.5 million on television alone during his 45-day campaign in New Hampshire. But a direct-mail solicitation went out on Monday to 40,000 Buchanan supporters, and the campaign hopes it will bring in $250,000. Two more mailings to 300,000 people will be sent out over the next week, and the campaign said that it hoped to get $1 million in Federal matching funds on March 2.
 
'Guerrilla Operation'
 In their post-mortems, New Hampshire Republicans expressed admiration for Mr. Buchanan's insurgent campaign, which one of them called "the best guerrilla operation since the Vietcong." But there was endless criticism of the Bush campaign, too, covering every point from the quality of the television commercials, which were described as bland and routine, to the amount of time the President spent in the state, to the decision to use an out-of-state telephone bank.
Gov. Judd Gregg, the chairman of the Bush campaign in New Hampshire, declined comment on the strains between the Washington staff and those in the state.
"I got the feeling that the White House was willing to take whatever hit they got in this state and move on," said a veteran of several Presidential primaries in the state. "They said they didn't want to go after Buchanan because it would upset the conservatives they'd need later."
Another Republican active in the Bush campaign here commented, "If the mission was to win big, they certainly didn't show it. You have to have a clear message in these things, and they were on cruise control, as if they thought that Bush was defined forever politically by Desert Storm."
 
Persian Gulf Mattered Little
 In fact, with the President's television commercials touching only lightly on the subject, exit polls showed that only 7 percent of primary voters named the Persian Gulf war as one of the issues that mattered most in deciding how they voted. Of those, 95 percent cast their vote for Mr. Bush.
On the economy and jobs, which not surprisingly mattered a lot to a lot of voters, there was no significant difference. But the President's attempts on his first trip here and in his early commercials to convince New Hampshire voters that he had not forgotten them apparently failed. Those voters who said choosing someone "who cares about people like me" mattered a lot to them, 13 percent of the total, split 70-30 for Mr. Buchanan.
Mr. Buchanan also pulled a majority of those who said their family situation was worse than 10 years ago and a majority of those who thought the national economy was declining.
There was support in the poll as well for the Bush lieutenants here who argued that the President's failure to push for the $500 exemption, which Mr. Buchanan attacked in advertisements during the final weekend, had been costly. Of those voters who decided in the last week, Mr. Buchanan got 56 percent, it showed, and of those who made up their minds in the last three days, he got 58 percent.

HEADLINE: Japanese Slain In Boston Hotel, Adding to Fears

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The president of a Japanese university, here to sign an exchange agreement with the University of Massachusetts in Boston, was shot and killed in his hotel room on Tuesday evening, an act likely to feed stereotypes in Japan about the prevalence of crime in America.
Iwao Matsuda, the 72-year-old president of Chukyo University in Nagoya, was shot in the back after a man with a bandana over his face forced his way into the visitor's 16th-floor room in the elegant Westin Hotel, the police said. 
 While Mr. Matsuda struggled with the masked intruder, his wife, Akiko, ran into the hallway and then heard a shot, said Joseph Saia, Boston's superintendent of police.
 
Nothing Taken From Room
 Mr. Saia said that while robbery might have been a motive, nothing had been taken from the room. The suspect escaped.
News of Mr. Matsuda's killing was prominently reported in many Japanese newspapers and television newscasts.
"I don't think this incident will have any political impact on Japan's relations with America," said Yoichi Kawakami, the New York bureau chief for Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's three national daily papers.
"But, I am sorry to say, this is because Japanese already know America is a very dangerous place to stay, especially the big cities," Mr. Kawakami said in a telephone interview. "So the Japanese people will feel this is one more example of what happens in America."
 
'A Particularly Bad Time'
 Mr. Matsuda's slaying comes at an especially sensitive time in America's relations with Japan, shortly after President Bush's controversial trip to Tokyo and amid rising calls for protectionism in the United States and a series of negative comments about Americans by leading Japanese politicians.
"Anything like this comes at a bad time, but this is a particularly bad time," said Donald Klein, a professor of political science at Tufts University and an expert on Japan. Mr. Klein said that while Japanese tourists to the United States have often been the target of thieves or muggers, he believed that Mr. Matsuda was the most prominent Japanese ever to be the victim of a serious crime in this country.
Mr. Klein said the incident could buttress in some Japanese their views about the United States as a society in decline. In the last few years some Japanese have taken an increasingly dark and sometimes contemptuous view of the United States, focusing on issues like the high crime rate, poor public schools and what is perceived in Japan as a general lack of self-discipline.
Mr. Matsuda, a onetime university track star, had arrived in Boston Tuesday afternoon to participate in the ceremonial signing of what was described by school officials as a "sister school" agreement with the University of Massachusetts in Boston, an urban branch of the state university system. The signing, scheduled for today, has been postponed.
Toshiki Saito, the consul for economic affairs in the Japanese consulate in Boston, said of Mr. Matsuda's slaying, "This tragedy is upside down, the exact opposite of what he was aiming at." Mr. Matsuda had come to Boston, Mr. Saito said, "to promote better understanding betweeen the United States and Japan" through the cultural exchange program.
The incident was promptly reported in Japan, whose newspapers and television stations had many reporters in the Boston area Tuesday to cover the Presidential primary in New Hampshire.
The agreement between the two universities would allow students at each school to study at the other, to share research and to develop a program of seminars on international trade, according to Walter D. Littell, a spokesman for the Boston branch of the University of Massachusetts. It would expand an existing program that began in 1990 under which Chukyo University has sent 35 to 40 students to Boston each summer for a three-week course, he said.
 
No Decision About Agreement
 Commenting on the program's future, Mr. Littell said: "I think in the back of everyone's mind is, 'How are the Japanese going to react? What are they going to think, again, about America?' "
A member of the Chukyo delegation said no decision had been made about completing the agreement.
Chukyo, which has 11,500 students, is a relatively new university in Japan, having been established after World War II. Several Japanese journalists said the university is better known in Japan for its athletes than its scholars. Mr. Matsuda himself was trained as a sports psychologist.
Noboru Nakagaki, vice dean of the faculty of management at Chukyo and one of six members of the school's delegation visiting Boston, described Mr. Matsuda as "very good and gentle." He knew no one in Boston, Mr. Nakagaki said.
He said the delegation had arrived at Logan International Airport in Boston at 3:30 P.M. Tuesday and had just settled in their rooms at the Westin Hotel in the city's fashionable Back Bay section when the incident occured at about 6 P.M.
Mr. Saia, the Boston police superintendent, said that after the shooting Mrs. Matsuda, who does not speak English, "was running down the hallway banging on doors, trying to get somebody's attention."
William McCreary, a senior vice president of Westin Hotel & Resorts, said the incident was the first slaying in the hotel's eight-year history.
He also said the hotel has an excellent security record, although it is part of a large, heavily patronized shopping complex, Copley Place, and is only a few blocks from Boston's South End, a high-crime neighborhood.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Iwao Matsuda, left, president of Chukyo University in Nagoya, Japan, was shot by a masked intruder in his elegant hotel room in Boston. Toshiki Salto, consul for Economic Affairs at the Japanese Consulate, expressed distress over the killing as Police Commissioner Mickey Roache looked on. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Tokyo Shift Seen on Rice

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Japanese Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, told lawmakers today that Japan had no choice but to open its rice market to imports, the Kyodo news service reported.
Replying to a question from an opposition member of the lower house of Parliament, Mr. Watanabe said Japan must open its market under a system of tariffs or risk being held responsible for a failure of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. 
 A breakdown of the GATT talks over agricultural trade would deal a severe blow to Japan's export-dependent economy, he said.
Assuming the United States and European Community reach agreement on a system of tariffs to replace nontariff trade barriers, Japan will have no choice but to go along, Mr. Watanabe said.
Japan's rice market is closed to all imports to protect the country's politically powerful farmers. Japanese rice costs roughly 10 times the global average.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 The Economy
The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, gave his most optimistic assessment in months of the economy's near-term prospects, though he said any upturn could still stall. He told a House subcommittee that he saw "stirrings" of a recovery, particularly in retail sales and homebuilding. [Page A1.]
New-home construction in January surged 5.5 percent from December to its briskest pace since May 1990. But the rise occurred only in the Midwest, with other regions falling. [D1.] 
 Consumer prices rose one-tenth of a percent in January, heralding what economists say could prove to be the least inflationary period in a generation. [D8.]
House Democrats modified their tax-cut measure in response to protests that it offered little to stimulate the economy. [D1.]
The Senate passed an energy bill intended to encourage alternative-fuel vehicles and ease regulations on utilities. [A1]
The business of tracking down assets hidden by white-collar criminals is booming, thanks to scandals and bankruptcies. [A1.]
A Federal appeals panel ruled that the Government may not favor women in awarding broadcast licenses. [A1.]
 
 Companies
A leading candidate to become the next chairman of I.B.M. will leave to head Hughes Aircraft. Analysts said the departure left I.B.M. with no clear successor at a crucial time. [D1.]
Pebble Beach golf resort in California is being sold by its Japanese owner to another Japanese corporation. [D3.] .
Centocor said the F.D.A. had raised "additional issues" concerning its flagship drug. [D4.]
The two main companies involved in the interruption of telephone service in the Washington area eight months ago said they had taken steps to insure the accident did not recur. [D4.]
A former Prudential Securities executive contends that the firm coerced executives into making political contributions. [D4.]
An important lawmaker supported newspaper publishers in their campaign to keep the regional Bell telephone companies from owning electronic data services. [D9.]
Tele-Communications, the largest cable operator, agreed to sell its United Artists movie theater chain for $680 million. The move came after it bought part of a telephone company. [D9.]
 
 International
Thirteen years before B.C.C.I. was seized in 1991, a senior American bank examiner warned that the Luxembourg-based bank was loaded with bad loans and used questionable practices. [D1.]
Swiss banking, long an unchanging symbol of discreet prosperity, is suddenly mired in difficulties. [D1.]
Germany forgave half the $5.5 billion debt Poland owes the Government, but German bankers criticized the action. [D3.]
 
 Markets
Stocks closed mixed, with blue-chips up slightly and the broader market moderately weak. The Dow rose 5.59 points. [D12]
Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates moved lower on signs that inflationary pressures remain modest. [D18.]
The dollar settled lower against all major currencies except the Japanese yen. Gold fell in the U.S., to $353 an ounce. [D19.]
Wheat futures prices ended with a modest gain on a report that the former Soviet republics were buying wheat futures. [D19.]
 
 Today's Columns
Oregon Steel Mills, which makes steel by melting scrap, is the only American steelmaker to increase profits last year. But its stock price doesn't reflect its success. Market Place. [D12.]
A program to police the content of political advertising is being reviewed after serious faults became evident in a test during the New Hampshire primary. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D10.]

HEADLINE: Beth Israel Reaches Pact With Union

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan reached a potentially precedent-setting accord with the hospital workers' union yesterday that guarantees all 4,000 employees their jobs for the duration of the 40-month contract, provides them with free medical benefits and creates an unusual partnership with management to improve recruitment, training and patient care.
The agreement does not specify the size of wage increases. Rather, it promises to match, at the union's option, whatever raises are negotiated either with the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes, the industry's main bargaining group for 38 institutions in New York City and Long Island, or with the hospitals operated in Manhattan and the Bronx by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. 
 The accord approved yesterday by Beth Israel's board could have profound implications locally and nationally. It further signals a shift in organized labor's top priorities from pay increases to job security and health care.
 
Accord Reached Early
 Strategically, the early settlement -- more than three months before the industrywide contract expires -- echoes the union's 1989 divide-and-conquer technique when it reached agreement first with the Archdiocese and then divided the hospital league by luring defectors, among them Beth Israel.
With a high occupancy rate, Beth Israel is regarded as being in better financial condition than many other private and voluntary hospitals in the league, some of which are contemplating layoffs in response to state budget cuts. In recent years, it has also pursued a labor relations policy that Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union, has described as enlightened and has attributed largely to Beth Israel's president, Dr. Robert G. Newman.
The contract, Dr. Newman said, "is a very new approach and it is made possible because of a very specific set of circumstances at Beth Israel Medical Center and they relate to attitude."
The new contract, effective on July 1, represents "a commonality of interest," he said, in labor peace, job security and patient care and marks "the most productive way to enhance revenues and economize on costs."
"As much as it sounds like a radical approach, the Japanese workplace concept is what we are putting into practice," Dr. Newman said.
Victor Gotbaum, a former municipal labor leader who heads the Center for Labor Management Policy Studies at the City University of New York Graduate Center, described the job security, health benefit and joint management aspects of the agreement as "a stunning breakthrough."
Industry executives were considerably more subdued. Chastened by its first encounter with Mr. Rivera, who revived the local after years of dissension, the hospital league has hired a new president, a labor negotiator and a public relations adviser in a determined effort not to be whipsawed by the union again.
"It obviously doesn't set a pattern if there's no money," said Bruce C. McIver, the league's president, who previously headed the Long Island Rail Road and was the city's labor relations director. "I don't think it's terribly important from my perspective."
Edward Silver, a veteran labor lawyer who is the league's chief negotiator, was equally sanguine. "They had to do what they had to do that was best for them," he said of Beth Israel, "but I should think it would not have any meaningful effect on the league's negotiations."
 
Beth Israel Still in League
 Beth Israel is still a member of the league but as Dr. Newman said yesterday after the medical center's board voted, "our membership under these circumstances is an irrelevance." The board chairman, Morton P. Hyman, described the settlement as "equitable, fair and appropriate."
Local 1199 represents maintenance, service, clinical, technical and professional workers. It also negotiates for many private hospital nurses, although they are covered by a separate contract. Formal negotiations have not yet begun.
The no-layoff provision, broached by Dr. Newman early last month, was embraced enthusiastically by Mr. Rivera, who then proposed the partnership involving recruitment, training and service delivery.
When the league capitulated in 1989 hours before a strike deadline, the union won wage increases of 7 1/2, 7 1/2 and 5 percent, plus $500 in the final year. Mr. Rivera hinted that the recession, combined with budget cuts being imposed or threatened by Albany, make increases that large less likely this time.
But the agreement on guaranteed job security, free health care provided by a panel of Beth Israel doctors, the partnership that Mr. Rivera said would contribute to "a friendly workplace" and the hospital's pledge not to obstruct union organizing reflected what the union's nearly 100,000 members in the metropolitan region say are their priorities.
One option now available to union members is to obtain medical services from an approved panel of doctors without paying any out-of-pocket expenses, but the preferred provider organization that would be established by Beth Israel for Local 1199 members who work there apparently would significantly expand the existing program for in-patient and out-patient services.
While they are adversaries at the bargaining table, Mr. Rivera has enlisted executives of the private and nonprofit voluntary hospitals in lobbying for higher Medicaid reimbursement rates and other assistance from the state, local and Federal governments, which benefit both the institutions and their workers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Job guarantees and free medical benefits were part of a tentative agreement reached yesterday between Beth Israel Medical Center and its hospital workers. Dr. Robert G. Newman, left, president of the medical center, and Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199, spoke about the new contract. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times) (pg. B2)
 
Chart: "Highlights: The Hospital Contract"
 From the 40-month contract agreed to yesterday by Beth Israel Medical Center and Local 1199 of the hospital workers union:
 * A guarantee of no layoffs for current employees and newly hired workers for the duration of the contract.
 * Creation of a preferred provider organization at Beth Israel, which will provide Local 1199 workers there with their present health care benefits and expand free benefits.
 * Establishment of a labor-management committee to develop programs to train union members in new skills, to increase the employee role in improving patient care and the structure of health-care delivery.
 * Neutrality by Beth Israel in response to union organizing campaigns.
 * An expedited arbitration and mediation process.
 * Preferential hiring for employees laid off by other hospitals and creation of an 1199 employment agency.
 * A promise to match wage increases granted by institutions represented by the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes or by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.
 * Contributions by Beth Israel to the 1199 employer child care fund; increased pension fund contributions. (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: Hearing NASA Head, Panel Condemns His Ouster

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Members of Congress today condemned what they said was the forced resignation of the space agency administrator, Richard H. Truly.
Their comments came as Mr. Truly appeared before them to defend the Bush Administration's budget for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. 
 Representative Norman Mineta, Democrat of California, said the Administration was using the space agency as "a political poker chip" and "a public relations tool for the rehabilitation of Dan Quayle."
Vice President Quayle and the National Space Council, which he heads, have been at odds with NASA and Mr. Truly over management issues. President Bush said last week that he had "regretfully" accepted Mr. Truly's resignation, although Mr. Truly said he had been asked to step down.
"Whatever political or policy agendas the White House may have, neither NASA or Admiral Truly deserve this treatment," Mr. Mineta said. Other Congressmen of both parties praised Mr. Truly's tenure.
 
Republicans Are Critical
 Mr. Truly appeared before the Space Subcommittee of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology. He defended the Administration's proposed $15 billion budget for NASA in the fiscal year 1993, although he said it provided for no growth after inflation.
But Republicans were sharply critical of that budget. Representative James Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin and others said the Administration is trying to continue too many space programs while failing to set priorities and eliminate unworthy projects.
Representative Dick Zimmer of New Jersey called it "a Buck Rogers budget -- long on fantasy but short on reality."
"There simply will not be enough money available in the future to complete all the programs set forth in this spending blueprint," Mr. Zimmer said.
Mr. Truly's resignation, effective on April 1, comes as the agency faces another battle in Congress over efforts to eliminate the $30 billion space station, which would receive $2.25 billion in the next fiscal year. Mr. Truly said that budget cuts had forced a nine-month delay on the station but that it remains essentially on schedule.

HEADLINE: 2 Items to Spur Investments Put Into Democrats' Tax Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Responding to protests from their colleagues that their tax plan offered little to stimulate the economy, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee modified the measure today to add two provisions to spur investment.
In a two-hour party caucus this morning, complaints rose across a broad spectrum of ideology that the original recommendation of a permanent one percentage point cut in the corporate income tax would not only do little good but would also look bad when compared with the measure's two-year cut in taxes for the middle class. 
 So the committee Democrats agreed this afternoon to scale back that corporate tax reduction to two years, which put their measure in surplus by $7.1 billion over six years. The tax increases in the measure, primarily increases in the top personal income tax rates, total $93.3 million.
They agreed on two other two-year measures. One was President Bush's proposal for an Investment Tax Allowance permitting increased first-year depreciation for new equipment. The second was a plan to allow small businesses to deduct directly -- instead of depreciating -- up to $25,000 of new investment instead of the current $10,000.
Democrats will discuss the revised plan at another party caucus on Thursday. If the changes are sufficient to satisfy today's critics, they plan to bring the measure to the House floor for a vote next week.
While the Democrats were tinkering, House Republicans were plotting and chortling. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 Republican in the House, said his troops planned to disrupt the House next week if the Democrats stacked procedural rules against them on the tax bill.
Democrats usually arrange House procedures to the disadvantage of the Republicans, who usually just complain. But Mr. Gingrich said his party would do more next week, using tactics he likened to those employed by outraged House members in the last century and by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the 20th.
The Republicans, at a caucus of their own, did not discuss adding any provisions to Mr. Bush's seven-point plan that he says is urgently needed to bolster the economy. Mr. Gingrich said that while some members might have suggested adding some form of middle-income tax break of their own, they did not because they enjoyed being in the position of citing the statement of the Democratic winner in the New Hampshire primary, former Senator Paul Tsongas, that he would veto the Democratic bill if he were President.
 
Tsongas Stand Invoked
 Representative Jerry Lewis, chairman of the House Republican Conference, called on Democrats to respond to their leader in New Hampshire. Mr. Gingrich said Democrats "refuse to pass a signable growth proposal and will not even write one that their own candidate, Paul Tsongas, would sign."
Mr. Tsongas has been especially critical of the heart of the Democratic measure, two years of tax credits of up to $400 a year for a couple earning $26,000 or more, and up to $200 for individuals earning $13,000 or more.
President Bush said today in Knoxville, Tenn.: "It's a little ironic that the Democratic front-runner, who could well be the party's standard-bearer, opposes what the Democrats in the House of Representatives are doing. I mean they are out of step with their own leader at this point."
House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, asked his view of Mr. Tsongas's stand, said, "I don't agree with it, and the public will decide whether Senator Dukakis is going to be able to veto anything." Mr. Foley later he had not meant to confuse Mr. Tsongas, a former Senator from Massachusetts, with that state's former Governor, Michael S. Dukakis, the Democrats' losing Presidential candidate in 1988. He said: "That was a slip. I'm not snide."
The latest version of the Democratic bill makes no changes in either its tax credit provision, questioned at this morning's caucus because it was temporary, or its plan to index capital gains to inflation, which went largely without criticism today.
The caucus began, several lawmakers reported, with a strong plea for party unity from Mr. Foley, and was punctuated by reminders that the Democrats, having made a fairness argument against the Republicans for months, had to keep on making it.
One of the sharpest criticisms came from Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin. Later, speaking more mildly, he told reporters that not many people had asked for the corporate rate cut, and that there were better uses for the money. He said the cut had been defended by members of the Ways and Means Committee today as a way to offer something to business in a way that would "fend off worse things that would have made the package vulnerable to a bigger bidding war."
Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts called the corporate rate issue the major bone of contention at the caucus. He said it "would not be particularly stimulative" and was expensive.
But even the provision's critics said passing the bill quickly was important. "The worst thing is to flounder," said Representative Leon Panetta of California.
"The faster we move the better," said Representative Timothy J. Penny of Minnesota.

HEADLINE: Anti-Crime Lottery Sales Falling Far Short of Goal

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
New York City officials said yesterday that a special city lottery intended to raise money for Mayor David N. Dinkins's broad anti-crime program has fallen far short of expectations and is now projected to produce just $5 million of the $38 million they orginally planned for this fiscal year.
The Mayor disclosed the shortfall as he announced the creation of a new $1 scratch-off game -- half the price of the old one -- that officials hope will step up sales. Last fall the city said the special lottery was raising only about half of what they expected, which they attributed to the price and to skepticism about how the proceeds would be used. 
 The collapse of the special city lottery undermines an important source of revenue for Mr. Dinkins's anti-crime program, which besides hiring more police officers was to expand education and youth programs. From the start, many city officials were skeptical about the lottery as a revenue source.
For the fiscal year that ends on June 30, the bulk of the anti-crime program's money, $130 million, is to come from a special property tax, and that is still on target, officials said.
 
Educational Programs
 By law, the money from the lottery was earmarked for educational programs -- $31 million for the Board of Education and $7 million for libraries -- and city officials said they would still provide the full $38 million to those agencies despite the falloff, making up the difference with unspecified cuts and savings elsewhere in the city's $29 billion budget.
But because of the city's earlier cuts in the Board of Education budget, board officials had said they have been able to count on using only about $3 million of the lottery money for the new after-school programs the Mayor originally envisioned, with the rest going to make up for cuts in basic classroom services.
Deputy Schools Chancellor Stanley Litow said that problem had not changed. He said the board had not had any discussions with the city about the latest lowered projections for the lottery. "But if the city is interested in continuing to provide funds to the board and holding us harmless for this," he said, "that would be good news."
At a City Hall news conference, the Mayor said: "As is true with so many elements of our local economy, the revenue shortfall for our 'Safe Streets' lottery games reflects national trends. This year, fully one-third of states that have lotteries have experienced a decline in revenues from the previous year."
Mr. Dinkins said the state expects to have its first decline in annual lottery revenues in 24 years.
 
'Invest in Kids'
 The $2 game was called "Invest in Kids" and used radio and bus-stop advertisements of a somber Mr. Dinkins urging New Yorkers to buy its silver and blue tickets. But from its start in September to January, it sold only about $3.4 million in tickets, producing $900,000 in revenues for the city and awarding the top prize, a $25,000 jackpot, only once.
For the new fiscal year that starts on July 1, city budget officials are projecting that the city lottery will raise $50 million.
Officials are hoping that the new game will perform roughly four times as well in the rest of this fiscal year. It is called "City Jackpot," with Day-Glo pink, green and yellow tickets, and will offer a much smaller jackpot -- $100 -- but more chances to win, with overall odds of 1 in 4.45 chances. The object is to find three matching drawings of apples, taxis, pretzels and other symbols of the city under any of three coated panels on the back of each ticket.
The type of symbol determines the prize, with three Empire State Buildings winning $100.
Even losers can have a second chance at a grand-prize sightseeing trip to California for four. Players can mail their losing tickets and an entry coupon to be eligible for a prize drawing March 16. New York Newsday and Newsday will run entry blanks.
Tickets will be sold at more than 4,200 lottery sales outlets in the city and at all 97 New York City Offtrack Betting parlors. Players must be at least 18 years old. Half of all sales revenues are to go for prize money, 15 percent to the New York Lottery for production and distribution costs, and the rest to the city for the anti-crime program.

HEADLINE: New-Home Building Again Shows Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
In a report that showed continued gains in new-home construction, builders in January broke ground on new dwellings at an annual pace of 1,167,000, the briskest since May 1990.
The 5.5 percent surge from December's 1,106,000 pace marked the fourth month in a row without a decline, but the gain was less robust than it appeared since it was heavily concentrated in apartment-house construction, which had nose-dived the month before. Moreover, the rise occurred only in the Midwest, with starts edging down in the South and West and falling 7 percent in the Northeast. 
 Still, the figures were seen as further improvement in the only sector besides exports that contributed to the small increase in gross domestic product during the final three months of 1991.
"The trend is definitely positive," commented David W. Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. He noted that while starts remained at less than two-thirds of their recent-year peak of 1.8 million in 1986, the 1991 record was one of steady improvement. Of the last 12 months, starts rose in eight and were steady in two, with declines only in March and September.
Today's Commerce Department report on permits issued for future construction was solidly positive, up 6 percent with virtually all the improvement in single-family houses, which have more impact than multifamily units on the economy at large. Sizable increases were posted in both the Northeast and the Midwest, while the South eked out a small gain. Permits were essentially unchanged in the West.
Some builders, it appeared, obtained permits last month that they failed to use, perhaps because of bad weather.
Although the number of permits issued is a component of the Government's index of leading indicators that tend to move ahead of the economy as a whole, builders frequently start single-family homes in the same month they acquire the needed permits. Multifamily housing, on the other hand, generally requires long-run plans.
Analysts also pointed to considerable other evidence that housing is increasingly buoyant, aided by sharp reductions in interest rates that moved as low as about 8 1/4 percent for 30-year conventional mortgages before rebounding in recent weeks to about 8 3/4 percent.
 
Ranks of Customers
 Sales of both new and existing homes are taking wing, mortgage applications are climbing similarly, contract cancellation rates have dropped and real estate agents in many parts of the country see swelling ranks of potential customers.
An agent in the Maryland suburbs of Washington espressed amazement on Sunday about how many for-sale signs had suddenly sprouted in the neighborhood where she was conducting an open house, apparently reflecting a belief that buyers are once again to be found.
On Tuesday, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported in its quarterly survey of real estate trends that housing improved substantially from late October to late January while the market for commercial properties remained depressed.
"Field reports showing rebounding housing activity outnumbered negative assessments by better than a four-to-one margin," William R. Watson, director of the agency's research division, said. The F.D.I.C.'s composite index for both residential and commercial real estate climbed to 60 last month from 57 in October.
 
Large Buildings Gain
 Today's report on housing starts showed single-family starts last month at a pace of 974,000, compared with 965,000 in December while dwellings in two- to four-unit structures eased to 31,000 from 44,000. Large buildings, with five or more dwellings, contained 162,000 new units at an annual rate, up from 97,000 in December and 145,000 in November.
Geographically, overall starts were at a rate of 459,000 in the South, 324,000 in the Midwest, 250,000 in the West and 134,000 in the Northeast. Permits, which totaled 1,118,000, were 430,000 in the South, 285,000 in the Midwest, 267,000 in the West and 136,000 in the Northeast.
Actual starts, without seasonal adjustment or annualization, amounted to 72,500 last month, compared with 52,500 in January 1991.
The department also reported that shipments of mobile homes, which lag a month, rose 3 percent in December to a rate of 176,000. For the year, shipments dropped 9 percent, to 170,900.

HEADLINE: A New Breed of Sam Spade Trails Crooks' Hidden Assets

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
Ed Pankau is a private investigator who seems to have walked off the pages of a pulp novel. A former Green Beret and the son of a bootlegger, the 46-year-old private eye has had his share of cases involving murder, mayhem and colorful characters.
A green Bugatti sports car adorns his suburban driveway. He won it years ago in a jailhouse poker game from a client, a wealthy rancher accused of manslaughter. In Mr. Pankau's world there are good guys and bad guys. Mr. Pankau is a good guy; he invariably describes his quarry as "sleaze balls" or "dirt bags" or both. 
 Despite his hard-boiled manner, Mr. Pankau is one of the new breed of financial sleuths who track down the assets hidden by white-collar crooks. And it is a booming field, thanks to the savings and loan debacle, bank failures, corporate bankruptcies and financial scandals like the collapse of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. When successful, these asset hunters can save taxpayers and lenders millions of dollars.
"We're in an age of high-tech crime, so the people with the skills to handle those investigations are in demand," said Joseph Wells, chairman of the National Association of Certified Fraud Examiners, a 5,000-member organization that trains investigators.
Today, financial investigation has become a flourishing business, embracing several hundred practitioners with a variety of skills, including so-called forensic accountants at major accounting firms like Price Waterhouse and Arthur Andersen.
But the new-breed private investigators are on the front lines. Some are lone wolves; others work for large firms like Kroll Associates Inc. of New York, which tracked Saddam Hussein's assets for Kuwait, or medium-size firms like Mr. Pankau's Intertect Inc. in Houston, which has pursued the assets of many failed savings and loans and helped the Panamanian Government search for the assets of Gen. Manuel Noriega, its deposed leader.
 
Foray in Panama
 Mr. Pankau was in Panama on an insurance investigation during the American invasion in 1990. In the confusion, he slipped into a building and made off with a computer printout listing more than $800 million in assets held in 18 countries, assets he is convinced are General Noriega's personal holdings.
Such forays have given Mr. Pankau the reputation of "a guy who kicks down doors," one rival said. Even his wife, Linda, said: "I don't ask questions about how Ed does what he does. I'm not sure I want to know."
But the Texas Board of Private Investigators says it has never had a serious complaint against Mr. Pankau, who readily acknowledges that he relies more on painstaking work than derring-do.
Unlike the Sam Spades of the past, who relied on a .38, a hip flask and a hunch, today's private eyes use computers and data bases. They tend to be accountants or former agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation or, like Mr. Pankau, of the Internal Revenue Service.
The new-style sleuths have even made inroads into the tradition-steeped genre of the detective novel with the appearance of characters like Catherine Sayler, a financial private investigator in Linda Grant's "Blind Trust," and Jay Jasen, an accountant in Jim Weikart's "Casualty Loss."
By most accounts, Mr. Pankau is a leader in applying computer-age technology to the cottage industry of private investigation.
"He's established the standards in this industry," said Charles Peck, vice president of marketing for Prentice Hall Legal and Financial Services, a unit of Paramount Communications Inc. that markets data bases of business and government records. "Once you get beyond Ed Pankau's rough-hewn promotional style, there is a lot of substance."
The Prentice Hall unit looked for a partner with expertise in finding hidden assets. After interviewing major accounting firms and several financial investigation firms, it chose Mr. Pankau to help develop methods so that Prentice Hall's extensive data bases of corporate and public records could be used more efficiently for asset searches.
The slumping economy and the financial wreckage of the last decade are fueling the demand for such services. The Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency established by Congress in 1989 to clean up the savings-and-loan mess, has created a huge market for financial experts as it tries to recover assets of the more than 650 failed institutions seized by the Government. Even though it has its own investigative staff, Resolution Trust contracts out asset-search work to 45 private firms. It also hired Mr. Pankau to help write a handbook on asset searches.
Other work comes from corporate clients. A bank, for example, will often hire a private investigator when a large individual borrower has fallen behind on loan payments. The bank wants to know what assets the person may have stashed away that could be put up as additional collateral, as real estate values fall. Banks also want to know how tight the client's financial pinch is, because the borrower's problems may soon become the bank's.
"The bank is often not yet in court, but it's in a fight and it wants to strengthen its bargaining position with a problem client," said Dan Karson, general counsel of Kroll Associates, which has conducted many such investigations for banks.
 
His First Assignment
 Mr. Pankau got into the asset-search business in 1978, tracing the recoverable funds of five small Texas banks that had failed because of bad management and fraud. His client was the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. He seemed to have been overly optimistic in taking the assignment; his three-person firm had to hunt for any seizable assets on about 500 bad loans in little more than a year.
"You never could have done it by the old method of going to the courthouse and pawing through the public records," Mr. Pankau recalled. "I realized there had to be a better way to do it."
So he made microfiche copies of government records, which he took to his office, and organized the bank records looking for patterns in the loan problems. He noticed, for example, that there were dozens of cases of local police officers who had taken out $10,000 car loans, made one payment, then retired and moved out of the state. Mr. Pankau located them for the banking authorities by tracing where their pension checks were sent.
Recognizing the potential for automation, Mr. Pankau bought 10 computers in 1983 in a bankruptcy sale. That move was prescient. In the last five years or so, the amount of information on people and companies available to anyone with a computer and a telephone has grown enormously. There are now thousands of data bases listing motor vehicle registrations, property held, assumed names, utility bills and owners of race horses and private aircraft.
 
Saving Time
 While the computer does not solve cases, it cuts the time spent on asset searches from days to hours. Mr. Pankau's contribution to the craft has been devising the methodology for searches, starting with personal information, by feeding Social Security numbers and dates of birth into a computer, then moving to business records, litigation history and other clues.
"In complex cases, you still have to travel, pore over documents and talk to people," Mr. Pankau said. "But the computer has revolutionized this business."
Today, Intertect has 46 employees, with offices in Houston, Dallas, San Antonio and Phoenix, and revenues of more than $3 million a year. Its clients include Chase Manhattan, Bank of America, Bank of New England, First Interstate and Bank One, Texas. The business has been growing roughly 40 percent a year in the last few years, and Mr. Pankau expects it to reach $10 million in three years.
His biggest client is the United States Government, going after assets connected with failed savings and loans and banks. He also instructs Federal agents on the fine points of financial investigations.
Mr. Pankau has searched for hidden assets connected to more than 100 failed institutions. Both the Government and private clients demand that pending cases not be discussed. And most of the cases do not become public, because Federal agencies and banks generally try to settle out of court, rather than lose years and millions of dollars in legal fees.
Yet bankers whom Mr. Pankau has worked for acknowledge that he has found hidden assets in forms ranging from gold coins buried in an executive's backyard to ill-gotten funds in Cayman Islands bank accounts to millions stashed in a child's trust fund. In the trust fund case, a former savings and loan executive received $10,000 a month as a "charity" payment from his child's trust.
Mr. Pankau's most notable savings and loan case to date has been investigating fraud and searching for assets held by the officers and directors of Vernon Savings and Loan Association of Vernon, Tex. In 1990 and 1991, Vernon's former executives, Don R. Dixon and Woody F. Lemons, were given lengthy prison terms and assessed more than $10 million in fines.
"The amazing thing in the Vernon case is how much money was blown on high living, hookers, yachts, you name it," Mr. Pankau said. "But I'm convinced Don Dixon still has a cash hoard someplace, maybe $50 million."

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Mixed, With the Dow Up 5.59

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed mixed yesterday with blue-chip issues up slightly and the broader market moderately weak. A firm bond market helped lift stocks from early losses, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed up 5.59 points, to 3,230.32
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 234.8 million shares, up from 234.3 million on Tuesday. The Big Board composite index rose 0.20 point, to 225.85, with losing issues outnumbering gainers by 963 to 753. 
 "The release of surprisingly stronger January Consumer Price Index and January housing starts data turned an already down bond market around, lifting the stock market with it," said Ricky Harrington, director of equity investments for Marion Bass Securities.
With the January inflation rate coming in at a low one-tenth of 1 percent and housing starts showing a sharp gain, investors bought cyclical Dow stocks.
 
Greenspan Testimony
 At the same time, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said in his semiannual Congressional testimony yesterday that he saw a pickup in business activity.
Some analysts warned, however, that the uncertainty created by President Bush's narrow victory in the New Hampshipre primary injected a potential negative to market volatility, which could translate to lower prices over the next few weeks.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, another blue-chip barometer, rose 0.88 point yesterday, to 408.26, while the American Stock Exchange index fell 1.74 points, to 407.46. Trading on the Nasdaq, also heavy throughout the day, pulled the composite down 4 points, to 622.41, with the Russell 2,000 index down 1.72 points, to 208.36.
Rohr Industries fell 2, to 18 1/8, as the company faces possible criminal charges from a Government inquiry into its Riverside, Calif., plant that may result in substantial fines, suspension and debarment proceedings. The plant, which produces parts for military aircraft, accounts for about 8 percent of Rohr's $1.3 billion in annual revenues.
First Union rose 1 1/8, to 37, after the financial institution raised the quarterly dividend to 31 cents from 28 cents, and Sandra Flannigan, an analyst for Alex. Brown & Sons, raised her recommendation to a "strong buy," adjusting the 1992 earnings estimate to $3.25 a share from $3.10.
Biomet, which makes surgical implants and orthopedic devices, rose 2 1/8, to 23, after saying it was comfortable with analysts' third-quarter earnings estimates of 11 to 12 cents a share. In the third quarter a year ago, the company earned 9 cents a share.
Centocor fell 8 1/8, to 33 1/8. The biotech company, which is suing Xoma Inc. and Pfizer Inc. over a patent that covers a mouse monoclonal antibody, reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $1.19 a share and said the Food and Drug Administration had raised additional issues concerning its product license for the HA-1A, an antibody.
Shares of Systemix Inc. tumbled 15, to 39 3/4, after Sandoz A.G.'s deal to buy a 60 percent stake in the biotech company was completed and its tender offer for about half of its shares was oversubscribed, analysts said.
Hewlett-Packard, rose 9 1/8, to 73 1/2. Tim McCollum, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds, raised his earnings estimate for the fiscal year, after the company reported a stronger-than-expected first quarter of $1.21 a share, compared with 83 cents.
Analysts said PNC Financial, the Pitsburgh-based bank holding company held a positive meeting with them Tuesday, convincing many that it has decisively dealt with its problems. Nancy Bush, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman, raised her repeated "strong buy" recommendation, while Thaddeus Paluszcek, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, raised the rating to "buy" from "hold." PNC stock rose 1 7/8, to 48 5/8, as both analysts also raised their 1992 and 1993 earnings estimates.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Key Lawmaker Wants to Keep Bell Companies Out of Information Business

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Newspaper publishers received support today from an important lawmaker in their campaign to keep the regional Bell telephone companies from being allowed to own electronic services offering information like news, stock quotations and sports scores.
At a hearing of the House Judiciary Committee's Subcommitte on Economic and Commercial Law, Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, made it clear that he favored continuing restrictions on the Bell companies. His committee has jurisdiction over antitrust issues. 
 Mr. Brooks attacked a recent court ruling that lifted a restriction on the Bell companies' owning information services. He ridiculed what he called the "child-like faith" of the Federal Communications Commission in pursuing a policy that he said was based only on "deregulation, deregulation, deregulation."
But other lawmakers on the panel at the crowded hearing today remained divided and ambivalent about the best way to address the issue, which has fueled multimillion-dollar lobbying and advertising efforts by the telephone companies and their opponents.
At issue are restrictions in the antitrust consent decree that broke up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984. These restrictions bar the seven regional "Baby Bell" companies created in the breakup from owning information services, manufacturing equipment or providing long-distance service.
But a recent court decision by Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene, who oversees the consent decree, lifted the ban on Bell companies' providing information services. That spurred frantic efforts by newspapers and other information providers to persuade Congress to reverse the ruling and forbid phone companies to enter their business.
The House is also considering legislation, already passed by the Senate, that would lift the prohibition on the Bell companies' making equipment. Those bills have aroused fierce opposition from A.T.&T., which retained the right to make equipment under the consent decree.
The battle on both issues comes amid a growing debate about the best way to foster international competitiveness in the telecommunications industry. The Bell companies -- Nynex, Bell Atlantic, BellSouth, Ameritech, Southwestern Bell, U S West and Pacific Telesis -- argue that they must be unshackled if they are to build advanced networks that can deliver everything from video programs to high-resolution medical images and "electronic yellow pages."
"Our nation urgently needs a coherent, efficient and competitive telecommunications policy," said Ivan Seidenberg, vice chairman of Nynex. "Does it make sense to exclude from the market companies with $160 billion in assets?"
But existing information providers argue that the Bell companies still retain a monopoly over local telephone services and would use this advantage to undercut the prices of competitors in information services.
 
Criticism of Newspapers
 While many lawmakers expressed concern about potential abuses by the Bell companies, some also had reservations about the newspaper industry.
Representative John Bryant, a Texas Democrat who supports tougher restrictions on the Bells, argued that the "newspaper industry is run by a group of monopolists or near-monopolists" in many cities.
Indeed, he said, representatives of the A. H. Belo Corporation, owner of The Dallas Morning News, came to his office arguing for tougher restrictions on the Bell companies at the same time that The Morning News was seeking permission from the Justice Department to buy the assets of The Dallas Times-Herald and allow it to cease publication.
In another twist, the newspapers were represented at the hearings in part by David E. Easterly, president of Cox Newspapers, publisher of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and other newspapers. Cox Enterprises, the corporate parent, operates the fifth-largest cable television company and plans to enter the telephone business.
 
Monopoly Position
 Cox recently acquired 12.5 percent of the Teleport Communications Group, a fiber-optic company that competes against local telephone companies. In addition, Cox has built an experimental wireless telephone system in San Diego. On Tuesday, the nation's largest cable company, Tele-Communications Inc. of Denver, moved to join Cox by agreeing to buy a 49.9 percent stake in Teleport from Merrill Lynch & Company.
But Mr. Easterly argued that the Bell companies retained a monopoly position in the local telephone market and would use it to dominate the market for electronic information.
"Our classified ads are a primary target for the 'telcos,' " he testified. Unshackling the telephone companies "would be devastating for newspapers."
Prospects for legislation are uncertain. Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, has introduced legislation that would bar the telephone companies from information services unless a competing network can reach at least half the homes in a market.
But Representative Edward Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee with jurisdiction over telecommunications policy, favors a broader bill that would give the Bells greater freedom.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields on Money Funds Are Down Slightly

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The yields on both tax-exempt and taxable funds moved down a bit for the week ended Tuesday, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
"Once more the yields on the tax-exempts declined," said Walter Frank, economist for Donoghue's. "And what we see is that the flow of money into the funds has dried up a little because of lower yields in the latest weekly period." As for the taxable yields, he said that large amounts of institutional money had moved out of the taxables to seek better yields elsewhere: for instance, in commercial paper or Eurodollar deposits. 
 Mr. Frank added that "the odds still favored a further easing by the Federal Reserve system" even after the Fed on Tuesday lowered the required reserves of its member banks.
The seven-day compounded average yield for the tax-exempt funds dropped 8 basis points, to 2.73 percent, while the seven-day simple yield dropped to 2.69 percent, also down 8 basis points. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
In the same period, the 30-day compounded yield dropped 2 basis points, to 2.80 percent, and the 30-day simple yield also fell 2 basis points, to 2.76 percent.
 
Top Performers
 Among the yield leaders in the New York area, the top Connecticut fund again was Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, which reported a seven-day compounded yield of 3.24 percent, down 11 basis points from the previous week.
In New Jersey, the top fund once again was Fidelity Spartan N.J. Municipal Money Market Portfolio, with a yield at 3.32 percent, down 14 points.
In New York, the top fund again was Salomon Brothers N.Y. Municipal Money Market fund. It had a seven-day compounded yield of 3.64 percent, down 10 basis points.
Assets of the tax-exempt funds dropped from the record $98.9 billion to $98.8 billion.
Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in the tax-free portfolios moved up one day, to 51.
Of the funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, Milwaukee, continued to lead the way with a seven-day compounded yield of 3.66 percent, down from 3.73 percent.
 
Taxable Funds
 Assets of the taxable funds, which were at a record level of $509.7 billion the previous week, declined in the latest period by $13.1 billion, to $496.6 billion. Most of the withdrawals -- $12.5 billion -- were by institutions seeking higher rates elsewhere.
Mr. Frank noted that the average days to maturity of holdings in the taxable funds rose by one day, to 58.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield was off 6 basis points, to 3.86 percent, while the seven-day simple yield fell 7 points, to 3.78 percent.
At the same time, the 30-day compounded yield declined to 3.98 percent, a drop of 7 basis points, and the 30-day simple yield dropped to 3.90 percent, also off 7 basis points from the previous week.
Two taxable funds tied for first place with the best seven-day compounded yield for the week. They were Fidelity Spartan Money Market fund, the previous week's leader, and Riverside Capital Money Market Fund, which is distributed by the Winsbury Company of Columbus, Ohio, both reporting a yield of 4.58 percent.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 3.75 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: Little of $100 Billion Loss Can Be Retrieved

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
During the 1980's, the savings and loan industry was a playpen for white-collar criminals. Losses from the debacle are estimated at roughly $100 billion, and while reckless lending in an overheated real estate market accounted for much of that, fraud by savings and loan officers and directors added billions of dollars to the bill for taxpayers.
In fact, fraud contributed to the collapse of 35 percent of the more than 650 savings institutions under control of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created to clean up the industry's mess. 
 How much of the money can be recovered by financial investigators?
Most experts estimate that only 5 percent to 10 percent of the losses can be traced and retrieved. Some former savings executives have stashed away millions, but most of the money has been squandered and spent, the experts say.
The story of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, which collapsed in 1989 at an estimated cost to taxpayers of $2.6 billion, is instructive. The huge losses and free-spending style of Lincoln's flamboyant former chairman, Charles H. Keating Jr., made the case a priority for the Government.
The Lincoln affair will be a matter of litigation for years, but so far, settlements accounting for less than $100 million have been reached. With luck, Government officials and investigators say, the total recovered for investors and taxpayers may eventually reach $200 million. Mr. Keating has been indicted on Federal charges of fraud, conspiracy and racketeering. He was convicted of securities fraud last year on state charges in California and is free on bail awaiting sentencing.
Savings executives typically spent lavishly on themselves and others. They paid exorbitant salaries to colleagues and high fees to advisers.
"Most of the money is spent in the American economy -- it's in Mercedes-Benz sedans on Rodeo Drive, spent on fancy restaurants in Los Angeles and elsewhere," said Peter B. Frank, a partner for Price Waterhouse & Company, which investigated the financial manipulations at Lincoln. "You don't usually find enormous cash hoards."
James Dudine, Resolution Trust's director of investigations, agreed: "There's no question that most of the money is gone. We're not going to recover a billion or two from Charlie Keating. It just isn't there."
 
Investigators' Goals
 For financial investigators, the goal in most cases is to find hidden assets and enough incriminating evidence to persuade the people under investigation to repay the money instead of facing prosecution.
The preferred method, they say, is to avoid the American court system. Otherwise, a defendant can put off a final judgment and repayment for five to seven years.
"For the real smart guys, white-collar crime does pay," said Ed Pankau, a Houston private investigator. "If you steal enough, you can afford to hire the high-priced legal talent so that you can keep some of your money."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Wheat Up as Traders See Moves by Ex-Soviet Lands

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wheat futures prices pulled out of a nose dive and ended with a modest gain yesterday on a report that the former Soviet republics were buying wheat futures.
Such activity, rare in the last year, could indicate the Commonwealth of Independent States was locking in prices for future wheat purchases, analysts said. 
 Wheat for delivery in March finished 1/4 cent above Tuesday's settlement at $4.11 3/4 a bushel after trading as low as $4.01 1/2 during yesterday's session.
Wheat has tumbled more than 50 cents since hitting an 11-year high of $4.63 1/4 on Feb. 10. It halted its slide toward $4 after the market wire service Futures World News reported that Exportkhleb, the grain-buying agency of the former Soviet Union, was buying United States wheat futures.
Such transactions, while not unheard of, have been rare in the last year because the republics' dire financial condition has restricted their ability to buy grain.
The commonwealth was also perceived as having temporarily satisfied its need for wheat with recent credit purchases subsidized and guaranteed by the United States Government.
"It sure turned the market around," Katharina Zimmer, grains analyst with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc., said of the report. She said she could not confirm it.
Susan Leighty, an analyst at Prudential Securities Inc., said she had doubts about the report in light of the commonwealth's economic distress.
"Given their financial problems, it raises some skepticism," she said.
Corn and soybean futures also rebounded strongly after following wheat lower early in the session. Their late advance was driven partly by ideas that tight wheat supplies could prompt farmers to expand spring wheat plantings at the expense of soybeans and corn, said Gordon Linn, president of Linnco Futures Inc. in Chicago.
Oil futures recovered some of Tuesday's sharp losses on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Most traders viewed the action as a natural rebound after crude oil plunged more than $1.30 a barrel on Tuesday in reaction to smaller-than-expected OPEC production cuts.
After the close, the American Petroleum Institute said in a weekly report that United States gasoline stocks rose last week by nearly three million barrels, an unexpectedly large increase that could put pressure on prices.
Crude oil stocks fell by two million barrels, as expected, while heating-oil stocks dropped nearly six million barrels, a larger-than-expected decline.
Crude oil for March delivery rose 29 cents, to $18.41 a barrel; March heating oil rose 1.18 cents, to 52.50 cents a gallon; March unleaded gasoline rose 0.74 cent, to 55.82 cents a gallon; March natural gas rose 5.8 cents, to $1.139 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in a Broad Retreat, But Gains Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled lower against all major currencies except the Japanese yen yesterday in thin, uneventful trading.
Gold prices were down in United States trading. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $353 a troy ounce, off 40 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold slid 5 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $352.75. 
 Analysts said currency traders were not particularly inspired by the latest economic data, which were better than expected. The Labor Department said consumer prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in January, the best inflation performance in six months. Separately, the Commerce Department reported that housing starts rose a strong 5.5 percent in January.
"The market took it all in stride," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
The market also shrugged off the Congressional testimony of Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, who reiterated that recent cuts in interest rates should be enough to guarantee a sustained recovery later this year.
"The market is waiting to see if its recent move up is legitimate," Mr. Donney said, which would be supported by signs that "the economy is really starting to come out of recession."
The dollar's move above 128 Japanese yen did not prompt any intervention by the central banks. That "emboldened speculators to test the dollar's upside," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA.
Still, the currency held to a relatively narrow range throughout the session.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.03 yen, to a closing 128.20 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 128.35 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 128.20 yen, up from 128.00 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7510, from $1.7500 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.7565 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.7545.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Wall St. Support For Oregon Steel

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
SOME Wall Street analysts are turning their attention to Oregon Steel Mills Inc., a minimill that produces steel by melting scrap and has the distinction of being the only American steelmaker to increase profits last year.
While Nucor Inc., the North Carolina producer of steel joists, bars and sheets, has long been the most prominent of the mini-mills, Oregon Steel has drawn a following for its niche products. The low-cost producer of steel plate and pipe has benefited from the surge in demand in the last two years for steel plate products to build or rehabilitate highways, bridges and oil and gas pipelines in California and other Western states. 
 The company, now one of the leading suppliers of plate and pipe products on the West Coast, earned $36.9 million last year, up 29 percent from $28.5 million in 1990. Revenue increased 47 percent, to $489.4 million from $333.6 million, despite the recession.
"They have been very successful because their markets surged and they have come to dominate the California and Oregon markets," said John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. "They are seeing much greater demand from oil and gas pipeline companies."
Analysts' enthusiasm is also based on the fact that Oregon Steel has virtually no debt and no liabilities for retirees' health care or pensions.
"Its balance sheet is extremely strong and the company has shown that it could get through the current recession without the sharp drop in earnings or losses experienced by the other steelmakers," said Charles A. Bradford, a steel analyst with UBS Securities.
The company has sharply cut costs and increased efficiency in the last few years, spending about $150 million in the last five years to upgrade its operations. It now takes 2.4 hours for an employee to produce a ton of steel, compared with about 4 hours three years ago, the company said. That figure compares with an average of about 2.5 at other mini-mills and about 5.2 at the nation's six largest steelmakers.
Oregon Steel's productivity was also helped by a profit-sharing program that distributes 20 percent of the company's profits to employees.
Still, such enthusiasm is not reflected in the company's stock price. Oregon Steel, which sold as high as $38 in the middle of last year, fell to the mid-$20 range toward the end of last year. The stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $23.50, up 25 cents.
Mr. Bradford of UBS said the weakness in the stock price was largely a result of rumors about a possible acquisition by Oregon Steel of CF&I Steel, a maker of rail, bar and tubular steel products based in Colorado.
Other analysts suggest that the fall in stock price might reflect expectations that demand from the oil and gas pipeline business may have peaked and will sag through the rest of this year.
"The plate market softened late last year and Oregon Steel ran into some production problems," said Thomas M. Van Leeuwen, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers. But he cited the company's acquisitions as evidence that Oregon Steel was working to move into other markets and geographic areas. The company acquired a plate mill in 1989 and a pipe mill in 1987, both from Kaiser Steel. It is also moving into electric welded pipe for oil and gas exploration.
Whether a deal will develop between Oregon Steel & CF&I is still unclear. The Colorado company is the only leading producer of rail steel west of the Mississippi. But the company, which is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, has many unresolved pension and retiree issues and Mr. Bradford said it was unlikely that an acquisition of CF&I would come in the near term, even though the depressed price of CF&I's stock presents a buying opportunity. Meanwhile, Oregon Steel continues to seek to reduce its dependence on niche markets by pursuing acquisitions and joint ventures. A proposed joint venture with Stelco, the Canadian steel producer, would give Oregon Steel access to the Canadian market while providing a strong customer for its steel plate.
"They have some good prospects in establishing joint ventures," Mr. Van Leeuwen said. "They have a track record of acquiring assets cheaply and making them pay off."

HEADLINE: California Fund In Housing Bid

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The California Public Employees Retirement System voted Tuesday to increase the financing for a new program to spur construction of single-family homes in California.
The retirement system said it would increase by $150 million, to $375 million, its investment in partnerships set up to give a boost to the state's recession-battered construction business. The system, known as Calpers, voted last month to invest $225 million in the program, the first time a public pension fund has invested directly in the large-scale building of single-family houses. 
 The program is designed to offset partly the lack of available developer financing from banks and savings institutions. The additional $150 million will be invested through two money managers, Alex. Brown Kleinwort Benson and AMB Institutional Realty Advisors Inc.
