HEADLINE: Bond Swap Announced By M.A.C.

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In a move that will produce more money for New York City officials to argue over as they seek to ease their fiscal problems, the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation said yesterday that it would raise $100 million by swapping some of its old bonds for new notes with lower interest rates.
The new refinancing will bring to $1 billion the total amount that the city might be able to tap from the assistance corporation over the next several years. But its chairman, Felix G. Rohatyn, said it was too soon to say how and whether the money could be spent, adding that the M.A.C. would be reviewing the city's budget plans before approving any aid. 
 City officials have been seeking various forms of help from the M.A.C. for months, and the new money would make them just that much more dependent on the largesse of Mr. Rohatyn, who has dominated the city's financial affairs since the corporation was set up to borrow money on its behalf in the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. Interest and principal on the M.A.C. bonds is paid using part of the city's sales tax revenues, so when the M.A.C. saves money, the city can, too.
Or as Mr. Rohatyn told the corporation's board of directors with some understatement yesterday, the extra $100 million will "meaningfully increase our popularity."
 
School Construction
 Mr. Rohatyn also made clear that he, too, has ideas for how the money might be spent, possibly using some to pay for school construction programs that the city proposes to cut to save money. The Mayor, the Governor and Mr. Rohatyn would ultimately have to agree on any use for the money, and if Mr. Rohatyn did not like it, by law he could simply use the surplus to pay off M.A.C. bonds.
What has come to be known as "the M.A.C. money" is two separate potential sources of cash. The first is $700 million that the city has proposed to raise over the next four years through a complex transaction that would amount to borrowing money to help pay for operating expenses while it cuts the work force and shrinks government costs. This is unaffected by yesterday's announcement. It calls for the city to sell new bonds, using the proceeds to buy back some old city bonds now held by the M.A.C. The corporation could then use the money it got to pay interest on its own bonds, thus freeing some sales tax revenues, which could be used by the city to help meet expenses.
But because the tight laws imposed in the 70's forbid borrowing to meet operating costs, Mr. Rohatyn has said he will not cooperate without assurances from the State Financial Control Board and bond-rating agencies that the city's four-year plan for keeping the budget balanced is credible and that he would not simply use the money as a Band-Aid to keep spending at the current rate. Those bodies have not yet passed on the plan, though the control board's staff gave an initial favorable review.
 
Cash Surpluses
 The second chunk of money is cash surpluses that M.A.C. has accumulated from past refinancings and by setting aside extra sales tax revenues in anticipation of undertaking an earlier bond deal for the city that it has since abandoned. Until yesterday, that surplus was $200 million. Now it will amount to about $300 million over the next three years.
The M.A.C. will raise the extra $100 million by taking advantage of recent declines in interest rates by swapping old bonds carrying 7.5 percent interest from the corporation's original bond resolution of the 1970's for new short-term notes bearing interest as low as 2.6 percent.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Municipal Assistance Corporation announced a refinancing yesterday that it said would bring to $1 billion the total amount that the city might be able to tap over the next several years. Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman, made the announcement. At right was Eugene J. Keilin, a board member. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. to Push for Logging in Owls' Forest

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
In anticipation of a Federal report that will require the Government to preserve thousands of acres of ancient forests in the Pacific Northwest to save the spotted owl, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said today that Congress should waive the key requirement of one of the country's strictest environmental laws, the Endangered Species Act.
Mr. Lujan proposed an exception to the law that would allow the northern spotted owl to remain close to extinction in order to save jobs and permit logging in the bird's only habitat, the last great stands of Douglas fir and spruce in Washington state, Oregon, and California. 
 Mr. Lujan said he was forming a new committee of Interior Department experts to develop a plan for cutting the forests that he hoped to introduce as Federal legislation as early as April.
"I don't feel comfortable with losing 31,000 jobs," Mr. Lujan said. "What I am proposing is aimed strictly at the owl. This new team will look at a plan that neither increases nor reduces the number of owls, but keeps them at a stable population close to current levels. This is an option that we will then turn over to the Congress. They can either adopt it or deny it."
The idea of keeping owl populations near their current numbers violates the provisions of the Endangered Species Act that require the Government to take every step necessary to increase the population of endangered species until it is no longer threatened. The adoption of the idea by Congress would mean that vast stands of ancient forests will be cut down.
 
National Treasure
 Mr. Lujan's proposal was fiercely opposed today by environmental groups who say the forests are a national treasure that should be preserved not only for their beauty but also to study their botanical riches, which have included the discovery of a drug derived from the bark of the yew tree that is effective in fighting certain types of cancer.
Environmental groups have taken the case for preserving the forest to Federal court. On Wednesday, Federal District Judge Helen Frye issued a preliminary injunction blocking all logging in ancient forests on Bureau of Land Management property because of danger to the owl's habitat.
The order, which will remain in effect until the rules on the merits of the case in the spring, blocks 26 timber sales awarded by the Government since Dec. 31 and 23 sales scheduled to be offered in February and March.
"These are the last remains of a unique and irreplaceable resource," said Michael Bean, a lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund in Washington and an expert on the Endangered Species Act. "They represent a treasure house of potentially useful resources."
The combination of an election year and a national recession has made the Bush Administration and Congress more amenable to a plan that addresses the concerns of the timber industry and its employees. In recent months, lawmakers have been besieged by residents of rural communities in the Northwest and other regions who are increasingly angry about the Endangered Species Act and other environmental laws that restrict commercial and industrial development.
Representative George Miller, the California Democrat who heads the House Interior Committee, said today that he had joined members of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee and the House Agriculture Committee in preparing legislation that he said would save jobs and protect the forests. Mr. Miller said the legislation was not finished, and he declined to elaborate on its details.
 
Strict Guidelines
 At the core of the struggle is the 19-year-old Endangered Species Act, which sets out detailed procedures for identifying plant and animals species that appear headed for extinction and establishes strict guidelines for saving them.
Though the law's enforcement almost always leads to confrontations between industrial and environmental interests, the pitched battle over the northern spotted owl between the timber industry and environmentalists is the most intense ever produced by the Endangered Species Act.
A committee of Federal scientists has been meeting for months to develop a plan to help the owl recover by saving ancient forests in accordance with the requirements of the Endangered Species Act. The committee is expected to make its plan public in April. Mr. Lujan said today that he expected the plan to restrict cutting of the great forests.
 
Moral Questions
 Last October, Mr. Lujan took his first step to lessen the effects of the Endangered Species Act in the Northwest by convening a committee of Cabinet-level officers to consider the struggle over forests and jobs in the Northwest. The law contains a provision that allows for the formation of such a committee that can weigh economic concerns against the moral questions involved in saving an animal or plant species from extinction in difficult circumstances such as those in the Northwest. The group is expected to announce its decision in April, a month later than previously announced.
But environmental groups have raised legal questions about the authority of that committee, known in environmental circles as the God Squad, to issue directives because of the steps the Interior Department did and did not take in the case of the northern spotted owl in the years leading up to the committee's formation.
Mr. Lujan, as a result sought other measures to resolve the dispute and to protect jobs in a region that is politically important to both parties. The Washington caucus is on March 3, the Oregon primary will be held May 19, and the California primary is June 2.
In the Pacific Northwest, timber industry and forest workers enthsiastically greeted Mr. Lujan's plan to study the economic effects of saving the owl and bypassing the Endangered Species Act.
"This is the missing link that we've all been waiting for," said Evelyn Badger, the owner of a Sears Catalog Store in Canyonville, Ore., and co-director of Workers of Oregon Development, a community group that represents loggers, farmers, and business owners.
"Secretary Lujan has stepped forward in a very bold move, obviously recognizing the hardships and the devastation that have come to the people of the Northwest.
"But it will also be important to other resource dependent people across the nation," Ms. Badger said. "The spotted owl of the Northwest will be coming to their neighborhood very soon in a different form."

HEADLINE: Eugene R. Black Dies at 93; Ex-President of World Bank

 BODY:
Eugene Robert Black, a courtly Georgian who became one of the world's most influential figures as president of the World Bank from 1949 to 1962, died in his sleep early yesterday at his home in Southampton, L.I. He was 93 years old.
Mr. Black probably died of heart failure and had suffered kidney failure, said his son William H. Black. 
 Eugene Black was a relatively obscure, exceedingly competent Wall Street bond man and banker before he rose to head the bank, formally called the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
In technical retirement after 13 peripatetic years as banker to the nations outside what was then the Soviet sphere, he became a financial adviser to the United Nations and sat on the boards of many institutions and businesses -- though he gave up almost all such posts as he grew older.
At home and abroad, Mr. Black benefited from an acute mind, an engaging Southern drawl and a lack of vanity. He also brought a bluntness that disabused heads of state and finance ministers of any notion that he was an international Santa Claus.
In the banking community, his prudence, supported by a fund of matter-of-fact information, won him confidence in the soundness of his judgments.
 
Took the Large View
 On the world stage, he embodied America's postwar confidence and high hopes. Shrewd as Mr. Black might be in assessing the worth of an investment project, he took a large view of the developing world. He sought to engender an international social conscience -- a feeling that extreme differences of poverty and wealth were intolerable among nations.
He was virtually born into banking and public life, being the son and namesake of a banker who was a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, and of Gussie Grady Black, daughter of a Southern editor and orator, Henry Woodfin Grady.
The future world banker was born on May 1, 1898, in Atlanta, graduated in 1917 from the University of Georgia, served in the Navy in World War I and then joined the Atlanta office of Harris Forbes & Company, a New York bond and banking house.
Showing a knack for salesmanship, he stayed with Harris Forbes and its successors as a bond expert until 1933, when he joined the Chase National Bank in New York as a second vice president. He became a vice president in 1937.
 
Reputation Grew
 The banking community respected him for his knowledge of the bond market, and his reputation grew. It was eventually at the insistence of John J. McCloy, the president of Chase, that he joined the World Bank, which was established by the Bretton Woods Conference in 1944 chiefly to provide loans for the rebuilding of postwar Europe. It began business in 1946, and Mr. McCloy became its president in 1947. In that year, Mr. Black joined its staff as executive director for the United States.
He did so well that in 1949, when Mr. McCloy resigned as the bank's president to become High Commissioner to Germany, Mr. Black succeeded him. From then through 1962, with Mr. Black in charge, the World Bank lent more than $6 billion of its own capital, plus billions more that it borrowed in private markets, without a default.
Defining the goals broadly, Mr. Black once said the bank was "concerned primarily to insure that its loans make the greatest possible contribution to increasing production, raising living standards and opening opportunities for further investment."
 
Goal of Loans Crucial
 He believed firmly that money should be lent only for projects that would create the income, directly or indirectly, to repay the loans.
And once, speaking of the bank's role in helping third-world nations in the context of the cold war, he said, "I don't think you can combat Communism, no matter how much money you give, unless the money is properly spent."
Indeed, Mr. Black sought to harness the power of Western capitalism and private enterprise by lending almost exclusively for industrial, agricultural and power projects that would stimulate the private sector.
"Governments must cease just tolerating private business," he declared. "They must welcome its contributions."
At another time, explaining the bank's success, Mr. Black said it tried "to develop a spirit of mutual trust with its customers."
"Countries come to us for help because they know we are not involved in politics," he said. "Instead of forcing our way of life on them, we try to build a working partnership."
 
Genial but 'Hard as Nails'
 In so doing, Mr. Black spent two-thirds of his time traveling the world. His British-tailored, 6-foot-2-inch frame, topped by a tilted Homburg, appeared at one time or another in most of the bank's member nations.
He leavened business discussions with smiles and anecdotes. "But his geniality was hardboiled," an associate recalled. "He was as hard as nails when it came to appraising a project."
Mr. Black played no favorites in lending money. He was also able to deal with sometimes difficult statesmen.
On meeting President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic, Mr. Black said, "I am a Wall Street banker." On this unequivocal footing, the two men became respectful friends, and in the long and tricky negotiations arising out of Mr. Nasser's seizure of the Suez Canal, Mr. Black was able to work out payments of the canal company's claims.
He was also instrumental, between 1952 and 1960, in bringing India and Pakistan to an accord over the distribution of the waters of the Indus River. The delicate negotiations were inspired in part by the bank's interests in its own projects along the waterways.
 
'He's a Charmer'
 But Mr. Black's implacable aversion to risky loans irked more than one finance minister. "I don't like your bank much," one of them told a Black aide after being turned down for a loan, "but that Black -- he's a charmer."
He was also sometimes diffident. "I'm not everything I ought to be for this job," he said after 10 years as head of the World Bank. "I had little experience in international banking. I am certainly no linguist, and I never make any speeches."
And yet Mr. Black built the World Bank from 48 member nations with a capital of $8.3 billion to 80 members with a capital of $20.5 billion. The bank also produced the International Finance Corporation and the International Development Association.
Sixty members received more than 300 loans in the Black administration. From Gabon to Guatemala, from Lebanon to Luxembourg, from Iceland to Indonesia, from France to the Philippines arose monuments to the bank's and Mr. Black's efforts in those years.
Until he resigned on Dec. 31, 1962, five months short of the mandatory retirement age of 65, his headquarters were at the bank's office in Washington, where he also made his home. In later years, he and his wife maintained homes in Brooklyn and Florida in addition to Southampton, where they eventually had their sole residence.
 
Took On Extra Jobs

Mr. Black's directorships and the like -- most of which he relinquished while in his 70's -- ranged far afield. He was a trustee of Oglethorpe College in Atlanta and the Johns Hopkins University, of the Institute for International Education and the Population Council Inc., of the National Trust for Historic Preservation and the Ford Foundation. In addition he was chairman of the John F. Kennedy Library.
On retiring from the World Bank, he was made chairman of the Brookings Institution and a board member of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Bowery Savings Bank, the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, the American Express Company, Julius Garfinckel & Company, the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company and other companies and financial institutions. He was a member of the board of the New York Times Company from 1963 to 1973.
 
Special Adviser to U.N.
 In 1963, Mr. Black was appointed special financial consultant to the United Nations. In this role he assisted in the marketing of United Nations bonds and in dunning members in arrears. After leaving the World Bank he was also a special adviser to the ruler of Kuwait in the 1960's.
Mr. Black's first wife, the former Dolly Blalock, died in 1928.
He is survived by his second wife, the former Susette Heath, whom he married in 1930; a sister, Julia Black Wellborn of Atlanta; a daughter and a son from his first marriage, Elizabeth Black Campbell of Falmouth, Mass., and Eugene R. Black Jr. of Easthampton, L.I., who is a retired investment banker; a son from his second marriage, William H. Black of Southampton, also a retired investment banker; eight grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren.
The funeral is to be private.

HEADLINE: Delinquent Parents Lose Windfall to New Jersey

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Scores of New Jersey residents who thought they had come into a windfall from a class-action discrimination suit against the USX Corporation are in for a surprise. The state has grabbed their money for child-support payments.
State officials, who called the action precedent-setting, have intercepted $1.2 million intended for New Jerseyans who are delinquent in paying child support. 
 New Jersey has some of the toughest child-support laws in the nation, allowing officials to attach everything from the paychecks to the lottery winnings of parents who are behind in payments, and the Department of Human Services said today that pursuing settlements in class-action suits would extend the state's reach.
"In individual cases we have gone after assets, but this is the first time we've been able to go after assets on a grand scale," said Marion E. Reitz, the director of the Human Services Department's Division of Economic Assistance.
 
Award for Discrimination
 Ms. Reitz said her division intercepted the awards of 192 plaintiffs in the suit, which was filed in 1976 against USX, formerly the United States Steel Corporation. A Federal judge ruled that USX had discriminated against blacks who applied for jobs as unskilled laborers at the Fairless Hills plant, near Philadelphia, between July 1972 and December 1974 and between January 1978 and December 1979. He awarded $12 million to the plaintiffs.
USX appealed, and the case was in the courts for several years before the company agreed late last year to a $33 million settlement that included interest on the original judgment.
"When we learned that the suit against USX had been settled for more than 2,400 plaintiffs, we thought many plaintiffs could be from New Jersey and might owe child support," Ms. Reitz said. "We were right."
Ms. Reitz said her department got a list of the plaintiffs and checked their names and Social Security numbers against a computerized file of parents who are delinquent in child-support payments.
Ms. Reitz said 320 names showed up owing a total of $2.5 million. Some of the people on the list owed money to county welfare offices because their families had qualified for welfare when no child support was paid, and others owed the support directly to their families.
The state concentrated its efforts in Mercer County, which had the biggest cluster of cases and the greatest amount of money awarded.
"Our society no longer is willing to look at child support as simply an argument between two adults," said the Human Services Commissioner, Alan J. Gibbs. "It is a legitimate debt, and we owe it to the children to force delinquent parents to pay."
For the last 10 years, the Division of Economic Assistance has intercepted Federal and state tax refunds of those who owe child support. Since 1981, it has checked monthly unemployment records to determine if recipients owe back child support payments.
Gov. Jim Florio has strengthened the laws even more since coming to office two years ago. In 1990, he signed legislation that allows the state to withhold child support payments from paychecks and the state began notifying national credit agencies of parents who are delinquent.
Before ending its two-year term in January, the 204th Legislature passed a law allowing the state to attach lottery winnings to cover back child support payments.
 
Thousands of Dollars Collected
 Human services officials said they recouped $814,193 of the $1.8 million owed to Mercer County welfare, collecting from 141 of the 194 residents who owed. The largest collection was $15,813.
They also collected $349,561 from 52 other parents and turned it over to their families to cover money owed in child support. The largest amount received for a single family was $12,000, Ms. Reitz said.
Officials say that plaintiffs whose checks were attached were both men and women. The state sent a check to any person who had money left over after clearing back child support.
There are 350,000 parents in New Jersey who are under court order to pay child support, Ms. Reitz said, and about half of them are at least two weeks in arrears.
New Jersey officials learned of the USX settlement only days before the first checks were to be dispersed, when they were called by a woman who was owed child support by one of the men receiving money.
Citing a section of the Social Security Act of 1988 that allows state officials to recover delinquent child support payments anywhere in the United States, state attorneys went to court to stop the award of payments to plaintiffs who owed child support.
"The state doesn't necessarily go looking for class action lawsuits," said Deputy Attorney General Jim Hill, who coordinated the effort. "But it was such a big case that we made a judgment that something had to be done about it."
He added, "The state considers it a manifest injustice for the plaintiffs to receive this windfall when they are under court order to support their children and refuse to do so."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Clinton Task: Making Message Heard

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., Feb. 20

 BODY:
Standing together just out of reach of the handshake of Gov. Bill Clinton, the Dionne brothers came to the town park here today looking for answers.
None of the three young men, ages 18 to 22, have any health insurance, and two are taking courses at Polk Community College here in the hope that it will help them find other jobs. Because of their economic circumstances, all three still live at home. 
 "Getting George Bush out of office is a big issue for us, whether it's Bill Clinton or somebody else," said Pete Dionne, the eldest brother.
His brother Henry, 21 years old, said, "I'm personally not concerned about the accusations and the mudslinging," and added, "Since George Bush has been President, my father has lost his job and I've lost my job."
None of the brothers had ever heard of Paul E. Tsongas until the former Massachusetts Senator won the New Hampshire Democratic Presidential primary two days ago. They were more familiar with Mr. Clinton because he is from the South. But their presence at the Clinton rally was due more to curiosity than commitment.
It is these voters -- young, male, alienated -- that Mr. Clinton must win if he is to regain his footing and win the Democratic nomination. To do so, his advisers realize, he must learn from the mistakes that nearly derailed his campaign in New Hampshire and capitalize on his convincing second place finish in New Hampshire.
 
'The Comeback Kid'
 It was an artful and successful bit of political spin that allowed Mr. Clinton to annoint himself "the comeback kid" at his election night rally on Tuesday. His advisers had started inserting the word "comeback" into all their conversations in the hours before the polls closed, and by the next day, astute campaign organizers in Georgia and Florida had lifted the phrase from the morning's headlines and plastered it on cardboard placards for rallies.
For the first time in weeks, the Clinton campaign had finally won the expectations game. And with the spotlight shifting away from Mr. Clinton and onto the Bush-Buchanan contest, Mr. Clinton also had a chance to catch his breath.
The Arkansas Governor acknowledged as much today, commenting on a plane ride between campaign stops that he had been in a "coma" for the past two days, hoarse from his nagging New England head cold and ready for a slower campaign pace.
But Mr. Clinton denied published reports today that he was scaling back his efforts in Maryland, which holds its primary on the same day as Georgia, March 3. Nonetheless, he told reporters he considered Maryland a Tsongas state.
"I would expect that a lot of people there would agree with some of the things he has said, because they are more upper middle class than middle class," he said.
Mr. Clinton's theory ignores the fact that Maryland is a state more Southern in nature than Mr. Clinton may realize and that its two largest metropolitan areas -- Baltimore and Prince George's County near Washington -- have majority black populations that supported Jesse Jackson in 1984 and 1988.
Mr. Clinton has scored well among former Jackson supporters in polls in other states, and all his Southern campaign stops are well-attended by black elected officials and other community leaders.
His challenge in the South, he said today, is to attempt to make sure that his messages are heard.
 
On the Death Penalty
 "I don't think what I did caused me a rocky time in New Hampshire," Mr. Clinton told reporters today in Albany, Ga. "I think I'm going to go back to the issues. I'm going to run the campaign I started with. And I think the campaign I started with will do real well down here."
Mr. Clinton also sought to play down comments made by Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia that Mr. Tsongas would not be considered electable by Southern voters because he opposed the death penalty. Mr. Tsongas has said he favored the death penalty only in certain cases, like for drug kingpins.
Mr. Clinton, who supports the death penalty and returned to Arkansas to preside over the execution of a convicted murderer on Jan. 24, said he considered Mr. Tsongas's position an attempt to "fudge" on the issue.
But he also said that he does not plan to emphasize their disagreement on the capital punishment issue to win votes in the South, where many people favor the death penalty.
"I've never tried to use the death penalty as a political issue," he said. "It's just that we have a law that we agree with and I follow it. That's my position on it."
He said New Hampshire voters became convinced that Mr. Tsongas was the candidate with the best new ideas because "my ideas were blown out of their consciousness for three solid weeks."
He added, "And in the last eight days when we finally got the campaign going again, what got people excited was the idea that I was a fighter, that I could plainly be President, that I could plainly stand up to George Bush and fight and argue."
Mr. Clinton salvaged his New Hampshire campaign by engaging in what one of his advisers later described as a "high-wire act" in which he was forced to perform credibly on live televison five times within a single week, including three nationally broadcast programs.
 
Looking to TV
 The Clinton campaign is now counting on turning its candidate's strength on television to quick advantage prior to the string of primaries that begin next week in South Dakota and culminate with the Super Tuesday grouping of 11 primaries and caucuses on March 10.
Gone are the rambling question-and-answer sessions Mr. Clinton held with New Hampshire voters after each speech and the late-night visits to doughnut shops and half-empty restaurants in search of hands to shake. Instead, Mr. Clinton has spent the last two days engaging in classic Super Tuesday strategy, hopping from fund-raising events to television markets and back again.
And now that the grueling pace of the New Hampshire primary is behind them, Clinton campaign strategists are beginning to hope for a little positive fallout from the events that just days ago had seemed only negative.
"Bill and Hillary are celebrities now," one of Mr. Clinton's advisers said last week. "I don't know if it's a positive or negative. I just know it's a fact. But something in my gut tells me it's a positive, because Americans forgive celebrities."

HEADLINE: RESEARCH SPENDING IS DECLINING IN U.S. AS IT RISES ABROAD

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
American spending on research and development has begun to fall for the first time since the 1970's, even as foreign rivals increase their investments in research, a Federal science agency said yesterday.
The amounts spent on research by the Federal Government and private industry each fell, worrying many analysts. They fear that the nation is losing its edge in the international race for discoveries and innovations that can form the basis for new goods and services. 
 The National Science Board, in its biennial report on the health of the nation's research enterprise, said overall spending on research by the Federal Government, industry, universities and private patrons slowed during the second half of the 1980's and began to fall in 1989, ending an era of extraordinary growth.
 
Recession and End of Cold War
 A Federal analyst, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the decline was caused by cutbacks in military research with the end of the cold war and by industrial reductions prompted in part by the recession.
Dr. James J. Duderstadt, president of the University of Michigan and chairman of the National Science Board, said in a statement that the decline, when coupled with educational woes, "should give us real concern for the continued vitality of our research enterprise."
He noted that the United States, despite the drop, still leads the world in overall spending on scientific research.
Yet analysts already edgy about America's status in the global contest for economic advantage expressed worry about the research decline. American spending is falling, they said, as similar investments by Japan and Germany are rising rapidly.
"Clearly it's another warning sign," said Kent H. Hughes, president of the Council on Competitiveness, a private group in Washington that seeks policies to promote industrial vigor. "Especially on the private side, I'd be concerned. That's the research closest to commercialization and marketable products."
Dr. Frank Press, president of the National Academy of Sciences, a federally chartered organization of scientists that advises the Government, agreed. "We especially need to ask why industrial research is down when for other countries it's going up," he said. "That's a matter of concern."
News of the overall drop came in a 487-page report, "Science and Engineering Indicators." Its author, the National Science Board, is the policy-making arm of the National Science Foundation, a Federal agency that supports science research and is responsible for monitoring the nation's overall scientific health.
The biennial report is meant to give decision makers in Government, industry and academia concise information about national trends in science spending, education, manpower and the various fruits of the research enterprise, including patents, scientific papers and new technologies.
In recent decades, the only other drop in overall science spending occurred in the early 1970's as the United States reduced space research after the Apollo moon landings and cut back on military research amid an early thaw in the cold war.
 
Peak at $154.31 Billion
 The new report shows that the United States, beginning in 1975, embarked on a spending spree that climaxed in 1989 with an annual national expenditure for research and development of $154.31 billion. After that peak, the amount for 1990 fell to $151.57 billion. The figures are in constant 1991 dollars to cancel the effects of inflation.
The report said that preliminary data suggest that the total for 1991 will be about the same as 1990. But a Federal analyst working on the data suggested that the 1991 total might go down further.
"The dip," said the Federal analyst, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, "is not simply in Federal dollars but in almost all sectors.
"The bottom line for industry is that they had tremendous growth in the first half of the 80's," the analyst said. "And now, with a change of expectations in profits and sales, and a certain amount of consolidation, there's been a slowing in research and development."
From a peak in 1989 of $78.83 billion, annual research spending by American industry dropped to $77.84 billion in 1990, according to the report. It was the biggest drop in three decades.
 
'Probably Will Get Worse'
 "It's bad news," said Erich Bloch, former director of the National Science Foundation. "And it probably will get worse. A couple of years ago, the leveling off had to do with restructuring. But the drop now has to do with the recession and restructuring."
Even before the decline, the rate of growth had fallen sharply. Between 1980 and 1985 the rate of annual growth for industrial research was 6.9 percent in inflation-adjusted dollars, the report said. Between 1985 and 1990, it fell to 1.2 percent.
The report also noted that the American share of the global market for high-technology goods had fallen from 40 percent in 1980 to 37 percent in 1988.
The report, which is required by Congressional legislation, is submitted by the National Science Board to the President, who in turn provides it to Congress. The current volume is the 10th in a biennial series begun in 1972.
In a preface to the report, Dr. Duderstadt of the National Science Board noted the rapid changes around the globe and warned that American research priorities and programs must be "refined and reshaped to adapt."

HEADLINE: Corporate Tax Cut Deleted As Democrats Polish Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Congressional Democrats moved today to increase the chances for passage of their tax proposals. House leaders dropped an unpopular corporate tax provision and a powerful Senator said he would try to include a politically attractive health insurance measure in the bill.
House Democrats, after a second day of party caucuses dominated by continual criticism of a proposed one-percentage-point cut in the corporate income tax rate, decided to eliminate the provision from the bill entirely. On Wednesday, they had decided to limit the cut to two years rather than make it permanent, as first planned. 
 Those shifts were aimed at winning Democratic votes for the six-year tax bill, whose centerpiece is a tax credit of up to $400 for married couples, financed mainly by raising the highest personal income tax bracket to 35 percent, from 31. The corporate tax cut provision had attracted no visible support, even from corporations.
The bill now has $79.1 billion in tax cuts and $93.5 billion in tax increases.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said in an interview that he would seek to attach a measure intended to improve access to private health insurance to the tax bill. The measure would set Federal standards for insurance companies and prohibit them from discriminating against people with existing medical problems, who now have difficulty obtaining insurance at affordable rates. It would also make it easier for small businesses to obtain group policies.
Mr. Bentsen said his proposal, which has wide support in Congress and has been generally endorsed by President Bush, should be part of the tax bill, both to get action on the insurance measure quickly and to make the overall package more attractive politically.
He said including the health insurance measure would make it harder for Mr. Bush to veto the bill, as Republicans have threatened because of the provisions raising taxes.
"It sure makes it a positive package," he said, adding that he did not think that overall health care reform could be enacted this year, but that this was an important "interim step."
Mr. Bentsen also announced, after a caucus among Senate Democrats, that any tax-cut bill his committee reported would be financed by tax increases. Last fall he had proposed paying for tax cuts with a cut in military spending. The shift in approach puts him on the same track as House Democrats.
 He said he thought that along with "better access to health care," any Senate bill should include a tax cut for the middle class, probably focused on children, and a cut in capital gains taxes "targeted to try to encourage new business and small business and venture capital."
Mr. Bentsen said he did not want to get into numbers today, but would make a proposed bill public on Monday. He does not dominate his committee the way Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, dominates the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, if not his party, in the House. The Finance Committee consists of 10 Democrats, some of them quite conservative, and 9 Republicans, some of them fairly liberal.
The committee will begin voting on the measure on Thursday, and Mr. Bentsen may find he has broader support for his insurance proposal, which has considerable Republican backing, than for the underlying tax measure.
 
 
Military Savings at Issue
 The acknowledgement that any tax cuts would be paid for with tax increases also ended a disagreement with Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat and chairman of the Appropriations Committee, who has insisted that any savings from military programs go to domestic needs.
In fact, under the 1990 budget act, military savings this year can be used only to reduce the deficit. But the House Government Operations Committee voted today to amend that act so that the savings could be used for domestic programs. Before the vote, Representative John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads that committee, called the restriction "an outdated and unnecessary budgetary straitjacket."
The Bush Administration is generally opposed to eliminating the so-called internal firewalls in the budget act. The proposed change is expected to come to the House for a vote in late March or early April.
 
 
Foley Predicts Passage
 The tax bill is expected to come up next Wednesday or Thursday. "The bill will pass," Speaker Thomas S. Foley said after today's caucus.
He said the House would also vote on Mr. Bush's proposals. "It's my view that in that comparison, this does more for tax equity and fairness, this does more for economic growth, and it's more fiscally responsible," he said.
Asked if Mr. Bush's promised veto did not reduce the Democratic bill to no more than a "political document," Mr. Foley replied: "No. Is not the President's threat just a political threat? We have to make our judgments, and the President has to make his." He said that if Congress gave way every time a President threatened a veto, that would "create a dictatorship."
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is his party's senior member on the Ways and Means Committee, complained today that the Democrats were being unfair in not permitting him to make changes in the President's proposal that will be offered on the floor. Since the Democrats were changing their bill from day to day, he said in an interview, he should have the same chance. "I've got 100 changes I'd like to make," he said.

HEADLINE: Dow Surges by 50.32, to a Record 3,280.64

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Surprising investors and traders alike, the stock market rallied sharply yesterday amid a barrage of program trades and speculation that weak numbers on jobless claims and merchandise trade will put pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 50.32 points to a new closing record of 3,280.64, surpassing the Feb. 12 mark of 3,276.83. 
 Heavy buying in secondary and transportation stocks, led by autos, helped spur stock purchases across the board.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange reached 270.7 million shares, up from 234.8 million on Wednesday, as the composite index gained 2.85 points to finish at 228.60. The number of issues trading higher jumped ahead of the losers by 1,158 to 593.
Other market averages recorded strong gains but not records. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 5.64 points, to 413.90, and the American Stock Exchange composite rose 5.40 points, to 412.86. Trading on the Nasdaq was also heavy: The composite rose 9.82 points, to 632.23, while the Russell 2,000 rose 2.53 points, to 210.89.
John Brooks, a technical analyst with Davis, Mendel & Regenstein, Atlanta, said yesterday's solid performance was not generated by program trading alone. "This was legitimate buying, with no one particular piece of news to pinpoint for the 50-point rally, which makes the whole day that much more solid-looking," he said. "What you are witnessing is a continuation of money coming from the money market, where yields are still low, and flowing into the stock market. Yesterday the money just overpowered the bears."
Birinyi Associates, a Wall Street research firm that tracks program trading, noted only two sell programs, in the morning. They raised the Dow 24.6 points, a little less than half of its gain.
A firmer bond market early in the session helped touch off the rally. Blue- chip issues opened modestly higher as investors speculated that a rise of 18,000 in weekly jobless claims, 6,000 more than expected, would put pressure on the Fed to ease interest rates again.
The merchandise trade numbers, also released yesterday, showed a widening of the gap to $5.94 billion in December from $4.17 billion in November.
The Dow shied away from putting into effect the Big Board's 50-point rule a number of times before reaching that point at around 2:15 P.M. Once the Dow is up 50 points, program traders are forced to do their transactions manually instead of by computer, slowing down the pace and assuring a more orderly session.
Short-sellers, who sell borrowed stock in the hope of buying it back at a lower price, are being routed as more investors bet on companies that would benefit from a recovery, Mr. Brooks said. "There has been a lot of shorting by investors in the last week or so, betting that the stocks were headed down, and yesterday some of those investors had to buy stocks in order to cover themselves," he said. He cited General Motors shares, which were around 27 before Christmas but closed up 5/8 yesterday to 39.
Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research for Gruntal & Company, stressed the importance of the recovery in transportation stocks. "Up until yesterday many of the technical people in the market were worried that the transportation sector had not yet confirmed the recent highs on the Dow," he said. "Getting both the Dow and the transportation indexes to move up in step confirmed the market's outlook for an economic recovery."
The Dow transportation index set a new 52-week closing high of 1,467.68, up 42.79 points for the day.
Some analysts noticed some futures-related trading as the market approached today's expiration of equity options and February major market index futures, a "double witching hour" that takes place the third Friday of every month.
The day's outstanding gainers including Ivax Corporation, up 2 3/8, to 35 7/8, on news that its Alzheimer's disease treatment will begin second round of studies.
Traders said shares of companies that make breast implants rose after a regulatory panel said there was no solid evidence linking the implants to autoimmune disease.
Dow Chemical rose 1 1/2, to 57 1/2, and Corning Inc. gained 3 3/8, to 33. Both companies own half of Dow Corning, the leading implant maker. Mentor Corporation gained 1 3/4, to 11; Bioplasty rose 1 1/4, to 6 1/4, and the Inamed Corporation rose 1/2, to 2.
Marvel Entertainment fell 2 1/8, to 52 7/8, after a rival comic book company, Malibu Graphic Publishing Group, said it had hired eight former Marvel comic artists and creators. Marvel dropped earlier this week after Barron's magazine questioned the company's prospects.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
In Quest of a Brighter Labor Climate

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20

 BODY:
Even when Presidents are Republicans, trade unions usually find grounds for getting along with secretaries of labor on some issues, even if agreeing to disagree on others. But union leaders meeting here this week to plan policies find the current incumbent, Lynn Martin, as hostile as they come.
Like previous labor secretaries, Mrs. Martin, who has been in office a year, appeared at a closed session of the 35-member executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. Participants at the annual gathering said she noted at least twice that a mere 16.1 percent of American workers belonged to unions. Unions attribute the decline in part to Republican policies that discourage people from joining unions, and they interpreted her remarks as a way of saying that unions do not matter. 
Asked later about Mrs. Martin's appearance, Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said, "The areas of disagreement and disparity of views that surfaced were nicely coated with expressions of concern." He mocked her "blithe optimism" that the trade agreement with Mexico would not result in the loss of American jobs.
Ready, Willing and Sidelined
Ronald Carey, elected president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters on a promise to purge the union of corruption, showed up at the door to the conference's first executive council meeting on Monday seemingly raring to go to work.
As head of the richest and biggest union, with 1.4 million members, Mr. Carey can be expected to wield some influence at these weeklong conferences, where leaders of the nation's major unions work out positions on legislative and other issues. But Mr. Carey discovered that he would have to wait for another day to get in.
As Mr. Carey approached the conference room, William J. McCarthy, who retired as teamsters president with Mr. Carey's inauguration on Feb. 1, invited Mr. Carey into an anteroom for a chat. Twenty minutes later, it was the retired president who emerged to take a seat at the conference. Without comment or evident emotion, the new teamsters leader headed back to his room.
The seat on the executive council, it turns out, was still Mr. McCarthy's because he was elected to it for another two-year term by delegates to an A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention in November. Normally, a member who loses his union job immediately relinquishes his council seat to his successor, although nothing says he must. Mr. McCarthy intended to give up his seat but in his own way.
"Billy indicated he wanted to spend the day listening to the presentations," Mr. Carey said of their chat. Inside, near the end of the meeting, John Sturdivant, president of the American Federation of Government Employees, said Mr. McCarthy made a gracious and brief speech.
"He said his health was bothering him, that he was having problems with his voice and hearing," Mr. Sturdivant said. "He submitted his resignation and proposed Carey," whom the council promptly elected.
Blaming the Unions
Unions tend to attribute their troubles to everyone but themselves. But on the fringes of the gathering here, some of the several hundred guests are blaming the unions for not getting their message to the public, and in particular they blame Mr. Kirkland's A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Greg Tarpinian, head of a labor advocacy group in New York, the Labor Research Association, distributed the results of a survey by Fingerhut/Granados Opinion Research showing that only 3 percent of American voters even knew who Mr. Kirkland is.
"Nineteen ninety-two should be a watershed year for American labor," Mr. Tarpinian said, adding that a weak economy could be used to drive the Republicans out of the White House. "But labor needs an overarching strategic outlook, and it doesn't have one," he said.
A state labor leader who refused to be named for fear of losing his job added: "There is nobody giving a vision of the labor movement to the American public. If you asked who is the spokesman for workers, it's Jesse Jackson, and he's not a part of the labor movement."
Search for a Rescuer
For an institution that fears it is sinking toward irrelevance as long as Republicans remain in the White House, organized labor seems apathetic about the men who are vying to dislodge President Bush. At meetings here two years ago, half the participants seemed to be wearing lapel buttons assailing Frank Lorenzo, head of the now defunct Eastern Airlines, for union-busting.
But of several hundred people attending a reception here this week, only one guest had a Presidential campaign button. David Schlein, a vice president of the American Federation of Government Employees, wore one reading, "Labor for Tom Harkin." One other man, Gerald McEntee, a council member who is president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees wore a Clinton sticker, but in deference to the council's agreement to stay neutral until later in the week, when a decision is made on whom to support, he kept it on the back of his lapel.
Political figures who arouse strong support here, like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, are not running, though hopes were high for a while that they would.
Rumors circulated at the start of the conference that the many New Yorkers who run unions were plotting to ally behind Mr. Cuomo.
"I think there's a real opportunity to throw Bush out," said Moe Biller, president of the American Federation of Postal Workers, a New Yorker who at 76 years old is the dean of the council. "I think Cuomo can do the number best."
But then came the write-in vote in New Hampshire that left Mr. Cuomo in the rear of the pack.
Upon agreeing to end their neutrality in the campaign, 14 unions said they would be supporting Senator Harkin, three said they would back Mr. Clinton, and the rest said they were still sounding out their members.
"We don't have anybody out there that people like," said Barry Feinstein, the top teamsters' leader in New York. "So people are settling."

McCarthy, left, the outgoing president, at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council meeting on Tuesday in Bal Harbour, Fla. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasuries Unchanged

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in extremely sluggish trading yesterday.
With auctions of new two-year and five-year notes next week, and many traders seeing the prospect of another reduction in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board dimming, there was some light selling of shorter-term bills and notes, and purchases of longer-term notes and bonds. But trading volume was very light. 
 "If I had a pillow I'd be asleep," a government-securities trader said.
Traders are taking recent comments by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, at face value. As recently as Wednesday, the Fed chief indicated that for the time being the Fed had finished easing monetary policy, although not ruling out further interest-rate cuts if the economy continues to stall.
For the most part, market participants ignored economic data released yesterday, including a wider trade deficit reported for December but a much smaller gap for all of 1991.
The 18,000 rise in initial unemployment claims for the week ended Feb. 8, to 452,000, was a bit higher than expected, but was met with little reaction.
 
Money Supply Rises
 Similarly, prices did not move much late in the day after the Fed reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Feb. 10.
The increase in the aggregates, particularly the $9.5 billion rise in M-2, the money measure most closely followed by the Fed, was bigger than most analysts had expected.
"We refer to these numbers as the money surprise, not the money supply," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America. "But it is clear that the money numbers have been growing at a much better pace since October. If you are an optimist about the economy, this has to be an encouraging sign."
Prices of outstanding Treasury notes and bonds remained locked in narrow trading ranges for most of the session.
By late in the day, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 1012/32 , up 1/32 , to yield 7.90 percent, unchanged from late Wednesday.
 
Treasury Note Action
 Among Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10025/32 , up 1/32 , to yield 7.38 percent. The 6 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 9810/32 , down 1/8 point, to yield 6.65 percent. And the 4 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 1/4, down 1/8 point, to yield 5.28 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved higher.
By late in the session, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.87 percent, up four basis points, or four one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.99 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by seven basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.17 percent.
A number of market participants said the chances of a rally would improve once next week's note auctions were over.
"The big problem right now is that there is still a lot of paper out there from the refunding," another Government securities trader said.
"But once we get through with the two-year and five-year auctions, it will be a month before we have to bid on more coupon issues. That will give dealers a chance to pare their positions, and we should get a bounce. I think we are setting up for a decent rally in March, provided the economic statistics don't blow us out of the water."
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Public Service Electric and Gas offered $250 million worth of 30-year and 7-year first and refunding mortgage bonds at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by the First Boston Corporation won the $150 million worth of 30-year noncallable securities, which mature Feb. 1, 2022.
The securities were reoffered to investors with a coupon of 8 3/4 percent at a price of $99.75, to yield 8.773, 87 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
 
Salomon Bid Wins
 The remaining $100 million of seven-year notes were won by a bid from a group led by Salomon Brothers.
The securities, which mature Feb. 1, 2000, were reoffered with a 7 5/8 percent coupon and were priced at $100, or par, 60 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, Harris County, Tex., offered a total of $448 million worth of bonds in a negotiated sale through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
The bulk of the issue consisted of term bonds maturing in 2017. These 6.50 percent securities were priced on a preliminary basis to yield 6.79 percent.
These bonds are insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, and are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
The remainder of the bonds are not insured, and are rated AA by Moody's and AA+ by Standard & Poor's.
Traders in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged at the end of a very slow session.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities, participants said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: At the Bar

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
Even in a recessionary economy, jury awards in personal injury cases continue to climb. According to the biweekly newsletter for trial lawyers, Lawyers Alert, last year's 10 top awards to plaintiffs amounted to "an eye-popping" $673 million.
The biggest award of them all -- $127 million -- went to an Illinois man whose ophthalmologist missed in administering a crucial injection. But to the Federation of Insurance and Corporate Counsel, the point is clear: something must be done to tame runaway, bleeding-heart juries, so profligate with their clients' money. 
 Enter J. Ric Gass of Kravit, Gass & Weber in Milwaukee, chairman of the federation's trial-tactics section. Mr. Gass is the auteur of "Handling Sympathy in Jury Trials," an hourlong videotape on how to counteract the compassion that human beings feel for brain-damaged infants, mutilated youngsters, amputees and quadriplegics.
Sympathy, Mr. Gass maintains, is "the major scare tactic" of the plaintiffs' bar. Faced with weak liability claims, he says, they pollute courtrooms with anguished "day-in-the-life" videos, dismal diagrams and photographs that would make a Goya wince. So Mr. Gass assembled for the video some colleagues in the defense bar to offer secrets for turning "boxcar" awards into snake-eyes.
Just how, for instance, did Jack Daniels of Los Angeles extricate his film director client from liability for an accident on the set of "Cannonball Run" that left a "gorgeous" young actress paralyzed from the neck down? By his own account, he made several strategically savvy decisions.
For one thing, he did not object to the victim's continuous presence in the courtroom. "I want to desensitize that jury," he said, so they get used to seeing the plaintiff in that catastrophic condition. "Otherwise, if you don't have the plaintiff there, the first time they wheel them in the courtroom, you'll hear a gasp."
Rather than grill the victim and make her even more pitiable, he continued, he elicited whatever damaging testimony he needed -- for example her failure to use a seat belt -- from others. And always, he treated her with conspicuous courtesy: holding open doors for her so she could wheel herself around, greeting her cheerfully each morning. "I didn't want anything to have those jurors feel that I didn't think she was a wonderful person," he explained. "That's my M.O. at the trial."
Plaintiffs, Mr. Gass noted, produce plenty of people to say how miserable their lives have become -- "moaners and groaners," he calls them. But another panelist, Michael Jones of Denver, urged defense counsel to accent the positive, to point out all those things, say, that paraplegics can do. One could get helpful hints, Mr. Jones said, from the National Wheelchair Athletic Association and its magazine, Sports and Spokes.
"They talk about scuba diving, sailing, bowling, archery, shooting -- all those activities that show that, yes, these people have a very severe, very debilitating injury," he said, "but there are aspects of everyday life that they can do, perhaps with some modifications." Never, never let yourself or your client look too downcast -- or in the other direction -- when things get too gory. "A jury's going to pick that up," he said.
At the same time, one cannot sidestep the negative. "John, you've developed a technique for dealing with the gruesome photographs that we all have to deal with it," Mr. Gass said cheerfully on camera to John Woodard 3d, a lawyer in Tulsa, Okla. Mr. Woodard then recounted how, in a successful medical malpractice defense, he pre-emptively showed four photographs of a mutilated body to prospective jurors rather than spring them on the panel at trial.
One must produce another kind of sympathy -- for the defense counsel, the video advises. Emphasize that simply because you work for an insurance company does not mean that you are a monster. Let a jury know that you, too, would cry if one of your own children had been similarly injured. And make it clear, as Mr. Gass put it, that "there's no line outside the courtroom of attorneys angling for my job."
Mr. Gass said that sales of the video were brisk and that the testimonials were rolling in. Richard Johnson of Everett, Wash., wrote to say that he views it before every trial. Robert Wilson of Los Angeles said it should be required viewing for all defense lawyers.
Thus far, the opposition has been silent, and understandably. "We don't sell it to plaintiffs' lawyers," Mr. Gass explained.

HEADLINE: Joseph Fisher, 78, Economic Adviser to Presidents

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Joseph L. Fisher, an expert on natural resources and an economist who advised two Presidents, served in Congress and was a local and state official in Virginia, died on Wednesday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 78 years old.
He died of a brain tumor, his family said. 
 Dr. Fisher was a senior economist for the Council of Economic Advisers to the President for four years under Harry S. Truman and one year under Dwight D. Eisenhower.
For the next 20 years Dr. Fisher worked for Resources for the Future, a nonprofit organization that analyzes the supply and use of natural resources. He was its president for 15 years and in 1962 directed a 1,000-page forecast of the nation's needs through the year 2000. He later served on Federal panels on oil policy and noise pollution.
A Democrat, he was elected to the Arlington County Board in 1964, serving until 1974. He was its chairman for three years. He also led the Washington Metropolitan Transit Authority and the Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments.
In the 1974 Democratic landslide that followed the Watergate revelations, he upset Joel T. Broyhill, a 20-year incumbent, to win a seat in Congress. Despite being a freshman, Dr. Fisher was given a coveted seat on the House Ways and Means Committee, and he became an influential legislator on the budget, taxes and Social Security. He also helped create a fund to clean up oil spills. He lost his seat in the Republican sweep of 1980.
In 1982, Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia appointed Dr. Fisher as State Secretary of Human Resources. He left government work in 1986 and began teaching political economics at George Mason University.
A longtime lay leader in the Unitarian Church, he was for several years the moderator and chairman of the international Unitarian Universalist Association. He was also a former board chairman of the National Academy of Public Administration and the Population Reference Bureau and was on the board of the Wilderness Society.
Mr. Fisher was born in Pawtucket, R.I. He earned a bachelor's degree from Bowdoin College, a master's and a doctorate in economics from Harvard and a master's in education from George Washington University.
Surviving are his wife, the former Margaret Winslow; four sons, H. Benjamin of Jakarta, Indonesia, Robert W., of Fort Worth, Tex., William B., of Great Falls, Va., and James H., of Yellow Springs, Ohio; three daughters, Caroline Ostrander of Ithaca, N.Y., Elizabeth Fisher of Hong Kong and Barbara W. Fisher of Arlington; 14 grandchildren, and a sister, Mary McWilliams of Canton, Mass.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Seasoned Executive Is Heading Air Canada

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Air Canada yesterday named Hollis L. Harris, a former top executive at both Delta and Continental, as vice chairman, president and chief executive.
The 60-year-old Mr. Harris, who was not available for comment, will face several challenges in managing Air Canada, the former state-owned airline that is now a publicly traded corporation. 
 Air Canada, based in Montreal, and its largest competitor, Canadian Airlines International, a subsidiary of the PWA Corporation, are battling for passengers amid a deep slump in travel. Yesterday, Air Canada reported a 1991 loss of $218 million (Canadian), or $184 million (United States), on revenue of $3.57 billion (Canadian), or $3 billion (United States).
Canadian Government and industry officials are considering several options to help the nation's troubled airlines. One would be to merge Air Canada and Canadian Airlines, which would probably make 10,000 jobs unnecessary. With Canada's unemployment rate above 10 percent, such a move is considered politically risky.
"That is not politically tenable or financially feasible," said Steven Garmaise, an analyst with First Marathon Securities in Toronto.
Canadian officials may also loosen foreign-ownership requirements. PWA is reportedly discussing ties with American Airlines. But relying on help from American carriers would also be politically unpopular among Canadians, who fear growing American influence. Although American partners would hold a minority interest, their level of control would likely be that of a majority owner, analysts said.
He left Delta to join Continental Airlines as chairman, president and chief executive in September 1990.
At Continental, which is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection, Mr. Harris adopted a strategy of expansion, even as the industry was in the midst of a recession and fare wars. Eventually, the airline's creditors and its board forced his departure. Last year, he joined Air Eagle Holdings, an Atlanta-based aviation consulting service.
Mr. Harris holds an aeronautical engineering degree from the Georgia Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: December Trade Gap Widened

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Dwindling exports resulted in a sharp widening of the nation's merchandise trade deficit in December, but for 1991 as a whole, the deficit narrowed to $66.20 billion, the smallest shortfall in eight years.
The Bush Administration hailed the full-year results as a sign of renewed American competitiveness, and members of Congress from both parties said that the improvement last year would be more important in the national debate over protectionism than December's poor showing. 
 In December, the deficit grew by 42 percent, to $5.94 billion, as exports fell and imports climbed, the Commerce Department said.
 
Exports Up in '91
 But for the full year, exports rose 7.2 percent, led by a 9.3 percent gain for manufactured goods, the main casualties from foreign competition during the 1980's. And imports fell for the first time since 1982.
"Those figures would tend to dampen down the enthusiasm for trade law changes," said Representative Don J. Pease, an Ohio Democrat who supports more trade restrictions. "If I were President Bush and could say that I'd reduced the trade deficit from over $100 billion to $66 billion, I'd be pretty pleased."
Economists, however, attribute much of the improvement from the $101.7 billion deficit in 1990 and the peak $152.1 billion deficit in 1987 to the weakening of the American economy, which has left businesses and individuals less able to afford imports.
 
Recession Is Cited
 "At least half, maybe two-thirds, of the year's improvement was due to the recession," said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington public policy research group.
And the widening trade gap reported for December served as unwelcome news for Mr. Bush's re-election campaign. as the seasonally adjusted deficit deteriorated by $1.77 billion from November.
J. Antonio Villamil, the Commerce Department's chief economist, said the increase in the deficit in December was not significant because a third of it reflected a decline in aircraft exports, which vary enormously from month to month as planes worth $100 million or more apiece are delivered in bunches.
But private economists generally agree that as other industrialized nations' economies continue to slow down this year, making them less able to buy American exports, trade balances in 1992 will more likely resemble the December results than the overall improvement in 1991.
The United States will avoid deterioration in its trade balance this year, Mr. Bergsten said, only if the economic recovery is exceptionally weak.
 
Exports Down in December
 Exports, which accounted for most of the nation's economic growth in 1990 and 1991 and which the Administration sees as powering the nation's economic recovery, dropped 2.2 percent in December. And the Commerce Department also revised today its November export figure to show a drop instead of a record high.
Japan and China, two of the nation's three least politically popular trade partners, showed bigger trade surpluses with the United States in 1991. The third trading partner, Mexico, with which the Administration is negotiating a free-trade agreement, last year posted its first deficit with the United States in a decade.
Exports to Japan dropped sharply in December and slightly for all of last year, so that the annual trade deficit between the nations widened to $43.44 billion from $41.10 billion, the first such deterioration since 1987.
The persistent deficit with Japan has grown to two-thirds of the overall deficit from a third in the last four years, and Congressional Democrats have made it a centerpiece of their recent criticisms of Administration trade policy.
"I think it's frustrating to see us make this kind of progress with the Europeans, with Mexico and many other countries" but not Japan, said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee.
The trade deficit with China expanded to $12.7 billion last year from $10.4 billion. After nearly a year of political maneuvering, the Senate is expected to vote within the next week and finally send President Bush a bill imposing conditions on the June renewal of China's trade access to the American market. The President has promised to veto the bill.
Today's report contributed little to resolving the fundamental trade-deficit question that has divided international trade experts and economists: whether the improvement of the last four years represents a structural and lasting change in America's role in world markets or simply the steep slide since 1985 in the dollar's value, which has made imports more expensive and American exports more competitive abroad.
Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., the president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington public policy group, said the rising deficit with Japan shows that foreign trade barriers persist while America's domestic weaknesses, such as high health-care costs, continue to hobble American exporters. "Devaluation of the dollar devalues U.S. assets and makes us all poorer," he said.
A study released today by Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a large accounting firm, said that Japanese investors had used the strong yen to buy $76 billion worth of American real estate since the mid-1980's, although the pace slowed significantly last year.
 
A Lasting Difference
 But Harold Malmgren, a deputy United States trade representative during the Nixon and Ford Administrations, said that slow growth in American industrial wages and the trimming of corporate middle management had made a lasting difference in keeping American goods affordable in foreign markets. The main threat to American exports this year lies in the possibility that the weakness of foreign economies will cause a rise in the dollar's value, he said.
The trade deficit announced today may be worse than it seems because it includes only goods and because exports are often undercounted, several economists said. The nation ran an estimated $34 billion trade surplus in services last year, largely because of a big increase in foreign tourism.
A report last month from the National Research Council estimated that American exports of goods were undercounted by 3 to 7 percent, or $13 billion to $29 billion last year, because duties were not charged on them.
Including the undercounting and services, the nation's trade in goods and services was nearly balanced last year.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
A School's 'Organizer Extraordinaire'

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: NORWALK, Conn.

 BODY:
IT'S probably the fault of Nan Haavik's parents. They were always so darned involved, speaking out and writing mayors and Congressmen as if individual citizens mattered and had a responsibility to contribute a little something to their community.
We now realize that's old-fashioned and silly, of course, like knowing everyone in your neighborhood and keeping an eye out for one another. What possible difference could one person make in the face of overpowering urban realities? (It might even be dangerous.) Today's silent common wisdom recognizes decay as virtually inevitable in cities, especially in an age when budgets are cut before they're assembled. Who needs the frustration? Who has the time? 
 Mrs. Haavik does.
"I'm a pusher," she says. (No, not that kind.) "You always need someone who's deaf to every reason why something can't be done." It all started a few years ago when she faithfully followed her son's teams into schools in surrounding suburbs. "They were all so clean and bright," Mrs. Haavik recalled, "as if someone cared."
Such was not always the case here at their son's school, Brien McMahon High School. The school, named for a United States senator who died of cancer in 1952, opened eight years later. McMahon High had a hard-working staff by all accounts, but it's hard to focus community spirit without a snappy mascot. (What kind of inspiring logo do teams called the Senators use -- a well-dressed man with his hand out?) It struggled to find an identity other than as Norwalk's other high school. There were rising enrollments, which stressed the sprawling West Side building and then declining enrollments, two-career families and unemployment to weaken involvements.
Like many schools, McMahon showed wear. Visitors were greeted by a red Coca-Cola machine. The long halls were lined with abandoned trophy cases and cement block walls painted institutional green. With so many problems, redecorating hallways didn't burst to the top of the priority list. But few seemed to notice.
"Nan," said Roz McCarthy, one of many McMahon parents who have been organized and volunteered by Mrs. Haavik, "became our organizer extraordinaire."
"It's like your own home," said Mrs. Haavik, a tax accountant and longtime Parents Club board member. "You don't see the dirt or wear until company is coming. I know this can seem unimportant in education. But it's part of a good education, teaching values, creating an atmosphere conducive to growth and learning."
The first project: Fixing the entrance. Many parents didn't see the point; some kids, being kids, would just mess it up. Why bother? Mrs. Haavik changed her name to Pollyanna. "Sure, there's wear and tear," she said at one meeting. "But if you give in to the worst, then we're all pulled down to the lowest level."
With the administration's enthusiastic endorsement, Mrs. Haavik organized a team of painting parents. But wait just one minute. Was this maintenance painting or decorative painting? Because, you see, there are union rules against parents doing maintenance painting.
Mrs. Haavik decided this was definitely decorative painting.
And was this fire-retardant paint? (She found a paint-dealer parent who assured her it was.) And who's paying the janitor required when school doors are open? (She made an alliance with the school's scheduling secretary to paint during team and band practices.) She also sought advice from custodians, who became eager helpers. Suddenly, useful equipment and new display cases appeared.
One parent who is an artist drew symbols for 16 school sports, which were painstakingly traced along the walls and then hand-painted over and over by more Nan-volunteered parents. The other day Mrs. McCarthy, Lynne Pratt and Lucie Sasaki-Scanlon painted music and arts symbols by those classrooms. The school entrance became a student art gallery.
One secret Saturday a band of guerrilla gardeners attacked the grounds, run by a different city department. The land was weeded and trimmed before anyone could object. One month after Mrs. Haavik spent 10 hours on the phone, a city crew fixed a shattered wooden bench.
"In a large troubled city like this," Mrs. Haavik said, "three boards in one bench seem unimportant. But they're very important in a school's small family. When something looks wrong, it feeds the decay."
Here's something really radical: Mrs. Haavik even took to thanking people afterward. Guess what? They proved happier to help the next time.
Next comes the green cafeteria and gym, probably under the leadership of Mrs. Pratt, whose garage up on Farm Creek Road is fast filling with ladders and buckets.
"Change isn't simple," Mrs. Haavik said, "even when it's for the better. There's lots of fear. I just try to make my path the path of least resistance, to show the world somebody cares. It's contagious."
But what's her most important lesson from being a civic catalyst? "You always need someone saying, 'Yes, yes, it is possible.' "
Might that work elsewhere? It is possible.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
