HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Poll;
Tsongas Gains Substantially, Pulling Near Clinton in Poll

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts made a substantial gain in national recognition as a result of his victory in the New Hampshire primary and has drawn close to Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas among Democrats who have chosen a favorite for their party's nomination, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
But all five main Democratic candidates remain virtually unknown to half or more of the likely primary voters in their own party, the poll found. 
 Mr. Clinton has the support of 29 percent of his party's likely voters, despite increased negative views about him that were detected in the poll, which was conducted Wednesday and Thursday. Mr. Tsongas is second with 24 percent and has made the greater gain of the two since the last Times/ CBS News poll, in January. He moved up 14 percentage points while Mr. Clinton advanced by 7 points. Because of the new poll's margin of sampling error, Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton could now be in a virtual tie.
 
Bush Leads His Challenger
 Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California was backed by 10 percent in the new poll, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska by 4 percent and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa by 3 percent.
Among Republican primary voters nationally, President Bush leads his conservative challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, by a 4-to-1 ratio, the survey showed. And while 80 percent of Republican primary voters agree that Mr. Buchanan is "saying some things George Bush needs to hear," 73 percent of those same voters say they want Mr. Bush to win his party's nomination.
But among all registered voters in the nation, regardless of party, 53 percent say they lack any clear idea of what Mr. Bush "wants to accomplish in a second term as President," even though he has been campaigning for re-election for at least six weeks.
This finding coincides with the judgment of Republican strategists who have criticized the President's "I care" message in the New Hampshire primary campaign. With 13 primaries scheduled for the next three weeks and Mr. Buchanan pressing his campaign, it also suggests that the White House needs to retool its strategy quickly.
It had been theorized by many politicians that neither of the top finishers in the Democratic voting in New Hampshire, Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton, would get much benefit nationally from their accomplishment because so much attention was focused on Mr. Buchanan's strong showing against the President. But the Times/CBS News poll showed they have become much the best-known of active Democratic candidates.
The current survey, which has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, suggests that the President retains ample room to change voters' minds and retake the initiative, and, like all incumbents, he has many tools with which to do so.
 
Trouble on Economic Front
 Still, the poll indicates that Mr. Bush has national difficulties, not just a local problem brought on by New Hampshire's severe recession. His approval rating is hovering at 42 percent, about the same as it was just before the State of the Union Message on Jan. 28, which had been widely heralded as the key to turning around the economy and halting the President's slide.
Clearly, the speech did not accomplish its political purpose, and polls indicate there was not even a brief lift for Mr. Bush.
The Times/CBS News poll showed only 18 percent approval of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy, the worst level for a President since Jimmy Carter, who was at 15 percent in July 1979. In the current survey of 1,044 adults, 75 percent said they disapproved of Mr. Bush's economic stewardship.
Hard economic times and a belief that the Bush Administration is responsible for them are evidently hurting the President, despite his effort in his speeches and his primary-state advertising to lay much of the blame on the Democratic-controlled Congress.
Asked whether Mr. Bush "cares about the needs and problems" of people like themselves, only 49 percent of registered voters said yes, a dangerous level for an incumbent who has had three years to connect with the electorate and especially dangerous for one who has been saying "I care" again and again. More directly, 46 percent said they placed "a lot of the blame" for the recession on the White House.
On another question in the same area, 52 percent of all those interviewed and 37 percent of Republicans, a significant minority, said Mr. Bush could have avoided raising taxes in 1990. It was the President's violation of his "no new taxes" pledge that Mr. Buchanan hammered home in New Hampshire television commercials.
Not suprisingly, given his blunt style of speaking and writing, Mr. Buchanan evokes contrasting reactions among Republicans. Of primary voters, 24 percent hold a favorable view and 26 percent an unfavorable view of the television commentator, columnist and former White House speech writer.
Nevertheless, 44 percent said Mr. Buchanan, who has never held elective office, "has the ability to be an effective President," while 34 percent disagreed with that.
Republican primary voters preferred Mr. Bush as the party's nominee, with 73 percent backing him, 17 percent supporting Mr. Buchanan, and 2 percent choosing David Duke of Louisiana, a former Ku Klux Klan leader.
 
Bush Leads Democratic Rivals
 The Democratic electorate has reached no consensus about a preferred challenger to Mr. Bush, at least partly because the party's candidates remain poorly defined in the public mind. Exactly half the Democratic primary voters questioned in the survey expressed no opinion about Mr. Clinton, despite torrents of publicity about accusations of marital infidelity and of efforts of avoid the draft during the Vietnam War. Even fewer had an opinion about the other candidates.
As a result, perhaps, Mr. Bush lost a trial heat against an unnamed and possibly idealized Democratic nominee, 40 percent to 45 percent, but he won theoretical races among registered voters: against Mr. Clinton by 51 to 40, against Mr. Tsongas by 47 to 40 and against Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, often mentioned as a possible late starter in the race, by 52 to 33.
Both Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton are rated favorably by 33 percent of Democratic primary voters nationally, but Mr. Tsongas is rated unfavorably by only 9 percent, while Mr. Clinton is so characterized by 16 percent. That could be the result of the accusations against Mr. Clinton this month.
Though relatively unknown, the Democratic hopefuls are apparently gradually persuading voters that they constitute a reasonable pool of talent. Last October, 64 percent of Democratic voters said they wished there were more choices, but this week only 45 percent said additional candidates were needed, while another 45 percent said they were satisfied with the field.
Among three potential late starters whose support was explicitly gauged in the poll, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, on whose behalf a write-in campaign was waged in New Hampshire, is the most popular. He is followed by Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the 1988 Vice Presidential nominee, and Mr. Gephardt.
Voters in New Hampshire repeatedly emphasized to reporters this year that "the issues" were what mattered most to them, and the 820 registered voters among those interviewed in the Times/CBS News poll said the same thing. Seventy-two percent said issues would play the largest role in their decision on how to vote; the next most frequently mentioned criterion, a candidate's moral character, was ranked first by only 5 percent.
But other answers suggested deeper currents. Asked whether the accusation about Mr. Clinton's marital life would affect their votes, 61 percent said no. But when asked whether the accusation would affect how other voters would react, only 28 percent said they thought the accusation would be seen as immaterial.
 
 
 
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted on Wednesday and Thursday with 1,044 adults, including 820 registered voters, around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the continental United States. The exchanges were chosen to insure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent to the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of a household's size and the number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for those who say they vote in Democratic primaries or caucuses, it is plus or minus five percentage points. For Republican primary and caucus voters, it is six percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Closing the Books in Hartford

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 21

 BODY:
It was perhaps inevitable, after 25 years in side-by-side offices poring over the same documents, that Leo V. Donohue and Henry J. Becker Jr. should start completing each other's sentences.
Mr. Becker: "I guess we knew each other ----" 
 Mr. Donohue: "Since about 19 ----"
In unison: "55."
Mr. Becker: "Yeah."
Their jobs, as Connecticut's co-auditors of public accounts, are unusual enough.
No other state takes a Democrat, in this case Mr. Donohue, and a Republican, Mr. Becker, and expects them to work in harmony, signing off as co-equals on what are sometimes politically charged audits of state agency spending and performance. That such joined-at-the-hip public accounting has worked since 1967 without the two having killed each other has made them something of a State Capitol legend.
They live in the same small town of Avon, a suburb of Hartford. Their children played on the same Avon High School football team. They took office on the same day two-and-half decades ago, during the administration of Gov. John Dempsey, and next Friday they will retire as they served: together. Yet they profess not to be particularly close friends, and are bit uncertain about when and if they'll even run into each other again. Perhaps the supermarket, they say.
Yet they leave an unmistakable if somewhat mysterious legacy. Because hardly anyone is left in government who even remembers previous auditors, Mr. Becker, who is 63 years old, and Mr. Donohue, 67, have defined their jobs in a way that few people ever get to, or want to. And the decades have hardened personal idiosyncrasies into institutional ones.
 
A Rougher Era
 They made a pact in the early days, for example, that an employment reference from a politician would be "the kiss of death" to anyone seeking a job on the 96-member auditing staff because, as Mr. Donohue put it, "We don't want to hire anyone to the office who feels more loyal to one of us than the other."
Officials at the National Association of State Auditors, Comptrollers and Treasurers also said that Connecticut is the only state in the nation that has adamantly refused to join the group to share information and auditing techniques.
"One being a Democrat, one being a Republican, maybe one of them couldn't ever leave Connecticut without fear of the other getting the upper hand," said Relmond Van Daniker, the 49-member association's executive director. "It's a very unusual situation."
Even how a new auditor is appointed is something that has had to relearned. "When we were putting in our notice to leave, from both sides we got questions like, 'Well, do we make the appointment?' " Mr. Becker said in a joint interview.
Many politicians are also beginning to realize that the new auditors will have to begin a new era of their own. Mr. Becker and Mr. Donohue, who served under 12 different governors in various state jobs since the 1940's, came of age and into office in a time of simpler, smaller government and more gentlemanly rules of political conduct.
"They came from a fair-minded era," said Thomas I. D'Amore Jr., a veteran of Connecticut state politics since the 1970's, most recently as co-chief of staff under under Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. "It was more balanced, less combative," Mr. D'Amore said. "It was O.K. to stand up and defend your position, but you didn't have to win every battle. Now it's win at all costs, do or die today."
The thought of a daily battle with the person in the next office has clearly given some people pause. But Mr. Becker said he told one worried applicant for the $74,000-a-year job that for a Democrat and a Republican, getting along now should be easier than ever, with a third-party independent Governor like Mr. Weicker in office.
"You've got a Governor up there that neither one of you can be very happy with," he said. "That alone should bring you together."
The statute that defines the auditors' jobs doesn't give much how-to-survive guidance, saying only that the auditors, once appointed by the General Assembly, shall "organize the work of their office in such a manner as they deem most economical and efficient." That could mean, theoretically, majority and dissenting reports, or audits within audits, as the minority party auditor checks the work of the majority.
 
Unique System
 For Mr. Becker and Mr. Donohue, the pressures appear to have driven them almost into a singular perspective. Their work -- all reports signed by both men -- is praised by party leaders on both sides as non-partisan. And on those occasions when one or the other party has been offended by a report, the two men have stood shoulder-to-shoulder against all comers.
Mr. Van Daniker at the Auditors Association said that while states vary widely in how they approach the job of auditing their own books, no other state has the sort of institutional duality featured here. New York is probably "the next most unique," he said, in having one man, Edward V. Regan, whose job as Comptroller also includes auditing duties -- thus the office that keeps the books also checks them.
The co-auditor system began in colonial times, Mr. Becker and Mr. Donohue said, and it is a system they swear by, however much their colleagues around the country scratch their heads.
"We both think that it is a lot better system than it appears," Mr. Donohue said. "When you have two people here, not of the same party, it's impossible for either to cover something up, or to overstress something, because you know that the person in the next office knows as much about the issue as you do. Nothing keeps you more honest than the threat of being caught."

HEADLINE: City Job Loss Called More Than Expected

 BODY:
New York City lost about 50,000 more jobs in 1991 than had been thought, according to revised statistics published yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor.
Previously, the city's job losses last year had been estimated at 160,000 jobs, but that figure has now been raised to 210,000, coming off a total non-agricultural employment base of 3.5 million. 
 About half of the additional 50,000 jobs that were lost came from the services sector, and the greatest losses in that sector were 9,000 in the business services category and 7,000 in engineering and management.
" That's a fairly substantial revision," acknowledged Jim Brown, a labor market analyst for the department. "It suggests that the city's economy has not yet bottomed out."
Mr. Brown said that the revision had occurred because the estimates are based on monthly samples, and the sample for the services group is especially small. Only when quarterly data depicting the actual number of employees come in can the department tell whether its sample figures need to be revised.

HEADLINE: Middle Class Shrinks, U.S. Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The Government has provided new evidence that the American middle class is shrinking.
A report released by the Census Bureau on Thursday shows that the percentage of Americans with middle incomes dropped from 71.2 percent in 1969 to 63.3 percent in 1989. 
 "The conclusion is obviously that inequality has grown rather substantially over the last 20 years," said Jack McNeil, the Census Bureau economist who wrote the report. "We're getting clusters toward both ends" of the income scale, he said.
The growing income inequality is partly due to the increase in the number of families headed by single mothers, who are less likely to work, Mr. McNeil said.
Several studies in recent years have documented the decline of the middle class, but the new report provides more detail on income trends in different population groups, Mr. McNeil said. For the first time, the Census Bureau used a measure of income that takes family size into account.
"The elderly are doing better than any other group," Mr. McNeil said. "You can see some improvement in their relative status."
The percentage of people 65 years old and over with middle incomes ranged from 21.5 percent to 29.9 percent in 1964, the report said. By 1989 the range had grown to 24.9 percent to 34.2 percent.
The study defined low incomes as less than half the median income, when adjusted for family size. High incomes were defined as more than twice the median.
By these definitions, a family of four has a low income if it makes below $18,576 a year. By contrast, the census defines a family of four as poor if its annual income is less than $13,359. The report showed that the percentage of Americans with low incomes rose to 22.1 percent in 1989 from 17.9 percent in 1969.

HEADLINE: U.S. Refuses To Supervise Newark Job

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Saying that they are satisfied with steps to improve the Newark Housing Authority, Federal housing officials have refused to appoint a receiver to manage the agency's long-delayed construction projects.
Burton Bloomberg, the acting manager of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development in Newark, said he was denying the receiver because he was satisfied that Newark, state and Federal officials were taking steps to speed up housing construction -- including naming a task force to help reduce bureaucratic delays and developing a $60 million revolving loan fund to help developers who had been unable to obtain financing during the recession. 
 "At this critical juncture, when the emerging signs of cooperative effort and marshalling of technical resources needed to further development are so encouraging, it is H.U.D.'s judgment that appointment of a receiver would be unwarranted and could impede progress," Mr. Bloomberg said in a statement released Tuesday.
But Victor DeLuca, chairman of the Newark Coalition for Low-Income Housing, which had requested the receiver in December, said that Federal housing officials did not address the myriad problems plaguing New Jersey's largest housing authority in arriving at its decision.
 
List of Delays and Missteps
 "We believe that the problems with the Newark Housing Authority are ones of capacity, of experience," he said, adding that the coalition may sue to force H.U.D. to name an overseer. "A new initiative to speed up construction isn't going to address their problems in implementing the process."
The Federal housing agency has appointed receivers to manage other troubled housing authorities or their programs, including those of Passaic, N.J., East St. Louis, Ill., and Chicago.
The coalition had requested the receiver in an application that chronicled a long list of delays and missteps in the authority's construction program dating to 1978.
Newark's public housing authority, by H.U.D.'s own measure, is considered among the most troubled in the country, with a long history of failing to maintain or build housing even when it had money to do both.
The coalition, which was formed by community and housing advocates in response to the Newark authority's plans to demolish 39 of its 46 high-rise buildings, sued H.U.D. and the housing authority in 1989 to block the planned demolitions.
 
No New Housing Since 1989
 The groups reached a settlement in September 1989 that guaranteed replacements for 1,777 units of housing that the authority plans to raze. Eleven buildings will eventually be leveled once construction of replacements begins.
Since the settlement, no new housing has been built. One partly built project blew down in a windstorm.
Mayor Sharpe James, who named the task force, has blamed the former housing director, Dr. Daniel Blue Jr., for the authority's failures. The director's contract expired on Dec. 31 and he has since joined the Chicago Housing Authority. Five top administrators resigned in December as well.
Mr. Bloomberg said that the Newark Housing Authority was to locate three candidates for the top position by March 1, with a selection to be made shortly afterward, and that efforts were under way to fill the other top positions.
"H.U.D. is satisfied that the N.H.A., with Mayor James's support, is moving forward decisively to resolve its personnel problems," he said.
But Mr. DeLuca said that a new executive director would be faced with an agency in turmoil.
"We have a lot of hopes that a new executive director will turn things around," he said. "We would applaud that. But construction isn't the agency's only problem. There is personnel, management of the housing. Unless you hire a super-person, the executive director can't do it all."

HEADLINE: U.N. Votes to Send Force to Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously tonight to start dispatching a 14,000-member peacekeeping force to Yugoslavia to monitor the cease-fire there and protect minority Serbs in Croatia until their future is settled.
The operation in Yugoslavia, which is already one of the biggest the United Nations has ever organized, will be followed by an even bigger and more complex one next week when the Council is expected to send military and civilian contingents to oversee the end of Cambodia's long civil war, disarm its rival factions, return refugees and organize nationwide free elections. 
 Initial estimates put the cost of those two missions at more than $3 billion, or more than four times the $700 million United Nations members were asked to pay for peacekeeping costs last year at a time when the organization is already owed nearly $1 billion by its membership in unpaid dues.
 
Deployment in Stages
 Agreement to send the force to Yugoslavia came after compromises were struck within the 15-member Council in disputes over its peacekeeping powers as well as over the operation's $634 million annual cost, which the United States and other Western members say is excessive.
As a result only part of the force will be deployed at first, while the United Nations Secretary General asks the parties to the fighting to contribute more toward the cost of the operation.
Under the United Nations peace plan, the 14,000 peacekeepers will be charged with insuring the security of about 14 Serbian minority enclaves in the breakaway republic of Croatia for at least a year until an overall political agreement is reached on the future of the Yugoslav federation.
But the United States, with support from other Western members, wanted to insure that the Croatian government of Franjo Tudjman, which has criticized aspects of the peace plan, had no possible legal basis for seeking the force's withdrawal before such an agreement is reached.
 
Fear Among Serbs
 As a result, it proposed deploying the force under the provisions of chapter seven of the United Nations Charter, which allows the Council to issue mandatory orders and enforce them by economic blockades or even military force.
As other countries recognize Croatia and the Tudjman government grows more self-confident, the Serbian minority fears Zagreb may try to remove the United Nations soldiers, leaving its members at the mercy of the Croatian majority and in danger of being driven over the border into Serbia.
But the Security Council's third-world members, lead by India, objected to invoking chapter seven, saying that would set a precedent by imposing a peacekeeping force on Croatia without its consent, thus expanding the Council's authority.
The third-world countries are fighting any move that enlarges the powers of the Security Council, which they increasingly see as an instrument of American foreign policy.
The final compromise drops all mention of chapter seven from the resolution's text. Instead the United States Representative, as this month's president, sought to add a statement to the resolution saying that Article 25 of the Charter "will apply to the decisions the Council will be taking in this resolution." Under Article 25, all United Nations members agree "to accept and carry out the decisions of the Security Council."
The United States, France, Britain, Russia and China, which as permanent Council members pay more than half the cost of peacekeeping operations, have also agreed to ask Yugoslavia to contribute more toward the costs of the peacekeeping force to reduce the bill they will face.
In particular, many countries want Yugoslavia to provide local barracks for the soldiers, thus saving the $110 million that the United Nations Secretariat has proposed for buying prefabrictaed housing for the peacekeeping force.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Maine;
A New England Contest That Is Hard to Predict

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 21

 BODY:
When it comes to the spring Presidential caucuses and primaries, a case can be made that as New Hampshire goes, so goes Maine.
That at least has been the political way of things in recent election years, particularly on the Democratic side. But when Democrats and Republicans caucus all across Maine on Sunday to express their Presidential nominating preferences for 1992, the results seem at this point to be anything but inevitable, especially on the Democratic side. 
 In other words, there is no guarantee for former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who won the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, that Maine will also make their fellow New Englander a winner.
Not only do Maine voters leave the impression that they are in an unpredictable and irascible mood, like voters everywhere, but the caucus process itself also adds to the uncertainty. Candidates can pack the caucuses with their supporters, bringing results that may not reflect the true feelings of the general electorate.
 
Organization's the Thing
 Although the candidates are spending less time here than in other, more delegate-rich states, their aides are aggressively lining up backers. The outcome may well depend more on organization than message, money or media, which was not the case in New Hampshire.
"I wouldn't bet a penny on anything; not this year," said Jo Karr, the chairwoman of Maine's Democratic Party. "You can't control it. You can't buy it with television. You can't predict it. You can't rely on what's happened in the past, on what they did over in New Hampshire -- certainly not this year, not the way people are feeling."
Every campaign organization is mostly working phones and sending out letters. Very few campaign advertisements are showing up on television or in newspapers. And because the candidates themselves are mostly elsewhere, there is little campaign news on the air or on the front page.
"A caucus state is a little like a duck on water," Ms. Karr said. "It's hard to tell how much paddling is going on."
 
Bush Victory Is Expected
 Political professionals say President Bush, who has a summer home down the coast in Kennebunkport and is regarded by many people in Maine as one of them, will win the Republican contest easily.
But given the weakness he showed in New Hampshire, the experts wonder whether a significant number of Maine Republicans might opt to send a message of discontent by voting for "uncommitted" in their caucuses.
And the political professionals wonder whether Mr. Bush's Republican challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, who has no visible campaign organization in the state, might nevertheless embarrass the President anew by attracting some insurgent support.
"Nobody expects the President to show badly," said Edward O'Meara, the chairman of Maine's Republican Party. "There's no real evidence of any Buchanan organization out there, not even a phone number. But you never know for sure."
On the Democratic side, the outcome of the caucus is anybody's guess.
At first glance, Mr. Tsongas seems almost certain to get a big boost from his victory in neighboring New Hampshire and from the fact that he comes from Massachusetts. If he does not he will be seriously weakened.
"Give us that second booster shot," Mr. Tsongas told voters on Thursday night when he showed up briefly in the state for a rally in Bangor.
While Mr. Tsongas would seem to have a regional advantage in Maine, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas is believed to have the best organization in the state, with four offices and eight paid campaign workers. And Mr. Clinton has decided to break away from campaigning in the South on Saturday for a pre-caucus supper in Lewiston.
"This is retail politics," said David Leavy, Mr. Clinton's field director. "You can't do it from afar. You have to get out and meet the people."
 
Brown Is Running Hard
 Adding to the uncertainty of the Democratic contest, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California has been working the state hard, committing himself to five consecutive days of campaigning here this week.
He did better in New Hampshire than most political experts had expected, winning 8 percent of the vote after polls showed him with about half that much. He and a number of experts here believe that his anti-establishment message may resonate well in Maine.
As for the other Democrats in the race, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa has visited Maine several times, though not this week. There is little expectation that he will finish near the top in the caucuses, but no one is writing him off; his unabashed liberalism has captured the support of much of the state's labor establishment.
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska paid a quick visit to Maine on Wednesday, saying he had come "to let you know I'm by no means out of this race." But his organizers say his expectations here are low.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edmund G. Brown Jr. did better in New Hampshire than had been expected, winning twice as many votes as polls had indicated. His anti-establishment message may be received well in Maine, especially with the state's large contingent of environmentalists. He received a tomahawk yesterday from the Penobscot Indians in Indian Island, Me. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Health Insurance for Nannies Urged as a Family Obligation

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Health insurance for domestic help is an idea whose time has come, according to employment agencies and insurance experts.
And most families that employ nannies, baby sitters, housekeepers or other household workers are usually aware that they may have to withhold from their employee's pay checks funds for Social Security, Medicare and various income taxes. 
 Health insurance is not required by law, but in an age of increasing medical costs, it is a benefit employers should think about if they are close to those who take care of their children, their elderly parents or their homes. Experts say it should be discussedwith any valued household employee.
 
It Makes Sense, Some Say
 The cost can either be deducted from pay, with the employee's permission, or paid by the employer at no cost to the worker.
Some employment agencies and insurers consider it a moral obligation just as compelling as paying taxes. They say it makes sense because some employers pay part or all of medical costs their employees cannot afford . Only about 2 percent of the full-time nannies in the United States are believed to have health insurance, according to M. Lynn Larsen, president of Pacific Benefits, a Salt Lake City insurance brokerage.
"Most nannies are permanent workers who have to use important personal judgment, so everything about it suggests that health insurance should be an incidence of their employment," said Carl Schramm, president of the Health Insurance Association of America. "A lot of people don't know that there are specifically formulated groups that make insurance available to nannies."
Nedra Kleinman, owner of the All-Home Services Agency, an employment agency for household workers in New York City, said, "If you want to attract good people to care for your children, health insurance is a way to help do it."
Among a dozen companies that offer special health insurance to domestic employees are the Home Life Insurance Company, the Acceleration Life Insurance Company and the Time Insurance Company. Some offer a group rate to applicants that is usually lower than individual rates. "In any case, you have to answer health questions," said Gordon M. Silverstein, president of the Triad Insurance Group, a Los Angeles insurance brokerage, "and you want to make sure of the rating of the company you're dealing with."
Mr. Silverstein, whose company handles the medical insurance of the International Nanny Association, a nonprofit advocacy organization for child-care providers who work in the home, said a typical policy would include a $300 deductible. Among factors governing that policy's premium are age, sex and geography. Someone in Los Angeles might pay about $150 a month, while someone in Memphis, where medical costs are lower, might pay $60 a month. Someone over 30 would pay more than someone under 30.
Other benefit programs are sold to household employers and employees. Pacific Benefits provides a pension plan for nannies through its subsidiary, Child Care Staffing. If employee and employer agree, the worker becomes an employee of Child Care, which leases the nanny to the employer. The employer is billed monthly for the salary, tax payments, health insurance and other agreed-upon benefits. The employee pays nothing for this service, but the employer pays $35 to $40 a month to Child Care.
"It's not for everyone," said Mr. Larsen of Pacific Benefits. "But there is a growing segment of employers and nannies who want taxes done correctly and who want some of the benefits offered to employees of regular companies."
Paul Rifkin, president of Domestically Yours, a household employment agency in New York City, said health insurance was a valuable perquisite for domestic workers. "My recommendation is that, after three months, the employer should offer it to the person, instead of giving her a raise," Mr. Rifkin said. "It shows her that she is working for nice people."
 
 
 
DON'T FORGET THESE DEDUCTIONS
 The most common required deductions from a household worker's pay are for Social Security and the Medicare tax, under the Federal Insurance Contributions Act, or FICA.
The law calls for deductions whenever a worker earns $50 or more in a quarter of a year, excluding the value of room and board but including money paid for transportation. Employees and employers each must pay 7.65 percent of a worker's pay up to $55,000, plus 1.45 percent each on wages between $55,000 and $130,200.
Of course, an employer can also voluntarily pay the employee's share, for a total of 15.3 percent of annual wages -- although this is additional income and is taxable. Payment is made quarterly to the Internal Revenue Service on Form 942.
Withholding Federal income tax from a paycheck is not required for services performed in or about a private home unless the employee asks for it and the employer agrees. But the employee remains responsible for paying a tax on earnings even when nothing is withheld.
Finally, employers must pay a Federal unemployment tax, for domestic service workers who earn at least $1,000 in a quarter year. The tax rate this year is 6.2 percent of the first $7,000 earned, with this tax reported on Form 940 or the simpler Form 940-EZ.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Bush Hits All Targets Except His Challenger

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 21

 BODY:
President Bush inveighed today against tax increases, socialized medicine, ambulance-chasing lawyers, the welfare system, Congress and big government. But he barely gave a rhetorical nod to his most nettlesome problem, ensconced in a hotel meeting room a block away.
In a speech to the Southern Republican Leadership Conference here, Mr. Bush all but ignored Patrick J. Buchanan, the rebellious opponent who cast a shadow over the President's primary-election debut this week. 
 Mr. Buchanan held a news conference at a nearby hotel minutes before Mr. Bush spoke, accusing the President of shutting him out of the Republican meeting and of dodging his call for a debate.
 
Upbeat Themes
 But Mr. Bush, sticking to the advice of his strategists, did not mention his foe by name and made only oblique stabs at Mr. Buchanan's bitter criticism of his policies. Those attacks drew blood in New Hampshire, where Mr. Buchanan gained 37 percent of the Republican vote.
So far, Mr. Bush's advisers seem content to ignore Mr. Buchanan in the South, where they believe better economic conditions make voters less inclined to cast a protest ballot against the White House.
Mr. Bush stuck today to the same upbeat campaign themes he has been sounding with limited success since the early fall, including his leadership of the assault on Iraq and his efforts to maintain America's leadership role in the world.
By comparison, he said, other unnamed opponents "just wish the world would go away" and have only pessimistic predictions about the future of the United States.
"Let's not listen to the gloom and doom from all those intense talking heads who are happy only when they say something negative," Mr. Bush said, apparently referring to Mr. Buchanan's career as a television commentator. He added, "We are the United States of America, and we don't have to put up with all that."
 
A Veto Is Promised
 The only new element in Mr. Bush's speech today was a pledge to veto the economic-relief package that Democrats in Congress are assembling if it includes any increase in the personal income tax.
The latest version includes a tax cut for middle-income taxpayers and a cut in the capital gains tax, to be financed in part by a surtax on million-dollar incomes and an increase from 31 percent to 35 percent for individuals with taxable incomes above $85,000 and for families with taxable incomes above $145,000.
The President's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, had refused to promise outright that Mr. Bush would veto a tax increase. In New Hampshire, Mr. Buchanan scored points by casting Mr. Bush as someone who had abandoned his 1988 pledge not to raise taxes and who could not be trusted not to do the same thing again.
But today Mr. Bush invoked more of the Persian Gulf war oratory that he used in his State of the Union speech last month, saying he is drawing "a line in the sand" on tax increases.
"I will veto it the minute it hits my desk," he said.
Mr. Bush drew repeated cheers from the largely adoring crowd of Republicans, some waving Bush campaign signs.
Earlier, Mr. Buchanan told reporters that Mr. Bush's new veto pledge was "the right thing." But he added, "I only wish he'd done that in 1990, and some of us would not be here today."
Mr. Buchanan attacked Mr. Bush's foreign policies, saying they would "diminish American sovereignty" by making Washington subordinate to the United Nations, and claiming that Mr. Bush's rhetoric on family values, taxes and other pressing issues did not match his commitment.
He also accused Mr. Bush, who has refused to debate him, of dodging a chance to defend his policies.
Mr. Buchanan said the state's Republican Governor, Carroll A. Campbell Jr., had laid what he called "the South Carolina trap" for him, hoping Mr. Buchanan would build up expectations of a good showing before suffering a lethal blow in the state's March 7 primary.
The South Carolina primary is on the Saturday between the March 3 primaries in Georgia and Maryland and the Super Tuesday primaries on March 10.
 
A Strong Bush State
 Mr. Buchanan conceded that South Carolina is a strong Bush state, but said he still hoped to surprise the President here.
Mr. Bush's aides said that the President planned to continue to refrain from personal assaults on Mr. Buchanan, but to talk in more general terms about his policies instead.
In Georgia, one of Mr. Bush's top campaign operatives said on Thursday that Bush strategists want to measure the depth of support for Mr. Buchanan before deciding whether to unleash negative commercials and personal attacks on their foe.
"I don't think they're sure what they want to do," the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said of the Bush campaign's approach to Mr. Buchanan. "We're being told to handle him with basically kid gloves. The word is, don't say anything in any sense that would anger Buchanan supporters, because we'll need them in the fall."
Today's trip to Charleston marked the start of two weeks of almost constant travel that will carry Mr. Bush on largely political missions across the South and West.
After a weekend at Camp David, the President plans to open his Maryland campaign in a Washington suburb on Monday. On Tuesday he leaves on a six-day trip to political events in California, political speeches and a drug-control summit in Texas, and more politicking in Georgia.
Mr. Bush will spend much of the following week in other Southern states, preparing for primaries that are to be held on March 3 and March 10.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush embracing Nancy Hawk, chairwoman of the Republican Party in Charleston, S.C., upon his arrival there yesterday. He later addressed the Southern Republican Leadership Conference. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. and Israel Still Fail To Resolve Loan Issues

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Israeli and United States officials tried again today to resolve their differences over American demands that Israel halt building new settlements in the occupied territories as a condition for American loan guarantees, but the two sides did not make any progress.
Israel's Ambassador to Washington, Zalman Shoval, met with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in their third negotiating session on the issue, but both sides said afterward that they were holding to their basic positions. 
 Leaving the State Department, Mr. Shoval said: "There is no agreement yet. We will have another talk." He declined to answer further questions.
The Israeli Ambassador, while signaling that Israel might be ready to slow down new settlement building, said Israel could not accept a total halt. But that is what Mr. Baker is demanding, officials said.
 
Talks Held in Private
 The talks between Mr. Baker and Mr. Shoval have been conducted solely between the two men with no aides present. Mr. Baker has formulated the Administration's position on the issue almost exclusively in consultation with President Bush, without the usual Middle East policy advisers.
The Administration's position is that it will support, in principle, Israel's request for the loan guarantees to help cover the cost of absorbing the influx of immigrants from the former Soviet Union, including housing for them, on three conditions. First, Israel would be allowed to complete only those housing units in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip that are already under construction. The Administration estimates that number to be around 6,000. The Israelis estimate that number at over 13,000.
Second, Israel would have to accept a halt on any new housing starts in the occupied territories. Third, the United States would deduct from the loan guarantees one dollar for every dollar Israel spends in the West Bank and Gaza to complete those housing units already under way. This would be to insure that United States funds do not contribute, directly or indirectly, to building settlements in the occupied territories.
The Israeli position is that it should be allowed to complete those settlements already under way, as well as start a limited number of new housing units each year.
 
Seek $10 Billion
 Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is seeking $10 billion in loan guarantees spread over five years. It is possible that if the Administration does not come around, Mr. Shamir may opt instead for a one-year deal, officials say. The political advantage of this is that the Israeli Prime Minister could tell voters at home that since Israel is being permitted to complete the several thousand housing units already under construciton, it is not be accepting any freeze, and at the same time he could tell the Bush Administration that he was not going to start any new units, thereby effectively accepting a freeze.
The loan guarantees allow Israel to borrow money on commercial capital markets at lower interest rates. The Israelis, though, have to pay all the money back themselves. The cost to the American taxpayer would probably be several hundred million dollars that must be set aside as insurance against an Israeli default.
Now that Yitzhak Rabin has defeated Shimon Peres in the Labor Party runoff to determine who will lead their party in the Israeli national election on June 23, Mr. Shamir may have a greater incentive to compromise with Washington, American officials say. The latest Israeli polls show that Mr. Rabin will be a much more formidable foe for Mr. Shamir, and may force the Prime Minister to try to attract the Israeli centrist voter.
Mr. Rabin is well liked by both President Bush and Secretary of State Baker, and Administration officials believe that an Israeli government led by Mr. Rabin would be more likely to reach an agreement with the Palestinians on self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. They also believe that Mr. Rabin would be more willing to accept the sort of halt to building new settlements that the Administration is demanding for the loan guarantees. This is another reason that the Administration has little incentive to soften its terms now to accommodate, and possibly strengthen, Mr. Shamir.
 
Talks Scheduled to Resume
 The Middle East peace talks are scheduled to resume in Washington on Monday, and despite the latest outbreak of fighting along the Israel-Lebanon border, all four sides in the talks -- Israel, Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and the Palestinians -- have said they still intend to attend.
This could be the last chance for substantive progress in these negotiations for several months. March and April will be occupied with the Muslim holy month of Ramadan and the Jewish festival of Passover, after which the Israeli election campaign will begin. The talks will likely have to be put off until the Israeli vote.
In Congress, Representative David Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin and the chairman of the House Foreign Operations subcommittee, held hearings today on the loan guarantee question. Mr. Obey, whose subcommittee overseas foreign aid, made it clear that although he supports in principle helping Israel resettle Russian Jews, he also wants to see a freeze on Israeli settlements in the occupied territores as a pre-condition to the loan guarantees.
In a statement issued recently on the issue, Mr. Obey said: "I fully support the President in declining to support a blank check $10 billion loan guarantee to Israel."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Use Antitrust Law As Weapon in Trade Fights

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Attorney General William P. Barr said today that he expected the Bush Administration to change its antitrust policy within weeks to allow the Justice Department to sue foreign trade groups that discriminate against American exporters.
Bush trade officials have said with increasing frequency in recent months that foreign business practices, rather than laws and regulations, are the biggest trade barriers still facing American companies overseas. 
 Japanese companies, in particular, tend to buy from other Japanese companies in which they hold shares, instead of importing American products that may be cheaper or of better quality. Because the financial base of Japanese industry is built on such interlocking share holdings, opportunities for American exports have been limited.
Japanese officials tend to agree that Japan's large industrial groups, which are known as keiretsu and typically include everything from banks and insurers to steel and automobile producers, are often too reluctant to deal with foreign companies. The Japanese Government has been stepping up its antitrust measures, but not fast enough to satisfy American trade negotiators.
Mr. Barr said today during the taping of the television program "John McLaughlin's One on One," to be broadcast this weekend, that the Justice Department was reviewing its policy with the State Department and the United States trade representative. He said he expected a change "within a matter of weeks."
He added, "I think the antitrust laws will be a useful tool against cartels that are excluding U.S. exports."
Mr. Barr denied that the Administration's apparent decision to change course was in any way motivated by political considerations. Trade disputes, particularly with Japan, have moved to the center of this year's Presidential election campaign with President Bush's trip to Tokyo last month and with the conservative columnist Patrick J. Buchanan's strong showing this week in the New Hampshire primary on a platform that emphasizes protectionism.
Eric L. Hirschhorn, a trade lawyer at Winston & Strawn in Washington and a former Assistant Secretary of Commerce during the Carter Administration, said a change in the Justice Department's guidelines might not make much of a practical difference.
Private companies and individuals have always been able to sue foreign trade groups for hurting their ability to import or export, but few, if any, cases have been successful, he said.
Hiroshi Hirabayashi, deputy chief of the Japanese Embassy here, said his Government's reaction to an American policy change would likely depend on how it was implemented.

PUB-DATE: February 22, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 38; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 684 words

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
Use of Preparers May Be Waning

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Tax preparation is considered an increasingly complex task, one that nearly half of Americans turn over to accountants, tax lawyers or other specialists.
Yet figures suggest that reliance on professional preparation may have begun to wane, easing last filing season to 46.4 percent of returns from a 1988 peak of 47.7 percent. A decade earlier the proportion was 37.9 percent. 
 The decline, according to an I.R.S. spokesman, probably results from the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which eliminated various deductions, and the development of simplified forms like the 1040-EZ. (For upper-bracket people and corporations, on the other hand, the filing job has gotten significantly harder in recent years.)
H & R Block Inc., which has 25 percent of the company's filing business, says its business continues to rise, mainly reflecting the I.R.S.'s ability for two seasons to accept returns electronically nationwide. "It brings in a lot of business," said Donald W. Ayers, the company's financial vice president and treasurer, noting that Block prepared 12,375,000 returns in 1991, up 771,000 for the year.
Academic work by Julie H. Collins at the University of North Carolina and two collaborators from California State University, Chico, has found that demand for preparation services has little to do with a desire to minimize effort. Rather, 70 percent of respondents said their main objective was to file accurate returns and 25 percent to minimize tax liability.
 
Surge of Early Filing
 Hard times seem to have prompted a surge in early filing as the size of refunds soars, Internal Revenue Service figures show.
Through mid-February, the Treasury sent $7.3 billion to 6.5 million couples and individuals, with checks averaging $1,122, or $140 more than in the comparable 1991 period. The number of returns filed was 26.4 million, 6.5 percent ahead of last year's pace, which was slowed by the gulf war.
The data pointed to a cash-short public eager to claim their refunds, which more than 75 percent of taxpayers arrange to collect each year despite the fact that this is tantamount to an interest-free loan to the Government.
The faster filing pace this year may also reflect the fact that there are many more jobless with the time to file early. At latest report, 8.9 million Americans were unemployed, compared with 7.7 million in January 1991.
Returns filed electronically have jumped more than 58 percent this year, to 6.2 million, or one of every four early returns. These produce refunds within a few weeks or even less if the money is to be paid directly into the taxpayer's bank account.
The Treasury said it opposed providing a tax credit to those who file this way, contending that electronic filers get more benefit from faster refunds than the Government gets from reduced processing costs. Representative Newt Gingrich, a Georgia Republican, suggested a credit but without specifying its size.
The I.R.S. also reported this week that more than 122,000 South Carolinians have participated so far this year in a program under which they can electronically file Federal and state returns together, with the I.R.S. relaying data to the state. This system, tested in parts of South Carolina in 1991, is being extended this year on a refund-only basis to parts of New York, Maine, North Carolina, West Virginia, Wisconsin and Kansas.
 
Footnotes
 * A survey by the General Accounting Office has found that fewer than one-half of 1 percent of the 11.6 million taxpayers receiving the earned-income credit in 1989 took advantage of their right to collect cash, through employers, in periodic installments throughout the year. The agency said participation has never exceeded 1 percent since the option was first offered in 1979.
* New and increased taxes proposed by the District of Columbia include a 2 percent levy on the gross receipts of professionals. Lawyers, accountants, architects, engineers and consultants are expected to be hit for $5 million this year and $26.8 million in 1993. A tax on the health industry, including doctors, would raise $20 million.
